fields.headline: Pilgrim knows how to progress
fields.standfirst: Plymouth's success stirs memories of 16 years ago
fields.trailText: Rob Steen on how Plymouth's success is stirring memories of 16 years ago, when the Pilgrims came as close as any side from the lower half of the league has ever come to the FA Cup final.
fields.body:
"The draw was a bit generous," acknowledges Kevin Hodges, only the teeniest bit huffily. Plymouth Argyle's manager and stoutest servant, whose side tackle Preston at Home Park on Saturday, is reflecting on the most improbable FA Cup run of modern times.

Sixteen distant years ago, when Kevin Keegan still looked like a poodle, Alex Ferguson was merely the pontiff of Pittodrie and John Barnes could do no wrong, plucky Plymouth came as close as any side from the lower half of the league has ever come to the FA Cup final. Indeed, had it not been for the present Celtic manager, Argyle, who avoided relegation to the Fourth Division only by winning their last two games that season, might have completed their impression of Foinavon.

In the third round, no fewer than 10 First Division teams were drawn together. With Manchester United humbled by Bournemouth, nine fell at the first. Then Brighton mugged Liverpool. Few Pilgrims have enjoyed such divinely aided progress.

Hodges, like keeper-turned-community-officer Geoff Crudgington, remains part of the furniture. Pilgrim man and boy, he made a record 530 appearances, committed high treason by leaving to manage Torquay, but returned after Plymouth dropped into the Third Division in 1997-98.

That most illustrious of former Pilgrims, Malcolm Allison, confessed: "There are two types who succeed in coaching: the con man or the intelligent man who builds your confidence and belief. I'm the con man." Hodges, slight of stature, modest of mien, pronounced of schnozz and as likely to wear a fedora as frilly knickers, is the very antithesis of Big Mal.

Four days had passed since Dame Fortune had fired her latest outrageous arrow, a blatant but unawarded penalty in the dying seconds at Swansea. "Look at the linesman," he cries, waving a photo from the Evening Herald: Shaun McCarthy is having his shirt ripped off his back. "Right in line and he didn't give it." Cue a gentle shrug, born of a lifetime in the mild, mild west.

From the undimmed spark of the assistant manager Steve McCall - still wearing the No13 shirt at 39 - and the dead-eyed tenderfoot Ian Stonebridge, whose brace sank Macclesfield on Monday to revive a stuttering promotion charge, Hodges' team mirrors its maker's tenacity. All three previous ties - against Brentford, Brighton and Reading -required replays.

Argyle showed similar resilience in the glory, glory year. "Two-nil down at home to Newport in round three, thought we'd blown it. Equalised with a last-minute penalty.

"And going to the Hawthorns was no picnic. West Brom were struggling but still in Division One. Tommy [Tynan] won it on a breakaway and there we were: a Third Division side in the quarter-finals.

"Then came Derby, in front of nearly 35,000. Tremendous noise. Phenomenal. The greatest since I've been here.

"We'd have won, too, if Gordon Staniforth's 30-yarder hadn't hit both posts and bounced out. Still, I suppose things evened up when Andy Rogers decided the replay direct from a corner." The absurdity endures.

"Only now do you look back and realise how close we got. Bloody hell.

"Like us, Watford had never got this far, so Villa Park was a really happy place. Twenty thousand came with us: four times our average home gate. We had enough chances to win. If Barnes hadn't produced that bit of magic to provide that cross for George Reilly..." The voice dissolves, the pause pregnant with regret.

"Near the end the ball came across to me on the right, on my left. Not my strongest. It was a snap shot. Tommy always followed everything in but even he didn't bother: it looked so certain. It missed by a millimetre. Graham Taylor conceded they'd have panicked if that had gone in."

Which begs the inevitable question: might Hodges have denied us the Turnip Years? No man should shoulder a burden that size.

fields.headline: Thatcher facing ban
fields.trailText: Ben Thatcher is facing a ban and possible fine after he was charged with misconduct by the Football Association yesterday for elbowing Sunderland's Nicky Summerbee in the face during Wimbledon's 1-0 victory on Monday.
fields.body:
Ben Thatcher is facing a ban and possible fine after he was charged with misconduct by the Football Association yesterday for elbowing Sunderland's Nicky Summerbee in the face during Wimbledon's 1-0 victory on Monday.

The FA watched a video of the incident to decide on what punishment Thatcher should receive after the referee Graham Poll and his assistant Grant Hegley failed to spot it.

Thatcher was apologetic after Summerbee was forced to be substituted with concussion, but insisted that the challenge, which occurred in the build-up to the only goal of the game, was accidental.

"We requested a video of the game yesterday morning and have charged Ben Thatcher with misconduct," the FA's spokesman Adrian Bevington said. Thatcher now has 14 days to respond to the charge.

Leicester's Matt Elliott and Brian Deane of Middlesbrough were both given one-match bans recently after the FA reviewed videos of similar incidents.

webTitle: McIlroy calls for Irish fighting spirit

fields.headline: McIlroy calls for Irish fighting spirit
fields.trailText: Sammy McIlroy was yesterday unveiled as the new manager of Northern Ireland and immediately pledged to restore passion and pride to the national team.
fields.body:
Sammy McIlroy was yesterday unveiled as the new manager of Northern Ireland and immediately pledged to restore passion and pride to the national team.

The Irish have failed to qualify for an international tournament since the former Manchester United midfielder captained them to the 1986 World Cup finals in Mexico. And McIlroy admitted he has his work cut out if he is to guide them to the next World Cup in South Korea and Japan in two years' time.

"There is a huge task ahead but I'm looking forward to it," McIlroy told journalists at the Irish Football Association's headquarters in Belfast. "We have got to get back to the fighting spirit of Northern Ireland's World Cup teams of 1958, 82 and 86.

"Getting this appointment is like a dream come true. I was proud to wear the green shirt as a player and I would be totally committed to this job."

The 45-year-old, who will take charge of Macclesfield for the last time on Saturday, has been given a two-year contract to take him through the World Cup qualifying process.

He will now consult the Irish FA over the appointment of a part-time assistant and on who will be responsible for running the Under-21 squad.

"I want total commitment from players and I'll be wiping the slate clean," said McIlroy, who was capped 88 times for his country. "Everyone who is eligible will be considered. We want to get back to the days when foreign teams were apprehensive about playing at Windsor Park.

"There are some quality players and it's up to me now to get the best from them. Our World Cup group, which includes the Czech Republic, Denmark, Bulgaria and Iceland, is a tough one but we will approach it positively."

Northern Ireland's next two matches are friendlies against Luxembourg, on February 22, and Malta, on March 27, and the first home game is against Hungary on April 27.

fields.headline: Leicester bin stadium blueprint
fields.trailText: Leicester's plans to relocate suffered a major setback yesterday when plans to build a 40,000-seat stadium at Bede Island South were scrapped.
fields.body:
Leicester's plans to relocate suffered a major setback yesterday when plans to build a 40,000-seat stadium at Bede Island South were scrapped.

The club's chairman John Elsom said that the board were not convinced that the developer Goldwing Properties could purchase all the land needed for the project.

Elsom said that alternative options, including the redevelopment of Leicester's present ground Filbert Street, would be considered in an attempt to have a new stadium for the 2002-03 season.

Liverpool's striker Robbie Fowler does not need another operation on his ankle but will be out for a further three weeks. He has been in discomfort since a spur was removed from his ankle bone in October.

Coventry's on-loan striker Cédric Roussel is close to completing a permanent move to Highfield Road from the Belgian club Ghent after agreeing a five-year contract. The two clubs have yet to agree a fee.

Southampton are planning to appeal after their application for a work permit for the Latvian international Imants Bleidelis was turned down. The midfielder was signed from Skonto Riga two weeks ago for £600,000.

Rangers have agreed a deal with Galatasaray to sign the Turkish international midfielder Tugay Kerimoglu subject to a work permit being granted.

fields.headline: United braced for Mexican wave
fields.standfirst: Necaxa plan a high-tempo game to make Ferguson's side wilt in the heat
fields.trailText: It is hard to imagine that Martin Edwards was pining for the FA Cup when he awoke in his hotel suite here today. But as Manchester United prepared to take on the world, their chairman made it clear he hoped this January jaunt was a one-off.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
It is hard to imagine that Martin Edwards was pining for the FA Cup when he awoke in his hotel suite here today. But as Manchester United prepared to take on the world, their chairman made it clear he hoped this January jaunt was a one-off.

It is not that he regards the World Club Championship as a waste of time. Nor has he had too much sun. In 10 days United will earn millions of pounds and gain enough global exposure to sell David Beckham knickers in Riyadh.

Yet as the treble winners limbered up for Necaxa this evening, Edwards made it clear the tournament had to find a new place in the calendar. Missing the FA Cup once, with all the accompanying flak, was more than enough.

"People have been saying for some time that football needs a world club championship," he said. "What we need from now on is to find the right time to fit it into our calendar. If it was played again at the same time next year it would create the same problem with the FA Cup.

"We hope it will be played every two years as a pre-season tournament so it won't clash with international events like the World Cup and the European Championship. That would make sense."

It makes sense too that Edwards believes victory here would enhance United's global reputation. He says he can feel the excitement mounting. "It's like the heavyweight world championship unification," he ventured. Finally, after all the controversy, it is showtime tonight.

Whereas Necaxa boast that they know everything about their opponents, for Sir Alex Ferguson this is more of a venture into the unknown. Such is the price of worldwide fame. What United's manager does know is that he must get off to a winning start.

"We watched a video last night," he said. "It was difficult to tell too much but they are big and tough at the back and we saw the systems they play. This match takes a high level of importance because we need to go into the Vasco game [on Saturday] with a win. That match will be the big one."

The Mexicans regard this fixture as the No1. They visited a favela yesterday to drum up local support and their constant references to the glory of Rio and the beauty of its women may earn them a few fans. "All the Necaxa players think the women are beautiful," the striker Octavio Becerril said.

Jovial and relaxed, Necaxa believe they can cause an upset. In training they have been hitting diagonal balls behind the full-backs and seem intent on playing as quickly and with as few passes as possible, on the counter-attack.

"The English are going to feel a lot of heat and won't be able to deal with a fast rhythm of game, which won't be a problem for us," explained their coach Raul Arias. "The time is right for us and I believe we will win. We want it hot because that will help us."

Ferguson has stressed the need to keep possession and conserve energy but the style will not change much. He intends to use his substitites and show the Brazilian public that even English clubs can play the beautiful game.

"We have become one of the most entertaining teams of the last decade," he said, "and if we go out and play our normal game the people of Brazil will be impressed. We have always tried to make an impression wherever we go."

United must beware Alex Aguinaga, the long-haired midfielder who makes Necaxa tick. How successfully they shackle the Ecuadorian could be decisive, particularly if Roy Keane's left knee plays up. In attack they must counter the aerial strength of Agustin Delgado.

Arias has made it clear he fears Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole. But his players are used to triumphing against the odds. They attract only about 2,000 people to the 115,000-capacity Azteca Stadium, yet established themselves as Mexico's team of the 90s.

Edwards intends to make United the team of 21st century, starting now. "Last season will never be repeated," he said. "To win here would be the next stage. I think this will grow into a very big tournament in years to come."

webTitle: Auntie back in fashion, even if the dress looks a bit tatty

fields.headline: Auntie back in fashion, even if the dress looks a bit tatty
fields.trailText: The World Club Championship may have limited appeal to the general public, but for the Beeb it is a golden chance to get back into the business of live football coverage.
fields.body:
By the end of next week you will be able to pull on a battered sheepskin and silly cap and do an impersonation of the Beeb's treasured Motty that even Rory Bremner might envy. You will be able to offer an expert rundown of the formations, tactics and trivia of such great football clubs as Al Nassr, South Melbourne, Necaxa and Raja Casablanca.

As a sporting event, the Fifa World Club Championship is about as meaningful as those World Cups and Ashes series we put our smaller siblings through in the back gardens of our childhood.

The analogy is not inappropriate because this, essentially, is a tournament of the imagination, one tortuously pieced together in the vain minds of Fifa's Joao Havelange and Sepp Blatter as a sweetener to the world's smaller football associations.

Basically this first World Club Championship is a competition between the best sides in the world outside Europe and South America, together with the Champions League winners Manchester United, the 1998 Toyota Cup winners Real Madrid, and two sets of Brazilians to lend much-needed gravitas: Corinthians, Brazil's champions for the past two years, and Vasco da Gama, the Libertadores Cup winners in 1998.

The whole enterprise is a little confusing for those of us who thought United were already the world club champions, on account of their other little jaunt to Japan last month when they beat Brazil's Palmeiras.

If you are not tempted, you will need to avoid BBC1, BBC Choice and Radio 5 Live. Auntie has forked out a reported £12m for the rights to cover all 21 hours of action in this little bash in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo. This, remember, is the tournament United opted to play in rather than defend the FA Cup.

All three networks will cover tonight's match between United and Necaxa, and later in the evening the game between Vasco da Gama and South Melbourne will be covered by both BBC1 and Choice.

If you don't like football, BBC1 is a no-go area on Saturday evening. United's game with Vasco da Gama will be covered in full from 8.05 and after a quick news break we will have Match of the Day.

Now, Auntie has become a bit of a soft target for those who feel the corporation totally underestimated the challenge posed by Sky and the greater vigour of the other terrestrial broadcasters. It has lost the rights to cover such major events as Test cricket, Ryder Cup golf and formula one and for too long now has resembled Eurosport, which presents its slender audience with such momentous events as Nordic combined skiing and snowboarding.

When the Beeb recently announced that it was going to extend the marketing of its archive material there were thoughts that it might have given up altogether. Certainly the recent Sports Personality of the Year would have looked a bit thin on footage without the tacked-on Personality of the Century.

There was one Sunday afternoon a few weeks ago when ITV, with a Rugby World Cup semi-final as well as the climax to the formula one season, attracted 6.9m viewers whereas 500,000 tuned into Sunday Grandstand.

But, limited though the World Club Championship is in its appeal, it does reveal that the Beeb is desperate to get back into live football coverage. It also insists it has paid no more than £6m for the privilege, and as that includes three or four live Manchester United matches it can be regarded as something of a snip.

The important thing is that the BBC finally appears to have got the message. Choice's coverage will include ticker-tape messages across the bottom of the screen, and viewers can email their thoughts.

One Broadcasting House insider said yesterday: "There's life in the old dog yet. Greg Dyke, who is very keen on sport, takes over at the end of the month instead of the spring and should sharpen everyone up and bring some know-how to our negotiating."

When Dyke was at ITV he was furious with the BBC for pulling out of an agreement to put up a better fight against Sky. This year the Beeb's football will consist of Premiership and FA Cup highlights, Euro 2000, the Uefa Cup and the European Super Cup. Not forgetting Necaxa and Al Nassr. It's a dodgy start. But it is a start.

webTitle: Shoaib appeal goes to the top

fields.headline: Shoaib appeal goes to the top
fields.trailText: Pakistan's appeal against the suspension of their fast bowler Shoaib Akhtar for bowling with an illegal action has been passed on to the cricket world's highest authorities.
fields.body:
Pakistan's appeal against the suspension of their fast bowler Shoaib Akhtar for bowling with an illegal action has been passed on to the cricket world's highest authorities.

A statement issued by the International Cricket Council yesterday said the matter would be considered by the body's president, Jagmohan Dalmiya, and chairman, Sir Clyde Walcott. "The request for the decision to be suspended is unprecedented as no formal procedure currently exists," the statement read.

webTitle: Hussain hurt by 'shambles' but lays blame on earlier damage

fields.headline: Hussain hurt by 'shambles' but lays blame on earlier damage
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey hears Nasser Hussain lay the blame for England's shambolic defeat on irresponsible shot selection.
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain described England's second innings yesterday as a "shambles" but pinned the blame for the defeat on the manner in which his batsmen had allowed the match to be turned from a position of strength on the first day to be 255 all out on Monday, the result of irresponsible shot selection.

"Today was just today," he said, "but the real disappointment was to be in that position early on, and 200 for three later, and end up making the same mistakes we used to make before the tour.

"What a shambles it was today. But, believe me, where we lost this game is where we were 200 for three on a flat wicket to collapse to 255 all out and give them the opportunity to bat on the wicket when it was at its best. It's just not good enough.

"Today we were up against it, and really papering over the cracks. I'm certainly not going to point a finger, slag anyone off and say you lost us the Test, but we have to make sure that we learn from the mistakes and that they are not repeated.

"It is possible that we got carried away in the overcharged atmosphere, and that is why I say we should not look too far ahead. We should look at what we are doing at the time and we should have made sure we got through that last session of the first day. If we were 200 for three, then you live in the present, see the day out, think about it and progress from there.

"I have said all along that we must not get too far ahead of ourselves and too high or too low. We are looking for a gentle upward curve and this is a blip. But it is hugely important that we learn. I shall be telling people subtly what I think and then it is up to them to work it out for themselves."

Hussain defended the character of his side and refused to blame selection policy. After the nadir against New Zealand last summer, it was felt that new blood was needed and there were experienced absentees from the tour party, most notably Mark Ramprakash and Graeme Hick.

"I don't regret any of the selections," Hussain said. "We made our choices and we stand by them, giving the players every opportunity to succeed. You can go round in circles otherwise. I believe you give them a chance, as we have with Chris Adams, and I will carry that on into the final Test in Centurion.

"If we are going to succeed we have to do what Australia, India and Pakistan do and bring the youngsters in. In the past two matches we have shown great character and you can add to that the effort in this match of Chris Silverwood, who tried his heart out, hit the deck and took five wickets on a flat pitch against a nine-man batting side. That is a real positive to come from the match."

On changes for the Centurion Test, Hussain added: "I think my hand has been forced a little by the injury to [Andrew] Flintoff so there is an opportunity there to give people another try. We'll look at the conditions and pick our best team. We're not going there for a trial match, we're going there to win a Test match."

fields.headline: England's decade of disasters
fields.trailText: 1989 Allan Border becomes the first Australian captain since Bill Woodfull in 1934 to win back the Ashes in England, winning the Old Trafford Test by nine wickets.
fields.body:
1989 Allan Border becomes the first Australian captain since Bill Woodfull in 1934 to win back the Ashes in England, winning the Old Trafford Test by nine wickets.

1992 Pakistan's sultans of swing Wasim Akram and Waqar Younis lead Pakistan to a comfortable 10-wicket win at the Oval.

1994 All out for 46 in Port of Spain as Curtly Ambrose batters England to a 147-run defeat. The only consolation for England is avoiding, by one run, their lowest-ever Test match total.

1994 South Africa mark their return to the international arena by flattening England for 99 in their second innings en route to a 356-run victory at Lord's in the first Test between the countries for 29 years.

1994 England are beaten by India - and a dodgy plate of prawns that left half the team reeling with sickness - in the Madras Test, going down by an innings and 22 runs.

1995 Greg Blewett scores his second Test century in only his second Test to lead Australia to a crushing 329-run win in Perth.

1995 Shot out for a measly 89 by West Indies to lose the third Test at Edgbaston by an innings and 64 runs, with still more than half an hour to go before the scheduled lunch interval on the third day.

1996 England lose in only three days to South Africa in Cape Town, put in their place by the last-wicket pair Dave Richardson and Paul Adams in a stand of 73 in a low-scoring match.

1998 England score a massive 445 in the first innings of the one-off Test against Sri Lanka at the Oval, with Graeme Hick and John Crawley scoring centuries, but still manage to lose by 10 wickets thanks to the guile of the spinner Muttiah Muralitharan, whose 16-220 is the fifth best in Test history.

1999 New Zealand, inspired by Chris Cairns, beat England in the Oval Test by 83 runs to send England to the bottom of Wisden's world Test ratings.

webTitle: Revenge is sweet for jubilant Cronje

fields.headline: Revenge is sweet for jubilant Cronje
fields.standfirst: Victorious captain tells England to stand by their underachievers
fields.trailText: Paul Allott hears Hansie Cronje, captain of an 11-man team, offer advice to Nasser Hussain, captain of a five-man team, as South Africa seek to challenge the supremacy of Australia.
fields.body:
So there were to be no heroics from England, just a clinically efficient performance from the South Africans. England could not come close to matching the batting effort produced by South Africa last week in Durban and duly lost the series yesterday at Newlands.

South Africa are a unit that consistently fire on all cylinders. The one time they have failed to do so in this series, in Durban, they regrouped and came away with a draw. Whether batting or bowling, there is never a hint of over-reliance on any one individual.

Essentially, this series has been a case of 11 South Africans competing against only five Englishmen. England have put their faith in - and based their performances on - Mike Atherton, Alec Stewart and Nasser Hussain with the bat, and Andrew Caddick and Darren Gough with the ball.

The South Africans, by contrast, rely on a team effort to win matches. Their runs in this series have been shared around. Daryll Cullinan has scored centuries at the Wanderers and Newlands, Lance Klusener in Port Elizabeth, Gary Kirsten a double hundred and Mark Boucher a hundred in Durban, and Jacques Kallis also got to three figures in Cape Town.

Five individuals making centuries in four Tests is good going, and when wickets had to be taken to win this match, two went to Klusener, three to Paul Adams, two to Shaun Pollock and the other two to Allan Donald and Kallis.

The weakest link in the chain may be the captain Hansie Cronje, who acknowledged his own poor batting form after the match yesterday but did not allow it to detract from his jubilant mood.

"I would like to score a few more runs myself," he said. "I feel the pressure from not contributing to my team-mates, but I will settle for not scoring runs and winning a series."

Cronje may not be batting well and he may at times be over-cautious in his decision-making, but he has a wonderful team at his command who respect him and give him the results he craves. His record of 25 wins in 50 Test matches as captain ranks alongside the very best.

Clive Lloyd captained West Indies to 36 wins from 74 Tests, Viv Richards 27 from 50, and Mark Taylor led Australia to 26 from 50. Compare this with England's longest-serving captain, Atherton, who won 13 from 52, and the gulf is obvious.

But Cronje's message to the England selectors yesterday was to be patient and wait for success to come their way, rather than ring wholesale changes in the wake of the latest debacle.

"If you are patient it will come right," he said. "You have the batters now and Andrew Caddick looks like he can hang around a bit. If you stick with them you will see the rewards later on. It is a case of giving people an opportunity and allowing them to settle down in the team.

"You can have it two ways. Some people want results, but skippers and coaches want to build a side. It is a difficult one but I would like to see a bit more patience."

Cronje highlighted his team's strengths as the length of their batting and their ability to bat themselves out of trouble - another glaring deficiency in the England team's make-up. "The whole team had a burning ambition to avenge the 1998 defeat by England, and the aim of South Africa is to get their world rating up there with Australia," he said.

"I think we have our own goals and our own preparation, but there was always this burning ambition to get back and beat England. I felt as captain in control, except maybe a bit in Durban... a series win against anyone is very satisfying. It is important to keep winning."

Cronje said his team had toiled long and hard since they surprisingly lost the last two Test matches against England in 1998 to let the series slip 2-1. "I am very happy for our guys. There were some long faces at Headingley when we lost that series against England. We have worked hard to get the players in the right frame of mind since then."

This South African side must now rank second to Australia in world cricket. They last lost a home series in 1997 when Australia beat them and since then they have defeated Sri Lanka, West Indies, Zimbabwe and England and drawn with Pakistan. They have won 11 of their last 13 Tests on home soil and their liking for playing at Newlands now extends to six wins in as many matches.

As Cronje's men go from strength to strength, they are in the process of making themselves invincible at home. The nucleus of the side is young enough to be together for at least another five years and the magnificent Donald has a natural successor, in pace at least, in the already groomed Nantie Hayward.

For South Africa to seriously challenge Australia's supremacy, however, they must improve their spin department, where only the unique Adams features.

For the moment, though, the millennium has begun on the sweetest of notes for South Africa. Revenge for '98 has come at last and emphatically so.

fields.headline: Our choice, not theirs
fields.standfirst: Labour must stick to its PR pledge
fields.trailText: For parties in permanent opposition,                                                    like the Liberal Democrats now, proportional representation has                                                    a huge appeal, offering more seats in the Commons, a share in                                                    government, a place or two in the cabinet. But for parties in                                                    power, the prospects are much less alluring: fewer parliamentary                                                    seats, government shared in place of freedom to rule on your                                                    own.
fields.body:
Electoral systems should be designed to give the electorate what it wants. Instead they are usually tailored to suit politicians, and specifically those in power. For them, the choice is never free of self-interest. For parties in permanent opposition, like the Liberal Democrats now, proportional representation has a huge appeal, offering more seats in the Commons, a share in government, a place or two in the cabinet. But for parties in power, the prospects are much less alluring: fewer parliamentary seats, government shared in place of freedom to rule on your own.

The new Labour government elected in 1997 looked set to break the pattern. The manifesto promised not PR but a referendum, letting the people decide if a change should be made. That seemed very much the kind of politics Tony Blair believed in: cooperative rather than confrontational. The leaked account of Paddy Ashdown's diaries, charting Mr Blair's readiness to admit Lib Dems to his government, even though he could comfortably govern without them, shows how deep that conviction went. A deal of some kind with the Liberals, short of pure coalition but amounting to a form of joint enterprise, promised to leave the Conservative party impotent and marooned for many years to come. And perhaps would have had the same effect on the Labour left. Some of Mr Blair's colleagues disliked that, not just because they thought it wrong and unnecessary for Labour to sacrifice power to others, but because they believed that governments with majorities were preferable to those dependent on coalitions or deals.

The manifesto promised an independent committee to recommend a proportional alternative to first-past-the-post. The Jenkins committee looked not for the system which in a rational, disinterested world would give the electors the best deal, but for one Tony Blair and Paddy Ashdown might be able to sell to their parties. It was not even truly proportional - simply less disproportional than first-past-the-post. But now - though the figures leaked yesterday are thoroughly unreliable - a Labour consultation process seems to have spurned even that. The numbers involved in the process, however, are small. There is no guarantee that those who replied were representative. The exercise has all the known defects of a self-selecting sample. This answer comes from exactly the sort of people who have most to gain from keeping the status quo. Academic research suggests that a survey based on one party member one vote would have produced a warmer response.

The cause of PR has had setbacks - notably the Euro-election results, with their very small turnout, though those were based on the use of an indefensible form of PR, and unhappiness in New Zealand after it made the change. And Labour is enjoying its new hegemony. Some MPs who writhed at the spectacle of Margaret Thatcher lording it on the basis of 43.9% of the vote find a Labour majority of 178 seats, based on 43.2%, wholly acceptable. But what about us, the consumers? Many sympathetic to Labour are troubled by the lack of checks on government freedom of action, and the way in which machinery which might create such checks - a proportional voting system, an elected Lords rather than one made up of nominees, a select committee system which could really challenge the government rather than just embarrassing it - seem to be slipping off the agenda. They may also have noted that not one of the new democracies of the 90s has chosen to run its elections by first-past-the-post.

Mr Blair's own view on PR remains shrouded in doubt. But that is not the issue. What matters here is the promise, on which Labour solicited our votes, to let the electorate choose in a referendum. There can be no defence for withdrawing that now. If the friends of first-past-the-post want to cling to the system which - for the present - suits them so well, let them argue their case at a referendum. But elections belong to us, not to them. It is we who must choose.

webTitle: Profile of former US Nazi Party officer William Pierce

fields.headline: The gospel of hate
fields.standfirst: Former US Nazi Party officer William Pierce, whose novel The Turner Diaries was accused of influencing the Oklahoma bomber, is using new technology to spread his anti-Jewish message. Julie Etchingham reports
fields.trailText: Former US Nazi Party officer William Pierce, whose novel The Turner Diaries was accused of influencing the Oklahoma bomber, is using new technology to spread his anti-Jewish message. Julie Etchingham reports
fields.body:
For many, the mountains of West Virginia are a retreat from the pressures of metropolitan USA. Tucked away between their slopes is Hillsboro, on the surface a village barely touched by the progress of technology. A few clapboard houses are strung out alongside the general store, which sells local honey and fishing bait to the occasional visitor. Farm machinery rusts in the quiet fields.

It seems odd, then, that the FBI should take an interest in Hillsboro. But they did after the 1995 Oklahoma bombing. The man who blew up the city federal building, Timothy McVeigh, had a fascination with The Turner Diaries, a novel about a violent Aryan uprising. It was written by the most notorious resident of Hillsboro: Dr William Pierce.

Pierce is a former American Nazi Party officer now in his late 60s, banned from entering the UK for fear his views might incite public dis order. He lives in seclusion on a 400-acre estate on the edge of Hillsboro. From there he runs the National Alliance, regarded by many as one of the US's most dangerous far right organisations, advocating racial separatism. Its headquarters are a stark, two-storey block, covered in corrugated metal and emblazoned with an imposing runic symbol.

Paying him a visit is an unsettling experience. On entering the building, we were left in darkness in a large hall. The door was locked behind us. After several minutes, Pierce himself appeared out of the gloom to invite us into his office. He works at his computer surrounded by a scholarly mess of books and newspapers. His burmese cat, Bradley, lounges disdainfully on the top of the monitor; Hitler's Mein Kampf sits alongside George Bernard Shaw's Man and Superman on the shelf behind.

Pierce, a former physics professor at Oregon university, is a prolific writer. Not only is he the man behind The Turner Diaries, under the pseudonym Andrew Macdonald, he also writes a lengthy tract each week with his spin on the issues of the day, which he then broadcasts on shortwave radio and publishes on his website. He says he abhors multiculturalism and invariably points towards the Jewish community as being the source of America's ills, convinced they have a monopoly of power in the government and the media.

"They would like to be the only ones who determine what the public opinion is, and what images are presented to the public. I would like to be a little harsh with them, and they might then have some difficulty in pouring spiritual poison into our people. We are able to act as a sort of truth squad, to challenge the sort of misinformation they have been used to disseminating. I address myself to the independent thinkers, to the perceptive and intelligent public - not to the ball game fans, not to the couch potatoes. I address myself to people who are capable of entertaining an idea which did not come to them from television."

He preaches a message of white separatism and the internet is playing an increasing role. It's become an invaluable tool for recruiting members to the National Alliance, now thought to number around 1,000.

"Probably 60% of our handling of the public is by internet, and all that has occurred within the past five years. I expect that number to grow, and anticipate that, in the next year, we will see full-screen, full-motion video on the internet. I hope we'll be able to take full advantage of that."

Pierce's appearance is one of a mild-mannered ageing professor. He says he does not advocate violence and he's not vitriolic when speaking to journalists. His website is illuminating. "Certainly, there may be bloody chaos if we resist the Jews and their collaborators," he writes in an essay entitled What Is a Patriot to Do? "And we should not flinch from this. We should not focus on the fact that it will be horrible and bloody, but on the fact that it will be necessary, and because it is necessary it is good. And because it is something which should come soon, it should be looked upon as a great challenge." He does not consider that such words promote aggression.

He also sells 600 different books and tapes mail order via his website. It's proved so successful that Hillsboro post office has had to be upgraded to cope with the workload. The list includes US Army manuals on the manufacture of explosives and booby traps, munitions and guerrilla warfare. But the bestseller is The Turner Diaries. Extracts from the book are published in several languages on his website.

Although the US Government did not link it to the Oklahoma bombing, The Turner Diaries was mentioned in evidence at McVeigh's trial. He'd sent copies of the book to friends urging them to read it, and the bombing he carried out was eerily reminiscent of the fictional attack on government buildings featured in the novel.

Personally, I can't see why anything in my books should be harmful to children or to which normal healthy parents should object. I can understand those trendy, politically correct parents might object. But I believe everything I have written contains healthy ideas which should be of more benefit to children than not."

America's commitment to the constitutional right to free speech means extremist material is easily available over the internet. Unless material can be proven to threaten a person directly, there are few constraints on what may be published. Pierce, however, has nothing but scorn for them.

That means that when they give ideas out which are destructive, I can point it out to the public - and when they put out false information, then I can give people the truth and a chance to check these things out for themselves.

I've been a teacher all my life, and I would like to continue doing things the way I'm doing them - trying to think about the really important issues which are facing us as a people today, and comment on those to help people clarify their thoughts on those matters. webTitle: New evidence shows record of war crimes suspect was not investigated

fields.headline: New evidence shows record of war crimes suspect was not investigated
fields.standfirst:
Simon Wiesenthal Center
The holocaust history project
The Home Office: Immigration information
fields.trailText: The suspected Nazi war criminal Konrad Kalejs has not been properly investigated, according to the former head of Australia's war crimes unit, Robert Greenwood.
fields.body:
The suspected Nazi war criminal Konrad Kalejs has not been properly investigated, according to the former head of Australia's war crimes unit, Robert Greenwood.

Scotland Yard's investigation, which concluded there was insufficient evidence to prosecute him, was partly based on Australian files.

The Guardian has also established that when British police interviewed Kalejs, 86, an Australian national, they did not question him about his alleged involvement in mass murder while second in command of a Latvian death squad during the second world war. Questions were restricted to confirming his identity and when he planned to leave Britain.

Dr Efraim Zuroff, of the Simon Wiesenthal centre in Jerusalem, said: "I think it is outrageous. It is a classic example of a police force that has no desire to bring a mass murderer to trial.

"If you have allegations that someone served in a murder squad, it is common logic to ask elementary questions about his activities in world war two."

Comments by Mr Greenwood added to pressure for Kalejs to be stopped from leaving Britain - possibly as soon as today - which Nazi hunters fear will lead to him escaping justice.

Mr Greenwood said no "responsible investigative body" in Australia had scrutinised the Kalejs case with a view to bringing a prosecution.

He said his unit had monitored US and Canadian investigations into Kalejs during the late 1980s and 1990s. But by the time Kalejs came to Australia after being deported from the US in 1994, the war crimes unit had been disbanded.

Kalejs denies allegations that he is implicated in the death of 30,000 people, mainly Jews, while a member of the Arajs Kommando unit which collaborated with the Nazis.

Lord Janner, chairman of the Holocaust educational trust, said Mr Greenwood's claim was an "extraordinary development". Robin Corbett, chairman of the Commons home affairs select committee, said Kalejs should be held in Britain while a full investigation was carried out to see if a prosecution was possible.

However, Scotland Yard said the Australian investigation, which was carried out when Kalejs moved there, was "by far the most in depth and extensive" into his past and included interviews with witnesses in Latvia in the early 1990s.

Speculation also intensified yesterday on where Kalejs may go if he chooses to leave Britain before being deported. The Mexican government responded to a Guardian report that he was believed to be heading there by announcing that he would be denied entry to the country.

A Scotland Yard spokeswoman, responding to questions about the scope of the interview with Kalejs, said: "We are not prepared to discuss who we may or may not have interviewed during the course of an inquiry."

fields.headline: The rise of the supernerds
fields.trailText: The trillion-dollar computer industry is now dominated by impossibly rich nerds, many of whom started their companies in garages. Now publishers are trying to cash in by producing a stream of books about these rags-to-riches stories.
fields.body:
The trillion-dollar computer industry is now dominated by impossibly rich nerds, many of whom started their companies in garages. Now publishers are trying to cash in by producing a stream of books about these rags-to-riches stories.

Tim Berners-Lee is, of course, an exception: he's British rather than American, and poor even by the standards of Microsoft programmers, thousands of whom are multimillionaires. Still, Berners-Lee's name will go down in history as the creator of the World Wide Web (his capitals), and to help history get its facts right, he's written it all down in Weaving the Web (Orion), with Mark Fischetti. It's not Homer but it's well worth reading.

Buy it at BOL

Another innovator to tell his own story is the multi-billionaire founder of Dell Computer, Michael Dell - with a little help from Catherine Fredman, who has also collaborated with Intel's Andy Grove. Again, Direct From Dell: Strategies that Revolutionized An Industry (HarperCollins Business) isn't a thrilling read, but it does build a gripping image of a very effective businessman. Would-be entrepreneurs should be able to pick up a few tips.

Karen Southwick's High Noon: The Inside Story Of Scott McNealy And The Rise Of Sun Microsystems (John Wiley & Sons) is a different matter, partly because McNealy is a far more colourful character. As cheerleader for Silicon Valley's anti-Microsoft brigade, he's never short of a well-honed insult. The problem is that there's little about him in High Noon: he declined to be interviewed for the book. Instead, Southwick provides an account of the rise of the company that currently dominates the Unix server market. She devotes far too little space to the "Unix wars" (1988-93) when Sun tried to take over the industry, and far too much space to the overhyped Java language. But that's probably what the market wants.

At least McNealy gets an easier ride than the characters in Michael S Malone's huge Infinite Loop (Aurum Press). Its lengthy subtitle - "how Apple, the world's most insanely great computer company, went insane" - does not mislead. Malone grew up alongside Apple's co-founders, Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak, and reported on the company for the local paper, the San Jose Mercury News. He does a thorough job of debunking the mythology Apple has spent millions of dollars fostering, and provides enough detail to keep trivia quiz compilers happy for decades.

Buy it at BOL

Like the PC software market, the publishing industry seems to be increasingly dominated by books about Microsoft and its nerdy co-founder, Bill Gates. Gary Rivlin leads the pack with The Plot To Get Bill Gates (Quartet Books). It's a racy read, which captures the essence of the story while skipping much of the detail. And while Rivlin frequently dishes the dirt on Gates, he doesn't spare Gates's envious enemies either.

Buy it at BOL

Paul Andrews - co-author of the best biography, Gates (Simon & Schuster) - has also returned to the field with How the Web Was Won (Broadway Books). This brings the story up to date from the time of the earlier book, published in 1993. Like Gates, it's meticulously researched and very readable. There's no obvious bias, but as a reporter for the Seattle Times, Microsoft's local paper, Andrews doesn't take the kind of pot-shots that Rivlin enjoys.

Buy it at BOL

Microsoft has also come in for some serious study, particularly in Winners, Losers & Microsoft: Competition And Antitrust In High Technology (Independent Institute) by two American professors of economics, Stan Liebowitz and Stephen Margolis. It's an important book, if sometimes heavy going. It looks as though it started as an examination of the economics of technology industries. Some of this material was published in journals in 1990-96 when Microsoft provided a useful case study, and the US government's anti-trust cases made it a crucial one.

Liebowitz and Margolis put a lot of effort into showing that some popular stories beloved of journalists - "alleged market failures" like the adoption of the QWERTY keyboard, and victory of JVC's VHS video cassette format over Sony's Betamax - are simply myths repeated by people who have not researched the facts.

The authors then test their theories against various personal computer software markets, comparing specialist magazine reviews with market shares. Their conclusion, briefly, is that good products win, whether they're from Microsoft or not.

Of course, Microsoft is just one of a string of companies that technological developments have thrown into remarkable prominence. Jeffrey Young has written extended essays about many of them, and they're collected in Forbes Greatest Technology Stories: Inspiring Tales of the Entrepreneurs and Inventors Who Revolutionized Modern Business (John Wiley & Sons).

Young covers the development of the first computers, the mainframe (IBM), microprocessors (Intel), personal computers (MITS, Apple, IBM), Windows (Microsoft) and so on. Some of the essays are stunning, and only a couple are duff. In sequence they provide an entertaining and informative, if very gappy, history of computing over the past 50 years.

fields.headline: Written on the body
fields.standfirst: At that time of year when New Body! New You! is all women hear, Alice Thomas Ellis, Helen Dunmore and Rebecca Ray sing the praises of old friends
fields.trailText: Helen Dunmore: From the furl and unfurl of a baby's hands to the dying person's plucking at the bedcovers, we discover the world with our hands.
fields.body:
Helen Dunmore on her hands

From the furl and unfurl of a baby's hands to the dying person's plucking at the bedcovers, we discover the world with our hands. I wouldn't change my hands, not because they are beautiful or elegant, but because my history is packed in the cells of my hands, at least as much as it's packed into my brain.

Like most writers, I spend a good part of each day with my hands spread over a computer keyboard. When I was about 12, I realised that, as a left-hander, I was never going to produce the model italic script demanded by my school. My handwriting was hard work and it looked it. There were always spatterings of ink and a callous on my second finger. I gave up and taught myself to type on a manual typewriter with clashing keys. Later on, a touch-typing course showed me the true pleasure of fast, automatic, rhythmic typing. While my hands flew, my mind was free to sink into thought.

That was the first skill I really built into my fingers. I belonged to perhaps the last generation of little girls who learned to hand-stitch blouses in primary school. We cut out from cheap, vomit-coloured cotton print, provided by our teacher. We knitted ourselves jumpers, chain-stitched, blanket-stitched, feather-stitched and sewed pincushions and plimsoll bags. I was told to sew with my right hand and did so. The scissors might be the wrong way round and my progress slow, but there was something hypnotically enjoyable about it all. The needle went in and out of the grubby cotton, and I went in and out to the teacher to be shown how to finish a collar with bobble detail.

There is an irresistible magnetism in the thought of making something with your hands, whether it's a garden, a snowman, cakes or a clay pot. I can see exactly why Virginia Woolf spent hours typesetting for The Hogarth Press. The work made a harbour after the voyages of her mind and at the end something was achieved that was simple, solid fact and didn't need reviewing.

Women writers who have children are often asked about them as if they are nothing but an impediment, or even a shackle that prevents the writer soaring off into boundless creativity. But I think it's much more complex and fruitful than this. My hands remember the soft, kid-glove texture of a newborn baby's head as well as the chemical scour of Nappisan. They remember their struggles with heavy carrier bags and grizzling, writhing toddlers, but also the way a child's newly- washed hair brushed the fingers like feathers. My family is widely spaced, so I have been walking hand-in-hand with a child for years. Maybe theirs are the hands I'll be reaching for when my own dying hands take their turn to pluck at the bedclothes.

Hands collaborate. They work with each other, with other hands and with whatever they are given. They work with heat and cold, time and weather, oil and metal, seeds and sunlight. In spite of broken nails, I prefer to garden without gloves. Bare hands know at once whether the soil is cold and clodded and will rot anything planted today, or whether it has the warm, crumbly, receptive texture that means everything will grow.

Again, the pleasure is cumulative. Over years, hands learn things that never quite reach the mind. They learn from the resistance of sauce to whisk when to turn down the heat, they touch a dozen lettuces and know which is the freshest, they slice ham into rosy shavings and roll pastry without crushing the air out of it. They weigh and measure, lift, change gear, coax, caress.

It's a paradox that the less physically demanding our lives become, the more we demand perfection from our bodies. But hands are lucky. They don't have to be perfect. Everything they know is hidden in them, ready to work.

Buy Helen Dunmore's Your blue-eyed boy at BOL

Alice Thomas Ellis on her feet

I have never been very interested in the body. I do not watch those TV programmes that explain where everything is and what it's for. I've scarcely seen a doctor in a professional capacity for 25 years and if I were constrained to visit one, I would not want him to give me any details about whatever condition was afflicting whichever organ or limb I was concerned about. I should request him simply to do what he had to do and let me go with the minimum of fuss.

I feel distant from my insides - which might as well be situated in Ulan Bator - while naturally trying not to abuse them, and hope they will continue to function adequately until the whole lot wear out in the course of time. Nor do I indulge in strenuous dieting or exercise, eating when hungry and drinking when dry, and finding running up and down stairs in search of things I've forgotten or mislaid quite sufficient to keep the blood coursing. Chasing and weight-lifting grandchildren takes care of the muscle tone and since none of the doors or windows fits too well, there is plenty of fresh air.

Besides, I was brought up during the war when there wasn't any junk food to interfere with or unbalance the vital processes. So, on the whole, apart from the exigencies of child-birth, I've never really needed to dwell much on the physical form, for which I'm properly grateful.

The aspects of it to which I am most indebted are, on reflection, my feet which have, as it were, stood by me through thick and thin. I do appreciate the utility of the other parts, eyes, ears etc, but there is something about the unselfconscious humility of feet that is particularly affecting. So much so that I once wrote a poem to my feet - with which I will not burden you. We were going for a walk and I suddenly noticed them going plod, plod through the mud and the fallen leaves, self-effacing and uncomplaining, while my hands, since I was carrying nothing at the time, just hung there, along for the ride, like distant aristocratic relations, too grand to acknowledge the workers bearing them forward.

Hands, of course, are indispensable, but they get far more attention than feet: people praise their dexterity and wave them about at times of emotion. Hands are almost always on stage and frequently the focus of the gaze, whereas feet generally go unremarked unless in exceptional circumstances - if you've fallen head first down a hole, for instance.

There are those who make a fetish of them but that seems uncalled for and vaguely insulting. Like all misplaced adulation, it loses sight of their true purpose and diminishes their value. I once knew a Freudian who held that foot fetishists got that way because her feet were the first bit of its mother a baby noticed when it woke, crying, in the night. It only takes a moment's thought to reject this explanation, unless the baby had fallen out of its cot and was lying on the floor - not, surely, a common occurrence, not one to initiate a life-long perversion.

I treat my feet kindly and with respect, never forcing them into unsuitable shoes, but giving them sandals or capacious boots to wear, depending on the season. Only once did I mistreat a foot. I dearly wanted to kick my spouse but thought it inadvisable, kicking the sofa instead. Unfortunately I hit on a wooden part and split a toe wide open. Even then I did not trouble the doctor nor look at it myself, but swathed it in a cloth and left it alone. After a few weeks it healed without trace of injury.

I am truly fond of my feet and shall continue to treat them with benevolent neglect while regarding them with respect. I shall let them take me for walks but I will never try to persuade them to go jogging.

Buy Alice Thomas Ellis's The evening of Adam at BOL

Rebecca Ray on her back

I sent off for a cosmetic surgery's price list once, full of excitement and the burning need to give someone else my money. It wasn't the tantalising read I thought it would be. And yet, gruesome and exorbitant though the list was, I still found myself wishing. Oh, the endless tucking and plucking and sucking, it's like a Toys R Us for grown-ups. They have an operation for every part of your body. Except your back.

Yes, it's true: back-jobs are unavailable. What a terribly cruel twist of fate this must be for people with overweight backs. And yet, thinking about it, I had never heard a woman complain about her back. Could all backs be equal? Surely not when Liz Hurley exists? (Actually, this is a matter of some debate: many believe Hurley is only a collection of pixels, through which the fresh air flows, unimpeded, like the wind between Hugh Grant's ears.)

The fact remains: my back is the only part of my body about which I have no reservations. Not only that, but it's undervalued. What item of clothing could be sexier than a dress that shows your naked back? An exposed back is beautiful, sensual without being overtly sexual, and there are very few parts of the body about which that could be said. It's also unusual; we're not desensitised to its exposure the way we are to cleavages or thighs. It's intimate.

My back isn't a girlie back, not the skinny, sticking-out shoulderblades kind. It's strong but I think it's still feminine and this is rare. I'd like to have the thighs of an 11-year-old, the hips of someone who's 13. But a back should be womanly, it should bring to mind the prowling lioness - a nice image when my womanly bottom brings to mind the prowling hippo. My back is free from Satan's foulest afflictions: cellulite, stretchmarks and spots.

My back is also very sensitive (I use it to sense armchairs at a hundred paces). I wouldn't go so far as to say it's an erogenous zone, but it is gorgeously ticklish. In fact, the possibilities of back-attention are endless: massaging, kissing, stroking. Back rubs suggest adulation; they are queenly, every woman should demand them. They're the ultimate self-esteem kick.

fields.bodyText: Helen Dunmore on her hands From the furl and unfurl of a baby's hands to the dying person's plucking at the bedcovers, we discover the world with our hands. I wouldn't change my hands, not because they are beautiful or elegant, but because my history is packed in the cells of my hands, at least as much as it's packed into my brain. Like most writers, I spend a good part of each day with my hands spread over a computer keyboard. When I was about 12, I realised that, as a left-hander, I was never going to produce the model italic script demanded by my school. My handwriting was hard work and it looked it. There were always spatterings of ink and a callous on my second finger. I gave up and taught myself to type on a manual typewriter with clashing keys. Later on, a touch-typing course showed me the true pleasure of fast, automatic, rhythmic typing. While my hands flew, my mind was free to sink into thought. That was the first skill I really built into my fingers. I belonged to perhaps the last generation of little girls who learned to hand-stitch blouses in primary school. We cut out from cheap, vomit-coloured cotton print, provided by our teacher. We knitted ourselves jumpers, chain-stitched, blanket-stitched, feather-stitched and sewed pincushions and plimsoll bags. I was told to sew with my right hand and did so. The scissors might be the wrong way round and my progress slow, but there was something hypnotically enjoyable about it all. The needle went in and out of the grubby cotton, and I went in and out to the teacher to be shown how to finish a collar with bobble detail. There is an irresistible magnetism in the thought of making something with your hands, whether it's a garden, a snowman, cakes or a clay pot. I can see exactly why Virginia Woolf spent hours typesetting for The Hogarth Press. The work made a harbour after the voyages of her mind and at the end something was achieved that was simple, solid fact and didn't need reviewing. Women writers who have children are often asked about them as if they are nothing but an impediment, or even a shackle that prevents the writer soaring off into boundless creativity. But I think it's much more complex and fruitful than this. My hands remember the soft, kid-glove texture of a newborn baby's head as well as the chemical scour of Nappisan. They remember their struggles with heavy carrier bags and grizzling, writhing toddlers, but also the way a child's newly- washed hair brushed the fingers like feathers. My family is widely spaced, so I have been walking hand-in-hand with a child for years. Maybe theirs are the hands I'll be reaching for when my own dying hands take their turn to pluck at the bedclothes. Hands collaborate. They work with each other, with other hands and with whatever they are given. They work with heat and cold, time and weather, oil and metal, seeds and sunlight. In spite of broken nails, I prefer to garden without gloves. Bare hands know at once whether the soil is cold and clodded and will rot anything planted today, or whether it has the warm, crumbly, receptive texture that means everything will grow. Again, the pleasure is cumulative. Over years, hands learn things that never quite reach the mind. They learn from the resistance of sauce to whisk when to turn down the heat, they touch a dozen lettuces and know which is the freshest, they slice ham into rosy shavings and roll pastry without crushing the air out of it. They weigh and measure, lift, change gear, coax, caress. It's a paradox that the less physically demanding our lives become, the more we demand perfection from our bodies. But hands are lucky. They don't have to be perfect. Everything they know is hidden in them, ready to work. I do not watch those TV programmes that explain where everything is and what it's for. I've scarcely seen a doctor in a professional capacity for 25 years and if I were constrained to visit one, I would not want him to give me any details about whatever condition was afflicting whichever organ or limb I was concerned about. I should request him simply to do what he had to do and let me go with the minimum of fuss. I feel distant from my insides - which might as well be situated in Ulan Bator - while naturally trying not to abuse them, and hope they will continue to function adequately until the whole lot wear out in the course of time. Nor do I indulge in strenuous dieting or exercise, eating when hungry and drinking when dry, and finding running up and down stairs in search of things I've forgotten or mislaid quite sufficient to keep the blood coursing. Chasing and weight-lifting grandchildren takes care of the muscle tone and since none of the doors or windows fits too well, there is plenty of fresh air. Besides, I was brought up during the war when there wasn't any junk food to interfere with or unbalance the vital processes. So, on the whole, apart from the exigencies of child-birth, I've never really needed to dwell much on the physical form, for which I'm properly grateful. The aspects of it to which I am most indebted are, on reflection, my feet which have, as it were, stood by me through thick and thin. I do appreciate the utility of the other parts, eyes, ears etc, but there is something about the unselfconscious humility of feet that is particularly affecting. So much so that I once wrote a poem to my feet - with which I will not burden you. We were going for a walk and I suddenly noticed them going plod, plod through the mud and the fallen leaves, self-effacing and uncomplaining, while my hands, since I was carrying nothing at the time, just hung there, along for the ride, like distant aristocratic relations, too grand to acknowledge the workers bearing them forward. Hands, of course, are indispensable, but they get far more attention than feet: people praise their dexterity and wave them about at times of emotion. Hands are almost always on stage and frequently the focus of the gaze, whereas feet generally go unremarked unless in exceptional circumstances - if you've fallen head first down a hole, for instance. There are those who make a fetish of them but that seems uncalled for and vaguely insulting. Like all misplaced adulation, it loses sight of their true purpose and diminishes their value. I once knew a Freudian who held that foot fetishists got that way because her feet were the first bit of its mother a baby noticed when it woke, crying, in the night. It only takes a moment's thought to reject this explanation, unless the baby had fallen out of its cot and was lying on the floor - not, surely, a common occurrence, not one to initiate a life-long perversion. I treat my feet kindly and with respect, never forcing them into unsuitable shoes, but giving them sandals or capacious boots to wear, depending on the season. Only once did I mistreat a foot. I dearly wanted to kick my spouse but thought it inadvisable, kicking the sofa instead. Unfortunately I hit on a wooden part and split a toe wide open. Even then I did not trouble the doctor nor look at it myself, but swathed it in a cloth and left it alone. After a few weeks it healed without trace of injury. I am truly fond of my feet and shall continue to treat them with benevolent neglect while regarding them with respect. I shall let them take me for walks but I will never try to persuade them to go jogging. webTitle: Putin admits Yeltsin quit to give him a head start

fields.headline: Putin admits Yeltsin quit to give him a head start
fields.trailText: The race for the Kremlin seat vacated by retiring President Boris Yeltsin got under way yesterday when the upper house, or federation council, set the last Sunday in March as the date for Russia's presidential election.
fields.body:
The race for the Kremlin seat vacated by retiring President Boris Yeltsin got under way yesterday when the upper house, or federation council, set the last Sunday in March as the date for Russia's presidential election.

Vladimir Putin, the prime minister and acting president who has been hand-picked by the Kremlin to succeed Mr Yeltsin, admitted that his chances of securing the highest office in Russia had been boosted immeasurably by Mr Yeltsin's dramatic New Year's Eve resignation.

As details emerged yesterday of the behind-the-scenes manoeuvring in the weeks leading up to last Friday's coup de thétre, it appeared the triumph of Mr Putin's allies in parliamentary elections a week before Christmas had been the key factor that persuaded Mr Yeltsin to go.

The election has to take place within 90 days of Mr Yeltsin's resignation, meaning that March 26, the poll date set, was the last possible Sunday for the ballot, confounding speculation earlier this week that Mr Putin was determined to call the election even earlier in order to quickly capitalise on his present popularity.

Mr Yeltsin's daughter, Tatyana Dyachenko, the highly influential and controversial Kremlin aide whom Mr Putin removed on Monday, insisted she knew nothing of her father's decision to quit until last Friday morning. But Mr Putin admitted the outgoing president had told him 10 days earlier, and there were few people in Moscow prepared to believe Ms Dyachenko.

Moscow newspapers with good Kremlin connections reported that Mr Yeltsin told Mr Putin of his decision to resign on December 22, two days after the magnitude of Mr Putin's allies' strong performance in the elections to the Duma, or lower house, became clear.

In a television interview, Mr Putin quoted Mr Yeltsin as telling him: "I made this decision because something I consider very important has happened - people trust you." The interview represented the latest move in Mr Putin's skilful presidential campaign, and was aimed at showing a warmer, more personal side to the former KGB agent who often appears cold and clinical.

"I came to him about 10 days before the new year to deliver a report on economic problems and the situation in the north Caucasus," said Mr Putin. "Soon after I started speaking, I realised that Boris Nikolayevich [Yeltsin] was thinking about something else. He interrupted me and said 'I have been thinking for a long time about the situation in the country and have made the decision to resign.'"

Ms Dyachenko, by contrast, said: "Dad said nothing to his family. When early on December 31 he said at home that he was going to resign, Mum did not even realise that he was resigning the same day."

But according to Moscow's Vremya-MN newspaper, Ms Dyachenko attended a meeting with Mr Yeltsin, Mr Putin, and other key associates at the presidential dacha outside Moscow two days earlier. The other intimates present were Alexander Voloshin, Mr Yeltsin's chief of staff whom Mr Putin has retained in the same post, and Valentin Yumashev, a former Yeltsin chief of staff and ghostwriter for the presidential memoirs, who is said to have written the resignation statement.

The decision to quit was the best-kept secret in Moscow for at least 10 days, it seems. On December 27, when Mr Yeltsin recorded the traditional new year's message to the nation, he made no mention of his intention to quit. However, he held several hours of talks with Mr Putin the same day and then told the television crew he was unhappy with the recording and would be making another speech.

Around mid-morning the next day, Mr Yeltsin recorded his "forgive me, I am quitting" message for broadcast at midday. According to the cameraman, Andrei Makarov, he then took out a handkerchief and dabbed away tears.

In his interview, Mr Putin admitted he was being helped by Mr Yeltsin. "He wanted the presidential campaign to develop according to his wishes. To put it bluntly, he gave me a head start in the current presidential campaign."

He appealed to Russians to "have a very kind and humane attitude to the first president of Russia".

As for Mr Yeltsin's future, Ms Dyachenko said he wanted to travel, to Britain and to France. "He's seen practically nothing," she said.

Yesterday Mr Yeltsin flew out to Israel in order to spend the Orthodox Christmas, January 7, in Bethlehem. The trip was planned before his sudden resignation last week

webTitle: BBC worst hit as digital TV begins to bite

fields.headline: BBC worst hit as digital TV begins to bite
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: BBC1 recorded its lowest ever performance for the second year running in 1999, according to figures released yesterday which showed that the first year of digital broadcasting hit audiences for all the main channels.
fields.body:
BBC1 recorded its lowest ever performance for the second year running in 1999, according to figures released yesterday which showed that the first year of digital broadcasting hit audiences for all the main channels.

The flagship channel's poor showing comes at a crucial time for the corporation. The government is deciding the future of its funding in the light of a critical select committee report and as the new BBC director-general, Greg Dyke, takes over next month. A six-month review of the channel has already been completed after some dismal ratings last year.

Of the main channels, only Channel 5 increased its overall audience last year, while Channel 4 maintained its share. But in the clearest indication yet that moving News at Ten has worked for ITV, executives claimed victory in the battle to increase audiences between 7pm and 10.30pm. They missed their targets by just 0.2%.

The BBC was hardest hit. BBC1, which has an annual budget in excess of £700m, again lost more viewers than any other channel, as its share fell to 28.3% of total viewing. Added to BBC1's drop, a fall in BBC2's share from 11.3% to 10.8% meant the BBC's slice of all television viewing has dropped under the 40% barrier, considered significant to the corporation's claim on the licence fee.

Black Wednesday

BBC1 was largely hit in prime time, whereas BBC2 lost ground in the afternoon and late night schedules. BBC1's autumn schedule was saved by landmark programmes, including Walking with Dinosaurs, and Wives and Daughters, but the channel had a poor summer, culminating in "black Wednesday" in September, when it was beaten on audience share by Channel 5. In August the BBC1 controller, Peter Salmon, called for £100m to be added to his budget to improve and increase drama on the channel this year.

Yesterday, the BBC stuck to the resolution of the director of television, Alan Yentob, that BBC1 should aim for quality, range and diversity rather than ratings.Mr Yentob acknowledged the effect of digital launches and increased competition on BBC1's figures, but added that Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, ITV's hit game show, had proved a key weapon in the ratings war. "It is a phenomenon," he said.

He added: "I'm relatively relaxed about the figures, it's what I would have expected. It is important that the BBC has substantial market share but not at the cost of the right kind of programmes."

At ITV, executives were celebrating, despite a 0.5% fall in the channel's share of overall viewing to 31.2%. The chief executive, Richard Eyre, and the director of programmes, David Liddiment, will pick up bonuses estimated at £100,000 and £75,000 respectively for meeting targets for primetime viewing. Between 7pm and 10.30pm, ITV increased its share of viewing from 37.9% in 1998 to 38.8% - slightly under the 39% it promised advertisers.

Meeting the targets was crucial to ITV, which justified the move of News at Ten by claiming it would increase its primetime audience.

The channel also declared an increase in young, upmarket viewers during the evenings, though overall its share of the ABC1 16 to 34-year-olds so beloved by advertisers has fallen.

Lead widened

Mr Eyre said that in prime time, the network had widened its lead over BBC1 and achieved record advertising revenue for shareholders. The take-up of multi-channel television had exceeded analysts' predictions providing much greater competition for the terrestrial channels.

At two-and-a-half, the baby broadcaster Channel 5 was the only terrestrial network to increase its share of viewing. The channel, often criticised as a mix of sport and soft porn, produced an audience share of 5.4% thanks to cherrypicking key sports events such as the England v Poland Euro 2000 qualifier and building a broader range of programmes in late peak time. Dawn Airey, director of programmes, said she was unsurprised by the gains. "We're a channel that's still in its infancy and there's a lot of potential for growth but it's fabulous - especially when other broadcasters are faltering."

Channel 4 displayed the most consistent ratings performance, though it has had an erratic year. Its cricket coverage launched to critical plaudits, although it failed to transform the ratings, while gay drama serial Queer as Folk proved popular while annoying the regulators. The channel also lost ground at breakfast time.

Tim Gardam, director of programmes, described 1999 as the "most competitive year in television history". He added: "It is a tribute to the quality and originality of our programmes and to the independent producers that supply them that the Channel 4 audience has stayed loyal."

Good Year/Bad Year

BBC1

Highs

Walking with Dinosaurs proved the corporation could be innovative and popular, a hit sitcom in the Royle Family and strong audiences for Andrew Davies' adaptation of Wives and Daughters .

Lows

Faked guests on The Vanessa Show , a bad start for the new lottery and Lulu show Red Alert, disappointing drama such as Harbour Lights . A poor spring and summer culminating in September's "black Wednesday" debacle when it was beaten by Channel 5.

BBC2

Highs

Critically acclaimed drama Births, Marriages and Deaths , awards for the Leag

entlemen

Lows

Axing One Man and His Dog proved very unpopular. Heavily criticised for under-representing arts in programming. Northern Ireland drama Eureka Street , though praised, was largely ignored by viewers.

Channel 5

Highs
Successful "boutique buying" of football matches, including the Euro 2000 England v Poland qualifier which scored a record audience, and the return of It's a Knockout .

Lows
Moving its news bulletin again, rows with regulators over soft porn and the loss of newsreader Kirsty Young to ITV.

Channel 4

Highs
First gay drama serial Queer as Folk , poaching test cricket from the BBC in a £60m deal, Ali G , Saturday bulletin for C4 News , 1900 House .

Lows
Another revamp for Brookside , TFI Friday 's decline, Kelly Brook's forgettable stint on the Big Breakfast ; a much-reviled documentary about Michael Hutchence's auto-erotic death, controversially paid interview with Monica Lewinsky .

ITV

Highs
Who Wants to be a Millionaire continued its ratings success, a much praised documentary about Alzheimer's, Malcolm and Barbara , Alan Bleasdale's adaptation of Oliver Twist .

Lows
Eclipse coverage non-existent, a late-night Coronation Street spin-off, After Hours, disappointing and news bulletins patchy - particularly local news - since the move of News at Ten .

webTitle: How much can you pay for...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: A doorhandle?
fields.trailText: A doorhandle?
fields.body: I feel a strange haze coming over me... I want hold these things, squeeze them, see how far I can turn them... yes, yes, yes baby... you guessed it: I'm in the Franchi doorhandle shop. Here, mounted proudly, jutting from the wall, are the Norman Foster doorhandles, the Antonio Citterio doorhandles, the Renzo Piano representative. And having a wee work of art by Norman Foster (if a bed can be nominated for the Turner prize, why not a doorhandle?) in your house will set you back £190. That's just the one, mind you, so put it where everyone will notice. Call Franchi International Design on 0171-351 4554.
