Here, mounted proudly, jutting from the wall, are the Norman Foster doorhandles, the Antonio Citterio doorhandles, the Renzo Piano representative. And having a wee work of art by Norman Foster (if a bed can be nominated for the Turner prize, why not a doorhandle?) in your house will set you back £190. That's just the one, mind you, so put it where everyone will notice. Call Franchi International Design on 0171-351 4554.

fields.headline: Christmas glitches
fields.trailText: After the scrum, the reckoning. Doing your festive shopping online may have seemed like a good idea in December, but it's not such fun in January when undelivered orders have to be chased or the wrong thing has to be returned.
fields.body:
After the scrum, the reckoning. Doing your festive shopping online may have seemed like a good idea in December, but it's not such fun in January when undelivered orders have to be chased or the wrong thing has to be returned. Shoppers flocked to the internet this Christmas, leaving the online retailers flattened in the stampede. Overwhelmed with orders, some struggled with what they euphemistically call "fulfilment systems" - that is, actually delivering the goods.

Julian Granville, managing director of Boden, the mail order clothing company, says demand was 10 times what he expected when he launched the company's website nine months ago. "We have had some problems, but we did manage to fulfil a great deal of our internet orders, and they are now running at £2 million - that's 10% of our turnover."

Different companies have had different problems. Boden's were incorrect stock details, and it will therefore be installing a system which gives real time stock information, online.

Tesco didn't deliver any orders after 22 December which meant no disappointments, but no last minute help, and in the United States, even Amazon, the bookseller, which set the standard for online retailing, had delivery problems.

If e-commerce lets you down, go to the Office of Fair Trading's site. It goes through the complaints procedure step by step with links to trading standards, advice agencies, ombudsmen schemes and explains, if necessary, court action.

The Consumer's Association will take up the case of anyone losing money with a company registered in its Which? Web Trader Scheme, although companies so registered are unlikely to be the ones causing grief. www.shopsmart.com, which reviews online retailers, may also be able to help with problems caused by retailers accessed via its site.

With companies ouside the EU, lawyers are still arguing over which country's law applies - the buyer's, the seller's or the service providers'. If you paid by credit card, and the item cost between £100 and £30,000, you can claim against the card issuer. Otherwise, prepare for a long haul. This is uncharted ground.

fields.headline: Upending a table, Chopping a line and Scoring a goal
fields.trailText: AND NOW, FROM RIO, IT'S THE QUIZ OF THE WEEK
fields.body:
AND NOW, FROM RIO, IT'S THE QUIZ OF THE WEEK

Which of the three following reports sent Manchester United manager Alex Ferguson into a flat spin, causing him to brand a British journalist a "liar" and subsequently brush past the errant hack in a testy manner as he left a stormy press conference?

a) Ferguson Paris Nightmare: "Ferguson accidentally locked the wheels of his British Leyland Maestro whilst going round a roundabout near the Champs Elysees and knocked over the Eiffel Tower."

b) Ferguson Bognor Regis Lunacy: "Ferguson has been arrested after upending a table in a local caff. The incident came about after a heated exchange in Ida's Seaside Diner over the amount of chips you get with a Spam Fritter Super Meal."

c) Ferguson Rio Farce: "Ferguson's delight [over recent Premiership results] turned to disbelief when he saw the dreadful state of the Maracana... the ground is little better than a building site... frantic rebuilding work will prevent his side training more than once at the ground... that has upset Ferguson."

Congratulations if you picked a or b, because you have a very fertile imagination. However, article c - by Martin Samuel in Tuesday's Express - is in fact the one which caused Fergie's anger, as the United manager hadn't even been to the stadium at the time of the report.

Ferguson didn't want to have to defend a gaffe he didn't make, especially as his team are said to have already made an extremely poor impression on their Brazilian hosts - United have been described as "miserable", "overwrought with paranoia", "snobbish" and "arrogant". And who tells us this? Why, Martin Samuel in today's Express, of course.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

COKE IT IS

Argentinian legend Diego Maradona woke up in his hospital bed to find his reputation in tatters this morning after police claimed his heart problems were the result of a cocaine overdose. Actually, hang on, this is Maradona we're talking about, let's try that again.

It was just another morning for stumpy Argie cheat Diego Maradona today after an alleged cocaine binge up left him sweating for his life in a Uruguayan intensive care unit. Once dodgy Diego has recovered (docs expect him to head home in a few days) England fans will be hoping the cops clap the handcuffs of God on him for his druggy doings.

Local police chief Maximo Costa Rocha said that Maradona had failed a urine test upon his entry into the swanky Cantegril Hospital yesterday. "This positive sample is due to an excessive consumption of cocaine. We will interview him when the medical authorities think it is convenient and when it suits everyone." The Fiver says - get him now while he's down!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I have had him around my home when things haven't been going well to give him a few words of support." - Deadly Doug Ellis on his close relationship with John Gregory. "Mince pie, John?" "Mmm, yes please, Doug."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WE ALL NEED A GOAL IN LIFE

In this new 21st Millennium, everybody has wished for something. For Francis Jeffers it was an altercation in Liverpool city centre. He got it. For Darren Anderton it was an excuse to leave Spurs. He got it. For Paul Gascoigne it was a sit down. He got that too. But would anyone give poor Lonely Nicolas Anelka a goal?

Yes they would, and Nic's first competitive strike for Real Madrid duly arrived last night against the mighty Al-Nassr in Sao Paulo. A glorious effort it was too, the ball spooning off a defender's shin before looping over Al keeper Al Shokia (and believe us, he played a Shokia too), spinning into the net and instantly turning red with embarrassment. In fact, if it wasn't all arranged by Nic's ghostly pals, then the Fiver's a headless horseman.

Not that the Spanish press were bothered. "Anelka showed that he can be an important player for Real in the future," wrote Juan Ruiz, columnist for Madrid-based sports daily Marca. "Anelka's luck has changed for the better. It's a new year and there's new hope for him," he went on, as if the words 'slight' and 'distortion' had never been invented. However the Real Madrid website remains eerily quiet regarding the event, its front page carrying just one, English phrase. "Ready for discharge!" it says.

Watch Anelka's goal in glorious blurry Quicktime here.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chelsea are said to be interested in Roma playmaker Francesco Totti. He would cost upwards of £15m.

Liverpool have bid £6.5m bid for Barcelona left-back Sergi. They are also likely to sign Norwegian under-21 goalkeeper Espen Johnsen for £600,000.

Sunderland are to make a £1m move for 21-year-old Argentinian striker Emanuel Ruiz.

Sheffield Wednesday want Nottingham Forest goalkeeper Mark Crossley - they are prepared to swap Pavel Srnicek or Kevin Pressman plus cash.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Rivaldo has resolved his differences with Barcelona coach Louis van Gaal. The Brazilian had refused to play on the left side of the attack, but after being dropped for two games has decided to back down. "I've decided to play as the coach wants me to. I've always thought I play better in the centre of midfield but I have to respect the coach's decision," Rivaldo said. "I wasn't expecting this so soon," responded van Gaal, "but this news leaves me very happy."

Peter Davenport is the new manager of Macclesfield following Sammy McIlroy's appointment as boss of Northern Ireland.

Jackie McNamara is ready to commit his long-term future to Celtic and will sign a four-and-a-half year deal to remain at Parkhead.

Charlton defender Eddie Youds has been ruled out for the rest of the season with a knee injury.

Notts County want to secure the services of on-loan Stockport striker Brett Angell for £100,000.

Aberdeen midfielder Andy Dow has signed a new two-and-a-half-year contract at Pittodrie.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: Match Of The Day (8pm)
Manchester United v Necaxa. At least try to look interested.

Match Of The Day (1.20am)
Highlights of the above. As if once wasn't enough.

ITV: World Football (3.25am)
Real competitions, and nothing to do with the Championshop.

Channel 5: Football Review (2am)
The best of Channel 5's 1999 coverage. So another chance to see that memorable Linfield v Wolverhampton Wanderers clash, then. Woo-hoo.

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm, 12.15am)
Joao Havelange presents a brand new variety show loosely based on 3-2-1 which opens every week with a topical dance routine from The Sepp Blatter Connection.

Spanish Football (8pm, 12.45am)
It's Spanish.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 2.45am)
It's pish.

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 7.30pm, 11.30pm SS1)
"Seamus Heaney may be favourite for the Whitbread Book of the Year but I prefer the work of Rose Tremain," says Stuart Nethercott. Team-mate Bobby Bowry disagrees vehemently.

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (6.30pm, 11pm SS2)
Brian Moore talks to John Connelly. Well you can never get too much Man U, can you?

World Cup Classics (10pm)
It's Mexico '69. England begin the defence of the trophy they won in 1964 by playing Romario, the team in yellow who feature Hagi and Ilie.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (8pm)
"Why the hell have I been sent out to Brazil? It's bloody freezing and the standard of the football is rubbish!"

fields.headline: Scientific evidence 'unreliable', defence claims
fields.trailText:
The case against Dr Harold Shipman is based on unreliable scientific evidence,
his murder trial jury was told today.
fields.body:
The case against Dr Harold Shipman is based on unreliable scientific evidence, his murder trial jury was told today.

In her closing speech, defence counsel Nicola Davies QC told Preston crown court that the prosecution had failed to provide the motive.

Mrs Davies said Dr Shipman, who denies murdering 15 patients and forging the will of one of his alleged victims, had been a caring general medical practitioner since the 1970s.

She said that before his arrest in 1998 he had a patient list of 3,100. "No patient had to register with Dr Shipman, but the fact that so many did must mean some inferences can be drawn," she said. "With a list size of 3,100, well above the national average, Dr Shipman must have been doing something right."

Miss Davies said the fact that the doctor was so caring he cold-called on his patients and visited them at home so they did not have to come to the surgery had been "turned on its head and that caring evidence used against him".

The fact that Dr Shipman avoided the need to put relatives through the distress of a post mortem examination was just another example of his caring ways. She said: "You may have formed the view that keeping records was not his forte. Within the scale of things what is really more important ... that patients are seen and cared for, or that immaculate records are kept?"

Miss Davies said that during the weeks and months of evidence one thing the prosecution had failed to raise was a motive. "Why should this doctor murder 15 of his patients?" she asked.

"In the opening of his case for the crown Mr Henriques suggested there was a power motive behind the actions of Dr Shipman. Where is the evidence? No psychiatrist has been called. We are not here to consider psychological theories. What we are here to consider is proof."

Miss Davies added: "The prosecution case is built on one foundation stone and that is toxicology. Without it there would be no case. Toxicology is a new science and untested by proven scientific methods."

Miss Davies said: "We contend that it is inherently unreliable and therefore unsafe, and without that toxicological evidence, all that flows from it, that you are asked to draw inferences, fail."

She said there needed to be clear unequivocal proof that the doctor administered "a specific and identifiable substance to each of the 15 women which wholly or substantially causes their death" and not novel, unreliable scientific evidence.

webTitle: Fusco wins judicial review in extradition case

fields.headline: Fusco wins judicial review in extradition case
fields.trailText: Former top IRA man and convicted killer Angelo Fusco was today granted  leave by   the High Court in Dublin for a judicial review into a court order for his   extradition to Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Former top IRA man and convicted killer Angelo Fusco was today granted leave by the High Court in Dublin for a judicial review into a court order for his extradition to Northern Ireland.

His victory follows protest today outisde the Irish high court by Republicans including Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams.

Mr Adams' presence underlined the high stakes in an extradition case stemming from the killing of an SAS captain 20 years ago. Fusco was convicted in his absence in Belfast in 1981 for the murder the previous year of Captain Herbert Westmacott, one of the most senior casualties in the Northern Ireland conflict.

Fusco's appearance in the Irish high court not only represents the latest twist in his personal odyssey, but also marks a test case for the Northern Ireland peace process. His lawyers argue that Fusco, 43, should not be returned to Northern Ireland because of the changed political climate following the 1998 Good Friday agreement. The early release of paramilitary prisoners is part of the accord, but Unionist politicians can be expected to react with fury if Fusco is not extradited.

Fusco was arrested in a surprise move by the Irish police in County Kerry earlier this week and he was going to be sent to Northern Ireland. But a police convoy escorting Fusco to the border with Northern Ireland was stopped on Tuesday when Irish high court judge Joseph Finnegan blocked the extradition and ordered him to appear before the court in Dublin today.

It was a dramatic reprieve for Fusco, a notorious IRA figure who has led a tumultuous life. Two days before being sentenced to life imprisonment for the killing of captain Westmacott, he and other IRA men shot their way out of a Belfast court. He was later recaptured in 1982 in the Irish Republic and jailed there.

Fusco was served with extradition warrants from the RUC on his release from jail in 1992 and finally exhausted legal efforts to avoid being returned to Belfast six years later. He went to ground and his arrest this week came as a surprise on both sides of the Irish border in view of recent advances made in the Northern Ireland peace process.

Meanwhile, the IRA last night yesterday accused British intelligence services of undermining progress in the peace process. It warned of a "negative impact" if Britain did not play its part in demilitarising the province. It was an indication that any move on decommissioning would depend on a dramatic reduction in the British military presence in the province.

Ulster Unionist Party security spokesman Ken Maginnis, MP, said the IRA statement was "defensive, insulting and very disappointing". Mr Maginnis added: "I can see nothing different in this year's statement despite the fact that there is the opportunity for political progress compared with the statements that have been issued in previous years."

Democratic Unionist Party security spokesman Gregory Campbell said the statement proved that the IRA did not intent to hand over its weapons. "The fact that there is no mention whatsoever of ongoing and verifiable decommissioning - that is the clearest indication that the IRA have no intention whatsoever of handing over a series of weapons that would qualify as decommissioning," he said.

fields.headline: Rebels thwart Russian advance
fields.trailText: Moscow's hopes for a swift conclusion to its Chechen campaign have been dashed by fierce resistance from rebels in the capital Grozny and in mountain strongholds, with increasing casualties on the Russian side.
fields.body:
Moscow's hopes for a swift conclusion to its Chechen campaign have been dashed by fierce resistance from rebels in the capital Grozny and in mountain strongholds, with increasing casualties on the Russian side.

Russia now admits that about 500 of its soldiers and interior troops have died since they entered Chechnya at the end of September. Both sides claim to be inflicting heavy losses while suffering relatively light casualties.

Former president Boris Yeltsin remains confident. Speaking on a trip to Jerusalem, he said: "Two more months and then we will plant our Russian flag in Chechnya."

His remarks echoed earlier predictions by senior Russian generals. But the generals also said they would take Grozny itself within days, yet have made little progress against about 2,000 rebel fighters holed up in the besieged city.

Russia's envoy to Chechnya, Nikolai Koshman, said that seizing Grozny, where between 10,000 and 40,000 civilians remained trapped with little food or firewood, has turned out to be much harder than expected. He said generals were right to go slowly, to keep Russian military losses to a minimum in the face of what he called "fierce resistance from the doomed".

Achieving a victory in Chechnya before 26 March, the date of the next presidential election, would greatly boost the chances of Mr Yeltsin's chosen heir, Vladimir Putin, of winning the vote decisively. webTitle: Blair orders shake-up of failing NHS

fields.headline: Blair orders shake-up of failing NHS
fields.standfirst: Radical changes imposed on GPs
fields.trailText: Health ministers have ordered a rapid acceleration of the NHS modernisation programme after Tony Blair admitted sharing public frustration at the lack of tangible results in the first 30 months of Labour's administration.
fields.body:
Health ministers have ordered a rapid acceleration of the NHS modernisation programme after Tony Blair admitted sharing public frustration at the lack of tangible results in the first 30 months of Labour's administration.

Officials have been told to give priority to a shake-up of arrangements for out-of-hours cover for family doctors, following survey findings that one in five people taken acutely ill at night has to wait more than two hours for a home visit.

Doctors will be offered the option of having all their out-of-hours calls dealt with by NHS Direct, the new and highly popular telephone advice line, where nurses will decide whether a home visit is necessary.

John Denham, health minister overseeing the programme, has also instructed officials to press on with opening more walk-in centres - where people can get basic NHS care and advice without going to their GP - and to develop more schemes where demarcations between health professionals are broken down and rule books torn up.

Doctors' leaders last night offered only muted criticism of the plans, indicating a growing readiness to accept the direction of government policy and a wariness of continuing to be typecast as dinosaur-like in resisting change.

John Chisholm, who chairs the GPs' committee of the British Medical Association, said: "We are going to see an increasing variety of models of care in the future and we have to defend the common values that the models have, while nonetheless accepting that people will want to access the NHS in different ways.

"We don't for a minute imagine that the traditional practice - the Dr Finlay and Dr Cameron model - will be the only way of working."

Health ministers argue that radical change is going on apace in the health service, but that much of it is invisible to the average patient. They say the modernisation amounts to a "quiet revolution" - a term picked up by the prime minister last week in his new year message.

On the other hand, Mr Blair said pointedly: "I understand the frustration at the pace of change in the NHS. I share it."

Ministers think a big part of the problem is that very few people any longer understand the structure of the service, particularly at the level of primary or non-hospital care where many of the most innovative changes are being made.

There are almost 300 "personal medical services pilots" operating across England, offering primary care outside the conventions and restrictions of the traditional family doctor practice. In Sunderland, one such scheme has brought the first GP service to the sprawling and deprived Pennywell estate.

In April, the first "primary care trusts" will start work, whereby GPs, nurses and other health professionals will take over the running of community health services and handle annual budgets of at least £60m.

While these schemes will remain the cornerstones of NHS modernisation, ministers accept that they need to do more to promote changes to which people can relate. The success of NHS Direct, and the convenience of walk-in centres, are seen as important pointers.

With NHS Direct now covering 65% of England, it fielded 10,600 calls on Christmas Day and 14,800 on New Year's Day, compared with a daily average of 5,000 in the autumn.

In a markedly conciliatory comment, Dr Chisholm said: "One of the things that ministers seem to have in mind is almost that the front door of the health service will increasingly be NHS Direct, rather than the general practitioner. I don't have any great problem with that."

What was essential was that all emerging models of care were thoroughly evaluated and fully co-ordinated, with GPs retaining comprehensive medical records for their patients, and that care thresholds were not distorted by greater accessibility of services.

fields.headline: Lessons of law's hard heart
fields.standfirst: The technical issues of the law mean that war crimes suspect Konrad Kalejs (above) has avoided extradition; if he is indeed guilty he should nonetheless heed Primo Levi's words on confession and redemption, says Martin Wainwright
fields.trailText: It was a sight to upset the most callous of courtroom observers: an elderly  stroke victim in the witness box, memory wavering, struggling to recall the  details of a ghastly allegation, a vicious piece of inhumanity to man.
fields.body:
It was a sight to upset the most callous of courtroom observers: an elderly stroke victim in the witness box, memory wavering, struggling to recall the details of a ghastly allegation, a vicious piece of inhumanity to man.

What followed was still more riveting. After the old man quavered to a halt with a final, forlorn cry that justice had not been done, the judge leaned over the wooden dais and said: "I am so, so sorry. If I was not wearing my wig, I would probably agree with you. Fate has played you a very bad hand."

The exchange took place this Wednesday at Bradford Crown Court, where a fraud case - the alleged swindling of the pensioner's £50,000 life-savings by a callous conman - collapsed because of the elderly man's honest admission that his recall of events had become hazy after the stroke. A tragic event, but small-scale; a paragraph at most in the national papers. Except that it has a bearing on the infinitely more publicised case of Konrad Kalejs, the alleged mass-murderer, torturer and concentration camp guard who has finally slunk out of Britain.

The alleged crimes do not bear the slightest comparison but the ways of the law do. The cry from the heart for justice which affected the Bradford judge, even as he ruled that the pensioner's evidence would inevitably be unsafe, is magnified six million times in the context of the Holocaust. But the war against the Nazis was fought for the rule of law as the guarantee of freedom, and their crushing defeat was those virtues' triumph. The head must rule the heart to hold that line.

The case of Kalejs has been considered by three democratic governments and the technical issues of the law - the assembling of evidence, of witnesses, of a courtroom timetable to try an 86-year-old before he dies - have been processed and re-processed with a fine-toothed comb. In each case, the decision has been the same as the Bradford judge's in the fraud case; and the solitary successful war crimes prosecution in modern Britain - of 78-year-old Anthony Sawoniuk last April - only lends those conclusions force.

If Kalejs did the terrible things of which he is accused, have no doubt that he will have suffered. He will be suffering now. And he will suffer until he dies. A life as a pariah, presumed guilty and effectively on the run from decent people, is not in any sense "getting away with it". But it pales in comparison with the torments of a guilty man or woman who knows their guilt.

What matters is that society, history and future generations do know that guilt. That they never have any doubt about the evil loosed in Europe by the Nazis and the complicity of countless "ordinary" people, whether Germans or Latvians like Kalej, who may individually have killed no one but in fact sealed the Holocaust victims' fate. That is the greatest message of survivors such as the late Primo Levi, who pointed unwaveringly to confession, and unqualified admission as the only path to redemption. Kalejs' reading matter on his flight to Australia should be Levi's The Drowned and the Saved.

Useful links
Nazi suspect leaves Britain
Extradition explained

Erogenous Leeds

Viewed the day after a hectic - but exhilarating - squash on the Embankment on New Year's Eve, the dome (and still more the beautiful new Underground station which serves it) was an exhilarating sight. Family tickets are already booked in this household for a Domeday, sometime after April when they should have got the glitches sorted out.

So it isn't a bit of "up-yours-London" Northernism to suggest an alternative outing in the meanwhile. If you're anxious about the huge queues reported at Greenwich, especially for the famous Body Zone with its pubic hair lice et al, take heart. The nearest thing Britain has to a national health exhibition, the Thackray medical museum in Leeds, has an Alternative Body Zone up and running.

It's mostly a giant walk-in gut and potter-through brain at the moment, but the museum (which has £3.5m of other gruesome attractions) announced plans yesterday for lungs and heart with room for shrieking schoolkids inside. Weekends in Leeds also feature for the first time this year in Which? Magazine's guide to short breaks; and though we haven't got a jellyfish-shaped tent, the Yorkshire sky forms a dome in itself, stretching from horizon to horizon and usually blue.

fields.headline: Tim Burton
fields.standfirst: The legend of Sleepy Hollow | Hammer films | Shooting Sleepy Hollow | Burton's reputation as an outsider | Animation
fields.trailText: The legend of Sleepy Hollow | Hammer films | Shooting Sleepy Hollow | Burton's reputation as an outsider | Animation
fields.body:
Mark Kermode: The films you make, even though they are live action, owe an enormous debt to animation, in the physicality of them. Do you think that there is a very specific Burton-esque manner of behaving, or is it just the critics' imagination?

Tim Burton: Spastic - that's my own personal behaviour [Laughter]. I love movement, and we considered Sleepy Hollow as a silent movie when we were thinking and talking about it and in the old monster movies as well there's something about movement that's just part of character and I think that comes from animation as well. Every aspect of the film from the look and the movement is important to the character of the piece.

MK: It's been said that the story of Sleepy Hollow is incredibly well known, but you describe Sleepy Hollow as a story that everyone thinks they've read but nobody has. Tell us about the relationship between the story and the film.

TB: I think in America, which is a relatively new country, there's not the wealth of stories, folk tales and fairy tales that there are in other countries so I think we were told that story in school because it was one of the only early American folk tales and that's why I was drawn to it. I remembered the story, but I talked to a lot of people who thought they knew the story, and I think it is the power of that image and the setting. I probably remember it more from the Disney cartoon actually. They did two different shorts Sleepy Hollow which was 20 minutes and Wind in the Willows a Mr Toad cartoon which they put together as a short feature. It's sung by Bing Crosby - which we kept out of our version.

MK: There's also an homage to Hammer films. You grew up in Burbank overlooking the studio. What was it - as an American - that you liked about Hammer films?

MB: It's like your first introduction to sex and the lurid beauty of the horror movie. In the early Universal films [] the look and the feel of it was very important to the mood. The dark and lurid colours, the sexiness of it and the strength of them going for it in the way a good folk tale would was always very powerful they [Hammer] brought that back which had been missing for a while. Those films where the images speak to you, I've seen Black Sunday probably 20 times and I still can't remember the story but the images stay with you forever. That's the kind of film that really speaks to me.

MK: You've said in Burton on Burton that you didn't understand why people got antsy about a film not being narrative because for you the primary cinematic experience was Expressionist, it was to do with remembered images, and I think you described the design as the look inside someone's head. Do you think your films are visual films not narrative films?

TB: In a simplistic way. It's meant as a compliment but it's a weird criticism to say the films just look good which is strange because I wouldn't know how to make a good-looking film; you don't enter into it that way. The place and the mood and the feel of it is very important, it's treated as another character in the piece and it's very nice when you're able to look at an image and goes inside as opposed to just thinking about it. Those are the films that stay with me.

MK: In the film it's upstate New York, but you shot Sleepy Hollow in England didn't you? I imagined like Hammer most of it was sound-stage but you built the village for outside, so how did you blend the two things together?

TB: We tried to make the stage look as real as possible and the stuff out in the location as fake as possible so that it would intermingle and match and we pumped smoke into everything and masked it that way. But I worked here 10 years before on Batman so I had the opportunity to work with the same artists. I really enjoy working here because working away from Hollywood you're able to focus more on the movie and there is a lot of good energy coming from the crew and the cast and the artists. People paint beautiful skies and paint the buildings with beautiful texture and make beautiful props and it's a real good energy.

MK: Do you sketch the thing out and then go to your art designer and say, "This is what it's going to be"

TB: Not really because my sketches are really crude, it would end up looking like a Charlie Brown Special if they were literally used that way. I've been lucky to work with people who sort of get the idea. I just show a rough sketch or talk about it and it goes through several layers before coming real. I try to rely even less on storyboards because I find people sometimes take them too literally, and with these technical films with all these great actors you don't want to completely follow a drawing from shot to shot.

MK: The thing I remember about Batman is helicopters flying over the set to take pictures and it was this terrible media circus. You seem to have avoided that this time - you assembled your cast and got on with your work.

TB: That's the way it should be, to get all that other stuff out of the way and just focus on what you're doing.

MK: What was it about the British actors that made you choose them?

TB: They're just great, there's just a difference. One of the first scenes we shot is when Ichabod opens the door and there they all are in the room and it actually felt that way with all these great people, it was scary. You open up the door and it's "Wooah, shall I shut it or go away, I don't know!" (Laughter). There's just a sense of craft and artistry and you learn a lot from these people. It's a different vibe then in America where people get more caught up in the business side of it. Here you just feel the people really acting and it's really enjoyable to watch.

MK: You have this reputation of being an outsider: you don't live in Hollywood anymore do you?

TB: Yes, sort of.

MK: You came up through the Hollywood system, you worked at Disney, you did Batman and people are wont to say that your films are about outsiders. In the case of Sleepy Hollow you've brought Ichabod in from outside - in the original story he's from the town itself. Do you see yourself as that outside loner, that misunderstood person, or are you part of the system?

TB: I always felt that Hollywood has a way of making you feel outside. I don't feel a part of it although I do feel lucky to have done the things that I have done through that system. I look back on it and I can't quite figure it out myself, maybe I just confused them so much that they have just given me some money to go away - I don't know! But I've been lucky.

MK: What's your relationship like with Disney now? You worked on Fox and the Hounds

TB: They were real happy I stopped working on Fox and the Hounds My foxes looked like road kills They were bad. I was not cut out for that style.

MK: Are they now "Yes, Tim Burton the great son of Disney"?

TB: The problem with studios is that there's such a quick turnover it's hard to know who's at what studio. They all become much more corporatised so it's hard to know who's where anymore.

MK: I think your films occupy a space somewhere between animation and real life, with animated characters you treat them as real characters, and with real actors you seem to move them the same way as you would animation. Do you think that's fair or do you get fed up with the animation tag?

TB: No, I don't care because I was grateful for that background, rather than going to film school you drew the sets, and also you did the sound editing and so in some ways it was the perfect film school training because you really got to experience all aspects of it, and also animation teaches you to be more opened up to things in certain ways. So I always felt very good about that background.

MK: Sleepy Hollow is not a film that is scared to be scary and I would imagine that in your mind it's aimed at a younger audience, but here it's a 15 certificate and in America it's an R. Do you find it strange that they should be so prescriptive about watching those films?

TB: I have a different attitude to theirs obviously because I grew up watching Hammer Horror films on Saturday afternoon TV and I haven't broken any major laws - yet! (Laughter). Before films, throughout the history of people there have been these stories which are quite gruesome. If you filmed any one of those literally it probably wouldn't even get a rating so we tried very hard to keep it within the realm of fantasy, not to shy away from the graphic-ness but to keep in that realm. Kids are intelligent, some would like it, some wouldn't, and I think people forget that. It's not like TV where you're forced to watch something - you still have a choice. We all knew it wouldn't get any less rating. The studio and the producers were quite supportive of that.

MK: You've had studios turn around despite the fact that it's you, haven't you?

TB: Yeah, I thought that after a couple of times it would get easier, you get lucky with a couple of successes and you think it's going to get easier but in fact it doesn't. Even a low-budget film costs a fair amount of money so they're always a struggle to get off the ground.

One of the first scenes we shot is when Ichabod opens the door and there they all are in the room and it actually felt that way with all these great people, it was scary. You open up the door and it's "Wooah, shall I shut it or go away, I don't know!" (Laughter). There's just a sense of craft and artistry and you learn a lot from these people. It's a different vibe then in America where people get more caught up in the business side of it. Here you just feel the people really acting and it's really enjoyable to watch. MK: You have this reputation of being an outsider: you don't live in Hollywood anymore do you? TB: Yes, sort of. MK: You came up through the Hollywood system, you worked at Disney, you did Batman and people are wont to say that your films are about outsiders. In the case of Sleepy Hollow you've brought Ichabod in from outside - in the original story he's from the town itself. Do you see yourself as that outside loner, that misunderstood person, or are you part of the system? TB: I always felt that Hollywood has a way of making you feel outside. I don't feel a part of it although I do feel lucky to have done the things that I have done through that system. I look back on it and I can't quite figure it out myself, maybe I just confused them so much that they have just given me some money to go away - I don't know! But I've been lucky. MK: What's your relationship like with Disney now? You worked on Fox and the Hounds TB: They were real happy I stopped working on Fox and the Hounds My foxes looked like road kills They were bad. I was not cut out for that style. MK: Are they now "Yes, Tim Burton the great son of Disney"? TB: The problem with studios is that there's such a quick turnover it's hard to know who's at what studio. They all become much more corporatised so it's hard to know who's where anymore. MK: I think your films occupy a space somewhere between animation and real life, with animated characters you treat them as real characters, and with real actors you seem to move them the same way as you would animation. Do you think that's fair or do you get fed up with the animation tag? TB: No, I don't care because I was grateful for that background, rather than going to film school you drew the sets, and also you did the sound editing and so in some ways it was the perfect film school training because you really got to experience all aspects of it, and also animation teaches you to be more opened up to things in certain ways. So I always felt very good about that background. MK: Sleepy Hollow is not a film that is scared to be scary and I would imagine that in your mind it's aimed at a younger audience, but here it's a 15 certificate and in America it's an R. Do you find it strange that they should be so prescriptive about watching those films? TB: I have a different attitude to theirs obviously because I grew up watching Hammer Horror films on Saturday afternoon TV and I haven't broken any major laws - yet! (Laughter). Before films, throughout the history of people there have been these stories which are quite gruesome. If you filmed any one of those literally it probably wouldn't even get a rating so we tried very hard to keep it within the realm of fantasy, not to shy away from the graphic-ness but to keep in that realm. Kids are intelligent, some would like it, some wouldn't, and I think people forget that. It's not like TV where you're forced to watch something - you still have a choice. We all knew it wouldn't get any less rating. The studio and the producers were quite supportive of that. MK: You've had studios turn around despite the fact that it's you, haven't you? TB: Yeah, I thought that after a couple of times it would get easier, you get lucky with a couple of successes and you think it's going to get easier but in fact it doesn't. Even a low-budget film costs a fair amount of money so they're always a struggle to get off the ground. webTitle: Zeta-Jones accepts Douglas's New Year's Eve proposal

fields.headline: Zeta-Jones accepts Douglas's New Year's Eve proposal
fields.standfirst: Also today, Spiderman caught in tangled web, Liz Hurley gets bedazzled and John Travolta plays dead
fields.trailText: Hollywood couple Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones are to tie the knot, Douglas announced last night on his official website. Douglas' publicist, Allen Burry, later confirmed that the Basic Instinct star proposed to the Welsh-born actress on New Year's Eve while the pair were celebrating the millennium at Douglas's mountain home in Aspen, Colorado. "While no official date has been announced, they plan to wed later this year," Burry confirmed. "He's now given her a ring."
fields.body:
Hollywood couple Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones are to tie the knot, Douglas announced last night on his official website. Douglas' publicist, Allen Burry, later confirmed that the Basic Instinct star proposed to the Welsh-born actress on New Year's Eve while the pair were celebrating the millennium at Douglas's mountain home in Aspen, Colorado. "While no official date has been announced, they plan to wed later this year," Burry confirmed. "He's now given her a ring."

Burry's statement comes at the end of months of gossip and speculation. On December 27, the Daily Star reported that the couple had split after Zeta-Jones flew back to Swansea to spend Christmas with her family.

Their liaison had been regarded with wry suspicion by many industry insiders, who viewed the romance as no more than a canny career move for rising star Zeta-Jones and an ego-boost for the ageing Douglas. The couple share the same birthday (September 25) but are separated by several decades. Douglas is 55, Zeta-Jones 30.

The pair first met at the 1998 Deauville Film Festival and have been dating since March 1999. Michael Douglas is the son of actor Kirk Douglas and an influential star and producer in his own right. Zeta-Jones came to fame in the 1991 TV series The Darling Buds of May and reversed a subsequent career slump when she moved to California in 1996. Recent roles in The Mask of Zorro and the heist thriller Entrapment have made her one of Hollywood's most bankable female stars. This will be Zeta-Jones's first marriage and her fiancee's second. A confessed "sex addict", Douglas finalised a divorce from his wife of 22 years, Diandra Luker, in 1999.

Spiderman caught in tangled web

Debate is heating up over who will direct Columbia/Sony's adaptation of the Spiderman comic-book, spurred on by rumours that Speed helmer Jan De Bont has been in talks with Columbia chairwoman Amy Pascal. But counter-claims from an unnamed source at Columbia/Sony insist that the prime contenders for the project remain Sam Raimi and Fight Club director David Fincher. "The talk about Jan De Bont is not true," the source states.

Such confusion suggests widespread jitters inside the Columbia/Sony camp, reflected in a recent Variety feature which remarked upon the studio's poor box-office returns in 1999: "it wasn't our best year," Pascal admits.

The original Spiderman comic (filmed once before in 1977) followed the fortunes of a nerdy New York high-schooler who gains super-powers after he is bitten by a radioactive arachnid. Columbia/Sony's current adaptation has been further dogged by an alleged rift between the studio and the comic-book publishers Marvel.

The studio source admits that Marvel were deeply dissatisfied with David Koepp's original screenplay and demanded an extensive rewrite. David Mamet, fresh from adapting the similarly troubled Hannibal, has been called in to produce a more Marvel-friendly interpretation.

Liz Hurley signs on for bedazzled remake

Elizabeth Hurley has signed up for a role in the Faustian comedy Bedazzled opposite Brendan Fraser and Mansfield Park actress Frances O'Connor.

The film, to be directed by Harold Ramis, is a remake of the 1967 Peter Cook and Dudley Moore caper about a suicidal office worker who sells his soul to the Devil.

While the jury is still out on Hurley's acting abilities, the British celebrity has carved herself a profitable niche sending up her starlet image in such successful Stateside comedies as Ron Howard's EdTV and the two Austin Powers pictures. Bedazzled goes before the cameras in Los Angeles on January 24.

Travolta plays dead?

John Travolta is poised to commit to the Warner Bros drama Steinbeck's Point of View, Variety reports. The Pulp Fiction player will star as a dying man who accepts his fate with the aid of some supernatural jiggery-pokery. Assuming he accepts the role, Travolta is reported to have a say in selecting the film's director.

Steinbeck's Point of View is scheduled to begin shooting in April, once the actor has completed work on the lottery comedy Numbers, currently being directed by Nora Ephron.

webTitle: IRA sounds new warning on arms

fields.headline: IRA sounds new warning on arms
fields.standfirst: Reduction in British military presence a condition of disarming
fields.trailText: The IRA last night sounded a warning to the peace process in Northern Ireland when it indicated that any move on decommissioning would depend on a dramatic reduction in the British military presence in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
The IRA last night sounded a warning to the peace process in Northern Ireland when it indicated that any move on decommissioning would depend on a dramatic reduction in the British military presence in Northern Ireland.

The IRA, in a new year's message, drew attention to the security services' bugging of a car used by the Sinn Fein leadership during former US senator George Mitchell's review of the Good Friday agreement as a breach of faith. But its representative is expected to meet General John de Chastelain, chairman of the independent international commission on decommissioning, tomorrow to discuss further moves on IRA disarmament.

It is believed the IRA is insisting that key members be allowed to retain personal protection weapons. Gen de Chastelain is understood to have no problem with that.

David Trimble, Northern Ireland's first minister, has indicated to his ruling Ulster Unionist council that he will quit if there is no movement on IRA decommissioning by the end of February.

The IRA's statement last night is seen as raising of the stakes ahead of the recalling of the UUC.

Gen de Chastelain is expected to release his report on progress towards decommissioning at the end of this month. It is due to be completed by May.

"As we move into a new century there exists an unprecedented opportunity to leave behind the failures of the past," the statement added. "The [IRA] leadership will continue to play a positive role in a genuine effort to realise a just and lasting peace."

The statement said that the Ulster Unionist party's "attempt to set preconditions" was not part of a political understanding of the Mitchell review of the Good Friday agreement.

Appearing in this week's issue of An Phoblacht, the newspaper of Sinn Fein, the statement also referred to the controversy over the bugging of a car used by the Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams, and the new education minister, Martin McGuinness.

It pointed to "recent revelations surrounding British intelligence covert surveillance operations", which, allied to al leged Royal Ulster Constabulary efforts to recruit informers, amounted to "clear evidence" of a continuation of the war against republicans.

The IRA said: "These activities are part of an ongoing attempt to defeat republicans and subvert the existing opportunity for the achievement of a durable peace.

"There can be no excuse for further delay in the implemen tation of those aspects of the Good Friday agreement which are the responsibility of the British government.

"Any failure on their part to rapidly implement a programme of demilitarisation can only have a negative impact on the potential for political progress and, therefore, serve the same agenda as those who continue covert surveillance operations."

fields.headline: A touch of the Tavs
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: If Michael Vaughan is catching "a touch of the Tavs" as Mike Selvey suggested in "The Guardian", is this a good or bad thing? What was Chris Tavare's final Test average? asks Stuart MacNeill
fields.body:
If Michael Vaughan is catching "a touch of the Tavs" as Mike Selvey suggested in "The Guardian", is this a good or bad thing? What was Chris Tavare's final Test average? asks Stuart MacNeill

Tavare finished with 1755 runs in his 31 Tests, at an average of 32.50. He made two centuries - 149 v India at Delhi in 1981-82 (a draw, and the match in which Geoff Boycott became Test cricket's leading runscorer) and 109 in the victory over New Zealand at The Oval in 1983. But "Tav" is probably best remembered for his slow-scoring double at Old Trafford in 1981 - a match England won by 103 runs, chiefly thanks to Ian Botham's rollicking 118. Tavare followed his 69 in 287 minutes in the first innings with 78 in 423 minutes in the second. It was the slowest half-century in English first-class cricket at the time. He's probably a bit unlucky to be remembered as a slowcoach - he was under orders to be the sheet anchor in Tests, and was quite a free scorer in county cricket.

How many cases are there of a player making his first-class debut in a Test match? When was the last example, and have any England players ever fallen into this category? asks Richard Graveling

This happened a few times in the last century, when privately raised sides toured with some makeweight players. Three England players - CJ Coventry, BAF Grieve and JEP McMaster - thus made their first-class debuts in what later became recognised as Test matches in South Africa in 1888-89. The expansion of the Test-playing ranks to include Sri Lanka and Zimbabwe - neither of which had a widespread domestic first-class competition - means that some players have recently played Test cricket after very few first-class outings. But I believe the only player this century to make his first-class debut in a Test match was Graham Vivian, for New Zealand v India at Calcutta in 1964-65. A 19-year-old legspinner, he seems to have been selected for the tour after some impressive net performances! He continued in first-class cricket until 1979, and played five Tests in all.

When Ben Hollioake made his Test debut against Australia in 1997, it was only his 12th first-class match, a postwar record for England. Two others came close: Lancashire's Ken Cranston made his Test debut in 1947: it was his 14th first-class match, and came less than two months after his debut. And Brian Close, in 1949, was chosen for England after less than three months and 17 matches for Yorkshire.

Who was the last right-hander to score a Test double-century against England? asks Janet Lapin of Woking

This questioner has probably spotted that the last eight double-centuries against England in Tests have been scored by left-handers - by Gary Kirsten (275 in 1999-2000, 210 in 1998), Sanath Jayasuriya (213 in 1998), Brian Lara (375 in 1993-94), Allan Border (200* in 1993), Vinod Kambli (224 in 1992-93), Aamir Sohail (205 in 1992) and Mark Taylor (219 in 1989). The last right-hander to reach 200 against England was Javed Miandad, who made 260 at The Oval in 1987.

When did Hansie Cronje of South Africa last score a Test century? asks Duncan Pringle

The most recent of his six centuries came in July 1998 at Trent Bridge, when he hit 126 against England. That was his first hundred in over three years, since he made 101 against New Zealand at Auckland in March 1995.

What was the result of the Test between England and Australia at Headingley in 1981 when Dennis Lillee and Rod Marsh bet against Australia? asks Paul Dobson

England managed to win that famous Test, by 18 runs. Lillee and Marsh laid their infamous bets when England were quoted at odds of 500-1. At the time they were 135-7 in their second innings, after following on 227 behind. All the England players had booked out of their hotel. But Ian Botham's amazing 149 not out, helped by 56 from Graham Dilley and 29 from Chris Old, took England to 356 - a lead of 129. And then Bob Willis, with 8-43, skittled Australia for 111. England were the only team to win a Test in the 20th century after following on (they also won after following on at Adelaide in 1894-95).

In the second innings of the Indians' tour match at Hobart, all 11 of Tasmania's players (including the wicketkeeper) bowled at least one over. Has this ever happened in a Test match? asks Debapriya Sen, from Calcutta, India

It has happened twice in Tests. First, at The Oval, in 1884, when all 11 Englishmen tried their luck as Australia ran up a total of 551. England's wicketkeeper, the Hon. Alfred Lyttelton, had the best bowling figures - 4-19 with underarm lobs. It happened again in a boring draw at Faisalabad in 1979-80, as Pakistan made 382-2 in reply to Australia's 617. All 11 Aussies bowled: Greg Chappell, their captain, kept wicket while Rod Marsh bowled for the first time in Tests. He sent down ten overs, but didn't manage a wicket.

With reference to the recent question about the former Middlesex and England fast bowler Fred Durston, you may be interested to know that his grandson, Jack, lives in Littleton, Colorado (USA), and plays both soccer and cricket here

Thanks to Dan Ruparel, the president of Littleton Cricket Club.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Heaney favourite for Whitbread prize
fields.standfirst: Nobel winner pips his old friend Ted Hughes in the race for literary award with reworking of Anglo-Saxon epic poem
fields.trailText: Nobel winner pips his old friend Ted Hughes in the race for literary award with reworking of Anglo-Saxon epic poem
fields.body:
Nobel prizewinner Seamus Heaney emerged yesterday as the strong favourite for this year's Whitbread Book of the Year award after winning its poetry category for the second time in four years.

He pipped his old friend, the late Ted Hughes, to whom Heaney had dedicated his winning book, Beowulf, a reworking of the Anglo-Saxon epic poem in praise of a great mythic warrior.

Hughes had been shortlisted for his version of Euripides's ancient verse play Alcestis about a king who cheats death when his wife offers herself in his place. He finished it weeks before his own death, and inevitably parallels were drawn with his first wife Sylvia Plath and his subsequent partner Assia Wevill, who both killed themselves.

Heaney and Hughes have had a stranglehold on the overall £21,000 Whitbread prize for the past three years. Hughes won last year from beyond the grave with his bestselling Birthday Letters and the year before with Tales From Ovid. Heaney won in 1996 with his last collection, The Spirit Level.

Rose Tremain, who picked up the fiction category for her highly praised historical novel Music and Silence, said she would not bet against Heaney again this year.

"He has to be favourite. It's been Seamus, Ted, Ted, and it will probably be Seamus again. He is a great man and its hard to argue to against him."

Tim Lott, who won the first novel category for White City Blue, said he would be taken aback if anyone else won.

"I feel intimidated being in the same room as Seamus Heaney never mind being in a literary competition with him. I am completely in awe of him. I would be astonished if I won and very surprised if he didn't."

Heaney said: "I didn't know I was the bookies' favourite, but I believe in these cases comment from the horse isn't really called for. The punters are probably the ones to check with. I just feel it was an honour to share this year's poetry shortlist with those other poets. Obviously I'm delighted that Beowulf was chosen but if any of the other shortlisted books had been named, I would still have been very happy."

Rose Tremain, who was shortlisted for the Booker with Restoration, is also highly fancied for her tale of an English musician caught in the romantic intrigues of the Danish court, while Lott's victory with what some critics see as a "lad novel" has raised a few eyebrows.

"The pressure is on me now," said Tremain, whose partner Richard Holmes won the Whitbread book of the year in 1986 for his biography, Coleridge, Early Visions. "I have never got near the Whitbread before, never mind the big one." Lott, 43, whose book centres around a "fly boy" west London estate agent, said he was shocked to have won.

David Cairns, whose has dedicated 30 years of his life to reviving the battered reputation of the French composer Berlioz, is also thought to be an outsider. Like his hero, Cairns has worked as a journalist to make ends meet as he toiled on the two-part biography.

Literary London has been awash with rumours that the rules of the Whitbread were changed this year to allow RK Rowling - author of the phenomenally successful Harry Potter trilogy - to romp away with the main prize.

Until now, the children's award winner has been barred from the main competition. The £10,000 award, in which Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban is pitted against books by Carol Ann Duffy, Jacqueline Wilson and Michael Morpurgo, will be announced on January 25, the same night as the Whitbread book of the year prize is awarded.

Line-up for the 2000 Book of the Year award

Beowulf by Seamus Heaney

Faber & Faber £14.99

"Heaney's poem simply flays more literal versions of Beowulf. He pipped his old friend, the late Ted Hughes, to whom Heaney had dedicated his winning book, Beowulf, a reworking of the Anglo-Saxon epic poem in praise of a great mythic warrior. Hughes had been shortlisted for his version of Euripides's ancient verse play Alcestis about a king who cheats death when his wife offers herself in his place. He finished it weeks before his own death, and inevitably parallels were drawn with his first wife Sylvia Plath and his subsequent partner Assia Wevill, who both killed themselves. Heaney and Hughes have had a stranglehold on the overall £21,000 Whitbread prize for the past three years. Hughes won last year from beyond the grave with his bestselling Birthday Letters and the year before with Tales From Ovid. Heaney won in 1996 with his last collection, The Spirit Level. Rose Tremain, who picked up the fiction category for her highly praised historical novel Music and Silence, said she would not bet against Heaney again this year. "He has to be favourite. fields.headline: The IRA's new year statement
fields.standfirst: An Phoblacht, republican news
fields.trailText: We were persuaded to take this step on the understanding  that it would help end the political vacuum which had been created and maintained by unionist  politicians for the previous 18 months and bring about forward political movement.
fields.body:
We were persuaded to take this step on the understanding that it would help end the political vacuum which had been created and maintained by unionist politicians for the previous 18 months and bring about forward political movement.

The subsequent attempt by the UUP to set preconditions on further political progress was not part of this understanding, is outside the terms of the Mitchell Review and serves only to undermine the potential for advancing the peace process.

Recent revelations surrounding British Intelligence covert surveillance operations and RUC efforts to recruit informers are clear evidence of a continuation of their war against republicans. These activities are part of an ongoing attempt to defeat republicans and subvert the existing opportunity for the achievement of a durable peace. There can be no excuse for further delay in the implementation of those aspects of the Good Friday Agreement which are the responsibility of the British government. Any failure on their part to rapidly implement a programme of demilitarisation can only have a negative impact on the potential for political progress and, therefore, serve the same agenda as those who continue covert surveillance operations.

The leadership of Oglaigh na hEireann [the IRA] will continue to play a positive role in a genuine effort to realise a just and lasting peace.

fields.headline: Sorry England are swept aside
fields.standfirst: Outclassed batsmen lose the plot again as South Africans romp home to seal series triumph
fields.trailText: England capitulated here yesterday in the sorriest fashion imaginable, losing the fourth Test by an innings and 37 runs. Faced with having to bat for two days if the match and the series were to be saved, they managed only two sessions instead, the last able-bodied man out on the stroke of tea.
fields.body:
England capitulated here yesterday in the sorriest fashion imaginable, losing the fourth Test by an innings and 37 runs. Faced with having to bat for two days if the match and the series were to be saved, they managed only two sessions instead, the last able-bodied man out on the stroke of tea.

With the injured Andrew Flintoff unable to bat, the wicket of Phil Tufnell, secured with a straightforward catch to slip off Paul Adams' quirky left-arm spin, set off joyous South African celebrations, beginning with an Aussie-style bonding huddle.

One could hardly blame them for that; although England competed admirably at times, Hansie Cronje's side, with a probably unparalleled depth to their batting, are mighty difficult to beat.

At least, that is, on good pitches. Only top-class spin, perhaps, on slow turning surfaces that would blunt the South Africans' pace attack and expose some rigid batting techniques might consistently dismiss them twice. Their forthcoming series in India should make for fascinating, and instructive, viewing.

Yesterday's 126 is the fifth lowest total, albeit for the loss of only nine wickets, that England have ever made in this country. As they were 115 without loss after 42 overs of the first day, it means that this team lost 19 wickets for 269 runs, including the last 16 for 171, on a pitch on which South Africa, for the ninth time in 11 Tests, exceeded 400.

Under Cronje South Africa have now gone 14 matches without defeat, winning 10 times, since England won twice in a row at home the summer before last. For an unexceptional captain Cronje is a hugely successful one, winning half and losing only 10 of his 50 Tests in charge.

England may have lost the plot competely yesterday with an abject display of batting but, as Nasser Hussain confessed afterwards, the game was lost when the opening partnership on the first day between Mike Atherton and Mark Butcher was not converted into a challenging total.

The captain was not prepared to point an accusing finger at any players but he was clearly upset by the way senior batsmen, most culpably Alec Stewart, had failed to carry into the match the lessons of the previous Tests.

Indeed Stewart's ill-judged hook shot on the first evening, when England should have consolidated and carried a good day into the next, can with hindsight be seen as the cause of the collapse.

"It is possible we got carried away with the overcharged atmosphere," Hussain confessed: in other words, adrenalin from the intensity of the competition, the bowling and the crowd, and a macho response to on-field jibes. Old hands, he knows, ought to respond better than that.

Yesterday all sense of opti mism had left Hussain's side, as if the pressure of hanging on to South Africa's coat tails had finally got too much after the disappointment of Durban. The tourists played for the most part like men who wanted it over and done with, and wickets were gifted to Lance Klusener, a man who cannot bowl a hoop down the high street at this level, to Adams and to Shaun Pollock.

The tone was set when Butcher decided - quite why, only he knows - to drive at Pollock's third ball of the morning as it passed by at least 18in outside his off stump, to be caught at the wicket. Neither Hussain nor the coach Duncan Fletcher will countenance this sort of batting beyond this series. Unless redemption appears in the last match, which starts tomorrow week at Centurion, next summer's series may well start with a new opener.

Hussain counterpunched by hooking Donald thrillingly for six but then, on 16, suffered a bizarre lbw decision from the Sri Lankan umpire B C Cooray when he edged a ball of full length from Klusener along the ground through the slips without a hint of pad. Under the circumstances his response was a model of restraint.

It was not a good day for Cooray, England benefiting when Hussain might have been lbw to Pollock and both Atherton and later Chris Adams given not out when they hit bat-pad catches to silly point.

Atherton indulged in a heated exchange with Daryll Cullinan and went on to top- score with 35, sticking it out until after lunch before he was caught at slip off Pollock's lifter. By then Michael Vaughan had slashed at Klusener to be caught behind.

Stewart was tied up in knots by the spin of Adams and eventually played all round a low full toss to be bowled leg stump.

Chris Adams had already embarked on a typical block-bash innings, taking hits to the body from Allan Donald but pummelling anything full or wide through the off. He and Andy Caddick added 39 for the sixth wicket, the highest stand of the innings, before Caddick drove Donald to square cover. Adams then dismissed Adams for 31, pretty much as he had Stewart, and he and Kallis then cleared up. Simple.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Gas escape
Sue Lakeman and her husband of Canterbury are the latest readers to have enjoyed a one-sided correspondence with the phantoms at British Gas. Last April her account was £355 in credit. Then came a letter informing her that some incorrect account details had been amended and a new bill, for somewhat more than she was used to, would be sent. This arrived in June, demanding payment of £626.88.

Lakeman rang to query this extravagant sum but no one seemed able to enlighten her. Then her husband wrote, pointing out that no meter readings were quoted on the paperwork, unlike the April bill which had quoted the correct number of units. The following month Lakeman wrote to ask why this letter had not been replied to. The result, four days later, was a disconnection notice. Once again Lakeman rang and was assured a hold would be put on the account while the queries were resolved.

Nothing more happened until September when a new bill for £681 arrived. Lakeman was advised to ignore it because her account was still on hold, pending an investigation. Only someone had forgotten to tell the British Gas billing department because two weeks later she was rung to be told she was in the process of being disconnected and no "hold" had ever been agreed. The couple are mystified as to how a £355 credit can turn into a £626 deficit in less than two months.

 According to British Gas, it's all Transco's fault for installing a new meter at the house and passing on incorrect details. "The replacement meter was imperial and the information on our database was metric," says a spokeswoman. But, she agrees: "It's unacceptable that it took so long to resolve the issue when the error was discovered in June."

So the Lakemans are to receive a £100 rebate on their next bill as a gesture of apology.

Flight fight
John Murray of Lancashire thought he had a good deal when he booked a KLM return flight to Rome for £78.10. Alas, by the time he returned to London Stansted, he was to find himself £470 poorer. His train to Rome airport arrived 20 minutes late. He hastily checked in and was told to go straight to the departure gate but, he says, at this stage he was not given back his flight coupon with the rest of the documents. When he reached the departure lounge he was told he could not board the plane without this document, so raced back to the check-in desk with his luggage to retrieve it.

Check-in staff claimed they had no idea where it was, so it was back to the gate where he was again refused entry and advised to book himself on to an Alitalia flight to London which was leaving shortly. In desperation he hared back to check-in and spent nearly £400 on a new ticket. By the time he reached the departure gate for the Alitalia flight an announcement was made on the tannoy, saying the KLM coupon had been found and advising him to return to the KLM gate. But after four different dashes across the airport with his bags, he was exhausted and Alitalia staff retrieved it on his behalf. "I should have taken the coupon with me in the first place," he admits, "but when I returned, with time to spare, they said it wasn't there when it was."

Murray received a letter from KLM saying the airline was unable to provide a full explanation, but admitting: "It does appear that in one way or another we have let you down and failed to provide the standard of service you would normally expect from a responsible scheduled airline." He was offered a free return ticket valid on any scheduled flights, minus the cost of airport tax. Murray, however, would prefer to get back the £400.

Consumer's efforts failed to move the airline which appears to have forgotten its admission of irresponsible service. "Once issued with a coupon it's the passenger's responsibility to produce it on demand," says a spokeswoman.

Rude mechanicals
Over the last year we have received a number of complaints from readers whose washing machines are insured by National Homecare Ltd but have had wait months for attention. The latest to experience problems are Eunice Anderson of Hertfordshire and Joy Peach of Whitby. After five months and three cancelled appointments Anderson is still being told Homecare is "waiting for parts" before her machine can be repaired. A desperate Peach went to an independent plumber after a month then felt she was being harrassed by Homecare to renew her contract with them three months before her old one expired.

 Consumer has had similar problems trying to contact the firm over several weeks. It turns out National Homecare went into liquidation in June. It was then bought by a new company now trading under the same name. "We're trying to put all the problems right but it's early days and we inherited a lot of difficulties," said a spokeswoman. "All our supply lines have to be put in order, but we will honour customers from the previous company."

Phone trials
As for 1st Line, the mobile phone service provider, complaints are still rolling in from readers dissatisfied with its sales techniques. It is by now a familiar story: cold-called householders are led to believe that they are talking to BT Cellnet (although 1st Line says this is unauthorised) bank account details are sought and direct debits mysteriously set up by 1st Line's billing arm, Cellular Operations, and phones are dispatched for a fortnight's free trial without a contact address should the recipient wish to return it. Hugh Cheap of Edinburgh, Zimeon Jones of Manchester and Tony Bailey of Brighton are the latest victims. SJ Hurst of Nuneaton tried in vain to persuade 1st Line to take back his phone after the trial proved unsatisfactory and eventually returned it to Cellular Operations by registered post. The company, however, denies having received it and is threatening Hurst with legal action unless he pays line rental charges.

C&W: Calls still queueing
Simon Marvin of Salford had a phone installed courtesy of Cable & Wireless.Two weeks later it was still not working. He has some tips for others who try to contact customer services: "Don't bother ringing the fault line - pretend you want to subscribe to adult movies and you might eventually get to talk to someone. Learn the distinction between customer facing operations and the technical people who actually install the phones. The former won't be able to tell you anything. The person you need is the operations manager."

Chris Banister of Stockport has been sampling C&W's new interactive digital television service which bills itself as "the most advanced digital TV on Earth".

"Pressing the interactive button produces a static picture of a yo-yo with the slogan 'TV has never been so much fun'," he reports. "This static image stays on screen for about half a minute before reverting back to TV. C&W presumably thinks watching paint dry is fun too."

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 0171-713 4731, send a fax on 0171-239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com
