fields.headline: Getting your name in lights
fields.standfirst: Why call an asteroid 1997 XF11 when you could call it Zappafrank? Duncan Steel explains
fields.trailText: There is indeed a Mr Spock out there in space. Asteroid 2309 Mr. Spock. It was called after a tabby cat. The feline itself was named for the Vulcan in Star Trek, on the grounds that he (the cat) was also "imperturbable, logical, intelligent and had pointed ears".
fields.body:
There is indeed a Mr Spock out there in space. Asteroid 2309 Mr. Spock. It was called after a tabby cat. The feline itself was named for the Vulcan in Star Trek, on the grounds that he (the cat) was also "imperturbable, logical, intelligent and had pointed ears".

Alongside such names as 1815 Beethoven, 2001 Einstein and 2985 Shakespeare a mere cat seems an unlikely addition. Since asteroid Spock got its name a couple of decades back, the International Astronomical Union - the IAU, the world-wide body which superintends such matters - has tightened up its rules, specifically discouraging the application of pets' names.

A committee of about a dozen astronomers vet all suggested names. If the discoverer declines to put forward an acceptable label then the naming rights may be taken away.

While some names are not allowed - like terms in bad taste, or people best-known for military or political exploits unless they've been dead for at least a century (Napoleon is all right, but not Margaret Thatcher) - the committee is not humourless.

Take 3142 Kilopi. Who was that? Well, think of the mathematical constant p which relates the circumference of a circle to its diameter, and multiply by a thousand (a kilo).

I was responsible for one little piece of mischief. In Bill Forsyth's film Local Hero one character, Felix Happer, was desperate to have a comet named for him. He'll just have to make do with asteroid 7345 Happer.

After an asteroid is discovered (the IAU insists they should be called minor planets) it will generally take a few years before its orbit about the sun is well-enough determined to deserve adding to the definitive list of asteroids. Then the discoverer can put forward a name.

Not their own name, though; any comet you find will get your surname with no argument. But for asteroids the done thing is to propose some other name. For one of my discoveries I suggested 9767 Midsomer Norton, the Somerset town where I was born.

The chairman of the asteroid naming committee is Brian Marsden, an Englishman who directs the Minor Planet Center at Harvard university. He is assisted by another Englishman, Gareth Williams. It was somewhat incongruous when three pommies joined together to name 2472 Bradman for the great Australian cricketer. It's only fair - think of the South African players Kepler Wessels and Herschelle Gibbs, each of whom have names derived from great astronomers.

And here's a little puzzle for the cricket buffs. One other asteroid is named after a prominent cricketer. Like Sir Donald Bradman, this man is also knighted, and played for South Australia. Who is he? (No, not Sir Richard Hadlee, although you would be correct to think of Trent Bridge.) So much for the names, what about the numbers? The sequence of minor planet names and numbers begins with 1 Ceres, discovered on January 1, 1801. Ceres is a behemoth, at about 600 miles across the largest of the asteroids. Mind you, that is still too small to see clearly in any telescope except Hubble, because it's so far away. The word "asteroid" means "star-like", because they look like stars through a telescope: mere pinpricks of light.

In the following decades dozens of asteroids were discovered, and given prosaic names derived from ancient mythologies. The Greek goddess of victory, Nike, had her name on an asteroid long before running shoes and shirts.

All was not altruistic, however. British astronomers were still smarting over the naming of the planet Uranus, discovered by Sir William Herschel in 1781. To flatter the king they had wanted to call it George's Star, but on the continent this name was rejected. Consequently, no sooner had the twelfth asteroid been discovered than it was named Victoria to less than universal acclaim.

Arguments over celestial names continue. A couple of years back we could see the number 10,000 approaching, and the suggestion was made that Pluto should be allotted to that number. Although this provoked a furore in the media - some people felt that Pluto was being downgraded from a major to a minor planet - the logic was plain. Pluto had been spotted in 1930, but no other objects were found beyond Neptune until, in 1992, another lump was found in these distant reaches of the solar system.

Since then a couple of hundred other rocky and icy bodies ranging up to 300 miles in size have been identified slowly circuiting in this frigid region. Given that Pluto is only about 1,400 miles across, one could question why it should be classed as a major planet, and the others as minor planets. Pluto is rather smaller than Mars or Mercury, or even our Moon. Where does one draw the line?

The solution seemed to be to add it to the list of minor planets in a special place, as number 10,000. But this provoked such public outrage that astronomers had to backtrack. In the end asteroid 10,000 was called Myriostos (myriad actually means numbering in the tens of thousands).

But what about 1997 XF11 or 1999 AN10? These are "preliminary designations". The first four numbers show the year of discovery.

The first letter shows the half-month the object was found. Letter A implies January 1-15 inclusive. The order is alphabetical, the letter I not being used, to avoid confusion with the number one. This means that December 16-31 has the letter Y. Why not also skip the letter O as it may be confused with zero? Because then Z would be used which could perhaps be mistaken for a number two.

The second letter indicates the ordering within the half-month. The first asteroid of the year is 1999 AA, the second is 1999 AB, and so on except that I again is not used, producing 25 possibilities.

When asteroid discoveries were few that was fine, but once the number found per fortnight exceeded 25 there was a problem. The fix was to employ numbers after the second letter (and to be strictly correct these are supposed to be subscripted).

This means that 1997 XF11 was the 281st asteroid spotted in the first half of December 1997. It became famous because for a short while we thought it might hit the Earth in 2028. We now are sure it won't. And soon 1997 XF11 will be given a permanent number and name. Perhaps Nearmiss would be appropriate.

There's a real Starr out there, and a Lennon, McCartney and Harrison too, not to mention 3834 Zappafrank and 4305 Clapton: for Eric, not the London suburb. There is no London in the sky, whereas Paris, Roma and Moskva have been up there for aeons. Check them all out on http://cfa-www.harvard. edu/iau/lists/MPNames.html

Some readers may say they've bought star names for friends and family, so what's all the fuss about asteroid names? Sorry, trying to slap your name on a star has no greater effect than saying you've re-named the street or village for yourself. The post office and map makers will pay no attention.

Neither does the IAU recognise names for stars. Save your money. Anyone can print up a gilt certificate saying a star is named for you. It simply has no effect.

And the answer to the cricket question? 6581 Sobers. Even Adelaide residents tend to forget Sir Garfield played for their state for a while.

fields.headline: Nazi suspect leaves Britain
fields.trailText:
Konrad Kalejs, a suspected Nazi war criminal and one of Britain's most
unwelcome visitors, today left the country voluntarily before he
could be deported.
fields.body:
Konrad Kalejs, a suspected Nazi war criminal and one of Britain's most unwelcome visitors, today left the country voluntarily before he could be deported.

The 86-year-old has left on a flight to Singapore, ultimately heading for Australia where he is a citizen. Despite widespread suspicion that he was involved in the murder of Jews at a concentration camp in Latvia, Mr Kalejs has managed to remain at large with police forces in Britain and Australia claiming they lack the evidence to justify an arrest.

Mr Kalejs's presence in England provoked a fierce outcry. Home secretary Jack Straw was pressed to answer how a man with such a past was allowed to enter the country. Once his identity emerged, the home office came under pressure to detain Mr Kalejs until a full investigation could be carried out. But Mr Straw said he was powerless under the law to keep Mr Kalejs in the country.

Mr Kalejs, who has been staying in an old people's home in Leicestershire, is suspected of being involved in the slaughter of Jews in Nazi-occupied Latvia during the second world war. The Simon Wiesenthal Centre in Jerusalem, the world's leading Nazi hunting organisation, claims Mr Kalejs was a member of a Nazi-run Latvian death squad responsible for killing 30,000 people.

The centre has been particularly critical of Mr Straw's decision not to hold Mr Kalejs pending a full inquiry. Scotland Yard said its inquiry failed to yield sufficient evidence for a prosecution. But when British police interviewed Mr Kalejs, they did not ask him about his alleged involvement in mass murder.

"I think it is outrageous. It is a classic example of a police force that has no desire to bring a mass murderer to trial," said Efraim Zuroff of the Simon Wiesenthal Centre,

Scotland Yard also relied on Australian evidence, which was described as "by far the most intensive and in-depth". But Robert Greenwood, Australia's former war crimes prosecutor, disputed that claim.

"What we did was to monitor the investigations and the evidence gathered by the Americans and the Canadians during the latter part of the 1980s and into the 1990s when Canada and the U.S. were playing pass the parcel with Mr Kalejs," he said.

Mr Greenwood, whose war crimes investigations unit was disbanded in 1993, said that it was "quite false to say that a responsible body (in Australia) ever investigated the matter as a priority".

Lord Janner, a former secretary of the parliamentary war crimes group, said that if Mr Kalejs went to Australia, Britain would press officials in Canberra to carry out an investigation. Mr Kalejs, an Australian citizen since 1957, denies the allegations against him. He was deported to Australia from the United States in 1994 and from Canada in 1997 because of his alleged war crimes.

Latvia's ambassador to Britain, Normans Penke, said yesterday that Mr Kalejs would be extradited from Australia if there is enough evidence to prosecute him. Mr Penke said Latvia's general prosecutor's office opened criminal proceedings against Kalejs last week "on the basis of evidence in newspaper articles" in Britain.

fields.headline: Alfred Hitchcock: Vertigo
fields.trailText: It is the strangest, most perverse movie [Hitchcock] ever created. It was never really popular except with the critics. But for once one can confidently say they were right
fields.body:
It doesn't seem so very long ago that Alfred Hitchcock was considered not much more than a superior craftsman specialising in slightly glib movies the public liked. A superior craftsman, perhaps, but scarcely a real artist.

Now, of course, we see things very differently. Hitch is dubbed a master and a round dozen of his films are regarded as classics. One of them, made in the late 50s, is Vertigo, the strangest, most perverse movie he ever created. It was never really popular except with the critics. But for once one can confidently say they were right.

The story has James Stewart as Scotty, a private eye cursed with a pathological fear of heights since being held responsible for the fatal fall of a fellow officer in the days when he was in the police. Hired to protect a threatened woman (Kim Novak), his "weakness", as the coroner puts it, stops him saving her from a suicidal leap. We know he was also in love with her.

When he comes out of the institution in which he is undergoing treatment, he meets another woman who reminds him of his dead love (actually it is the same one, since her death was fabricated as cover for a murder). Obsessively he tries to make the woman resemble her previous incarnation. "Couldn't you like me, just me, the way I am?" she says after an uncomfortable shopping expedition.

What he wants seems to be what Hitch himself always wanted - a blonde ice goddess. And the film seems to fit perfectly into its director's own view of sexuality, which seldom reaches beyond an unrequited obsession that virtually deranges those in thrall to it. But the film isn't just about that. Scotty and his woman are caught up in more than their slightly lunatic affair. The plot twists and turns around the original murder with almost Gothic abandon until its famous, and superbly shot and edited, climax in the belltower.

You could call Rear Window, Vertigo and Psycho an unequalled trilogy about voyeurism or, if you want to be more orthodox, a set of films forcing ordinary audiences to admit their unordinary fears. Hitchcock's great films, as the critic David Thomson says, are only partly his. They also belong to the minds of those who interpret them.

However you look at them, they do at least prove that Hitch was a director whose art consisted of considerably more than a vast knowledge of the tricks of his trade and a consuming ambition to play with the susceptibilities of his audiences. There is a coldness alongside his calculations, it is true. But the essential greatness remains. You can see it as well as anywhere in Vertigo, made all the more noteworthy by Bernard Herrmann's ghost-ridden score, Robert Burks's sharp-etched cinematography and, above all, the scaled-down eloquence of James Stewart's central performance.

Vertigo is a great film. But for me it couldn't stand comfortably beside something like Renoir's Rules of the Game. Conjurors are not comfortable as philosophers.

 The best of Hitchcock on the web

fields.headline: Hurrah! Nobody hurt their foot!
fields.standfirst: Safety killjoys and the millennium mini-roundabout | Offensive Teddy's 'satirical mime'
fields.trailText: Safety killjoys and the millennium mini-roundabout
fields.body:
I agree with all the letters written this week complaining about people complaining - a new landmark in negativity, I think - about the millennium celebrations. I particularly would like to complain about the man who complained about seeing "elegant women urinating in shop doorways". For me Hogmanay's just not Hogmanay unless I've seen some Penelope Keith lookalike squatting over a steam stream in the porch of DKNY.

Let me nail my colours to the mast: I was at the big party in Greenwich, and I had a fantastic time. My girlfriend's big party in her house off Greenwich High Road, that is. I was, of course, offered a ticket to the Dome - not by the New Millenium Experience (didn't they have a big hit in 1967?) but by a desperate-looking man on the street outside Stratford Tube. "Fifteen quid and I'll buy any spare," I believe were his words, even before I had a chance to tell him how much I'd always liked Roland Rat.

One group of people, however, should be immensely pleased with the overwhelming criticism aimed at the celebrations at the Dome: Greenwich Council. Because, as long as more and more punters come forward with horrific tales of waiting in the rain and being forced to watch Mick Hucknall, no one is going to point out the absurdity of what was happening in the rest of the borough, where, basically, a large section of SE10 had been transformed into a pre-Gorbachev police state.

Greenwich village itself was cordoned off on all sides with police barriers, access through which was granted only by the flashing of a special non-removable wristband. These wristbands were like gold dust: there was talk of them, in the month before, fetching up to £500 on the black market. Our own supply at the party was only available because my girlfriend's friend had cried down the phone to a member of the council. You might imagine, therefore, that something incredible was happening between the police barriers, that these wristbands were effectively tickets to a street party in central Nirvana.

But, in truth, the phrase "bugger-all" struggles to cover what was going on in Greenwich that night. There was a concert, the British Gas Millennium Party, with a bill that would send any dad's heart racing, but the wristbands gave you no entry to that, and large boards had been set up to make sure that not a laser beam of it reached the eyes of the non-paying ordinary resident. I walked through the cordoned-off area four times, my eyes desperately searching for the extraordinary event that would justify such huge policing costs, only to be met by the similarly searching eyes of people coming the other way. So we stayed in.

But at midnight, we ventured out again - surely something would be happening at midnight, on December 31 1999, on the line of the meridian? Like many others, we decided to walk up the hill in Greenwich Park, to the Observatory, the place where new time itself was beginning - only to discover that, of course, Greenwich Council had closed the park. They had closed the park and surrounded its fences with a ring of police three deep. We saw the 21st century in standing on a mini-roundabout on neighbouring Maze Hill Road.

Obviously, Greenwich Council had closed the park. Because the most important criteria for the authorities in this country, when faced with the possibility of people enjoying themselves, is: let there not be trouble. Let there not be disruption. Let there not be too much litter. What did Chris Smith say when announcing that, elsewhere too, people were not going to be allowed anywhere near a symbol of the event - the Millennium Wheel? "Better safe than sorry."

Better safe than sorry is the byword of the British bureaucrat. Trouble is: for celebrations to be any good, they have to include a certain degree of risk. Who would ever describe a great party they'd been to as "safe"? No one, except Ali G, and he'd mean something quite different.

It's a British disease. I was in Cornwall for the eclipse, the other great cosmic event of this year, and a similar attitude prevailed. Not "what can we do to really enhance this experience, to make everyone fully feel that they have indeed touched the divine?" but "what can we do to warn people about traffic congestion?"

So much, in fact, was the main emphasis on warning, that almost no one bothered to make the trip to Cornwall at all: and that, for the people in charge, was deemed a success. Just as I'm sure Greenwich Council will deem what it laughably called its Millennium Night Celebrations a success, because nobody died or hurt their foot and noise pollution was kept to respectable levels, considering.

Why, some policemen even joined in with Auld Lang Syne! Keeping an eye that things didn't get out of hand on the mini-roundabout, of course.

Is Teddy paying tribute to the great Lars Von Trier?
Talking of the good people who write into this paper - good people whose zeal to police the politically incorrect (judging from the enormous sack of righteous anger that my column about race generated the other week) remains undiminished - could I draw their attention to the front cover of the Daily Mirror yesterday? A front cover on which Teddy Sheringham, of Manchester United and England, is sticking his tongue into his lower lip, screwing his face up and flapping his wrists about.

Last time I saw this posture it was at primary school, and the nine-year-old doing it was saying: "Urrrrrrggghh, my name is David Baddiel." Surely Sheringham cannot be doing what I believe is called - and here, again, I do apologise to Guardian readers, but evils such as these have to be named to be flushed out - a "spaz" impression.

Surely he cannot be saying, in what I'm afraid is known as a "mongy" voice: "Urrrrgh, my name's David Beckham." And what is the Daily Mirror thinking about printing such an image?

The Mirror Group and Manchester United will claim many things in Sheringham's defence. They may claim he was only performing a tribute to the great Dogme '95 film-maker Lars Von Trier, in whose film The Idiots such "spazzing" was granted artistic status; or, perhaps, that he was entertaining Andy Cole, who is known to dislike Glenn Hoddle, with a satirical mime on the events leading up to the previous England manager's final resignation. Let none of this deflect us. It's time to start using the word "offensive".

Is this really what Manchester United pulled out of the FA Cup for?

 Catherine Bennett returns next week

Greenwich village itself was cordoned off on all sides with police barriers, access through which was granted only by the flashing of a special non-removable wristband. These wristbands were like gold dust: there was talk of them, in the month before, fetching up to £500 on the black market. Our own supply at the party was only available because my girlfriend's friend had cried down the phone to a member of the council. You might imagine, therefore, that something incredible was happening between the police barriers, that these wristbands were effectively tickets to a street party in central Nirvana. But, in truth, the phrase "bugger-all" struggles to cover what was going on in Greenwich that night. There was a concert, the British Gas Millennium Party, with a bill that would send any dad's heart racing, but the wristbands gave you no entry to that, and large boards had been set up to make sure that not a laser beam of it reached the eyes of the non-paying ordinary resident. I walked through the cordoned-off area four times, my eyes desperately searching for the extraordinary event that would justify such huge policing costs, only to be met by the similarly searching eyes of people coming the other way. So we stayed in. But at midnight, we ventured out again - surely something would be happening at midnight, on December 31 1999, on the line of the meridian? Like many others, we decided to walk up the hill in Greenwich Park, to the Observatory, the place where new time itself was beginning - only to discover that, of course, Greenwich Council had closed the park. They had closed the park and surrounded its fences with a ring of police three deep. We saw the 21st century in standing on a mini-roundabout on neighbouring Maze Hill Road. Obviously, Greenwich Council had closed the park. Because the most important criteria for the authorities in this country, when faced with the possibility of people enjoying themselves, is: let there not be trouble. Let there not be disruption. Let there not be too much litter. What did Chris Smith say when announcing that, elsewhere too, people were not going to be allowed anywhere near a symbol of the event - the Millennium Wheel? "Better safe than sorry." Better safe than sorry is the byword of the British bureaucrat. Trouble is: for celebrations to be any good, they have to include a certain degree of risk. Who would ever describe a great party they'd been to as "safe"? No one, except Ali G, and he'd mean something quite different. It's a British disease. I was in Cornwall for the eclipse, the other great cosmic event of this year, and a similar attitude prevailed. Not "what can we do to really enhance this experience, to make everyone fully feel that they have indeed touched the divine?" but "what can we do to warn people about traffic congestion?" So much, in fact, was the main emphasis on warning, that almost no one bothered to make the trip to Cornwall at all: and that, for the people in charge, was deemed a success. Just as I'm sure Greenwich Council will deem what it laughably called its Millennium Night Celebrations a success, because nobody died or hurt their foot and noise pollution was kept to respectable levels, considering. Why, some policemen even joined in with Auld Lang Syne! Keeping an eye that things didn't get out of hand on the mini-roundabout, of course. Is Teddy paying tribute to the great Lars Von Trier? Talking of the good people who write into this paper - good people whose zeal to police the politically incorrect (judging from the enormous sack of righteous anger that my column about race generated the other week) remains undiminished - could I draw their attention to the front cover of the Daily Mirror yesterday? A front cover on which Teddy Sheringham, of Manchester United and England, is sticking his tongue into his lower lip, screwing his face up and flapping his wrists about. Last time I saw this posture it was at primary school, and the nine-year-old doing it was saying: "Urrrrrrggghh, my name is David Baddiel." Surely Sheringham cannot be doing what I believe is called - and here, again, I do apologise to Guardian readers, but evils such as these have to be named to be flushed out - a "spaz" impression. Surely he cannot be saying, in what I'm afraid is known as a "mongy" voice: "Urrrrgh, my name's David Beckham." And what is the Daily Mirror thinking about printing such an image? The Mirror Group and Manchester United will claim many things in Sheringham's defence. They may claim he was only performing a tribute to the great Dogme '95 film-maker Lars Von Trier, in whose film The Idiots such "spazzing" was granted artistic status; or, perhaps, that he was entertaining Andy Cole, who is known to dislike Glenn Hoddle, with a satirical mime on the events leading up to the previous England manager's final resignation. Let none of this deflect us. It's time to start using the word "offensive". Is this really what Manchester United pulled out of the FA Cup for?  Catherine Bennett returns next week

webTitle: Back to your prunes, Lord MacLaurin

fields.headline: Back to your prunes, Lord MacLaurin
fields.trailText: The worst thing about yesterday's England freefall was not the abrupt end, nor even Nasser Hussain's lbw decision, but Lord MacLaurin's Blimpish performance in front of the camera. "Many people said we would lose 5-0," he crowed, as if a probable scoreline of 3-0 was much of an improvement. "And Chris Silverwood bowled superbly yesterday."
fields.body:
The worst thing about yesterday's England freefall was not the abrupt end, nor even Nasser Hussain's lbw decision, but Lord MacLaurin's Blimpish performance in front of the camera. "Many people said we would lose 5-0," he crowed, as if a probable scoreline of 3-0 was much of an improvement. "And Chris Silverwood bowled superbly yesterday."

Talk about ignoring the facts. This sort of bluster wouldn't have got MacLaurin very far as chairman of Tesco: "Well, we may be miles behind Sainsbury's, Asda and Waitrose in the Retail World Championship, but our Moroccan prunes are jolly nice."

And let's not forget why everyone started predicting a whitewash. The selectors picked a transparently flimsy batting line-up, ditching a man who had made almost 400 runs on both of England's previous two winter tours, largely because of pressure from MacLaurin. The public wants change, he said, and Mark Ramprakash felt the effects.

The issue was highlighted in a round-robin discussion in last week's Sunday Telegraph, when Graeme Pollock asked Hussain and Atherton: "Why turn round and occupy the crease when there were a lot of balls you could have scored off?" Hussain replied: "I'd say the first thing in the back of your mind is the length of your tail." And Atherton chimed in: "What Nasser won't say as captain is that we've only got three experienced batsmen in our team." I know that we at Wisden spend a lot of time singing the praises of Ramprakash, but this is a surely a cut-and-dried case. It's not just that Ramps would have made twice as many runs as the hapless Adams, guaranteed; he also has a proven record at occupying the crease, which would have taken some pressure off the big guns at the top of the order.

MacLaurin has now been the ECB's chairman for three years, and has only succeeded in lowering the standard of our Test and county cricket. Two divisions have come in, agreed, but without reducing the workload that turns promising players into drudges. If it hadn't been for the World Cup, 1999 would have been the least satisfactory cricketing summer in living memory, thanks largely to the ECB's ineffectuality: they failed to find England a coach, to police county pitches properly, or to do anything sensible with the glut of one-day competitions. It's time MacLaurin went back to his prunes.

webTitle: Heaney pips his late friend to award

fields.headline: Heaney pips his late friend to award
fields.trailText: Late Poet Laureate Ted Hughes was denied the chance of a third successive Whitbread Book Of The Year title today by his friend Seamus Heaney.
fields.body:
Late Poet Laureate Ted Hughes was denied the chance of a third successive Whitbread Book Of The Year title today by his friend Seamus Heaney.

Nobel prize winner Heaney's translation of the epic Beowulf has been named the winner of this year's Whitbread Poetry Award, beating Hughes's Alcestis.

The accolade now puts Heaney in the shortlist for the overall title alongside three other individual category winners announced today - Rose Tremain, Tim Lott and David Cairns.

Heaney's reworking of the Anglo-Saxon classic was dedicated to Hughes, who died in 1998. The pair had worked together in the past to co-edit two anthologies.

They have dominated the previous three Book Of The Year titles. Hughes won in 1999 with Birthday Letters and 1998 with Tales From Ovid, while Heaney won the year before that with The Spirit Level.

Tremain, whose absence from the Booker Prize shortlist last year raised eyebrows, took the Whitbread Novel Award for her book Music And Silence, beating 104 other entries.

The First Novel Award went to Lott's White City Blue - a look at end-of-the-Millennium laddishness.

Cairns' book Berlioz Volume II: Servitude And Greatness, his work on the great 19th-century composer, took the Biography Award.

There will be a fifth entrant for the overall title when the winner of the Whitbread Children's Book Of The Year prize is awarded later this month.

Each of today's successful authors wins £2,000, with the chance of a further £21,000 for the eventual winner of the main prize.

The Book Of The Year winner will be chosen by a panel of nine judges - including model Jerry Hall and chaired by Dr Eric Anderson - and announced on January 25 at a dinner in Whitbread's London headquarters.

The children's prize will be awarded the same night.

The Whitbread awards are now in their 29th year, although the Book Of The Year category was not introduced until 1985.

Tremain could chalk up a family first if she takes the Book Of The Year title later this month; her partner, the biographer Richard Holmes, won the 1986 Whitbread Book Of The Year.

The winners were as follows:

Whitbread Poetry Award
Beowulf, by Seamus Heaney
(Faber & Faber, £14.99)

Heaney's reworking of the Anglo-Saxon poem tells of the eponymous mighty warrior who comes to the aid of a Danish king, Hrothgar. He defeats two monsters to rule a kingdom before finally facing a dragon which terrorises the country.
Heaney, who lives in Dublin, went to Queen's University, Belfast, where as an undergraduate he studied Beowulf. His first book, Death of a Naturalist, appeared in 1966, and he has since published poetry, criticism and translations. He was first commissioned to translate Beowulf in the mid-80s but put the project on hold. Heaney was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1995.

The Whitbread judges said: "In a year notable for many strong works, including three brilliant translations, Heaney's recovery of Beowulf for a contemporary readership stands out. He brings an extraordinary sensitivity and breadth of language to this Anglo-Saxon warrior epic. In a translation that brilliantly combines the faithful with the original, Seamus Heaney has reclaimed the first classic of the English language for a contemporary readership."

Whitbread Novel Award
Music and Silence, by Rose Tremain
(Chatto & Windus, £16.99)

Set in 1629, it revolves around Englishman Peter Claire, who arrives at the palace of the Danish King Christian IV to join his court orchestra, and the complicated friendships and love affairs which develop. The king seeks harmony and order through the music created by his orchestra whilst Kirsten, his adulterous wife, detests music and craves silence.

Music and Silence is the eighth novel by Rose Tremain, who lives in Norwich, Norfolk. A best-selling author in Britain, America and France, her work has been translated into 14 languages.

Tremain's Booker Prize-nominated Restoration was made into a film starring Hugh Grant, Meg Ryan and Sir Ian McKellen. The Whitbread judges said: "All the books had strengths but this stood above the others. She writes about both men and women with huge imaginative sympathy - all the characters are lit from the inside."

Whitbread First Novel Award
White City Blue, by Tim Lott
(Viking, £9.99)

A tragi-comic novel about male friendships, narrated by Frank, an estate agent in Shepherd's Bush. In a series of flashbacks he describes how his group of mates became friends and how they developed through their adult lives with a shared passion for QPR football club and a series of mad escapades.

Tim Lott, who lives in Notting Hill, west London, has been a television producer, editor of the listings magazine, City Limits, and a rock journalist.

In 1996 he wrote the award-winning memoir, The Scent of Dried Roses, an exploration of his own depression and his mother's suicide.

He is currently working on the screenplay of White City Blue and writing his second novel. The Whitbread judges said: "We all passionately agreed on the winner. Heartbreaking about the reality of growing up, and a novel that we all felt that we wanted to carry on reading.

"An intense and revealing look at male friendships. Technically assured and funny."

Whitbread Biography Award
Berlioz, Volume II: Servitude And Greatness, by David Cairns
(Allen Lane The Penguin Press, £25)

Hector Berlioz was one of the great composers of the nineteenth century and one of the most significant conductors of his day. A friend of Liszt and Wagner, he was feted in Germany and Russia but rejected by his native Paris and struggled for money most of his life, relying on journalism to make a living. His struggles for artistic recognition and financial security form two of the book's themes.

David Cairns, who lives in Putney, south London, has worked as music critic at The Sunday Times and arts editor at the Spectator. He has also had an academic career at the Getty Centre in Santa Monica; Merton College, Oxford; and the University of California, where he is a visiting professor.

The Whitbread judges said: "The judges had a long and agonised debate between Hilary Spurling's Matisse and David Cairn's Berlioz. Both captured the eras in which their subjects lived and worked, as well as elegantly relating the technicalities of their respective crafts.

"David Cairns' Berlioz wins this year's Whitbread Biography Award for his masterly evocation of the inner man as well the outer world in which he lived and worked.

"The judges felt that this biography is a work of art in itself which will still be enjoyed and admired in centuries to come."

webTitle: Star turns paying off for internet start-ups

fields.headline: Star turns paying off for internet start-ups
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Whoopi Goldberg, Cindy Crawford, Jonathan Ross and the Antiques Roadshow's Hugh Scully have all done it. Geri Halliwell is mulling it over. David Beckham, Michael Owen and Alan Shearer are about to sign up.
fields.body:
Whoopi Goldberg, Cindy Crawford, Jonathan Ross and the Antiques Roadshow's Hugh Scully have all done it. Geri Halliwell is mulling it over. David Beckham, Michael Owen and Alan Shearer are about to sign up.

The eclectic mix of film stars, models, television presenters and footballers are, or are about to, act as the public faces of fledgling internet companies.

At a time when the internet is transforming business practices, the value of some things, such as the cachet of celebrity, remains resolutely the same. Following the stellar performance of many internet shares the stars are increasingly looking for a piece of the action.

New start-ups looking to build brands and credibility as quick as possible are fighting to sign up celebrities to publicise their services. Unlike with traditional endorsement contracts the deals are not straight cash arrangements. The stars, having seen the massive gains made by the shares in the more successful dot.coms are demanding equity and, in some cases, an input on business strategy. For start-ups starved of cash equity is a great way of paying the bills.

Inevitably in a land where both dot.coms and celebrity are valued more highly than anywhere else, the US has led the trend. Ms Goldberg has a two-year contract to act as a creative-marketing adviser and spokeswoman for flooz.com, an online gift currency provider. She says she likes the ownership aspect of her contract. "If I'm going to bust my butt out there, I want a piece of it," she told reporters.

Ms Crawford joined the board of eStyle, a Los-Angeles based online womens retailer, when it wanted to launch a babies site aimed at mothers and mothers to be. She was pregnant at the time and now hosts on-line chats recommending products for consumers with young children based on her personal experience with her new baby.

William Shatner, who played Captain Kirk in Star Trek, is said to be sitting on a paper fortune of millions after agreeing to become celebrity spokesman for priceline.com in 1998. Drag queen Ru Paul has stock options in WebEx, a California based interactive web meeting service.

Publicist Matthew Freud, who is the founder of on-line toy shop Toyzone.com and employs Jonathan Ross as the company's public face, says a carefully chosen celebrity can give an internet brand instant recognition. "It is a very quick way of establishing a brand. We chose our celebrity very carefully. Jonathan is like what Toyzone set out to be. Enthusiastic, irreverent, a bit child like but in an adult way.

"Jonathan has a standard endorsement deal but rather than there being a dollar sign at the end of his contract there is an equity figure. He is a participant in the business rather than just a hired hand.

"He's a passionate toy collector with a virtually definitive comic library and one of the biggest collections of Japanese robots in the world. He advises us on what sort of toys people want and has strong opinions on what the next craze will be."

On-line auctioneer QXL.com has paid Mr Scully around £3m to give up his position on the BBC's Antique's Roadshow and value customer's goods by email. QXL hopes Mr Scully will attract "silver surfers" to the site.

Mr Freud admits that star endorsements are no guarantee to business success. "Planet Hollywood went from zero to hero instantly because of celebrity equity but there was no sustainability behind the concept," he said.

The stars themselves are aware that only a few internet start-ups are likely to survive in the long-run and that they have to be selective about which one they pin their colours to. At the moment Mr Ross appears to have picked a winner. He has 1% of the equity in Toyzone, which advisers Lehman Brothers may float later in the year for up to £250m.

However, Ms Halliwell, the former Spice Girl, turned down the chance to front one of the recently launched women's portals because she did not think it was the best vehicle for her talents. She is considering other offers.

Footballers David Beckham, Michael Owen and Alan Shearer have been inundated by endorsement offers from sports driven start-ups. Their agency, the UK sports division of US entertainment group Sfx Entertainment, says that after sifting through dozens of offers the trio are on the verge of signing deals that should net them several million dollars over the next two to three years.

"Picking the company to go with is like trying to pick which horse to back in the Grand National," said managing director Jon Holmes. "Except in this case there are 250 runners with no form and no-one is quite sure whether this is a race over hurdles or the flat."

Mr Holmes says that to protect the interests of his clients he has negotiated deals that combine equity and cash. Either way his partners win.

A department of trade and industry spokeswoman said no decision had been taken on whether to increase the minimum wage or keep it at the present rate. The youth rate, for 18-21-year-olds, will rise from £3 to £3.20 in June under a previous arrangement.

The Times reported today that the next increase for adults is likely to come in spring 2001 - not this April, the first anniversary of its introduction.

Bill Morris, general secretary of the Transport and General Workers' Union, said: "Any suggestion that it shouldn't be up-rated on its anniversary would be totally unacceptable and an injustice to the people on the minimum wage.

"If we are now to abandon the up-rating principle it seems to me that we'll be abandoning the fight for a fair workplace and against poverty," he told the Radio 4 Today programme.

When it was introduced last year, low paid workers and unions welcomed Britain's first national minimum wage, which gave two million people a pay rise. However, some union officials would like to see the rate rise to £5 an hour, with younger workers paid the same rate.

In September 1999 the Confederation of British Industry said the minimum wage had not made a significant impact on the economy because of the "prudent level" at which it had been set. Despite warnings that the measure would lead to job losses, there has been little evidence of sackings to help fund the minimum wage.

Industry managers and workers last month submitted evidence to the Low Pay Commission, which has reported to ministers on the effects of the minimum wage and the arguments for and against an increase.

Commenting on the reported freeze in the minimum wage, Dave Prentis, deputy general secretary of Unison, Britain's biggest union, said today: "If these reports are true it is a disgraceful way to start the new millennium. The government talks about a crusade against child poverty - there is one sure way to help rid the country of poverty, and that is by having a decent living wage."

Mr Prentis said that failing to increase the minimum wage in April would "waste" all the effort involved in setting up the statutory rates.

Unison urged the government to deny the reports and said it would step up its campaign for a "decent living wage".

webTitle: Tunnel chiefs unveil road link to France

fields.headline: Tunnel chiefs unveil road link to France
fields.standfirst:
£2.7bn project may be running within 25 years
More about transport
fields.trailText: A motorway beneath the sea to link Britain and France could be built in the next 25 years under proposals unveiled yesterday for a second channel tunnel.
fields.body:
A motorway beneath the sea to link Britain and France could be built in the next 25 years under proposals unveiled yesterday for a second channel tunnel.

The ambitious £2.7bn project would involve the construction of the longest tunnel of its kind in the world, containing two 46km-long carriageways, one on top of the other, which would allow motorists to complete the journey in about 30 minutes.

The feasibility study submitted to the department of transport by Eurotunnel also outlines the potential for a second rail link which would be used by Eurostar and international freight trains, leaving the existing tunnel to be used by freight and car shuttle services.

The proposals, especially the road link, are certain to be highly controversial and will reignite concerns about passenger safety and the environmental impact of both car use and large-scale undersea construction.

But Eurotunnel yesterday emphasised that the plans were "illustrative only at this stage" as neither project would become a reality until demand for the existing tunnel reached full capacity - something that is not forecast to happen until 2025.

Patrick Ponsolle, the executive chairman, said: "The option of adding a second fixed link is a long term issue. Eurotunnel would only embark on such a venture if it would enhance the profitability of the company and was in the interest of its shareholders."

The study was carried out only because the company was obliged under the terms of its original tunnel concession to submit proposals for a road link to the government by the end of 1999.

In 2010 the British and French governments must decide whether to go ahead with one of the options. If plans for a second tunnel are given the green light, Eurotunnel will have first refusal on building and running it.

As with the original tunnel proposals, the study, carried out by British and French consultants, rejects the options of a bridge or a submerged structure because of technical difficulties.

Instead, the link would be contained within a single bore tunnel which would probably following the same line as the existing one, although the start and end points have yet to be identified.

The road option would involve two dual-lane carriageways with a hard shoulder and would be closed to lorries and coaches to reduce the risk of accidents and fires.

It would also include such features as "information to customers, knowledge that help is at hand, a comfortably dimensioned carriageway, good visibility especially at curves and high quality lighting, tunnel marking and ventilation."

The study concludes: "The sense that the driver is being 'shepherded' through the tunnel helps to allay fatigue and drowsiness, improves concentration and relieves claustrophobia."

Approving this option would leave the government open to criticism that it was encouraging car use, but Eurotunnel said it would take passengers off the existing shuttles and create space for up to 51m tonnes of freight a year, 13 times the expected amount for this year. The rail option would allow up to 73m tonnes of freight to be transported - 20 times the expected level for 2000.

fields.headline: Getting online
fields.standfirst: The digital revolution won't even pause for breath in 2000. Get ready for another year of rapid change - in the devices we use to surf, in the way we get connected and in what we do when we're online. Fledgling e-retailers and music industry giants had better brace themselves for a tough 12 months
fields.trailText: Neil McIntosh says that the introduction of flat-rate pricing will mean that we will spend more and more time online
fields.body:
1999 was the year of reluctant promises from BT, Britain's telecoms monopoly. Pressure groups like the Campaign for Unmetered Telecommunications, as well as internet users, had been casting envious eyes overseas where internet access was not only priced at a flat, monthly rate (rather than by the minute) but was also super fast thanks to DSL (Digital Subscriber Line) technology. Why did Britain have neither?

The answer came in December, when BT's chairman, Sir Iain Vallance, said he thought the internet was still not "fit for purpose" and that BT needed to hold back "over-exuberant children" - BT's customers. The company, many concluded, was either not "getting" the internet, or was playing dumb to protect revenues. Still, we over-exuberant children will - eventually - get what we want.

Its arm twisted by telecoms regulator Oftel, BT has been forced to act. By March it should be offering ADSL (Asymetric Digital Subscriber Line) to six million households and businesses in the UK. These lines can deliver digital content at least 10 times the speeds of today's fastest conventional modems, and will be "always on" - meaning you won't have to wait to dial up to the internet. ADSL is more than just fast internet access - it opens up the doors to new interactive entertainment like on demand television and sophisticated online gaming.

We might even see BT signing up internet service providers to offer the new services. That's because its grip on the "local loop" - the telephone wire from the exchange - will be loosened from the middle of next year, allowing other operators to offer their services direct to users.

For those of us who don't live in one of the big cities in the first round of the ADSL rollout, there's still something to look forward to - flat rate internet telephone calls. From April, net addicts will be able to choose from several packages which will give unlimited dial-up access at certain times for a flat monthly fee.

The fee varies depending on when you go online: unlimited weekend access will be £6.99 a month, while anytime all week will be £34.99 a month. Critics say the prices are still high.

But the most exciting side-effect of flat-rate pricing is that our behaviour will change. Freed from the worry of a meter counting our every minute online, we'll be happy to search for more, read more online content, browse web shops at our leisure, send even more emails and pit our wits against each other in online gaming arenas.

fields.headline: Maradona tests positive for cocaine
fields.trailText: Diego Maradona is set to leave an intensive care unit in Uruguay today after being treated for a heart complaint. But contrary to earlier reports, it appears the cause of his illness was an overdose of cocaine, and the former Argentinian international can expect to be interviewed by police on his release.
fields.body:
Diego Maradona is set to leave an intensive care unit in Uruguay today after being treated for a heart complaint. But contrary to earlier reports, it appears the cause of his illness was an overdose of cocaine, and the former Argentinian international can expect to be interviewed by police on his release.

A first analysis of a urine sample provided by Maradona upon his entry into the private Cantegril hospital revealed traces of cocaine which police claimed had been taken in an excessive amount, leading to an overdose. And police have already launched a series of searches and interviews as they expand their investigation.

Maradona, initially admitted for hypertension and irregular heartbeat problems, will be discharged onto a normal ward later on Thursday, according to doctors. "He is feeling better and will leave [intensive care] in the next few hours," said doctor Frank Torres.

Maldonado district police chief Maximo Costa Rocha earlier told a press conference that the drug had been detected in the first sample. He said: "This positive sample is due to an excessive consumption of cocaine. We will interview him when the medical authorities think it is convenient and when it suits everyone."

However, assuming the test findings are confirmed, it is thought that police are concerned with discovering where Maradona obtained the drugs rather than punishing the player for personal use.

fields.headline: Anelka seals Real deal
fields.standfirst: Anelka 22, Raul 62, Savio 70 pen - Al-Husseini 45 pen
fields.trailText: Nicolas Anelka finally opened his goal account for Real Madrid in bizarre fashion as the Spanish side overwhelmed Saudi Arabian outfit Al Nassr in Sao Paulo last night.
fields.body:
Nicolas Anelka finally opened his goal account for Real Madrid in bizarre fashion as the Spanish side overwhelmed Saudi Arabian outfit Al Nassr in Sao Paulo last night.

The £23million summer capture from Arsenal recorded the first-ever goal in the World Club Championships with a freak block that looped in from 20 yards to put the Spanish giants ahead.

Anelka, who had not previously scored for the seven-times European Cup winners in 16 games, sealed the game by winning a 69th minute penalty, converted by Brazilian midfielder Savio.

Al Nassr, who qualified for the FIFA tournament by winning the Asian Super Cup in 1998, had created a shock by equalising in first-half injury time only for another bizarre incident - an own goal from goalkeeper Mohammed Babkr - to allow Real to regain the lead.

After a quiet opening, 20-year-old Anelka chased a seemingly harmless through ball from Guti. The French international striker blocked an attempted defensive clearance by Ibrahim Al Shokia just outside the penalty area and watched as the ball looped over Babkr to put his side ahead on 22 minutes.

Ahmed Bahja, bought by the mega-rich Saudis especially for the tournament, was proving to be the biggest threat in a game of slow tempo, a thumping 25-yard free-kick forcing Casillas into a smart save. And it was the lively striker Bahja who got Al Nassr back into the game on the stroke of half-time, charging into the penalty area and going down under Christian Karembeu's challenge.

Al Husseini calmly slotted the equaliser from the spot, sending Ilker Casillas the wrong way, to send the sides in level at the interval.

But Al Nassr squandered the chance of a surprise result by gifting Real a second goal in the 62nd minute - Babkr, under no pressure at all, seemingly having Geremi Njitap's left-wing cross covered, only to palm the ball over his goal-line and Raul followed up to make sure.

Steve McManaman was employed as a second-half substitute but it was the other former Premiership star, Anelka, who sealed the game, turning in the area and being brought down by Babkr.

Savio fired home the penalty to leave Vicente del Bosque's side with a more comfortable last 20 minutes.

Al-Nassr Babkr, Al-Husseini (Al-Khathran 79), Al-Amin, M. Al-Dosari (Mehalel 83), Bahja, Al-Mousa, Al-Karni, Saib (Triki 67), Al-Harthi, Sharify, Al Shokia. Subs Not Used: M. Al-Dosari, Sharifi, Al-Halawi, F. Al-Dosari, Aboshahin, Al-Ghamdi, Al-Janoubi, Al-Dhaferi.

fields.headline: Corinthians break Raja spirit
fields.standfirst: Luizao 49, Luciano 64
fields.trailText: Corinthians opened their campaign with a controversial win over Moroccan side Raja Casablanca.
fields.body:
Corinthians opened their campaign with a controversial win over Moroccan side Raja Casablanca.

The Brazilian champions had to wait until five minutes into the second half before breaking down a brave Moroccan side.

Rising star Luizao, scorer of 19 League goals last season, slid in at the far post to prod home a superb cross from the right wing by Marcelinho.

But it was their second goal which will hit the headlines for all the wrong reasons.

After 64 minutes, centre-half Fabio Luciano had a close-range header saved by Mustapha Chadili and then fired the rebound against the bar before Casablanca defender Hicham Misbah cleared off the line.

Polish linesman Jacek Pociegiel correctly stood his ground but Italian referee Stefano Braschi somehow decided that the ball had crossed the whitewash to give the home side a decisive advantage.

Both Misbah and Chadili were booked for protesting about the decision and the African champions never recovered from the blow.

Corinthians Dida, Indio, Carlos, Vampeta (Edu 89), Kleber, Marcelinho (Senna 76), Rincon, Luizao (Dinei 83), Edilson, Ricardinho, Luciano. Subs Not Used: Mauricio, Daniel, Costa, Baiano, Augusto, Mario, Gilmar, Adilson.

Raja Casablanca Chadli, El Haimeur, El Karkouri, Misbah, Safri, Jrindou, Moustaoudia, Kharbouch, Nejjary, Aboub, Ereyahi, Khoubbache (Achami 59). Subs Not Used: Bouabdellaoui, Sarraj, Daakali, Khoubbache, Armounen, El Moubarki, Hafid, Miki, Nater, Kherazi, Rizki.

webTitle: Pupils to learn how to think

fields.headline: Pupils to learn how to think
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: All children are to be taught thinking skills in their first three years at secondary school under a programme to develop imagination and creativity announced yesterday by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary.
fields.body:
All children are to be taught thinking skills in their first three years at secondary school under a programme to develop imagination and creativity announced yesterday by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary.

He said teachers would be trained in techniques developed at King's College, London, and Newcastle university for stretching pupils' problem-solving capabilities.

The programme will be launched on an experimental basis at volunteer schools this autumn, but last night Mr Blunkett said he envisaged extending it throughout England over the next few years.

In the King's College experiment pupils taught to use thinking skills performed substantially better in GCSE science. But Mr Blunkett said the benefits could extend beyond academic attainment.

"I want children to be able to think creatively and problem solve to address the issues of tomorrow - not just about work, but contributing to the debate about genetic engineering, the future of the planet and issues of global citizenship."

At the north of England education conference in Wigan Mr Blunkett will today set out a blueprint for overhauling the teaching of 11 to 14-year-olds to tackle a dip in pupils' performance in the first three years at secondary school. It is ex pected to include guidance on teaching literacy and numeracy along similar lines to the programmes already in force in primaries.

Last night he said: "I'm very impressed by the growing evidence of the impact on standards of systematic teaching of thinking skills. This is not about some loosely defined or woolly approach to study skills. It is about the ability to analyse and make connections, to use knowledge effectively, to solve problems and to think creatively. It is about developing mental strategies to take on both academic and wider challenges."

Last year Mr Blunkett rejected suggestions that creativity should be taught as a separate subject in the curriculum. Under the new programme teachers will be trained to teach thinking skills within their own subject areas.

He said pupils should get lessons in thinking and creativity tailored to their interests and levels of attainment. This could range from "problem solving to develop life skills" to thinking about social and political issues.

Guidance on teaching thinking skills will be included in handbooks on the revised national curriculum to be published later this term. "The aim is to demonstrate that thinking skills are embedded in programmes of study," said Michael Barber, head of the department for education and employment standards unit.

Citizenship classes would give opportunities for debates on moral, social, political and environmental issues. These would be ideal contexts for using inquiry, information processing, reasoning, problem-solving and evaluation, Professor Barber said.

But there were signs last night that Mr Blunkett's plans to tell secondary schools how to improve teaching in literacy and numeracy may be resisted by the unions.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers said: "The government must be careful not to overload secondary schools. I do not believe that secondary school teachers will blithely tolerate the unrelenting impositions heaped upon their primary colleagues in recent years."

Mr Blunkett is expected to announce national tests for 12 and 13-year-olds that schools could introduce on a voluntary basis. "The many pressures placed upon schools, backed up by the Ofsted inspection police, make a mockery of the term 'voluntary'. The government will have to find external markers for these tests which will cost money.

"The government will also have to accept that more and more teachers will teach to the test and that other areas of the curriculum might suffer as a consequence," Mr de Gruchy said.

Guidance on teaching thinking skills will be included in handbooks on the revised national curriculum to be published later this term. "The aim is to demonstrate that thinking skills are embedded in programmes of study," said Michael Barber, head of the department for education and employment standards unit. Citizenship classes would give opportunities for debates on moral, social, political and environmental issues. These would be ideal contexts for using inquiry, information processing, reasoning, problem-solving and evaluation, Professor Barber said. But there were signs last night that Mr Blunkett's plans to tell secondary schools how to improve teaching in literacy and numeracy may be resisted by the unions. Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers said: "The government must be careful not to overload secondary schools. I do not believe that secondary school teachers will blithely tolerate the unrelenting impositions heaped upon their primary colleagues in recent years." Mr Blunkett is expected to announce national tests for 12 and 13-year-olds that schools could introduce on a voluntary basis. "The many pressures placed upon schools, backed up by the Ofsted inspection police, make a mockery of the term 'voluntary'. The government will have to find external markers for these tests which will cost money. "The government will also have to accept that more and more teachers will teach to the test and that other areas of the curriculum might suffer as a consequence," Mr de Gruchy said.

webTitle: Flight from a hard place to the Rock

fields.headline: Flight from a hard place to the Rock
fields.standfirst: Bars and restaurants opening, rents doubling. That's Gibraltar, new home of British betting
fields.trailText: Beneath the sunny skies of Gibraltar, an economic revolution is brewing. Where previously only squaddies, ex-pats and apes would tread, a new breed of resident is emerging. In the process they are transforming the economic landscape of the tiny British outpost at the tip of the Iberian peninsula.
fields.body:
Beneath the sunny skies of Gibraltar, an economic revolution is brewing. Where previously only squaddies, ex-pats and apes would tread, a new breed of resident is emerging. In the process they are transforming the economic landscape of the tiny British outpost at the tip of the Iberian peninsula.

Over the past year, bookmakers have become the largest employer in Gibraltar after the government. Leading the charge has been Victor Chandler, a London-based bookmaker, who moved his entire telephone betting operation offshore in May to escape the British government levy on betting.

Mr Chandler was quickly followed by Ladbroke's, Britain's biggest bookie, which has opened a telephone betting operation down by the port. Many of their competitors are looking to follow suit by establishing offshore operations.

Gibraltar's attraction is its favourable tax regime. Instead of charging punters a government enforced 9% betting duty, Mr Chandler is able to demand just a 3% service charge.

John O'Reilly, managing director of Ladbroke International, said: "Gibraltar is ideal for us. It has favourable tax breaks, a solid regulatory regime, an English-speaking workforce and none of the hurricane problems associated with some of the tax-free states we might have looked at in the Caribbean."

On the evidence of Mr Chandler and Ladbroke's experience, punters cannot get enough of it. Mr Chandler's operation is expanding at a startling rate to keep up with demand. A year ago his Gibraltan operation employed 20 people. Now it employs 340 and that number could double over the next 12 months.

Ladbroke, which opened its offshore telephone betting centre in October, employs 150 and is growing fast. Gibraltar's population numbers only 30,000 so the impact on the economy, which has flagged in the past decade as the number of squaddies posted there has halved, has been great.

The average salary in Gibraltar is about £8,000. Victor Chandler pays his call centre operatives £10,000-£12,000. New bars and restaurants have opened up to cater for the tastes of his mainly young staff's spending habits. Residential rent prices have doubled. Ladbroke has bought a hotel to house some of its staff.

"This year has been a record for us," said Tim Hirtes, deputy manager of the Elliott, one of Gibraltar's largest quality hotels. "Dozens of Chandler and Ladbroke staff stay here and you only have to walk around town in the evening to see the kind of money they are spending."

Advertising banned

British bookmakers claim the rush offshore forced by the government's intransigent attitude towards cutting betting duty could cost 1,400 jobs at high street bookies. Gordon Brown, the chancellor, has announced a review of gambling to examine ways of protecting the £479m the treasury makes from it each year.

He has banned offshore bookies from advertising in British newspapers and on domestic TV, and soon they will also be banned from advertising on Teletext.

Gibraltans and Mr Chandler couldn't care less. "Moving offshore has cut our costs dramatically and is giving the punter a better deal," Mr Chandler said. Victor Chandler International is now taking 40,000 bets a week over the phone. Ladbroke is opening 700 new accounts a week.

British customers are important to them but the North American and Far East markets are key. About 35% of Mr Chandler's business is from Asia and 40% from the US, with the remaining 25% from Britain and Europe. Separate trading floors at Mr Chandler's offices deal with separate time zones. Country specific freephone numbers route callers to operators who can speak their language.

The Asians bet heavily on football played in the leading leagues in England, Italy and Spain and Mr Chandler employs Malay, Thai and Mandarin telephone operators to serve them.

'Mastery of fixed odds'

US customers bet heavily on American football, illegal in the US where federal law forbids bets being placed on sports games or over the internet. But bets placed through foreign bookmakers based offshore are more difficult to stop.

"Making it illegal to bet with us would be very very difficult," Mr Chandler said. "We're a legitimate business based in Gibraltar and governed by Gibraltan law. There is nothing the US government can do if some of their citizens want to bet with us."

Mr O'Reilly said: "The opportunity in the US market is absolutely phenomenal." He believes the real revolution will come with the advent of online interactive betting, which both bookies hope to offer in the new year. He says betting margins could be transformed by the internet, which will strip out costs such as telephone and shop staff. It will also access a global market.

The personalisation and interactivity new media will bring to betting also has the potential to turn it into a truly mass activity, he says.

"British bookmakers have the heritage, the know-how and the mastery of fixed odds to become bookmakers to the world," Mr Chandler said. "The potential rewards are enormous but the government does not seem to want us to take that opportunity."

Take your chances offshore

webTitle: Labour rivals row over blow to PR hopes

fields.headline: Labour rivals row over blow to PR hopes
fields.standfirst:
Party denies calculated leak of result of survey on voting reform
Proportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: A furious row broke out yesterday between supporters and opponents of electoral reform for Westminster after campaigners for retention of the historic first-past-the-post system claimed to have won overwhelming support from grassroots Labour supporters.
fields.body:
A furious row broke out yesterday between supporters and opponents of electoral reform for Westminster after campaigners for retention of the historic first-past-the-post system claimed to have won overwhelming support from grassroots Labour supporters.

As mud flew over the details of Labour's consultation exercise, rival camps accused each other of sharp practice and of spending large sums to sway voters ahead of the referendum on proportional representation (PR) which Tony Blair has promised to hold, though not before the expected 2001 general election.

Though the cabinet's chief proponent of Lib-Lab coalition politics, Mr Blair remains agnostic about the case for PR made in 1998 by Lord Jenkins's commission, not least because the introduction of "fair" PR for last June's Euro-elections helped to cut Labour's team of MEPs from 62 to 29.

The pro-PR Make Votes Count (MVC) campaign, which gets £100,000 a year from the Rowntree Foundation, complained that supporters of First Past the Post (FPTP), run from the AEEU union HQ in London, had encouraged a false impression of the results of the survey.

All the signs were of a calculated leak by Labour HQ at Millbank, where the party general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, is a known opponent of demands to extend PR reforms to the election of the 659 Westminster MPs.

That was categorically denied. It was claimed that some 1,500 submissions to Labour headquarters revealed a 5-1 ratio against PR. The figures were a casual "guesstimate," Millbank officials said. They had not yet been properly analysed, though only 500 of the submitted responses from unions, local Labour parties and individuals were "substantial" documents.

Many were simply written on preprinted postcards, a bundle of which was delivered by the AEEU just before Christmas, pro-PR campaigners claimed. Millbank confirmed that was so.

The AEEU, whose boss, Sir Ken Jackson, is an outspoken critic of PR, admits it provided postcards as well as newsletters and speakers.

"We have organised it all," the union said, though it claimed to be spending less than £15,000 a year on the campaign.

The union and its allies claimed that the rival MVC campaign had used lobbyists to win over waverers among Labour's 419 MPs. Only a quarter are believed to back PR.

Charles Kennedy, whose long-term relations with Labour inside their joint consultative committee depend on progress on PR, yesterday kept his head down. But angry Liberal Democrat officials accused opponents of PR of not taking "the wider, long-term view of the needs of progressive governance, but of taking the narrow, tribalist, short-term view of Labour's interests."

Labour opponents of PR such as Fraser Kemp MP hinted that Mr Blair may drop the referendum commitment before the next election. But although the party's policy forum meeting in Liverpool in July will probably submit a sceptical report to the annual conference, it suits Downing Street to keep the issue open.

Claims that John Prescott had threatened to resign rather than accept the appointment of Liberal Democrats to Mr Blair's cabinet were authoritatively denied last night. However, Mr Prescott, along with most senior cabinet colleagues, is known to be passionately opposed to a Lib-Lab coalition.

fields.headline: Millbank, j'accuse
fields.standfirst:
The death of PR? A vicious blow to the Liberals' pet project appals one campaigner, but delights another
Proportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: You work for the Labour party and on your first day back after the winter break, you return to a desk groaning under the weight of 1,500 responses to a consultation document on voting systems which were due in by December 31 and are still coming in. What is the first thing you do? For at least one person at Millbank Tower, the answer was apparently to grab a phone and spin a line to the media that the supporters of our present first-past-the-post voting system outnumbered the supporters of electoral reform by at least two to one.
fields.body:
You work for the Labour party and on your first day back after the winter break, you return to a desk groaning under the weight of 1,500 responses to a consultation document on voting systems which were due in by December 31 and are still coming in. What is the first thing you do? For at least one person at Millbank Tower, the answer was apparently to grab a phone and spin a line to the media that the supporters of our present first-past-the-post voting system outnumbered the supporters of electoral reform by at least two to one.

This wasn't difficult to work out, since 1,000 of the replies were in the form of identical postcards which were supplied by the first-past-the-post campaign to anyone prepared to sign their name. They weren't even posted. They were brought into Millbank in a cardboard box.

The remaining 500 replies are more detailed and give considered responses to the 10 questions in the Labour party's consultation paper on the Report of the Independent Commission on the Voting System. They haven't all been opened yet, let alone read or analysed.

When the party does analyse them, it will of course pay far more attention to the replies from local policy forums or constituency Labour parties which are the result of debate, than postcards signed by one individual. And the results will be far more evenly balanced than yesterday's headlines suggested.

But what concerns me right from the start of what promises to be a bare-knuckle fight for the soul of this Labour government is that Millbank should stay right out of it. It is not the business of any party official to spin lines to the media in an internal consultation, any more than it would be in an internal election.

I once worked for the Labour party in the days when it was based at Transport House and there was a clear understanding in those days that party headquarters remained scrupulously impartial on internal party affairs. Most party officials will, I am sure, observe strict neutrality on an issue which divides the Labour party at every level, but clearly the first-past-the-posters already have a friend at the heart of the party machine who is prepared to leak information when it is to their advantage.

The party leadership would do well to stamp on this from the start. They can't have failed to notice from their experience in Wales and in London that partisanship can be entirely counter- productive when it comes from within the party machine. Our subscriptions pay their wages and we are entitled to neutrality.

The same could be said to trade unions such as the AEEU who have thrown their weight - and their money - behind the first-past-the-post campaign. Unlike Millbank, they have a perfect right to be partial if that is what their members want, but they too may find that involvement proves counter-productive. The AEEU believes in the same vision of new trade unionism as Tony Blair. That vision, as the prime minister said in Unions Today magazine, should be "far more focused on the individual needs of union members and far less on what used to be the playing out of political roles, which often did a lot of damage". The fact is that ordinary Labour party members do not want to be bounced into taking a premature decision on what everyone recognises is a very complex issue and a very important one for the future of this Labour government.

It is absolutely staggering to hear it suggested - as one of the pro-first-past-the-post MPs did yesterday morning - that the Labour party should go back on its solemn promise to hold a referendum on electoral reform because of the response to an internal consultation document.

It will be some time before we learn the results of the consultation process, but even if there is a two-to-one majority in favour of the present voting system, as the leaks claim, that is absolutely no excuse for ratting on an election pledge.

John Smith gave his word when he was leader of the Labour party that the issue of changing the voting system would be put to the electorate in a referendum. That pledge was taken up by Tony Blair and it led to a clear commitment in the Labour party's election manifesto. Neither an internal consultation nor even a party conference vote can justify reneging on that commitment.

T he consultation wasn't even about whether we should stick to our pledge to hold a referendum. That was taken for granted. The only question it asked on the referendum was whether the Labour party should take a formal position for or against. Personally I think there is a strong argument that the Labour party should not.

John Smith said the voting system should be decided in a referendum precisely because it is too important to be left to politicians. Voting systems are the process by which politicians are elected and should not therefore be decided upon by politicians or parties who have a vested interest in the outcome. The New Zealand parties lost sight of this fact. The leaders of all the parties urged the electorate to vote against a change in the voting system. Smelling a rat, the voters replied by voting 80% in favour. Despite reports to the contrary, they have no intention of returning to the old system.

The same thing may happen here. Almost every opinion poll on electoral reform has shown a majority in favour of reform. And whatever the consultation may show, the most recent survey of grassroots Labour party members, conducted by professors Patrick Seyd and Paul Whiteley in the summer of 1997, showed that 52% believed that the electoral system should be replaced by a system of proportional representation' with only 27% against.

Among Labour MPs there is a huge majority against reform. But MPs have a vested interest in a voting system that elected them. They overlook its most obvious faults. And they tend to judge public opinion by talking to their own supporters in their own constituencies.

This method of sampling public opinion may work on other issues, but it does not work on voting systems. MPs' own supporters in their own constituencies are, by definition, people who are happy with the voting system. They voted Labour, they got a Labour MP, they have no problem with it.

If MPs want a truer picture, they should also speak to Labour supporters in the 223 seats that do not have Labour MPs. They should talk to the half- million Conservative voters in Scotland who have no representative in parliament. They should wake up to the real world where millions of people are discontented with our voting system, where 12m people abstained at the last election, where 15m cast wasted votes, where the great majority of electors know - as the election approaches - that they have absolutely no chance of making any difference to the result in their constituency. It is a wonder so many go and vote.

If the Labour party is a party of reform, if this government is serious about renewing our constitution, then this is the test. We cannot pretend to be radical if we do not reform our antiquated, 700-year-old voting system. And we cannot let the first-past-the-posters carry out their threat, made by Labour MP Fraser Kemp yesterday, of "killing it off altogether at the next conference". Millbank take note.

Martin Linton is Labour MP for Battersea.
