fields.headline: Our choice, not theirs
fields.standfirst:
Labour must stick to its PR pledge
Proportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: Electoral systems should be designed to give the electorate what it wants. Instead they are usually tailored to suit politicians, and specifically those in power. For them, the choice is never free of self-interest.
fields.body:
Electoral systems should be designed to give the electorate what it wants. Instead they are usually tailored to suit politicians, and specifically those in power. For them, the choice is never free of self-interest. For parties in permanent opposition, like the Liberal Democrats now, proportional representation has a huge appeal, offering more seats in the Commons, a share in government, a place or two in the cabinet. But for parties in power, the prospects are much less alluring: fewer parliamentary seats, government shared in place of freedom to rule on your own.

The new Labour government elected in 1997 looked set to break the pattern. The manifesto promised not PR but a referendum, letting the people decide if a change should be made. That seemed very much the kind of politics Tony Blair believed in: cooperative rather than confrontational. The leaked account of Paddy Ashdown's diaries, charting Mr Blair's readiness to admit Lib Dems to his government, even though he could comfortably govern without them, shows how deep that conviction went. A deal of some kind with the Liberals, short of pure coalition but amounting to a form of joint enterprise, promised to leave the Conservative party impotent and marooned for many years to come. And perhaps would have had the same effect on the Labour left. Some of Mr Blair's colleagues disliked that, not just because they thought it wrong and unnecessary for Labour to sacrifice power to others, but because they believed that governments with majorities were preferable to those dependent on coalitions or deals.

The manifesto promised an independent committee to recommend a proportional alternative to first-past-the-post. The Jenkins committee looked not for the system which in a rational, disinterested world would give the electors the best deal, but for one Tony Blair and Paddy Ashdown might be able to sell to their parties. It was not even truly proportional - simply less disproportional than first-past-the-post. But now - though the figures leaked yesterday are thoroughly unreliable - a Labour consultation process seems to have spurned even that. The numbers involved in the process, however, are small. There is no guarantee that those who replied were representative. The exercise has all the known defects of a self-selecting sample. This answer comes from exactly the sort of people who have most to gain from keeping the status quo. Academic research suggests that a survey based on one party member one vote would have produced a warmer response.

The cause of PR has had setbacks - notably the Euro-election results, with their very small turnout, though those were based on the use of an indefensible form of PR, and unhappiness in New Zealand after it made the change. And Labour is enjoying its new hegemony. Some MPs who writhed at the spectacle of Margaret Thatcher lording it on the basis of 43.9% of the vote find a Labour majority of 178 seats, based on 43.2%, wholly acceptable. But what about us, the consumers? Many sympathetic to Labour are troubled by the lack of checks on government freedom of action, and the way in which machinery which might create such checks - a proportional voting system, an elected Lords rather than one made up of nominees, a select committee system which could really challenge the government rather than just embarrassing it - seem to be slipping off the agenda. They may also have noted that not one of the new democracies of the 90s has chosen to run its elections by first-past-the-post.

Mr Blair's own view on PR remains shrouded in doubt. But that is not the issue. What matters here is the promise, on which Labour solicited our votes, to let the electorate choose in a referendum. There can be no defence for withdrawing that now. If the friends of first-past-the-post want to cling to the system which - for the present - suits them so well, let them argue their case at a referendum. But elections belong to us, not to them. It is we who must choose.

fields.headline: North's sink estates are 'beyond saving'
fields.standfirst:
Crime, vandalism, chronic unemployment - good homes can only be demolished because most people do not want to live in them
North-south divide special report
fields.trailText: Many rundown housing estates in northern England should be considered beyond redemption and demolished, according to a devastating report published yesterday.
fields.body:
Many rundown housing estates in northern England should be considered beyond redemption and demolished, according to a devastating report published yesterday.

The report concluded that some neighbourhoods, particularly in the north-east and north-west, could not be saved because they suffered from insurmountable problems ranging from crime and heavy unemployment to a poor image.

In the unfashionable west end of Newcastle upon Tyne, Lorraine Simpson knows the problems all too well.

Her home is a fortress. Behind the strengthened front and back doors of a rented semi, protected by big steel gates, she keeps an eye on a security camera positioned by the bay window.

It is an area where hundreds of modern homes are boarded-up, or derelict, and every caller and passer-by is filmed. They are all a potential threat. No matter that the estate is monitored by closed circuit television cameras on high pylons linked to the local police station. People have been driven to extreme measures.

"I had to spend hundreds to protect us when the two houses next door were set alight," laments Ms Simpson, mother of a 10-year-old girl. She points to a modern block nearby. "Not so long ago a cou ple of flats were boarded up and within minutes they had been set on fire. I recognised the kids who did it, went to the police and asked them what they were going to do and they said 'nothing', that it was pointless doing anything because no one was living there."

Until recently, the area was a model of modernisation, an estate reborn after rioters torched houses and shops seven years ago. Scores of older properties, structurally sound but impossible to let, were demolished. Many more were modernised at a cost of £30,000 apiece. Some roads were landscaped. Others were partly blocked in a series of traffic calming measures to thwart young joyriders. But crime remains high.

It could be almost any big city in Britain, from Glasgow to Plymouth, Sheffield to Bristol, where successive governments have poured billions of pounds into improving areas where few people want to live.

It just happens to be the unfashionable west end of Newcastle which has achieved notoriety because a modern block of flats, largely empty since being built five years ago at a cost of £1.7m, was recently demolished. This promped the government's housing corporation to question whether it was worth supporting areas of so-called "low demand".

Yesterday, the corporation, which funds public housing, got an answer to the problem of declining estates. The report it commissioned from Shef-field Hallam university's centre for regional economic and social research makes gloomy reading.

Researchers studied 18 housing associations and councils in Newcastle, Salford, Manchester, Sheffield, Liverpool and Leeds, all suffering from the demoralising impact of low demand. They concluded that while some areas could be regenerated, authorities would simply have to manage the decline of many other estates.

Despite huge Whitehall investment, it says it is difficult to find a success story where a neighbourhood in severe decline has been turned round.

According to Ian Cole, who led the research team, many housing associations, now the sole providers of new public homes, had carried on building homes when there was no need for them.

Outlining the full scale of unwanted and unpopular housing in England for the first time, it found that almost 500,000 council and housing association properties were blighted by low demand - over 10% of public housing stock. It also calculated that over 460,000 private properties, often northern terraces in relatively good condition, were resting on a knife-edge.

The report, underpinned by research from Edinburgh's Heriot-Watt university, warned that problems had increased over the past three years, with almost 60% of councils now reporting a rising number of difficult-to-let homes, mainly in the north.

Ministers partly blame the last government for failing to ask sufficient questions before pumping money into sink estates. But they have also accused some council housing managers of failing to reveal the extent of low demand.

Much of the problem, which is largely confined to northern cities and old colliery areas, comes from the collapse of traditional industries. Between 1981 and 1993 alone, the big conurbations lost 652,000 manufacturing jobs. Unable to find work, around 60,000 people a year are leaving the north, often for the south - where there is an acute housing shortage.

The result is that modern estates, such as the neighbourhood behind Mrs Simpson's semi, are approaching the point of no return. Surprisingly, she does not want to leave. "I can manage and it's convenient," she said.

But up the hill at Scotswood, in a new housing association terrace, others are preparing to get out. "I only came here in September and I'll be out soon," said a young mother, with her 18-month-old daughter. "I thought I was coming to heaven, but this is hell."

fields.headline: 'Independent' Mannesmann plans rights issue
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Vodafone
fields.trailText: Mannesmann, the German telecoms group fighting a £85bn bid from British rival Vodafone, is planning a new rights issue to fund further acquisitions if it remains independent, Klaus Esser, chief executive, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Mannesmann, the German telecoms group fighting a £85bn bid from British rival Vodafone, is planning a new rights issue to fund further acquisitions if it remains independent, Klaus Esser, chief executive, said yesterday.

In a series of interviews with German newspapers Mr Esser went on the offensive against Vodafone's hostile bid before launching his company's de fence document within the next week.

He told Börsenzeitung, a Frankfurt stock exchange newspaper, that he explicitly sought a rights issue worth "substantial billions in euros" to underpin the company's strategy and rejected the argument of Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, that Mannesmann's £20bn takeover of mobile phone operator Orange would limit its capacity to raise capital.

Mr Esser said that the planned float of the company's engineering and automotive business in July would raise euro 4bn (£2.5bn) - and these would be used not to fund the Orange purchase but "future transactions in the year 2000".

He told the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung that Mannesmann planned to take on further majority stakes in European telecom companies after extending its holdings in Arcor, Infostrada and Omnitel - and taking over Orange - last year.

The Mannesmann defence strategy is focused on the group's integrated approach to mobile and fixed-line telephony and Mr Esser told the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung that new integrated products offering access to both the internet and telecommerce would be available later this month.

Castigating Vodafone as "a loss-making concern", Mr Esser said that it would have to book an unprecedented €100bn or more in goodwill if it won Mannesmann - and compensate Mannesmann shareholders with up to euro 60bn in cash if it was forced to sell on Orange at an unfavourable price.

Shares in the Düsseldorf-based group lost euro 11.40, or 5%, to close the session at euro 217, while its British predator also lost nearly 5% of its value in a declining market for telecoms stocks.

webTitle: $10m bid for web address a hoax

fields.headline: $10m bid for web address a hoax
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

www.Year2000.com
fields.trailText: EBay said yesterday that the record $10m (£6.1m) bid for website address Year2000.com turned out to be a prank.
fields.body:
EBay said yesterday that the record $10m (£6.1m) bid for website address Year2000.com turned out to be a prank.

Tenagra Corp, which put its rights to the domain name up for auction on EBay, asked the auction leader to investigate the $10m bid after not receiving any response from the bidder, EBay spokesman Kevin Pursglove said.

EBay's investigation team then examined the bidder's contact information and tried to get in touch with the buyer without success, Mr Pursglove said. "We came to the conclusion that this was a prank bid," he said.

EBay also ruled out the second and third highest offers for the website address, because one appeared to be a prank and the other because the bidder withdrew the offer shortly after.

The top remaining bid was for $2m.

The Year2000.com website address was created for disseminating information about the millennium bug. The site is a joint venture of Petrus & Associates - a subsidiary of Tenagra, a Houston-based internet marketing firm.

Tenagra, which registered the address, put Year2000.com and its content up for sale on EBay on December 22.

The sale was held in a private auction, meaning EBay did not display any of the bidders' names.

Had it been legitimate, the $10m bid would have topped the $7.5m ECompanies paid for Business.com in November last year.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It seemed ironic somehow that in the first week of 2000, for so long the dateline of science fiction fantasies, hi-tech stocks should take such a battering - what about that shiny new future? But yesterday the rout continued.
fields.body:
It seemed ironic somehow that in the first week of 2000, for so long the dateline of science fiction fantasies, hi-tech stocks should take such a battering - what about that shiny new future? But yesterday the rout continued.

The overnight slough on the technology-laden Nasdaq caused many of the stock market darlings of 1999 on this side of the Atlantic to slide. Computer services group Misys lost more than 6% to 835p, Logica fell almost 7% to £13.95 and Psion dropped 14.5% to finish on 416p.

Among others to take a hit, Freeserve , the internet service provider which set the benchmark for the sector when it floated last year, was 7% lower at 554p and Sage Group 7% off at 659p.

Among the biggest losers were semiconductor maker Arm Holdings off 8.5% at £36.69 and computer services group CMG , down 11% at £38.50.

Some dealers noted there had been little institutional selling in the stocks and the kind of freefall which some had been fearing failed to materialise. Perhaps the army of private investors in the sector needed to pay off some hefty post-Christmas credit card bills.

Much of the nervousness in markets worldwide had been triggered by fear of a tightening of interest rates. The Bank of England monetary policy committee meets next week.

After the record plunge on Tuesday, the FTSE 100 index fell another 130 points yesterday to close on 6535.9.

Stocks with an exposure to Asia also weighed heavily on the FTSE after the previous session's sharp fall in Hong Kong. Cable & Wireless , tipped as a stock of the year by a number of the Sunday newspapers, fell 43p to 994p, Standard Chartered was off 37p at 897p and HSBC 30p lower at 792p.

Some of the money being drained from the hi-tech sector found its way back into defensive stocks. National Power was marked up 21p at 385p and PowerGen was 11p better at 450p.

Food retailers held out with Sainsbury up 5p at 347p and Tesco improving 1.5p to 185p. Drinks group Diageo was 4.5p better at 504p.

The powerhouse performance from Next in the run-up to Christmas had investors hoping for a repeat elsewhere. Discount fashion retailer Matalan was 27p higher at £16.65, department store group Selfridges was up by more than 6% at 285p and Marks & Spencer added 1p to end the session on 311p. Next itself didn't fare so well, dropping 15p to 600p.

webTitle: Hamiltons coy on Labour MP's gift

fields.headline: Hamiltons coy on Labour MP's gift
fields.standfirst: Hamilton, Al Fayed libel trial
fields.trailText: Support for Neil and Christine Hamilton comes from the unlikeliest of quarters. Yesterday, the wife of the disgraced former Tory minister revealed they had received a donation from a Labour MP.
fields.body:
Support for Neil and Christine Hamilton comes from the unlikeliest of quarters. Yesterday, the wife of the disgraced former Tory minister revealed they had received a donation from a Labour MP.

Mr Hamilton is struggling to pay a £2m legal bill following the failure of his libel action against the Harrods owner, Mohamed Al Fayed. But despite the couple's public humiliation, messages of support - many accompanied by cheques - had arrived over the holiday period, they said in a television interview.

One had even come from the other side of the political divide, Mrs Hamilton said, "which, I think, probably most people would find quite surprising." But, in case the MP feared derision from colleagues, Mrs Hamilton told Sky News that "wild horses" would not drag from her the backer's identity. Neither did she reveal the value of the contribution.

Mr Hamilton hinted that the couple's fighting fund came nowhere near meeting his debts. "Financially, of course, I'm ruined."

He has become a political pariah since he failed to convince a jury at the high court in London that Mr Fayed had libelled him by claiming he accepted cash to ask questions in parliament on behalf of Harrods. The Tory party chairman, Michael Ancram, said after the case that he hoped the one-time corporate affairs minister would fade into the background. Mr Hamilton made it clear that this was unlikely. He is examining transcripts of the trial with a view to mounting an appeal. A decision will be announced in the next two weeks.

In an earlier interview on GMTV, Mr Hamilton attacked his party's attitude. "It is the Conservative party that appears to be lying down and dying at the moment, if I may say so. I don't think Michael Ancram's rather inhumane and self-interested comments in the aftermath of the verdict in my case merit more than two seconds' consideration. He showed himself up for what he was."

He and his wife were determined to get on with their lives, despite the "tragedy" of their failed action. They praised the support of their friends - although there were unkind suggestions that the mysterious Labour MP's motivation may have been less philanthropic than the couple believed.

A Labour source said: "If the Hamilton saga drags on, it can only be good for us. Perhaps the national executive committee could sanction a contribution."

fields.trailText: • Sales up Internet retailer Amazon.com said fourth-quarter sales jumped more than 150% from the previous year, but losses would not be trimmed partly because of new inventory in start-up businesses such as toys and electronics.
fields.body:
 Sales up Internet retailer Amazon.com said fourth-quarter sales jumped more than 150% from the previous year, but losses would not be trimmed partly because of new inventory in start-up businesses such as toys and electronics.

Fourth-quarter sales were more than $650m (£378m) compared with $253m in the 1998 fourth quarter - exceeding sales for all of 1998 of $610m.

 Notable Provider of infrastructure services for websites InfoSpace.com said it had joined Intel in the chipmaker's plans to develop internet devices, such as notepads.

Intel intends to have the devices resold through internet service providers and telephone companies, beginning in mid-year.

 Helping hand Subscribers to internet access provider AOL will be able to access email through hand-held computers under a deal with Compaq and Casio Computer.

AOL will make its software available free for download from its proprietary service.

fields.headline: Focus  NatWest
fields.trailText: Be warned: the fight for NatWest will explode again soon as the three sets of bank bosses race to woo investors before the deadline, on Valentine's day.
fields.body:
Be warned: the fight for NatWest will explode again soon as the three sets of bank bosses race to woo investors before the deadline, on Valentine's day.

While the banks have spared us from a further round of publicly aired tit-for-tat over the Christmas holiday, Royal Bank of Scotland - the second predator for the troubled bank - is working behind the scenes in a "charm offensive" of banking analysts and shareholders. While the stock market continues to expect Royal Bank to win the battle, its shares have taken a pounding since launching its bid - as have Bank of Scotland's, the first to launch its attack on the clearing bank.

Analysts at Deutsche Bank calculated yesterday that Royal Bank's shares have lost 20% of their value, and they believe it is time to start buying the shares again. Such buy recommendations must be music to the ears of Sir George Mathewson, chief executive of Royal Bank, as the higher his company's share price the higher the value of his bid for NatWest, because it contains a hefty share component.

His counterpart at Bank of Scotland, Peter Burt, will also want to boost his bank's share price in the last days of the battle, and for the same reason.

Any upturn in either bank's share price might upset the new bosses of NatWest, who have been able to hide behind the apparent weakness of their predators' share prices.

If Sir David Rowland and Ron Sandler have any real wish to keep NatWest independent they will hope for continued weakness in the bidders' shares which might help them escape without pulling any major surprises.

webTitle: Waiting for Marconi bug to blow over

fields.headline: Waiting for Marconi bug to blow over
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: George Simpson must have had an excellent Hogmanay: as the crepuscule descended on a momentous year, Marconi, the company he has transformed into a high-rolling communications group, saw its market cap reach £30bn for the first time.
fields.body:
George Simpson must have had an excellent Hogmanay: as the crepuscule descended on a momentous year, Marconi, the company he has transformed into a high-rolling communications group, saw its market cap reach £30bn for the first time.

But, as for most Scots in early January, come the dawn, come the hangover, that Caledonian brew of anxiety, guilt and remorse. Marconi, an under-performing defence and engineering group as GEC, got caught in the vortex engulfing hi-tech stocks and suffered a severe dose of dot.com flu.

Yesterday the bug remained virulent; Marconi fell 69.5p or 6.77% to end the day at 956.5p, a far cry from the near-£11 the stock hit the day before millennium eve. But chief executive Lord Simpson of Dunkeld still has time to prove his worth. At Hogmanay 1998, just prior to the ground-breaking £8bn merger of its defence arm with British Aerospace, GEC shares stood at 534p. Five months later, even after spending £4bn to buy two US telecom equipment providers, Fore and Reltec, GEC's market cap was just £17.5bn.

It was in May that Lord Simpson and John Mayo, finance director and fellow deal-maker, set out their plans to double the group's value within five years. By the end of the 20th century, they had done it within 12 months, not least because of the name-change to Marconi on November 30.

The Bruton Street duo and some 2,500 senior managers have a lot riding on the group's and the market's performance over the next 30 months. The managers get a maximum bonus if they double the value of their segment of the business within three years.

Lord Simpson has even more at stake. If he meets a range of targets in five years after taking over from Lord Weinstock in September 1996 - including the stock outperforming the market by 10% - he stands to pick up £10m.

Last year GEC-Marconi outperformed by 40%. So Simpson must be hoping that the current flu' will swiftly become a mere cold and the market's correction of "irrational exuberance" in IT stocks remains just that. Then, come July 2002, at 60, he can play golf and put some of his millions into a Celtic start-up.

fields.headline: Bell's spin for regulatory nod
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Bell Atlantic has proposed spinning off GTE's internet operations in an attempt to win regulatory approval for the $70bn (£43bn) merger of the two American telecommunications groups.
fields.body:
Bell Atlantic has proposed spinning off GTE's internet operations in an attempt to win regulatory approval for the $70bn (£43bn) merger of the two American telecommunications groups.

The proposed $2.5bn spin-off is designed to circumvent anti-monopoly laws which bar local telephone groups from operating long-distance lines. GTE's "backbone" forms part of the infrastructure over which web data travels.

American regulators have also voiced concerns about the potential for a handful of telecoms groups to control access to the internet. This issue has so far delayed approval for the Bell Atlantic-GTE deal, which was announced last year.

The proposal represents Bell's third attempt to win official support for a merger. It has previously suggested a separate tracking stock for GTE's internet business as well as setting up a trust.

The Federal Communications Commission is under stood to have rejected both suggestions as an inadequate response to the law.

Under the latest proposal the newly merged group would continue to own 10% of internet operations, with the rest of the new company being publicly traded.

However, Bell is keen to include a clause giving it the option to buy back between 80% and 90% of the internet business within five years if it manages to meet regulatory requirements by then.

The company is barred from carrying voice or internet traffic over long distances until it shows that its local markets are open to competition. So far it has managed to do so only in the New York area.

The FCC said that the Bell-GTE deal was the first attempt by a "Baby Bell" to merge with a long-distance partner. The commission is also looking at the proposed merger of MCI and Sprint, two long-distance and wireless groups.

The merger of Bell and GTE would create the largest local group in the United States.

fields.headline: Physician heal thyself - or else
fields.standfirst:
Incompetent, outmoded and even spendthrift doctors are now coming under surveillance. But there's rivalry over who will do the policing
More about the NHS
fields.trailText: Doctors' dilemmas
fields.body:
Doctors' dilemmas

 20 GPs have been struck off the medical list by the NHS tribunal since April 1996

 29 hospital doctors are currently suspended for six months or more

 In 1998, 277 cases were referred to the GMC's preliminary proceedings committee; 31 doctors were found guilty of serious professional misconduct

 The Nuffield Trust has reported high levels of psychological disturbance among hospital doctors and GPs

Source: Supporting Doctors, Protecting Patients (department of health)

Mad, bad and dangerous practitioners form a small minority of our profession, say doctors. The government agrees. Exchanges last year at the launch of the government's proposals for protecting patients from this dodgy element were genteel. Yet now doctors are deeply worried: is the department of health (DoH) going for the sledgehammer approach to crack this nut?

The medical profession is beleaguered. Scandals - particularly that over the Bristol Royal Infirmary where low standards led to babies un necessarily dying in complex heart operations - have exposed the shortcomings in an area where doctors used to be unchallenged kings of their craft. What we are seeing now is a race between government and the doctors' organisations to put structures into place that will ensure doctors are appraised and their work audited. At issue is who controls the medical profession: is its 140-year-old tradition of self-regulation to be replaced by rule from Richmond House, the DoH headquarters?

The doctors' disciplinary body, the General Medical Council (GMC), knows that the government is fully prepared to impose change. The public inquiry now under way is not just looking at what happened at Bristol but at every aspect of the hospital system in England and Wales that might have a bearing on practice and procedure there. From the GMC to the royal colleges to the DoH itself, the top tier of the medical profession has been grilled on what went wrong. Eventually, it is expected that Ian Kennedy, the QC chairing the inquiry, will produce a far-reaching reform plan.

Meanwhile the GMC and royal colleges are frantically trying to get their own system of revalidating doctors up and running as soon as possible. Yesterday the Royal College of GPs, together with the BMA GPs committee, published the first consultation document, suggesting a wide range of tests to determine whether a GP is working correctly and effectively. Each of the other colleges - covering all specialities from surgery to paediatrics - will produce its own blueprint for best practice. This will be the profession's answer to the problem of doctors not keeping up with medical advances.

There is general agreement that every five years doctors will have to submit evidence of their competence, such as internal assessments by their peers, satisfaction ratings from patients, and even video evidence from consultations.

From the profession's point of view, this is going to be a fair and thorough system, which will link in, if a doctor is failing badly, with the GMC's performance procedures. These are themselves new. Only a few years ago, a doctor could only be disciplined for "serious professional misconduct" such as a crime or a sexual liaison with a patient. The performance procedures were introduced to enable the GMC to strike a doctor off the medical register for being simply a bad doctor - after attempts to re-train him or her had failed.

But to make all this thorough and fair will take time, because a host of different specialities, each with their own royal college, are involved. You cannot require the same proofs of competence from a GP and a heart surgeon. So each college is painstakingly producing its own blueprint.

While ministers make pleasant noises about revalidation, however, there are signs that they have not got the patience to wait for the profession to sort itself out. That is where the document produced last year (Supporting Doctors, Protecting Patients) by the chief medical officer (CMO) for England and Wales comes in. Health secretary Alan Milburn and the CMO, Liam Donaldson, see this as the answer to poor performance. But while the royal colleges and the GMC have been scrupulously polite about it, there is dismay in some quarters. The NHS, as the employer, must have ways of dealing with complaints about doctors and systems of care, they feel, but clinical performance is the profession's own territory.

At least it has been in the past. Professor Donaldson's document proposes "appraisal" for all doctors. It asserts that the NHS has a responsibility to ensure its doctors are up to standard.

Basically, here is a plan to test doctors, send them off to new assessment and support centres for retraining if necessary, and suspend or dismiss them at managers' discretion. It is a complete package. While revalidation and professional self-regulation are frequently mentioned, doctors could be forgiven for thinking those are secondary to the task of satisfying the employer - the NHS - that the doctor is fit for the job.

The medical establishment has been almost as anxious about the way the document was produced as its content. (It was almost exclusively Professor Donaldson's work.) One source said professional bodies were given 12 hours to read a draft, two weeks before publication. It is a consultation document, but they wonder how much scope there is for change.

Medical practice has already been streamlined. The National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice), unkindly dubbed the government's rationing body, is to appraise new medicines and treatments. For the first time, Nice will compare one licensed drug with another and advise doctors. The Commission for Health Improvement (CHI) will take an interest in doctors who ignore Nice. This is the government's new inspectorate. Shortly after Bristol, the Royal College of Surgeons began work on a scheme to send in troubleshooters should there be any suggestion of a serious problem. But again, the government has made the territory its own.

Does it matter who sets these bodies up? Whoever takes the lead, the same people will sit on them: only certain people are qualified and they are all members of the profession. Everybody agrees that standards need to be set, but it is control of the agenda that matters - to a government which wants radical modernisation of the NHS and to doctors who want to preserve their professional freedom. As the saying goes, he who pays the piper calls the tune.

Sarah Boseley is the Guardian's health correspondent

webTitle: Healthy side-effects of bypassing rule book

fields.headline: Healthy side-effects of bypassing rule book
fields.standfirst:
How a different financial deal for doctors led to one deprived estate getting its first medical centre
More about the NHS
NHS Primary Care pages
fields.trailText: They could never persuade a doctor to set up on the Pennywell. Although the Sunderland estate was incubating some of the biggest health and social problems in the country, the system worked directly against provision of traditional primary care.
fields.body:
They could never persuade a doctor to set up on the Pennywell. Although the Sunderland estate was incubating some of the biggest health and social problems in the country, the system worked directly against provision of traditional primary care.

"You couldn't get anyone to come here, simply because it's not the sort of place you would want to be from a GP's point of view," says Will Richardson, who is now leading the estate's first medical practice and has attracted more than 2,000 patients.

"We are right up top there for things like teenage pregnancy, heart disease, lung cancer, social isolation and poverty. There are a lot of burned-out buildings all around us: it's a bit of a wasteland, really."

Dr Richardson is one of a small but growing band of salaried GPs, employed directly by health authorities. Because they do not own their practice - a system which means, in effect, operating a small business - they are bringing primary care to pockets of the country that have never before proved fertile soil for it.

The Pennywell is one of almost 300 personal medical services (PMS) pilots in England, where innovations like salaried GPs are fostered and the normal rules and regulations of general practice, laid down in the notorious "red book", can be bypassed.

"By trashing the red book, and getting away from all the limitations and requirements in there, it has allowed us to be much a more flexible and patient-orientated service," says Dr Richardson, who used to work in a traditional practice.

"If the building gets vandalised, that's not my problem. I can concentrate on the clinical side of things, which is what I am paid for. If I'd wanted to be a businessman, I'd have gone into business."

What is happening on the Pennywell, and in many other PMS pilots, is how ministers want to see the government's NHS modernisation programme develop and accelerate.

While the pilots are three-year experiments, nobody doubts that the successful ones are here to stay, signalling the end of a single, rule-bound model of primary care.

Ironically, the first pilots were planned under the Conservative administration, but Labour has taken them for its own and made them a centrepiece of its modernisation drive.

Dr Richardson and his 10-strong team of nurses and other health workers started work on the Pennywell, one of the largest estates in Europe, in April 1998.

"I reckon 50-60% of my caseload is related to mental health," he says. "And there is a great deal of drug abuse among the kids. There's a lot of heroin around and many of them are using prescription drugs. We've got 13- and 14-year-olds regularly using 100mg of Valium a day. They aren't going to see 20."

One of the features of the Pennywell practice is an open-door surgery policy, no appointment necessary. Ministers see this kind of access as essential for the NHS to develop in the modern, consumer era.

David Colin-Thomé, the government's lead adviser on primary care, has forecast that people's expectations are such that it may be "difficult to sustain" the traditional, personalised service offered by a GP to his registered patients.

Writing in Visions of Primary Care, published by pro-New Labour pressure group New Health Network, he says: "Empirical trend evidence, confirmed by the NHS user survey, is that patients increasingly place greater value on easy access to care above a long term relationship with their personal doctor."

Dr Colin-Thomé, a GP as well as director of primary care for the NHS executive, warns that "while the practice with its registered population will remain the bedrock of primary health care, it will only do so if primary health care workers are prepared to play a more responsive, wider and proactive role as a resource to their communities".

His words will be ringing in the ears of GPs over the coming months as they discuss a report, commissioned by the British Medical Association and expected shortly, on the future of general practice. Debate will peak at a special national conference in March.

John Chisholm, who chairs the BMA's GPs' committee, says: "I think it is safe to say we shall be seeking constructive engagement on the change agenda, rather than any Luddite retrenchment."

fields.headline: Doctors leaders set out their blueprint for excellence
fields.standfirst: More about the NHS
fields.trailText: An excellent GP listens to what patients have to say, does not gossip about them, makes sure his or her letters are legible and works hours that suit the patients rather than just himself, according to a new blueprint published yesterday.
fields.body:
An excellent GP listens to what patients have to say, does not gossip about them, makes sure his or her letters are legible and works hours that suit the patients rather than just himself, according to a new blueprint published yesterday.

The Royal College of General Practitioners, together with the GPs committee of the British Medical Association is sending two consultation documents to every family doctor in the country which define what leaders of the profession expect from good doctors. They include checklists of good practice and also bad.

Inadequate doctors may have phone lines which are frequently engaged, the documents say, and do not respect confidentiality or listen to the patients' concerns. They may have restricted opening hours. They may not respond fast enough in an emergency. They may stock out of date drugs. They may assume the patient consents to treatment without asking.

Most doctors will meet some of the excellent criteria and few will fall squarely into the bracket of inadequates - a few hundred at most, doctors leaders say. But the publication of these documents is a necessary step towards reassuring the public that all doctors are competent and can be trusted, following a series of scandals, such as the unnecessary deaths of babies at the Bristol Royal Infirmary and the botched surgery of gynaecologist Rodney Ledward.

The two documents are the first draft proposals for revalidating doctors - assessing their fitness to practise. The profession's disciplinary body, the General Medical Council, and the Royal Colleges which govern all the different specialties in medicine have agreed to work towards revalidation every five years on average for all doctors. The GMC wants the process to begin next year, but the Royal College of GPs is the first to produce its proposals and the other colleges are some way behind.

The two reports, Revalidation for Clinical General Practice and Good Medical Practice for General Practitioners, spell out to GPs what will be required of them. They will then have to demonstrate to their peers that their practice more often than not meets the standard set for excellence. GPs who are considered to be failing will be assessed in their surgeries by local revalidation groups including other doctors, health professionals and also lay people. The panel could ask them to undergo some re-training. If the GP fails or refuses to improve, the last resort is to the GMC, which could remove him or her from the medical register.

Dr John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's GPs Committee, said: "A poor GP consistently or frequently provides care described by the unacceptable GP criteria. An excellent GP meets the excellent criteria all or nearly all of the time. A good GP meets most of the excellent GP criteria most of the time.

"We do not believe that any GP can be expected to provide care described by the excellent GP all the time - though he or she will aspire to that. Likewise we recognise that good GPs will, on occasion, provide care that appears to be unacceptable by these standards. Sometimes this may be due to lack of resources; where standards are not met, it may not always be the fault of the doctor."

He pointed out that the revalidation exercise, while necessary, will be expensive. "Although for revalidation most GPs should be able to submit evidence already collected for other purposes, there will be a cost involved. Local revalidation groups, for example, will have to be set up to visit GPs when questions arise. One of the crucial questions is who will pay. Revalidation cannot go ahead in the absence of adequate resources. We will negotiate resources and the further development of revalidation will depend on the outcome of those negotiations."

Professor Mike Pringle, chairman of the Council of the RCGP, said it was important that the public as well as doctors understood what was required. "We are applying explicit criteria to our revalidation proposals. They must be understood by and be credible with the public. They must identify unacceptable performance and identify good performance. The proposals must be supported by - and be supportive of - the profession." He believed the two documents fit all the criteria.

Doctors hope the government will provide funds, but ministers have been setting out their own ideas on the appraisal and assessment of doctors, which were published in a report from the Chief Medical Officer, Liam Donaldson, towards the end of last year.

Dr Chisholm said he believed the government's ideas were wrong in certain respects. Professor Donaldson proposes that failing doctors should be sent off to assessment centres - the Royal College wants to see local teams go in to help doctors in their surgeries. "The sort of appraisal in the CMO's report is managerial and punitive", he added. "We want something informative and constructive so people can analyse their own performance in terms of where they are doing well and where they are not." But he says he believes the two approaches can be reconciled.

webTitle: Burned-out GPs fall prey to stress

fields.headline: Burned-out GPs fall prey to stress
fields.standfirst:
The British Psychological Society website
More about the NHS
fields.trailText: Many GPs are suffering from "burn-out" because of the stresses placed upon them by their job, a study suggests.
fields.body:
Many GPs are suffering from "burn-out" because of the stresses placed upon them by their job, a study suggests.

Researchers found that family doctors are ground down by demanding patients, feel ill-equipped to deal with people suffering from complex problems, and worry about the prospect of litigation. Emotion-related problems were widespread, with some turning to drink and drugs.

The report, presented to the British Psychological Society conference yesterday, said: "Emotional conflict eventually gives way to stress related disorders such as those described as 'burnout', the symptoms of which were found in the majority of GPs in this study and included relationship problems with spouse, partners and patients and alcoholism.

"There was anecdotal evidence of drug dependency and falling asleep during consultations."

Report authors Nigel King and Chrystal Frost, co-ordinator of the primary care research group at the university of Huddersield, suggested that the stresses associated with the job could explain the fall in numbers of GPs over the past 15 years.

The researchers questioned 20 GPs; a further 21 GPs declined to take part. Eight were on long-term sick leave, five "semi-retired" due to long-term illness, five "far too busy" and three private GPs said "emotions were not part of a GP's professional life".

The report says: "GPs are expected to keep their personal feelings to themselves during surgery hours and present a public display of professionalism and compassion. They hide their feelings behind a facade of professional neutrality which can create an internal conflict of emotions leading to symptoms of stress.

"GPs often fail to recognise these sorts of problems in themselves, probably because they have received no formal tuition in emotion management during their medical training."

The researchers identified three main sources of stress. These were "heartsink" - feeling ground down by demanding patients whom they dreaded; a feeling of inadequacy in dealing with situations for which they felt ill-equipped, such as treating patients with psychological disorders; and a perceived threat of litigation.

All the GPs felt patients are, to a certain extent, encouraged to complain. Some GPs who had been the subject of a patient's complaint felt "little or no support was given to them".

Ms Frost said: "We found that while GPs can easily identify stress in other people, they are less likely to identify it in themselves. And it is rife right across the board, younger and older ones. They want someone to listen to them and they feel they have been neglected."

Ms Frost, who conducted in-depth interviews with her subjects, added: "It has certainly changed the way I consult my GP. I will only go now if I have symptoms which last for more than a week."

webTitle: Doctor 'duped families to save his skin'

fields.headline: Doctor 'duped families to save his skin'
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: The trial of Harold Shipman, the GP accused of murdering 15 women patients, was told that it would be quite incredible if his alleged victims had all died of natural causes.
fields.body:
The trial of Harold Shipman, the GP accused of murdering 15 women patients, was told that it would be quite incredible if his alleged victims had all died of natural causes.

In his closing speech to the jury at Preston crown court, Richard Henriques QC, prosecuting, asked if it could be a coincidence that all the women had been seen by Shipman on the day of their death.

Mr Henriques said in each case Shipman had failed to call an ambulance, or to examine the women or attempt resuscitation. He had visited their homes when he had not been called and, in seven cases, he had falsified medical records.

He said the 15 women had trusted Shipman, who ran a sole practice in Hyde, Greater Manchester, with their health and their lives.

"They trusted him to care for them," he said. "Their relatives trusted him to tell the truth about the circumstances in which his patients died. The community trusted him to keep records and documentation with insight and knowledge."

The prosecution asserts that he breached that trust. "He did not care at all for these 15 patients he killed," said Mr Henriques. "He did not tell the truth to their relatives - he duped them in order to save his own skin."

He said there could hardly be some other killer on the loose in Hyde seeking out Shipman's patients and following the same route as the doctor.

The prosecution claims Shipman would "overbear, belittle and bamboozle" grieving relatives. "As they grieved, this determined man employed every device to make sure no postmortem examination took place," he said.

"The poisoner, of course, fears the pathologist. He fears ambulances and he fears hospitals."

He said the GP had told barefaced lies to convince his victims' relatives that he had called ambulances to help the women but that they had suffered natural deaths. He took advantage of their grief and their lesser knowledge of medicine and procedures.

The prosecution claims the trail of murder would have been halted sooner if the relatives had got together to compare notes.

Shipman, 53, of Mottram, near Hyde,denies murdering the women with injections of diamorphine and forging the £386,000 will of one alleged victim, Kathleen Grundy.

Mr Henriques said Shipman did not attempt any resuscitation: there was no point because he knew they were dead. "He was too arrogant and too self-confident to go through the motions." He said the GP had gambled that authorities would not check his stories.

The trial resumed yesterday after a 22-day break. It continues today.

webTitle: Militant at heart of hijack vows to 'liberate' Kashmir

fields.headline: Militant at heart of hijack vows to 'liberate' Kashmir
fields.standfirst:
More about the Indian Airlines hijacking
The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
fields.trailText: The leading Kashmiri militant released by India to end a bloody airline hijack vowed last night to fight to liberate the majority Muslim state from Indian rule.
fields.body:
The leading Kashmiri militant released by India to end a bloody airline hijack vowed last night to fight to liberate the majority Muslim state from Indian rule.

In a speech that is bound to heighten tension between India and Pakistan, Maulana Masood Azhar told some 10,000 followers in a park in central Karachi that he would not rest until Kashmir had been "liberated".

Mr Azhar told the throng, many of whom were members of his militant group, the Marakat-ul-Mojahedin: "I have come here because this is my duty to tell you that Muslims should not rest in peace until we have destroyed America and India."

He said the five hijackers of the Indian Airlines jet, who he said were all Indian Kashmiris, had returned to Kashmir and were "preparing for their next assault".

Earlier yesterday, Islamic Jihad Council, an umbrella group for a dozen Muslim groups fighting Indian forces in Kashmir, insisted the freed hijackers were still in Afghanistan.

The ruling Taliban said that the hijackers, Mr Azhar and two other militants freed in the deal to release 155 hostages, Mushtaq Ahmed Zargar, an Indian Kashmiri, and Ahmed Umar Saeed Sheikh, a Pakistani-born British citizen, had all left the country.

The men took control of the Indian Airlines plane in the skies over India on December 24. One hostage was killed.

The hijackers have not been seen since they left Kandahar airport in southern Afghanistan. They were given 10 hours by Afghanistan's ruling Taliban to leave the country.

The conflicting claims over the whereabouts of the hijackers have fuelled Delhi's claims that Pakistan was involved in the incident, and have led to bitter exchanges which have plunged India's relations with Pakistan's new military ruler to a new low.

The ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, on Tuesday said India was launching a propaganda campaign against his country to deflect criticism over how New Delhi handled negotiations with the hostage-takers.

India's home minister, L K Advani, said India had "irrefutable evidence of Pakistan's involvement in cross-border terrorism and in this particular hijacking." But he did not offer details, and he said India has not yet offered the proof to other countries.

Pakistan has condemned the hijacking and denied involvement. Pakistan said after the hijacking that its border security was put on alert and the hijackers would be arrested if found.

On Wednesday, Pakistani officials demanded that India make public information it claims to have on the hijackers' identities.

"Fabrication of allegations without a shred of evidence is reprehensible," a Pakistani foreign ministry statement said.

Mr Azhar's speech in Karachi will further confirm India's suspicions, although Pakistan said Mr Azhar, whose father is a retired school teacher from Bawahalpur in eastern Punjab province, would be allowed to return to his homeland because he did not face any charges at home.

A fiery speaker and charismatic leader, the Pakistani-born cleric conducted a tour of British mosques shortly before his arrest in Febuary 1994.

Faisal Bodi, news editor of Q-News, a Muslim magazine, wrote in the Guardian that it was a measure of Mr Azhar's importance that his supporters have mounted two attempts to free him. A previous attempt ended in the killing of at least one of six western captives. Another four are missing, presumed dead.

Mr Bodi said that Mr Azhar is intensely popular among British Muslims: "In particular Azhar's recommendations that young men undergo military training in Afghanistan has found many a receptive ear - to the alarm of governments who fear it could swell the ranks of the indomitable international mojahedin. Naturally in a Muslim world which sees all that is western as irredeemably hostile, Azhar's reputation has grown since the US state department included on its list of terrorist organisations the Harkat-ul- Ansar, a group of which he was a leading ideologue."

fields.headline: Bore Dome
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee gets straight to the nub when she refers to "exhibition organisers with nothing to exhibit" (Comment, January 5). The gaping vacuum at the heart of the Dome project from its conception has always been that it is ultimately a big space, and what can you do with a big space but fill it with with things? In 1851 "things", whether steamship turbines or sewing machines, were at the leading edge of human endeavour. Even in 1951, things still had the power to enlighten and enthrall. But 50 years on, everything that's exciting and different, and engaging the most innovative minds, is not physical and three-dimensional, but intangible, invisible and directly accessible to anyone with a computer and modem.

Polly Toynbee gets straight to the nub when she refers to "exhibition organisers with nothing to exhibit" (Comment, January 5). The gaping vacuum at the heart of the Dome project from its conception has always been that it is ultimately a big space, and what can you do with a big space but fill it with with things? In 1851 "things", whether steamship turbines or sewing machines, were at the leading edge of human endeavour. Even in 1951, things still had the power to enlighten and enthrall. But 50 years on, everything that's exciting and different, and engaging the most innovative minds, is not physical and three-dimensional, but intangible, invisible and directly accessible to anyone with a computer and modem.

Things, sadly for the Dome, are just not what they used to be.
Alan Paterson
London alan.paterson@easynet.co.uk

Re Andy Dawson's letter (January 3), I came away from the Dome having seen the future, not so much in the official zones as in the scattering of stores and fast-food outlets. It seemed that global capitalism had taken the best toys for itself and was putting them to work. I was struck most by the animated 3D posters for Kodak film and the video screens behind the McDonald's counters; as for the changing colours of the rest zone, I, had seen the technology at work last week in a River Island clothes store. Even the digital avatars and videophones of the talk zone were part of a thinly disguised advertisement for British Telecom.
Will Brooker
London

webTitle: Saga of bugs in the IT programme

fields.headline: Saga of bugs in the IT programme
fields.trailText: It is interesting that the government computer system failures named (Report, January 5) were those purchased under PFI. The reason for purchasing IT under the scheme was to ensure that the government only paid for fully operational systems, the design, build and finance of these systems being entirely the responsibility of the contractor.
fields.body:
It is interesting that the government computer system failures named (Report, January 5) were those purchased under PFI. The reason for purchasing IT under the scheme was to ensure that the government only paid for fully operational systems, the design, build and finance of these systems being entirely the responsibility of the contractor.

These system failures have one common feature, caused in part by the purchasing methodology, and that is the failure to project-manage the contract on both or either side. It is worth remembering that the public and private sectors are significantly different, for good reasons. Their "yardsticks" are different. Since it is profit that counts to the private sector, companies can and do discard areas judged to be not promising against the criterion of profitability. The public sector cannot afford that luxury. The public agenda is essentially political; it is ultimately set by the public. The measure of efficiency in the public sector, therefore, is how completely the full range of issues can be anticipated to avoid failures in the system. It is the delivery of such service by efficient means at the lowest possible cost and within budgetary targets, that is the measure of public service efficiency. In the dynamic emerging digital environment, with IT central to the modernisation of government services, there has to be a better way of contracting for these services.
Sheila Beck
Oxshott, Surrey

I'm sure Duncan Campbell is right (The great bug panic, January 5) when he says "the millennium bug was a saga from Christian, calendar-based myths", but the hysteria was nevertheless entirely appropriate to the silicon age, as such millennialist anxieties are always founded on fears about the stability of the dominant ideology of the period, Christianity last time round, and this time, of course, scientific technology.
Donald Fraser
Glasgow
D.Fraser@strath.ac.uk

What is all this about the bug not striking? Since last Friday, whenever I try to fax from my computer, the software schedules it for 2028! I'm not well known for speedy responses - but 28 years?
Mike Greetham
Huddersfield
mike@greetham.com

Since it is profit that counts to the private sector, companies can and do discard areas judged to be not promising against the criterion of profitability. The public sector cannot afford that luxury. The public agenda is essentially political; it is ultimately set by the public. The measure of efficiency in the public sector, therefore, is how completely the full range of issues can be anticipated to avoid failures in the system. It is the delivery of such service by efficient means at the lowest possible cost and within budgetary targets, that is the measure of public service efficiency. In the dynamic emerging digital environment, with IT central to the modernisation of government services, there has to be a better way of contracting for these services. Sheila Beck Oxshott, Surrey I'm sure Duncan Campbell is right (The great bug panic, January 5) when he says "the millennium bug was a saga from Christian, calendar-based myths", but the hysteria was nevertheless entirely appropriate to the silicon age, as such millennialist anxieties are always founded on fears about the stability of the dominant ideology of the period, Christianity last time round, and this time, of course, scientific technology. Donald Fraser Glasgow D.Fraser@strath.ac.uk What is all this about the bug not striking? Since last Friday, whenever I try to fax from my computer, the software schedules it for 2028! I'm not well known for speedy responses - but 28 years? Mike Greetham Huddersfield mike@greetham.com

fields.headline: ... and the fatherless
fields.trailText: The two gay men who have made legal history by registering as parents of twins born to a surrogate mother in the US raises many questions. Legally it appears the mother's husband is the father, though he had not fathered them. As the mother is American, it may appear that the CSA cannot sue the father in the US and, as the children are officially Americans, it seems that they will require the granting of UK citizenship before the gay fathers can adopt them. Your leader (January 4) adds: "Their two male parents are rich, and have already engaged a leading law firm ... to fight officialdom." Children starting life as a "gleam in the lawyer's eye" seems an apt comment.
fields.body:
The two gay men who have made legal history by registering as parents of twins born to a surrogate mother in the US raises many questions. Legally it appears the mother's husband is the father, though he had not fathered them. As the mother is American, it may appear that the CSA cannot sue the father in the US and, as the children are officially Americans, it seems that they will require the granting of UK citizenship before the gay fathers can adopt them. Your leader (January 4) adds: "Their two male parents are rich, and have already engaged a leading law firm ... to fight officialdom." Children starting life as a "gleam in the lawyer's eye" seems an apt comment.

But the twins start life with three recognised fathers, so even if the worst comes to the worst, they will end up with at least one. Not so the case for one in four UK children. Around 800 children a week lose their father. Your own figures indicate that 50% of divorced fathers lose all contact with their children within two years. As more than a third of the children born in the UK are by unmarried parents, and separations in that category are much higher, the estimate of around 3m children without fathers might well be an underestimate. Put another way, one in four men who become fathers will never see their children grow up. It will be one in two within 10 years.

When the home office has sorted out the situation of the gay men, it might turn its mind to the incompetent family court welfare service, which does more to break up families than any other single cause due to its lack of training, money and time. Gay couples should of course be allowed to have families. Let's hope the best legal minds in the country can also turn their thoughts to what to do about parents who break court orders for contact with impunity.

The UK has the highest number of single-parent families in Europe, around 11%. By this time next year it will be about 12% and another 40,000-plus children will be fatherless.
Stan Hayward
London stan@hccat.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Plea for gay fathers ...
fields.trailText: We agree with your leader (January 4), Jack Straw should show more compassion than the immigration officials have done over the children of Tony Barlow and Barrie Drew. To present these loving parents with such a dilemma is unforgivable. A similar threat of separation from our own children was held over us more than 20 years ago, so we can understand the dreadful feelings these two young men are presently experiencing. We fought to avoid losing our children. Happily we succeeded, and in these more liberal times for gays and lesbians, we were beginning to believe that heartless attitudes which keep families apart in this way were coming to an end
fields.body:
We agree with your leader (January 4), Jack Straw should show more compassion than the immigration officials have done over the children of Tony Barlow and Barrie Drew. To present these loving parents with such a dilemma is unforgivable. A similar threat of separation from our own children was held over us more than 20 years ago, so we can understand the dreadful feelings these two young men are presently experiencing. We fought to avoid losing our children. Happily we succeeded, and in these more liberal times for gays and lesbians, we were beginning to believe that heartless attitudes which keep families apart in this way were coming to an end

As citizens of this country, these two young men should be entitled to bring their children up here, as they clearly wish to do. Jack Straw should explain the reason for the abysmal treatment they suffered at the hands of the immigration officials and reverse this decision immediately.
Bill Keeton and Ron Thompson
Chesterfield

The confused and uncertain start to their lives in the UK of the two babies brought over here by a gay couple was entirely predictable. The babies have arrived with no legal status recognised in the UK. No one outside of the two men knows who is the biological father; there were two women who are "mothers" to the children; and their day-to-day care will be supported by nannies who, inevitably, will be replaced by others over time. This entirely adult-centred process is little to do with the children's needs and any lack of security the children face is entirely the responsibility of the two men, who should have obtained clear legal advice before embarking on this selfish venture. The home office is right to look at this whole dubious process most carefully.

Of particular concern though is the future welfare of these two children. Let us remind ourselves why and how these children were created. The men could not obtain children via legal surrogacy in the UK. This is rightly only available to married couples, perhaps because parliament recognised it as a flawed procedure, having within it the intention of the surrogate mother to give her child for money, with marriage hopefully providing some normality to the inherent confusion. They then went to California and sought two women, one who supplied the eggs, the other the womb. Then, to compound future confusion for the children, only one of the men is the biological father but they will only tell the children which one when they deem the time is right

There are rights here that are being denied. They are, though, those of the children, whom, it seems, will have little chance of being able to answer the questions basic to identity formation - who is my mother, who is my father?
JM Richards
Catholic Children's Society

Immigration double standards in this country allows entry to a US-deported suspected Nazi war criminal, then denies entry to the new born babies fathered by two gay men. I know which the public would want in.
Dannie Bonner
Stafford
dannie_bonner@hotmail.co.uk

fields.headline: Hegelians' stock rises
fields.trailText: I can only agree with Ben Rogers (Bookshop philosophy, G2, January 4) that Waterstone's Charing Cross Road had the best philosophy section of any London bookshop. However, as buyer for that section from 1989 to 1998, I feel that Ray Monk cannot take all the credit. I had the pleasure of introducing Ray on a number of occasions at the many philosophy lectures I arranged at the shop and oversaw the substantial expansion of the philosophy department (including the British Hegelians).

I had the pleasure of introducing Ray on a number of occasions at the many philosophy lectures I arranged at the shop and oversaw the substantial expansion of the philosophy department (including the British Hegelians).

Since retiring from the hurly-burly of bookselling for the world of publishing, I have ceded my position as number one philosophy buyer to Phil at Compendium.
Martin Jenkins
London martinajenkins@yahoo.co.uk

Ben Rogers should not assume that all of Waterstone's branches are identical. Pressure of space may limit the amount of philosophy available for Northampton's public to browse through, but we are more than happy to order in their requests. What we do have (including Rogers's own biography of Ayer) is simply shelved alphabetically.
Drew Gray
Northampton

fields.headline: Maths year not a lottery
fields.trailText: To say Unesco made 2000 world mathematical year "for no particular reason" (Maths counts Tube posters, December 30) doesn't quite add up. The credit for the idea must go to the International Mathematical Union, which proposed the initiative in 1992. 2000 was chosen to underline the importance mathematics will have for the 21st century (proving nicely that mathematicians are not pedantic about when we opt to start the century).
fields.body:
To say Unesco made 2000 world mathematical year "for no particular reason" (Maths counts Tube posters, December 30) doesn't quite add up. The credit for the idea must go to the International Mathematical Union, which proposed the initiative in 1992. 2000 was chosen to underline the importance mathematics will have for the 21st century (proving nicely that mathematicians are not pedantic about when we opt to start the century).

As for the underlying reason, you pinpointed it: to raise awareness of the importance of mathematics for economic development. As maths uses a universal language, it is an area ideally suited for international co-operation. Unesco helps the poorest countries develop their mathematical research. Maths is a tool for bridging the gap between wealth and poverty across the globe, the greatest challenge of the 21st century.
Maurizio Iaccarino
Assistant director-general for Science, Unesco
Paris

Dare we hope the maths posters on the Underground will include practical applications, how to calculate the infinitesimal chance of winning on the Lottery, the true cost of "special offers", or how to estimate income tax etc, rather than puzzles and conundrums.
Norma Haemmerle
London

fields.headline: Out of tune
fields.trailText:
When I was a teenager in the 30s we used to sing popular music (Grammy awards, January 5) that had words and tunes, such as Red Sails in the Sunset, Home on the Range, and Singing in the Rain. In the war songs with tunes continued (Wish me Luck, Run Rabbit Run etc). But 50 years ago singers began to have sore throats and words and tunes disappeared. Are we ever to have pleasant tunes back?
Geoffrey Watson
Winchester

fields.headline: Nasty, but necessary
fields.standfirst: Runaway markets needed cooling down
fields.trailText: The markets melted yesterday, knocking $26bn off UK shares, following a record fall the previous day. That sounds like trouble.
fields.body:
The markets melted yesterday, knocking $26bn off UK shares, following a record fall the previous day. That sounds like trouble. And yet the world's economy has seldom looked healthier. The US, accounting for 35% of the wealth of the 29-nation OECD, has embarked on a record ninth successive year of positive growth. In the past four years its internet-driven economy has averaged a gravity-defying 4% a year without, so far, any worrying resurgence of inflation. Asia, the basket case of 1998, is recovering much faster than expected. The 11 countries of Euroland are at last poised to raise growth from 2% to 3%. The UK has confounded critics by expanding by almost 2% in 1999, instead of no growth at all as some feared. Even Russia managed to grow by between 1% and 2% last year after a contraction of 5% in 1998.

In these circumstances yesterday's meltdown was a necessary correction which could give the overheated markets the slow puncture they need to bring them back to reality. Stock markets cannot keep on rising by 20% a year as they have done in the US (and far more for the hi-tech stocks) without running into serious turbulence.

A "soft landing" for the world's overinflated stock markets is needed everywhere, but particularly in the US, where it could be critical in preventing an eventual implosion of the economy. Private consumption expanded by 5% a year in 1998 and 1999 as consumers went into debt to finance a spending spree, safe in the knowledge that their financial wealth (measured in exploding share prices) was still growing. But if a sudden slump in share prices turns this process into reverse and US consumers (whose imports have kept the rest of the world's industry in business in recent years) stop spending, then the world's exports could catch a severe cold.

In present circumstances, with synchronised expansion taking place all over the globe, central banks are probably right to think about a rise in interest rates, if only as a warning shot across the bows about the dangers of inflation. The only surprise is that the financial markets have taken such a long time to realise that a rise is probably imminent. Yet any rise should be modest - particularly outside America. Euroland is barely at the start of a recovery. It has lots of underutilised capacity and a current ac count surplus. It does not need a rise in interest rates either to check inflation or to prevent overheating. One of the reasons for US success (apart from the dynamism of its hi-tech sector) is the fact that Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve - whom President Clinton backed this week for a fourth term - was prepared to risk not raising interest rates to test whether the world was entering a new era of low inflation thanks to globalisation and the deflationary forces of the internet. This is a theory that Europe's central bank should now also test over a long period.

In Britain, the situation is complicated by the fact that while two-thirds of the economy (most of the service sector) may need a rise in rates, the remainder - especially manufacturing, farming and tourism - definitely does not. The south of England needs checking, but most of the north needs a drop in interest rates. Manufacturers are still suffering from the debilitating effects of the overvalued pound (notwithstanding the recent rise in activity caused by the rise in world trade). Higher interest rates would make it even more difficult to bring the pound down to a realistic level. Instead they would reinforce the doomsday scenario that has been forced on most manufacturers - that the strong pound is here to stay and they will have to live with it or die with it. They are following the only escape route open - firing workers and importing components instead of buying them from UK companies. That is why the latest figures show a 1.6% increase in service employment in the past year, but falls of 4.3% in manufacturing and 5.6% in agriculture and fishing.

The governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, tries to wash his hands of the matter by claiming that no one could seriously suggest that "we should put the whole of the economy at risk to protect certain parts". But the problem only arises because the government has so enthusiastically adopted the "one-club" economics policy -reliance on interest rates - that it castigated so much in opposition. Is it too much to suggest that it is possible to tackle the underlying problems (like housing, inflation and regional deprivation) with other weapons as well as with interest rates? After all, in this sophisticated age no one suggests that Concorde should be flown with one start/stop button.

webTitle: Clinton gets Middle East talks under way Israel and Syria reach milestone in talks

fields.headline: Clinton gets Middle East talks under way Israel and Syria reach milestone in talks
fields.standfirst:
Negotiations begin after two days of wrangling
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Syrian and Israeli delegations finally embarked yesterday on detailed negotiations aimed at reaching a lasting peace settlement, after two days of posturing and brinkmanship, and anxious mediation by the US president, Bill Clinton.
fields.body:
Syrian and Israeli delegations finally embarked yesterday on detailed negotiations aimed at reaching a lasting peace settlement, after two days of posturing and brinkmanship, and anxious mediation by the US president, Bill Clinton.

Joint committees of experts sat down with US arbitrators at a conference centre in Shepherdstown, West Virginia, to discuss the issues that have divided the two countries since Israel's creation in 1948: territory, security, water and the normalisation of relations.

Both Israeli and Syrian officials agreed that the committee meetings, the first such technical discussions for four years, marked an important milestone for the negotiations.

The talks had been bogged down for their first two days by procedural problems. Syria, led by the foreign minister, Farouk al-Shara'a, wanted to begin by discussing the return of the Golan Heights, captured by Israel in 1967.

Israel wanted to start with its chief area of concern, security, and in particular how Syria intends to stop attacks across the Lebanese border by the guerrilla movement Hizbullah, which is backed by both Syria and Iran.

President Clinton, who is determined to make the talks succeed, proposed a compromise, suggesting that security and territory be discussed simultaneously. The committees assigned to deal with border demarcation and water rights immediately held brief informal talks.

White House officials are reportedly making exploratory contacts with the American congress to pave the way for a massive US aid package which will be needed to make any peace agreement stick. The Syrian government needs economic aid, while the Israeli defence ministry has presented a shopping list of military hardware it wants to make up for the loss of the natural defensive barrier of the Golan.

James Rubin, the US state department spokesman, said Israeli newspaper reports that the list added up to $17bn (£10.4bn) and included cruise missiles were "wildly premature". But he did not deny them outright.

Mr Rubin said that the three-way meeting chaired by Mr Clinton on Tuesday had been "a very constructive and productive discussion that put the process clearly on track. But he added it was unlikely that an accord could be reached by the end of the week. White House aides said Mr Clinton had set aside the weekend and at least some of next week to allow him to join the talks if necessary.

The Israeli army pulled out of six bases and camps in the northern and southern West Bank yesterday as part of the transfer of 3% of the land to Palestinian civil rule.

The withdrawal was to be one of the last before Israel and the Palestinians draw their final borders in a peace treaty in September. Once the pull-outs are completed, the Palestinians will have full or partial control over 40% of the West Bank.

Today, the Palestinians are due to receive full control over an additional 2% of the land.
