Mr Rubin said that the three-way meeting chaired by Mr Clinton on Tuesday had been "a very constructive and productive discussion that put the process clearly on track. But he added it was unlikely that an accord could be reached by the end of the week. White House aides said Mr Clinton had set aside the weekend and at least some of next week to allow him to join the talks if necessary. The Israeli army pulled out of six bases and camps in the northern and southern West Bank yesterday as part of the transfer of 3% of the land to Palestinian civil rule. The withdrawal was to be one of the last before Israel and the Palestinians draw their final borders in a peace treaty in September. Once the pull-outs are completed, the Palestinians will have full or partial control over 40% of the West Bank. Today, the Palestinians are due to receive full control over an additional 2% of the land.

fields.headline: My back
fields.trailText: Rebbecca Ray: What item of clothing could be sexier than a dress that shows your naked back? An exposed back is beautiful, sensual without being overtly sexual, and there are very few parts of the body about which that could be said.
fields.body:
I sent off for a cosmetic surgery's price list once, full of excitement and the burning need to give someone else my money. It wasn't the tantalising read I thought it would be. And yet, gruesome and exorbitant though the list was, I still found myself wishing. Oh, the endless tucking and plucking and sucking, it's like a Toys R Us for grown-ups. They have an operation for every part of your body. Except your back.

Yes, it's true: back-jobs are unavailable. What a terribly cruel twist of fate this must be for people with overweight backs. And yet, thinking about it, I had never heard a woman complain about her back. Could all backs be equal? Surely not when Liz Hurley exists? (Actually, this is a matter of some debate: many believe Hurley is only a collection of pixels, through which the fresh air flows, unimpeded, like the wind between Hugh Grant's ears.)

The fact remains: my back is the only part of my body about which I have no reservations. Not only that, but it's undervalued. What item of clothing could be sexier than a dress that shows your naked back? An exposed back is beautiful, sensual without being overtly sexual, and there are very few parts of the body about which that could be said. It's also unusual; we're not desensitised to its exposure the way we are to cleavages or thighs. It's intimate.

My back isn't a girlie back, not the skinny, sticking-out shoulderblades kind. It's strong but I think it's still feminine and this is rare. I'd like to have the thighs of an 11-year-old, the hips of someone who's 13. But a back should be womanly, it should bring to mind the prowling lioness - a nice image when my womanly bottom brings to mind the prowling hippo. My back is free from Satan's foulest afflictions: cellulite, stretchmarks and spots.

My back is also very sensitive (I use it to sense armchairs at a hundred paces). I wouldn't go so far as to say it's an erogenous zone, but it is gorgeously ticklish. In fact, the possibilities of back-attention are endless: massaging, kissing, stroking. It's the ultimate indulgence, totally decadent, like Elizabeth Taylor as Cleopatra when Caesar walks in to find her being oiled. Back rubs suggest adulation; they are queenly, every woman should demand them. They're the ultimate self-esteem kick.

Basically, I love my back. It will never age or sag or bloat. It will never stand between me and that fifth eclair. And it will never, ever reduce me to the level of ordering plastic surgery price lists.

If you'll excuse me now, I have to go. The massage oil awaits.

webTitle: Fifa plans world cup for veterans

fields.headline: Fifa plans world cup for veterans
fields.standfirst: Fifa
fields.trailText: The race to find the best club side in the world has already started and it could soon be followed by a competition to find the best team of veterans on the planet.
fields.body:
The race to find the best club side in the world has already started and it could soon be followed by a competition to find the best team of veterans on the planet.

As Manchester United and other leading teams compete in Brazil for the accolade of being the world's premier club at the new world championships, Fifa, world football's governing body, is planning a world cup for senior and retired footballers.

The prospect of seeing the likes of Pele, Sir Bobby Charlton, Geoff Hurst and Michel Platini lacing up their boots and taking to the field once more is the brainchild of Antonio Matarrese, Fifa's vice-president.

The organisation has been considering a variety of competitions to try and sustain interest in the beautiful game and believes that a veterans world cup would be popular with spectators.

A Fifa spokesman said: "Former great players may not have the same pace and fitness levels but they still have lots of skill. There is a desire among fans to see former great players, but the crucial question will be whether they are capable of still playing."

Only former professional footballers aged 40 or over would be eligible to represent their country at the first veterans tournament which could take place before the 2002 World Cup in Japan and Korea.

Dr Matarrese, writing in Fifa's monthly magazine, claims that many senior and retired players have been overlooked when it comes to spreading football around the world.

But he warns that pitching retired professionals against today's young stars could be dangerous.

Dr Matarrese writes: "Football is of course a game based upon physical exercise and fitness. It would be foolish to advocate direct confrontation on the field of play between extremely fit young people and opponents a few decades older ... my concern is to provide greater opportunities for those older players who feel they are not, at the moment, receiving sufficient attention from the game's authorities."

A veterans world cup has already been discussed by Fifa's executive committee, which is now examining the cost.

Fifa is keen to follow the example of sports such as golf and tennis which have developed a lucrative veterans circuit drawing large crowds.

fields.headline: My feet
fields.trailText: Alice Thomas Ellis: I do appreciate the utility of the other parts, eyes, ears etc, but there is something about the unselfconscious humility of feet that is particularly affecting.
fields.body:
I have never been very interested in the body. I do not watch those TV programmes that explain where everything is and what it's for. I've scarcely seen a doctor in a professional capacity for 25 years and if I were constrained to visit one, I would not want him to give me any details about whatever condition was afflicting whichever organ or limb I was concerned about. I should request him simply to do what he had to do and let me go with the minimum of fuss.

I feel distant from my insides - which might as well be situated in Ulan Bator - while naturally trying not to abuse them, and hope they will continue to function adequately until the whole lot wear out in the course of time. Nor do I indulge in strenuous dieting or exercise, eating when hungry and drinking when dry, and finding running up and down stairs in search of things I've forgotten or mislaid quite sufficient to keep the blood coursing. Chasing and weight-lifting grandchildren takes care of the muscle tone and since none of the doors or windows fits too well, there is plenty of fresh air.

Besides, I was brought up during the war when there wasn't any junk food to interfere with or unbalance the vital processes. So, on the whole, apart from the exigencies of child-birth, I've never really needed to dwell much on the physical form, for which I'm properly grateful.

The aspects of it to which I am most indebted are, on reflection, my feet which have, as it were, stood by me through thick and thin. I do appreciate the utility of the other parts, eyes, ears etc, but there is something about the unselfconscious humility of feet that is particularly affecting. So much so that I once wrote a poem to my feet - with which I will not burden you. We were going for a walk and I suddenly noticed them going plod, plod through the mud and the fallen leaves, self-effacing and uncomplaining, while my hands, since I was carrying nothing at the time, just hung there, along for the ride, like distant aristocratic relations, too grand to acknowledge the workers bearing them forward.

Hands, of course, are indispensable, but they get far more attention than feet: people praise their dexterity and wave them about at times of emotion. Hands are almost always on stage and frequently the focus of the gaze, whereas feet generally go unremarked unless in exceptional circumstances - if you've fallen head first down a hole, for instance.

There are those who make a fetish of them but that seems uncalled for and vaguely insulting. Like all misplaced adulation, it loses sight of their true purpose and diminishes their value. I once knew a Freudian who held that foot fetishists got that way because her feet were the first bit of its mother a baby noticed when it woke, crying, in the night. It only takes a moment's thought to reject this explanation, unless the baby had fallen out of its cot and was lying on the floor - not, surely, a common occurrence, not one to initiate a life-long perversion.

I treat my feet kindly and with respect, never forcing them into unsuitable shoes, but giving them sandals or capacious boots to wear, depending on the season. Only once did I mistreat a foot. I dearly wanted to kick my spouse but thought it inadvisable, kicking the sofa instead. Unfortunately I hit on a wooden part and split a toe wide open. Even then I did not trouble the doctor nor look at it myself, but swathed it in a cloth and left it alone. After a few weeks it healed without trace of injury.

I am truly fond of my feet and shall continue to treat them with benevolent neglect while regarding them with respect. I shall let them take me for walks but I will never try to persuade them to go jogging.

webTitle: Gore trumps his rival with Kennedy ace

fields.headline: Gore trumps his rival with Kennedy ace
fields.trailText: Vice-president Al Gore's uphill struggle to prevent his Democratic rival Bill Bradley from winning the crucial New Hampshire primary next month received a huge boost yesterday when Senator Edward Kennedy gave his personal endorsement to Mr Gore as the Democratic party's White House choice.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Manchester, New Hampshire
fields.body:
Vice-president Al Gore's uphill struggle to prevent his Democratic rival Bill Bradley from winning the crucial New Hampshire primary next month received a huge boost yesterday when Senator Edward Kennedy gave his personal endorsement to Mr Gore as the Democratic party's White House choice.

The much-coveted Kennedy endorsement was carefully timed to take place only hours before the latest Gore-Bradley televised debate in New Hampshire last night, and came as the latest poll showed the two contenders in a statistical dead-heat in New Hampshire, where the first presidential primary takes place in less than four weeks' time, on February 1.

Mr Kennedy may be a political lion in winter these days, but his icon-like status within the party, his huge local influence in New England, his deep knowledge of the two rivals from their senate years, and his standing as the Democrats' most unrepentant liberal, give his backing for Mr Gore enormous weight.

With Mr Gore at his side, Mr Kennedy told reporters in his home town of Boston that the vice-president spoke for "our Democratic priorities" such as health care, education, good jobs and a clean environment.

Mr Gore had "the ability, the vision and the experience to lead this nation wisely and well in the coming years, and I'll be proud to stand with [him] in the great battles that lie ahead", Mr Kennedy said.

The latest poll, by the American Research Group (ARG), shows Mr Bradley commanding 42% of support among the state's Democratic voters, with Mr Gore on 39%.

Allowing for the poll's margin of statistical error, it puts the two men in a dead heat, and suggests that Mr Gore is narrowing the gap on Mr Bradley, who led by 12 points in a similar survey a month ago.

The closeness of the Democratic contest in New Hampshire lent fresh significance to last night's debate, for which both camps had promised a more combative approach, reflecting the more intense language of their campaigning since the new year.

Mr Bradley, who in every sense is the loftier candidate of the two and who has performed well in earlier match-ups with his rival, yesterday accused Mr Gore of campaigning in "desperation" and warned Democrats that the vice-president would be a weaker presidential nominee because of his questionable 1996 fund-raising tactics.

"The Republicans think it's a problem and I think they will use it in the fall campaign [if Mr Gore is the nominee]," Mr Bradley said.

Since campaigning resumed following the Christmas-new year break, both Mr Gore and Mr Bradley have sharpened their language in what had previously been a remarkably civil contest.

But with Mr Gore now using a much more aggressive campaigning style, repeatedly trying to raise doubts about Mr Bradley's policy pledges, both men now appear readier to resort to tried and tested political black arts.

With few major issues or ideas to divide them, Mr Gore has finally focused his assault on the charge that Mr Bradley's ambitious universal health care plan is unrealistic and too costly.

While Mr Bradley hit back this week with a counter-claim that the vice-president's supposedly more "responsible" health plan, which focuses on medicare plans for the poor and the elderly, would overspend federal balanced budget forecasts by $350bn over 10 years.

This week, choosing another new tack, Mr Gore said that Mr Bradley had given education reform a "short shrift" by comparison with his own plans for pre-school entitlements and said the Bradley plans were badly costed. A Bradley administration would "blunder into another recession", Mr Gore charged.

Mr Bradley said yesterday that he was "not going to stand by when people misrepresent my views", adding that Mr Gore's charges sounded "a bit to me like desperation".

webTitle: Irate Danes warn of bacon war

fields.headline: Irate Danes warn of bacon war
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Britain was last night facing a bacon war as Danish pig producers accused UK farmers of rubbishing their meat and treating them like Viking invaders.
fields.body:
Britain was last night facing a bacon war as Danish pig producers accused UK farmers of rubbishing their meat and treating them like Viking invaders.

The Danes claimed the struggling British industry's complaints over animal welfare and food safety abroad would undermine consumer confidence in pork throughout Europe and do nothing to help the £5.3bn a year trade in Britain.

Pig industry leaders blame a combination of the strong pound, measures to prevent any possibility of a BSE-like disease in pigs, and tougher welfare and food standards for threatening up to 25,000 jobs.

But the Danes said their £250m worth of bacon and gammon exports to Britain met all British standards. In addition, unlike British pigs, all their animals were free of growth-promoting antibiotics, and there were tougher controls to prevent salmonella.

Anne Birgitt Lundholt, managing director of Danske Slagterier, the Danish pig farmers' body, said: "We have so far resisted the temptation to enter into a war of words, but our patience is not inexhaustible."

Hinting at a massive new marketing campaign, she warned a farming conference in Oxford: "You must expect us to defend our corner if our integrity is being challenged."

Commenting on calls by some defenders of the British pig industry for modern day Danes to be repulsed, she said the latest "Viking invaders" had a resolve to succeed that was as strong as ever.

The meat and livestock commission in Britain apparently accepts that Danish export contracts meet all British standards but say around a third of its national pig herd is still raised to lower standards.

Meryl Ward, a Lincolnshire pig farmer and member of the pig industry support group, said: "We had costs that made us uncompetitive with the rest of Europe and we had to make a noise to make sure the public understood there was a difference." The Danish reaction suggested the campaign had been worthwhile, she added.

Robert Persey, a pig farmer from Honiton in Devon, accused the government of being determined to kill the British pig industry by not giving it sufficient support. Producers were losing £5.23 a pig "through no fault of our own".

But Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, told the conference he was urging public bodies, from the army to the NHS, to buy only supplies that met British standards, including meat from animals that were not raised in a narrow stalls system for breeding sows.

He was also planning changes in labelling rules to end misleading descriptions about where meat came from.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Warning on balconies
A coroner yesterday urged holiday firms to highlight the dangers of balconies after a 23-month-old British boy fell 30ft to his death from a Turkish hotel in June 1998.
fields.body:
Warning on balconies
A coroner yesterday urged holiday firms to highlight the dangers of balconies after a 23-month-old British boy fell 30ft to his death from a Turkish hotel in June 1998.

A verdict of accidental death was recorded on Brandon Bamforth by coroner Roger Whittaker at the Huddersfield inquest.

Jail chief's private post
The prison service's director of security, Elaine Bailey, yesterday announced her intention of joining a private prison company.

Ms Bailey will face home office vetting before she can take up her job with the US-owned Premier Prison Services, which runs Doncaster jail.

Footballer fined £200
England footballer Michael Gray was fined £200 yesterday for urinating in the street following his club's Christmas party.

The 24-year-old Sunderland defender pleaded guilty at Sunderland magistrates' court.

Council's court move
Wandsworth council in south-west London will next week launch a high court challenge to try to overturn a ruling by the government's school admissions watchdog that it must cut by up to half the number of pupils selected according to ability at three of its secondary schools. Rebecca Smithers

Jersey man named a hero
The courage of a Jersey man who hid a Jewish woman from occupying Nazi forces during the second world war was recognised by Israel yesterday.

Yad Vashem, Israel's Holocaust martyrs' and heroes' remembrance authority, said Albert Bedane, who died in 1980, had been recognised as a hero and awarded the title of Righteous Among Nations.

Atlantic feat
Diana Hoff, 55, has become the first British woman and oldest person to row solo across the Atlantic.

fields.headline: Dads match hormones of mums-to-be
fields.trailText: Expectant fathers experience a similar hormonal rollercoaster to that of their pregnant partners, according to research findings reported yesterday in New Scientist.
fields.body:
Expectant fathers experience a similar hormonal rollercoaster to that of their pregnant partners, according to research findings reported yesterday in New Scientist.

Researchers in Canada speculate that it might be nature's way of preparing a father for the birth of his baby.

webTitle: Towel ad is TV's most irritating

fields.headline: Towel ad is TV's most irritating
fields.trailText: The most irritating TV advertisement of the year is a commercial for a kitchen towel, according to a survey released yesterday.
fields.body:
The most irritating TV advertisement of the year is a commercial for a kitchen towel, according to a survey released yesterday.

Procter & Gamble's Bounty kitchen towels and their jingle "the stronger soaker upper" topped the chart of most hated advert of 1999 in a survey commissioned by Marketing magazine. The advert, created by Leo Burnett Frankfurt, irritated 44% of the 1,000 people surveyed for Marketing by NOP.

Respondents criticised the German TV commercial for the "grating jingle", "dubious acting" and "spurious product demonstration", the magazine said.

However, J Walter Thompson's Chicken Tonight adverts came a close second in the annoyance stakes, with 43%.

Footballer Ian Wright's star appearances in the campaign to launch the Sizzle and Stir varieties proved to be a bit of a turkey.

Running in third place was the Renault Scenic advert, a Sound of Music-themed offering featuring a car rolling off an idyllic green mountainside.

Other well-known commercials which made the most hated top 10 included the Benecol adverts featuring Carol Vorderman at five, Iceland's special offer adverts in eighth place and in the ninth spot, the Citroen Xsara adverts featuring Claudia Schiffer.

Despite being named in the advertising rogue's gallery, it is believed many of the products probably benefit from being so annoying.

A spokesman for Marketing magazine said: "It is assumed there is some correlation between an irritating advert and its memorability."

webTitle: If it doesn't smell right, blame left

fields.headline: If it doesn't smell right, blame left
fields.trailText: If something does not smell right, you are probably smelling with the left nostril. Californian researchers have discovered that a scent inhaled through the right nostril is on average more likely to seem pleasant than a whiff through the left.
fields.body:
If something does not smell right, you are probably smelling with the left nostril. Californian researchers have discovered that a scent inhaled through the right nostril is on average more likely to seem pleasant than a whiff through the left.

But, according to a report in New Scientist today, the left nostril is more discerning. Larry Cahill, of the university of California, and colleagues got 32 volunteers to use just one nostril to sniff eight smells ranging from lemon to peppermint, rate them, and identify them. Then, later, they repeated the test with the other nostril.

The left nostril was more likely to identify the smell correctly, the right more likely to appreciate it.

This, according to Dr Cahill, fits neatly with ideas about how the brain might process smells: each nostril sends its information to the appropriate hemisphere of the brain. The brain's right hemisphere handles emotional business; the left is associated with cooler forms of reasoning.

"Your emotional reaction to an odour actually depends on which hemisphere does the processing," he said.

webTitle: Intensive counselling may damage disaster victims

fields.headline: Intensive counselling may damage disaster victims
fields.standfirst:
British Psychological Association Conference hears of help that can do more harm than good, and when partners should stay silent
The British Psychological Society website
fields.trailText: People involved in traumatic incidents such as rail crashes, bombings or armed robberies may suffer more in the long run if they undergo intensive counselling, psychologists said yesterday.
fields.body:
People involved in traumatic incidents such as rail crashes, bombings or armed robberies may suffer more in the long run if they undergo intensive counselling, psychologists said yesterday.

Despite popular belief, "debriefing" - in which victims are encourage to relive their experiences immediately after the event by talking about them - may not help those suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder.

And, in certain circumstances the treatment, used after the Paddington rail disaster, the bombing of Manchester city centre and the Soho pub bombing, may even make their symptoms worse.

The warning was given at the British Psychological Association conference in Brighton, following research commissioned by the health and safety executive.

After analysing the results of seven random controlled trials, the researchers - from Birkbeck college, London, and the university of Sussex - found there was no evidence that debriefing helped victims in the long term but there was evidence that it had harmed them.

"At best its efficacy is neutral and at worst it can be damaging," said Jo Ricks, principal research fellow at the institute of employment studies at the University of Sussex.

"In one study of victims of road traffic accidents, those suffering from severe post- traumatic stress had worse symptoms a year after the accident if they underwent debriefing than those who did not." Such symptoms included flashbacks, emotional numbness and a heightened sense of fear.

Debriefing, which emerged in the early 1980s, was initially used for emergency service personnel. It is a highly structured form of counselling comprising a one-off session lasting several hours. It is offered between 24 and 72 hours after a traumatic incident.

Counsellors take an individual or a group through the incident, encouraging them to talk through their emotions.

"It's based on the principle of catharsis" said Dr Ricks. "The idea is that, by going through this in a very structured way, it enables people to make sense of what happened".

But Dr Ricks continued: "Feelings can be very complex and the idea that they can be dealt with in a one-off session is unrealistic.

"Debriefing is widespread in industry because there is an unquestioned belief in its success. However, it is a crude process which can be harmful to some people. Our concern is that the automatic inclusion of debriefing when tragedy strikes may present problems."

She said that, with 75% of all victims overcoming their post-traumatic stress disorder without debriefing, organisations such as banks and shops needed to assess whether it was necessary.

fields.headline: Union attack on church investment
fields.trailText: The Church of England reacted furiously yesterday when a leading trade unionist called on the Archbishop of Canterbury to review multi-million pound "unethical" church investments in the wake of his attack on materialism.
fields.body:
The Church of England reacted furiously yesterday when a leading trade unionist called on the Archbishop of Canterbury to review multi-million pound "unethical" church investments in the wake of his attack on materialism.

John Edmonds, the leader of the GMB union, questioned George Carey over the church's £6.8m shareholding in Marks & Spencer, which has recently forced thousands of textile workers on to the dole.

In a letter to the archbishop, Mr Edmonds reminded Dr Carey of his millennium sermon at St Paul's Cathedral in which he attacked the worship of wealth.

"As you may be aware the church is a major investor in Marks & Spencer, a company which is to blame for the sacking of thousands of British workers. We were wondering if you felt there was anything you felt you could do to intervene on behalf of the workers who are facing redundancy as a result of the materialism that you so rightly condemned."

A church spokesman insisted that the 2.2m M&S shares held by the Church Commissioners accounted for a fraction of the company's value. "You have to keep this in proportion or it become meaningless."

In his sermon on Sunday the archbishop said that the morality preached in the Sermon on the Mount now appeared "topsy-turvy".

The cry had now become "blessed are those who are rich because they will inherit the earth".

Marks & Spencer has ended a series of supply deals with British textile firms in favour of cheaper overseas deals.

webTitle: Oasis form their own record label

fields.headline: Oasis form their own record label
fields.standfirst: Oasis Official Site
fields.trailText: Noel Gallagher, guitarist and songwriter with Oasis, has confirmed that the group's new album will be released on the band's own label, ending a seven-year association with Creation Records.
fields.body:
Noel Gallagher, guitarist and songwriter with Oasis, has confirmed that the group's new album will be released on the band's own label, ending a seven-year association with Creation Records.

The formation of the new label, Big Brother, has been widely expected since November when Creation's chairman, Alan McGee, the man credited with discovering the band, said he would be leaving the company to pursue other projects.

In an interview with GQ magazine, Gallagher said that each of the band's five members would have an equal say in the running of the new label, which would also sign new acts.

The band released their previous three albums under licence to Creation in the UK, although they are officially signed to Sony, who in 1992 bought a minority stake in Creation for £3.5m. The new album will be distributed by Sony.

Oasis's decision to release records in the UK under their own imprint echoes the foundation of Apple Records by the Beatles, a huge influence on the group.

In November, a spokesman for the band described talk of a split with Creation as "com plete rubbish", but today confirmed that the band's fourth album, Standing on the Shoulders of Giants, would be released on the new label at the end of February, and that the label would be mainly staffed by former Creation employees.

webTitle: Discovery may lead to male contraceptive and aid fertility

fields.headline: Discovery may lead to male contraceptive and aid fertility
fields.trailText: British scientists believe they may have found a new approach to a male contraceptive pill. The same discovery, they think, could also produce a treatment for some forms of male infertility.
fields.body:
British scientists believe they may have found a new approach to a male contraceptive pill. The same discovery, they think, could also produce a treatment for some forms of male infertility.

Catrin Pritchard and Richard Evans of the University of Leicester report in Nature today that they were looking at the way a family of proteins worked in laboratory mice when they stumbled on a vital piece of machinery that introduced sperm to semen before ejaculation.

To study the effect of a gene, scientists "knock out" the gene from a test animal: then they can see, from what goes wrong, what the gene is really for.

They eliminated a cell-surface receptor called PX21 in a laboratory mouse.

The receptor is known to have some function in smooth muscles. It turned out to be important, however, in a tube called the vas deferens - the piece of plumbing in the male reproductive tract that gets tied up in a vasectomy.

"When we deleted this receptor in mice," said Dr Pritchard, "the sperm could no longer be ejaculated. But the sperm was still there, it just stayed in the testes.

"The mice could copulate normally, they just couldn't ejaculate sperm."

The guess is that humans and mice have the same basic reproductive arrangements. If so, it might be possible to devise a drug that would temporarily have the same effect on male humans - a kind of brief vasectomy.

The same discovery could also be used to help some males father children. "Malfunction of this receptor could explain some cases of male subfertility," Dr Pritchard said. "That would obviously be something we could look into."

The mice without the gene are apparently surviving normally. The receptor is also important in the muscle that lines the blood vessels.

"We thought that may result in differences in blood pressure. We've not found a significant difference yet," she said.

"They don't seem to have any behavioural abnormalities. It doesn't affect testosterone levels or anything like that. So men could be reassured they would be quite normal."

webTitle: Four in 10 now own mobile phone

fields.headline: Four in 10 now own mobile phone
fields.trailText: Four in ten Britons are carrying mobile phones after huge sales in the run-up to Christmas sealed the gadget's transformation from yuppie accessory to everyday item.
fields.body:
Four in ten Britons are carrying mobile phones after huge sales in the run-up to Christmas sealed the gadget's transformation from yuppie accessory to everyday item.

Figures released yesterday showed that more than 4.4m phones were sold in the last three months of 1999, taking the total number of handsets in use to 24m. That means there is more than one mobile phone for every household in the country.

The pace of growth has been driven by the introduction of pre-pay services, which allow users to keep a tighter control of costs by replacing monthly bills with credit vouchers. Pre-pay accounted for well above 80% of sales and has broadened the appeal of mobile phones to lower income groups.

The growth in mobile phone usage is expected to take another leap with the introduction this year of handsets that will allow internet access at speeds as high as PC modems. Within three years, video phones will also become commercially available.

"The use of mobile phones has been one of the greatest social changes of the past decade," said Alexander Gunz, a telecoms analyst at investment bank ABN Amro. "At the beginning of 1994 there were 2.5m people with mobile phones, which means the market has grown tenfold in just six years."

Orange was the best performing of the four networks in the last quarter of 1999, selling 1.4m phones. It shifted 1.2m of its Just Talk pre-pay kits at around £69.99 each and is widely thought to have won the battle for Christmas sales by removing the expiry date on its credit vouchers. Orange sold 856,000 phones in December alone.

"The people queueing up in the shops now are the same ones who 10 years ago were saying 'I'll never get one of those'," said Kenny Hirschhorn resident Orange futurologist.

Vodafone, the world's largest mobile phone company notched up 1.1m sales in the last three months of the year followed by BT Cellnet with 1m and One2One, the smallest of the four networks adding 903,000 customers. That figure included 100,000 from Virgin Mobile, One2One's joint venture with Richard Branson which launched in November.

The introduction of pre-pay has also proven popular for parents wanting to buy phones for their children without the fear of spiralling costs.

For once, take-up of a new technology in Europe has far outstripped North America. The most developed country in the world is Finland where 65% of the population now carry mobile phones. In the US the figure is around 29% and in Canada 20%.

Both markets have been hampered by a system where the person receiving the call is billed instead of the person making the call, making users reluctant to leave their phones switched on. The sheer size of the US and Canada has also meant national networks have been slow to develop.

webTitle: Diana fund faces £1m bill over memorabilia case

fields.headline: Diana fund faces £1m bill over memorabilia case
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The fund set up in memory of the late Diana, Princess of Wales, faces a legal bill of up to £1m after losing a US court battle over the commercial exploitation of her image.
fields.body:
The fund set up in memory of the late Diana, Princess of Wales, faces a legal bill of up to £1m after losing a US court battle over the commercial exploitation of her image.

A court in Los Angeles threw out a claim by the fund that Diana plates and a doll violated her "rights of publicity".

The decision opens up the prospect of more US firms cashing in on the market for Diana goods - many of which have been criticised for being tacky. It is a further blow for the fund which has endured criticism for the way it has distributed grants. The princess's brother, Earl Spencer, has called for the fund to be wound up.

Yesterday the fund said it would continue with its legal fight. The chief executive, Dr Andrew Purkis, said: "We are determined to assert our legal rights for the sake of vulnerable people who depend on the fund's efforts to continue the princess's humanitarian work round the world."

He claimed that the case had secured a change in Californian law, which meant the fund could bring further court actions in the future.

Franklin Mint, the Pennsylvania-based company which produced the gifts, said it was pleased by the decision of the appeal court in Los Angeles.

"We would never do anything to harm Princess Diana's image nor the respect that we know the British people have for her memory," it said.

A spokesman added that it would be "actively considering" the recovery of its costs for the two-year case, which legal sources estimated could reach £1m.

The fund - which has pledged £25m in grants since it was set up - said it would not face any claim for costs until the outcome of a further hearing scheduled for later this year. This will decide on a second claim that Franklin Mint misled its customers about how the money raised from the sale of its goods would be distributed to Diana's causes.

A proportion of the money raised by the sale of the mint's memorabilia ($2.5m so far) goes to causes dear to the princess, but not to the memorial fund itself.

fields.headline: Pinochet in hospital check-up
fields.standfirst:
General, 84, given medical tests to ensure he is fit enough to be extradited to Spain
Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The Augusto Pinochet circus rolled up at a London hospital yesterday, where the ageing and apparently ailing general underwent a series of medical tests designed to find out whether he is fit enough to be extradited to Spain.
fields.body:
The Augusto Pinochet circus rolled up at a London hospital yesterday, where the ageing and apparently ailing general underwent a series of medical tests designed to find out whether he is fit enough to be extradited to Spain.

A team of senior doctors spent more than six hours examining the former Chilean dictator, who is wanted on charges of torture, inside the concrete edifice of the Northwick Park NHS hospital in Harrow.

The results of the tests are not expected to be known for at least three weeks, when they will be sent in confidence to the home secretary, Jack Straw, Pinochet himself and government legal advisers. If the doctors do find Pinochet, 84, is as ill as his supporters claim, it could pave the way for Mr Straw to send the general back to Chile on humanitarian grounds.

In an elaborate manoeuvre, his entourage avoided the press as they left his rented home in Surrey just before 8am yesterday morning by driving around the roads of the private Wentworth estate and leaving through a back exit.

The cavalcade arrived at Northwick Park just over an hour later. Squashed between two bodyguards in the back of a silver people carrier, the general was accompanied by a delegation from the Chilean embassy and two doctors, his Surrey GP and a Chilean physician, who were allowed to observe the medical tests.

While the rest of the patients at the hospital queued up in the packed waiting rooms, where doctors were trying to catch up after the Christmas and new year holidays, Pinochet was taken through the back door to the Lister unit for infectious diseases where he was examined in isolation for security reasons. While police with sniffer dogs patrolled outside and officers stood guard at the doors, Pinochet was examined by a team led by two gerontologists and a neurologist, before being whisked back to Wentworth in the late afternoon.

He is said to be suffering from renal problems, possibly brought on by diabetes, a heart condition and a neurological condition, which has manifested itself in three minor strokes. He is also said to be suffering from depression, brought on by his 16 months under house arrest.

Supporters of the general de cided some time ago that his best chance of being returned to Chile, rather than being sent to Spain to be tried for torture, rested with the humanitarian option.

Various stories were leaked to the press, including an account of how a priest had been called to the general's Wentworth home to administer the last rites after he took a sudden turn for the worse. He recovered sufficiently for the priest not to be needed when he finally arrived.

Pinochet's problems

A team of senior doctors spent more than six hours examining the former Chilean dictator, who is wanted on charges of torture, inside the concrete edifice of the Northwick Park NHS hospital in Harrow. The results of the tests are not expected to be known for at least three weeks, when they will be sent in confidence to the home secretary, Jack Straw, Pinochet himself and government legal advisers. If the doctors do find Pinochet, 84, is as ill as his supporters claim, it could pave the way for Mr Straw to send the general back to Chile on humanitarian grounds. In an elaborate manoeuvre, his entourage avoided the press as they left his rented home in Surrey just before 8am yesterday morning by driving around the roads of the private Wentworth estate and leaving through a back exit. The cavalcade arrived at Northwick Park just over an hour later. While the rest of the patients at the hospital queued up in the packed waiting rooms, where doctors were trying to catch up after the Christmas and new year holidays, Pinochet was taken through the back door to the Lister unit for infectious diseases where he was examined in isolation for security reasons. webTitle: Counting chimp the equal of four-year-olds at arithmetic

fields.headline: Counting chimp the equal of four-year-olds at arithmetic
fields.trailText: Apes could be as good at arithmetic as many four-year-old children in Britain, with a female chimpanzee called Ai able to place Arabic numerals from 1 to 9 in ascending order, researchers reveal in the magazine Nature today.
fields.body:
Apes could be as good at arithmetic as many four-year-old children in Britain, with a female chimpanzee called Ai able to place Arabic numerals from 1 to 9 in ascending order, researchers reveal in the magazine Nature today.

Even more importantly, she can also remember a sequence of up to five numbers at a time. This puts her at the same level as many pre-school children in Britain.

Two Japanese researchers at Kyoto university trained Ai to use a touch sensitive screen and to recognise Arabic numerals.

They then worked out a way of testing her memory.

Adults can easily memorise phone numbers and post codes if they are up to seven items long.

The "magic number seven" effect, as it is known, represents a limit to the number of items that can be handled simultaneously by the brain.

The scientists, who were led by Nobuyuki Kawai and Tetsuro Matsuzawa, tested Ai to determine the equivalent "magic number" in a chimpanzee.

They gave her a set of five numbers on the screen and asked her to choose them in ascending order - something she could already do with perfect accuracy.

But once she had selected the first number, they masked the others with white squares.

This meant that Ai also had to remember the numbers' positions. With tests involving four numbers, she scored 90% success. With five, she got things right 65% of the time.

It was the second such demonstration of primate perceptiveness in 15 months. In 1998, a team at Columbia university in New York showed that rhesus monkeys could master mental arithmetic at least as well as a two-year-old child.

Ai demonstrated not only that she understood the concept of numbers, she could also concentrate better than a two-year-old.

"In one testing session, after Ai had chosen the correct number and all the remaining items were masked by white squares, a fight broke out among a group of chimpanzees outside the room, accompanied by loud screaming," say the scientists.

"Ai abandoned her task and paid attention to the fight for about 20 seconds, after which she returned to the screen and completed the trial without error."

webTitle: Kashmir body may be hostage Briton

fields.headline: Kashmir body may be hostage Briton
fields.trailText: Foreign office officials and Scotland Yard forensic experts were last night attempting to confirm reports that DNA tests carried out by Indian authorities proved that an exhumed body was that of the British backpacker Paul Wells, kidnapped by Kashmiri rebels five years ago.
fields.body:
Foreign office officials and Scotland Yard forensic experts were last night attempting to confirm reports that DNA tests carried out by Indian authorities proved that an exhumed body was that of the British backpacker Paul Wells, kidnapped by Kashmiri rebels five years ago.

New tests on a body exhumed in the north of the region three and a half years ago appear to confirm it was that of the photography student from Blackburn, Lancashire, but they contradict earlier findings by the Metropolitan police who examined DNA and dental evidence in 1997 and 1998.

Now the foreign office and police are considering a possible third round of DNA testing and forensic officers are on stand-by to fly out.

Mr Wells was 24 when he was abducted along with six other tourists on a mountain trekking trip in July 1995 by members of Al-Faran, a previously unknown Islamic militant organisation and one of many groups fighting to separate the Himalayan region from India.

One of their demands was the release of Maulana Masood Azhar - the man finally freed as a result of the Indian Airlines hi-jacking a week ago.

Last night Mr Wells's mother, Diane, said while she was convinced Paul was dead the family was still upset by the confusion surrounding his disappearance. His father, Bob, said his son's memory had been "betrayed" by the release of Azhar.

One of the hostages kidnapped with Mr Wells, an American, escaped and the body of another, from Norway, was found beheaded. The other hostages were last sighted in southern Kashmir in December 1995.

Detectives investigating the case said Al-Faran was a front name for the Harkat-ul-Ansar group, one of the most prominent among groups fighting in Kashmir.

The body Indian authorities now believe was Mr Wells was exhumed from Akingam, a village in southern Kashmir, in July 1997. Initial tests could not conclusively prove that the body was that of Mr Wells and it was flown to several cities in India before the central forensic science laboratory confirmed that the DNA of the body matched the blood samples of Wells's parents.

The Harkat-ul-Ansar was renamed the Harkat-ul-Mujahideen after it was put on a list of terrorist organisations by the United States. The group is based in Pakistan.

webTitle: Tories split over seats to target

fields.headline: Tories split over seats to target
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague's American skiing holiday was disrupted again yesterday when his aides were forced on the defensive over the party's plans for the general election.
fields.body:
William Hague's American skiing holiday was disrupted again yesterday when his aides were forced on the defensive over the party's plans for the general election.

Party officials insisted that they would be fighting to unseat Labour after activists called on Mr Hague to lower his sights and concentrate on winning back traditional Tory seats which fell to Labour in 1997.

One former MP, who is hoping to return to parliament, said that central office had set an unrealistic target of capturing 200 seats in the general election, expected to be held in the spring of next year.

The MP said the party should concentrate on capturing around 50 of the most winnable seats because hardly anyone expected the Tories to overturn Labour's 178-seat majority.

A Tory spokesman declined to comment on the size of the party's target list because Conservatives want to guard their election plans. But sources said that the party chairman, Michael Ancram, would stand by his target of 200 because Tories were aiming for victory.

"Anyone who stands up and suggests that we should aim for only 50 seats will be laughed out of court," one source said. "This shows that with 18 months to go until the election people are getting twitchy."

Tory MPs say privately that Mr Hague will have done well if the Tories win back more than 50 seats, particularly given the party's dismal standing in the opinion polls. But Mr Ancram is insisting that he is aiming for victory because he believes that support for Labour is thin.

"We were wiped out in 1997, but Labour should never forget that this was done with less than the vote John Major won in 1992," one Tory said. "Tories did not come out and vote for Tony Blair in 1997 - they just didn't vote for John Major."

The new row over party tactics came as Labour attempted to exploit renewed Tory divisions over Mr Hague's leadership. On Tuesday the former deputy prime minister, Lord Howe, joined the fray when he warned that the Tories were not a credible alternative government because Mr Hague had abandoned the centre ground.

Margaret Beckett, the leader of the Commons, said: "William Hague's lurch to the right shows that the Tories haven't listened, they haven't learned and they still can't be trusted.

"While New Labour has set its hand to modernising Britain the Tories are stuck in the past and are now prisoners of their own growing extremism."

webTitle: Banks make lepers of the poor, says study

fields.headline: Banks make lepers of the poor, says study
fields.standfirst: Newcastle University website
fields.trailText: Building societies that become banks ruthlessly shut branches in deprived areas, creating a "class of social lepers excluded from mainstream society", according to research from the university of Newcastle upon Tyne.
fields.body:
Building societies that become banks ruthlessly shut branches in deprived areas, creating a "class of social lepers excluded from mainstream society", according to research from the university of Newcastle upon Tyne.

The newly converted banks were expected to close branches to maximise shareholders' profits, but the extent of the damage to deprived areas had not been understood, the five researchers discovered.

Richard Willis, of the centre for urban and regional studies, told the geographers' conference that the short term gains for some were at the expense of society as a whole. Since 1990 around 10,000 branches of banks and building societies had closed. Because people tended to shop where they drew their money from, the bank closure had a knock-on effect on the neighbourhood.

Where all mainstream financial outlets closed the deprived and least financially adept people were forced to go to money lenders, pawnbrokers and credit unions, said Mr Willis.

The survey covered the period 1995 to 1998 when eight building societies converted to banks. The re searchers looked at affluent and deprived areas, urban and rural, in Edinburgh and Lothian, Northumberland, Tyne and Wear, West Midlands, Bristol and Avon, and Hertfordshire. In that time building societies opened 242 branches and closed 227, while the new banks opened 105 and closed 282.

In the more deprived areas, the building societies converted into banks closed 44 branches and opened 22. By contrast, building societies opened 51 new branches in these areas and closed 32.

Mr Willis said building societies were able to keep branches open with less profit margin than the new banks, which had to satisfy shareholders as much as customers.

He said there were now 69 building societies, compared with 101 in 1990.

It was in the poorest section of society, where 10% did not have access to a telephone, that lack of financial services amounted to social exclusion.

"They become social lepers excluded from mainstream society. When financial services go to another location, so do the shoppers.

"It has a knock-on effect on local traders, and even on prospective employers," he said.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Violin (R3) | In Business (R4)
fields.body:
Andrew Manze begins a nine-part series exploring the evolution of The Violin (4.0pm, Radio 3), opening with performances on two instruments preserved in the Salzburg museum and once owned by Mozart. The first is the half-sized version the composer used from the age of six, played by the 12-year-old Austrian prodigy Maria-Elisabeth Lott in a quite stunning interpretation of the Sonata in G (K301). Yuuko Shiokawa demonstrates Mozart's adult instrument in his Sonata in G (K379).

Economists, as ever, are split down the middle about the state of the stock market, where the indices continue to rise and rise, and of the broader economy. One group has been proclaiming for two years or more that the boom must end in tears. The other looks at low unemployment and negligible inflation to foresee unparalleled prosperity. Peter Day gets some of them together for In Business (8.30pm, Radio 4) to gaze into their crystal balls.

fields.headline: The end of the line
fields.trailText: The X Files | Bomber | My Mate Charlie
fields.body:
The story has to stop sometime. At least, that used to be the idea. The Old Testament was the story for Jews. Christians continued - or so they believe - the narrative in the New Testament. Islam had its own prophet and its own stories about what God expected of us. But who is to say when the story ends? Dogma, a film now probably at a cinema near you, has Alanis Morissette playing God, since She is female, and a black actor (Chris Rock) playing Rufus, Jesus's 13th Disciple who was written out of history because he was black. Eat your heart out Salman Rushdie, the world is full of people who want to continue the story as if it belonged to them.

The X Files (BBC1) - yes, I'm afraid it is back again, for the sixth time - is another neverending story and shows no signs of tiring of its debate between Faith and Doubt, personified respectively by Agents Mulder (David Duchovny) and Scully (Gillian Anderson). Will Mulder ever get it into his pretty little head that aliens don't exist? Will Scully, the Doubting Thomas of our age, ever accept that Mulder is right - aliens are in our midst and who knows what conspiracies have been woven around their existence?

One of the strange things about The X Files is that its story of Faith and Doubt is not only played out between Mulder and Scully - the series itself has become a matter of faith. Do we believe in its creator Chris Carter, and his team of writers, or have we lost faith in the whole, long-winded project? Are we thrilled to be told that that the production of the series has moved to California? Can we give a damn?

Last night's episode, The Beginning, is intended to bring us up to speed, to remind us where we've got to, what with Scully having been infected by an alien virus, and Mulder and Scully having seen (didn't you see the movie?) an alien spaceship pull itself out of a polar icecap and fly off into the skies. It is all very confusing. Even Mulder and Scully probably need time to warm up after the polar shenanigans.

The Beginning turned out to be almost a parody of The X Files. Write me a letter (I've had a few rude ones lately) if I miss anything out, but here are some of the components: Scully lets Mulder down in front of an FBI board; the boy who can read other people's minds (and can therefore be used to find an alien who has hatched out of some poor human being) has been kid napped; meanwhile bad stuff is going down at a nuclear installation where the alien is hiding; Mulder and Scully have been taken off the X Files, the Cigarette Smoking Man (not to mention the Elders) are conspiring on overtime; and most of this episode seems to have been filmed in the dark (either that or aliens are interfering with my televi sion set). The truth is still out there but many a fan may be about to recant the faith. Hang on in there, friends tell me, it is going to get better. But how do I know my friends aren't aliens?

Meanwhile, ITV has been telling us that "Anyone can be a bomber. Anything can be a bomb." Bomber, as Nicholas Barber told us in G2 yesterday, had "everything an audience could possibly want: sex, suspense and house-levelling explosions". This, alas, was part of the problem - Rob Heyland's very professional script seemed too anxious to deliver everything the thriller genre demands. He also seemed to be short of a convincing bomber. The bomber in our midst might have been rented from a Stephen King novel. The first explosion was terrible; the last one laughable.

My Mate Charlie (C4) was as appreciative of cocaine as Sherlock Homes was, but it didn't neglect the downside, all those rotting noses, ruined lives and bouts of paranoia. Regular users never know when they might be out in the garden looking in the bushes for the person who is out to get them. Maybe Agent Mulder is a sniffer and all those aliens are just a consequence of what has gone up his nose. The FBI should give him a blood test.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.standfirst: Satelite, cable and digital
fields.trailText: Satelite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Anaconda (Luis Llosa, 1997) 8pm, Sky MovieMax

OK, so it might be an interminably slow boat trip up the Amazon and the story's hard to swallow, but once the intrepid film-makers finally stumble on the 40-foot long killer snake it's all worthwhile. Who will survive the big squeeze when it comes? Cool cameraman Ice T? Boffin Eric Stoltz? Director Jennifer Stoltz? Maybe. But you can bet from the start that crazed snake-hunter Jon Voight, whose leer is rather more Monty Python than awesome anaconda, is in for a predictably gruesome end.

Funny Bones (Peter Chelsom, 1994) 8pm, FilmFour

The comedy is closer to tragedy in Chelsom's quirky follow-up to Hear My Song. Oliver Platt plays an up-and-coming comic falling flat on his face in Las Vegas and returning to the Blackpool roots of his ever-so-successful dad, Jerry Lewis. There he unearths long-buried family secrets, Lee Evans (pictured) as a neo-Norman Wisdom, and Oliver Reed being not very funny. Weird plot, but some good jokes, too.

Eddie Irvine: The Inside Track 10pm, C4

Eddie Irvine seems to be living most men's dream: an annual income of about £4m, homes in exotic places, a private jet, a yacht and a constant supply of willing girls. He doesn't, of course, have the Formula One championship (he missed it by all of one point), and in this revealing documentary he doesn't show too many likeable qualities: off-handed arrogance and his famed cavalier attitude towards women, to name but two. But at least he has more than a smattering of personality, in wild contrast to most of his wooden fellow drivers.

The Mark Thomas Product 11.05pm, C4

The irrepressible comedian is back on the warpath for a fifth series. Some of his targets can be uncomfortably soft, but he starts off with a cracker: the vagaries of the intelligence services and the Official Secrets Act, and he is dead chuffed to find that MI5 has a file on him (if not entirely accurate). After four series, however, it must be getting harder for him to go about his business, as even the police, who gently move him on from MI6 headquarters, admit to being fans of the programme, and know full well how they're going to look if they're caught on camera.

The 20th-Century Garden 8pm, C4

Reinforcing the notion that this is a nation of eccentrics, this three-part series cheerfully shows how far people have gone to create their own green and pleasant land over the past 100 years.

fields.headline: The usual suspects
fields.standfirst: The millennium has prompted a deluge of TV programmes telling us how we're going to be living in the future. The only problem is, says  Tim Radford  , they always feature exactly the same pundits, saying exactly the same things...
fields.trailText: The millennium has prompted a deluge of TV programmes telling us how we're going to be living in the future. The only problem is, says Tim Radford , they always feature exactly the same pundits, saying exactly the same things...
fields.body:
To film the future, first bleach your backdrop. For some reason, nothing about the future is ever rusty, or caked with crud. Furnish the set with shapes gleaming and curved, to indicate a smooth slide towards terminal technology.

Dub in some music for futurity (fin-de-siècle Viennese works very well). Film some tomorrow people, such as a scrubbed and powdered baby or two. These babies must not express any emotion: wide-eyed wondering is the look that works best. Just think what decor and actors and music like that did for Stanley Kubrick in 2001: A Space Odyssey.

Introduce a narrator with a minimum of inflection. Get him or her to say something solemn, but non-committal, about the startling shape of things to come. Then bring on the professional futurologists. You could decapitate them, and just mount their heads on one of your curved surfaces (being careful to do it all with what are known in the trade as Left Nostril Shots). Or you could turn them into apparent holograms, or you could have them apparently doing something with pipettes and test tubes, still pointing the camera up their left nostrils.

Actually, scientists important enough to appear on programmes like this hardly ever touch test tubes, but why spoil the imagery? Bear in mind Arthur C Clarke's Third Law, which begins: "When a distinguished and elderly scientist states that something is possible, he is almost certainly right." For programmes like these, scientists don't have to be elderly, just grizzled enough to seem to know the score, to be men of the world. They don't even have to be distinguished: your programme will distinguish them.

But they do have to be articulate, and to say things that sound alarming. Such people will have been saying much the same things in books, in newspaper interviews (and don't think we aren't grateful to them) and at conferences for years. That, of course, is why they appear so articulate.

If your programme is to be about the technological future, the day of the cyborg and the march of the machine, go for Kevin Warwick, professor of cybernetics at Reading, author of The March Of The Machines (and part-time cyborg? - he had a chip sewn in his arm which literally opened doors for him in his own department). Prof Warwick will cheerfully predict that machines will take over the world, and beat us, unless we join them by becoming cyborgs. Or Ian Pearson, BT's own futurologist ("Much more accurate than Mystic Meg, much cheaper, but about the same dress sense") who reckons - actually he said it again in the Guardian last week - that machines will get smarter and nicer and eventually we'll be able to cheat death by backing up our minds on the internet and downloading them into obliging androids.

And if you were planning a programme about what genetics could do for the human race in the next century (Life And Death In The 21st Century, the last in a Horizon trilogy, tonight, 9.30pm, BBC2), how could you not include Lee Silver?

Silver is a distinguished and not very elderly Princeton prof who says that, in a winner-take-all world, the rich will reprogramme their children with better and better genes, so that eventually they will be so different from the children of ordinary people that there will be two human races, unable to breed with each other, one group composed of persons of great beauty, high intelligence and astonishing athletic skill, and the rest of us looking pretty much like the Royle family.

The one sure thing about the future is that at any time (especially a time like this) a television producer is preparing a 50-minute special about the future. And on it will appear at least one, and perhaps more, of a cast of the usual suspects, long selected by the media - including this newspaper - as gurus with necks perfectly designed for sticking out. And, if satellite links and lungpower permit, one of them is likely to be Arthur C Clarke himself, who has been predicting the future for nearly six decades, sometimes getting it dead right.

But predicting the future is a nightmare occupation. Even the cleverest get it wrong. The capacity of great minds to conjure up a future that stubbornly refuses to arrive is so pronounced that GK Chesterton - he was actually taking a poke at HG Wells at the time - in 1904 proposed that ordinary mortals were involved in a game of Cheat-The-Prophet: people listened politely to what seers foresaw, and then stubbornly went and did the opposite.

He never foresaw television, but then, according to a wonderful 1962 book by Arthur C Clarke called Profiles Of The Future (and just updated and reissued by Gollancz for the millennium) nobody else saw television coming either. Which should tell you something about futurology, even on television.

webTitle: MPs name and shame town halls with councillors fiddling housing benefit

fields.headline: MPs name and shame town halls with councillors fiddling housing benefit
fields.trailText: Two MPs yesterday named and shamed 57 authorities for allowing councillors and officials to put in fraudulent housing benefit claims.
fields.body:
Two MPs yesterday named and shamed 57 authorities for allowing councillors and officials to put in fraudulent housing benefit claims.

The MPs reveal that 382 councillors and officials have been caught fiddling the housing benefit system and getting away with an average of £2,200 in fraudulent claims. The average fiddle by claimants is £550 a time.

The council fraud was described as "staggering" and "incredible " by Gerry Steinberg, Labour MP for Durham, and Charles Wardle, Tory MP for Bexhill - who demanded the information. They were even more shocked when they were told that some councils do not prosecute, and as a result no national records are kept of fraudulent officials or councillors.

They sought the information as part of an inquiry by the Commons public accounts committee into housing benefit fraud. They were told initially that the names of the authorities were being kept secret by the audit commission, the monitoring body, which refused to disclose them in last year's annual review.

In London, 12 out of the 32 boroughs reported cases of fraud including Labour controlled Hackney, Hounslow, Lambeth, Lewisham, Hammersmith and Fulham, Tower Hamlets and the then Labour controlled borough of Islington. Tory boroughs included Westminster, Harrow and Barnet.

Fraud was also reported among big city councils from Tory Bournemouth; Liberal Democrat Liverpool, to Labour controlled Bristol, Sheffield, Blackburn, Walsall, Wolverhampton, Leeds, Birmingham and York.

Fraud among officials and councillors was also reported in rural backwaters, notably Cotswold, Castle Morpeth, Chiltern and Tewkesbury.

MPs were also told that many authorities reported they had prosecuted no one and never supplied any data to central government. This included a number of authorities which admitted fraud had been going among officials and councillors, including the London boroughs of Hackney and Hammersmith and rural authorities like Chiltern and Castle Morpeth.

Rachel Lomax, permanent secretary at the department of social security, admitted to MPs that it was "a deplorable situation" claiming that the problem would be solved by a government ethical policy for councillors and officials.

But Mr Steinberg said: "It might be government policy, but it seems to me that it is pussyfooting around, to be quite honest. If I found a local authority where members and officials were fiddling the books I would do something about it. Frankly, I would not be waiting for an ethical policy to come along or whatever it is called. It is an incredible statistic."

fields.headline: Computers
fields.standfirst: The digital revolution won't even pause for breath in 2000. Get ready for another year of rapid change - in the devices we use to surf, in the way we get connected and in what we do when we're online. Fledgling e-retailers and music industry giants had better brace themselves for a tough 12 months
fields.trailText: The digital revolution won't even pause for breath in 2000. Get ready for another year of rapid change - in the devices we use to surf, in the way we get connected and in what we do when we're online. Fledgling e-retailers and music industry giants had better brace themselves for a tough 12 months
fields.body:
The "convergence" of computing and consumer electronics will be one of the themes of the year. Games consoles are becoming as powerful as PCs, while the PC industry is trying to make its products as easy to use as games consoles. Indeed, some PC companies may start manufacturing games machines, and Microsoft is working on a schematic console design, code-named X-Box. Its chairman, Bill Gates, may have announced plans in this area after Online went to press, during his show-opening "new millennium keynote" speech at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas last night.

Using PC technologies in a games console has been tried before: in Sega's Dreamcast console, launched in the UK last October. Many more PC manufacturers will target a growing market for simplified computers designed to access the internet. Hewlett-Packard's ePC, Compaq's iPaq, and Dell's webPC should be among the flood of machines running Microsoft Windows 98.

Cheaper and simpler pad-like "web companions" may also appear in the UK, if they achieve reasonable success in the US. Like Sega's Dreamcast, some of these run Microsoft's Windows CE (originally Consumer Electronics) operating system. Others will run a version of Be Inc's BeOS called Stinger - which Compaq has licensed -or QNX, or Microware's OS9, or GNU/Linux.

Games consoles will become more like PCs. First, they'll offer internet access, like Sega's Dreamcast. Second, they'll have high-capacity DVD (Digital Video Disk) drives instead of CDs or cartridges. The most eagerly-awaited example is the Sony PlayStation 2, to be launched at the Tokyo Games Show in Japan on March 4. Nintendo's next-generation console, code-named Dolphin, will probably be unveiled at Space World in Japan in August. European gamers will have to wait until at least 2001.

Britons will be offered other digital technology products, including disc-based video recorders like the TiVo (launched in the US last year) and "white goods" like the Ariston washing machine, which can be operated using a mobile phone (launched in Italy last year).

Standard PCs probably won't change that much in 2000, but they will get faster. Both AMD and Intel will ship processors that run at 1000MHz (1GHz) or more. But interest could fall in faster chips if Microsoft's Windows 2000 operating system catches on. Windows 2000 was completed last year, but a retail launch is planned for February 15 in San Francisco. Based on Windows NT (New Technology), it handles more than one processor as standard, and in businesses is often used in four- and eight-way servers. Desktop PC users should find that two slower (500MHz) processors are not just cheaper than one 1000MHz screamer, they work better, too.

The year will see more rapid progress in the handheld and notebook markets, where performance is still hardware-limited, and profits are higher. Mobile machines will also start to communicate better thanks to Bluetooth (short range radio) and wireless networking, as handhelds start converging with mobile phones. But don't think any category of device is going to replace any other. So far the only really successful convergence product is the radio alarm clock, and that didn't make either clocks or radios obsolete.

fields.headline: E-commerce
fields.standfirst:
The digital revolution won't even pause for breath in 2000. Get ready for another year of rapid change - in the devices we use to surf, in the way we get connected and in what we do when we're online. Fledgling e-retailers and music industry giants had better brace themselves for a tough 12 months
e-finance: special reports
fields.trailText: Victor Keegan on the future of online trading
fields.body:
The one certain thing about predicting the future of e-commerce is that we ain't seen nothing yet. The selling of goods to consumers via the world wide web (e-commerce) is less than five years old in the United States while e-businesss (company to company transactions) are even younger.

Britain is at least two years behind the US in both areas (though catching up) so we can at least get early warning of what might happen to us by monitoring events in the US.

Expect two countervailing forces over the next year or two: explosion and implosion. Explosion because of the way industry - led by the largest companies in the world - will move their delivery and supply chains to the web. Ford and General Motors have already transferred hundreds of billions of dollars worth of business to the net. Others will follow - or be impaled by the loss in competitiveness involved in not doing so. The business-to-business side of the web explosion will be far and away the biggest phenomenon (about 80% of all web business activity) but it will be all but invisible to the consumer. All you will see is the dead bodies.

Implosion because there will be, as night follows day, a shakeout of the early internet start-up companies. This will happen in two bursts. First the puncturing of some of the more ludicrous values put on some of the bubble.com companies on the stock markets followed by the actual failure of a number of first wave companies.

At the moment the people who should be making money -the risk taking pioneers of web trading - are nearly all making losses while those who wouldn't be there but for the pioneers - the manufacturers of the infrastructure and the lawyers and accountants - are coining it. This doesn't mean web trading is doomed- it will eventually take over the world - but not in the way people expect now and not necessarily by the same pioneering companies.

In hardly any previous revolutions have the pioneers taken the cream and no one has yet provided a convincing case why the net has made an essential difference. People often ask whether the internet revolution is like the tulip speculations in 17th century Holland, the Californian gold rush of 1849 or the Victorian railway mania. The answer is that although there are similarities (like the famed shovel manufacturers who cleaned up in the the gold rush like the component suppliers now) there is one crucial difference.

For the first time there is a global infrastructure that is (almost) freely available in industrialised countries. You don't have to build your own railway to get in on the act. This will make it easier to try out your own new ideas than at any other time.

But never before have there been so many potential competitors all over the world. This leads many pundits to say that the Big Brands, backed by limitless advertising budgets will win. Don't be so sure. The same web that has enabled giants to go global has also enabled consumers to respond globally. That contest is only just beginning.

fields.headline: The mobile net
fields.standfirst: The digital revolution won't even pause for breath in 2000. Get ready for another year of rapid change - in the devices we use to surf, in the way we get connected and in what we do when we're online. Fledgling e-retailers and music industry giants had better brace themselves for a tough 12 months
fields.trailText: Neil McIntosh argues that the internet on your computer is about to become a thing of the past
fields.body:
Internet on your computer? That's sooo 1999. The next great technology frontier is the mobile internet - email and the web on your mobile phone. Making that possible is WAP - Wireless Application Protocol - which finally arrived, after some delay, in December.

The choice of WAP handsets is limited, and they are not cheap, but don't let that fool you into thinking WAP is not going to take off. By 2005, there will be more people using WAP handsets to access the net than those using computers. Microsoft, never slow to spot an opportunity - and a potentially vast threat - to its business,has moved into wireless in a big way. Last month, it announced a joint venture with mobile phone maker Ericsson to develop WAP software.

What will we do on our WAP phones? Initially, reading news, checking the football scores and monitoring our shares. But the big applications will eventually include scheduling and, of course, email - all perfect for the tiny windows on the wired world our mobiles will soon provide.

fields.headline: Music
fields.standfirst: The digital revolution won't even pause for breath in 2000. Get ready for another year of rapid change - in the devices we use to surf, in the way we get connected and in what we do when we're online. Fledgling e-retailers and music industry giants had better brace themselves for a tough 12 months
fields.trailText: Martin Clark predicts that the 2000 will be the year that the music industry finally embraces the digital marketplace
fields.body:
To MP3 or not to MP3? That is the question, but what is the answer? For all those with their heads in the sand, 1999 saw the meteoric rise of one digital audio format over all others: MP3 had arrived with more hype than hypertext.

Compressing sound files to manageable sizes by cutting out sounds inaudible to the human ear, it turned downloading into something that took a fag break not a fortnight. Now your best single was a click away and you could hear the follow up before you bought it. Embraced by techies and musicians alike, it turned geeks into rock stars, surfers into A&R men and websites into record companies.

Despite the acceleration of new technologies, the barriers that came between MP3 and global domination in '99 remain. The problems facing MP3 range from global battles to public misconceptions.

Hand held devices, like those made by Diamond, have yet to come down sufficiently in price to convince the market. After a recent public endorsement of a rival to MP3, Microsoft's MSAudio format, Sony seems keen to expand in both the digital distribution (its Bitmusic site) and portable player sectors.

"We have to start selling music online, considering the prospects for an explosion of internet usage and a proliferation of distribution technologies," a Sony music spokesman said. "But we still face the challenge of protecting our copyrights and intellectual property."

Copyright is why many multinationals have been reluctant to adopt the technology The other problem is that the public is loathe to pay for something that is apparently free.

Overcoming that last problem is something only the public can do .
