fields.headline: The Countess of Barcelona
fields.standfirst: Her quiet diplomacy healed the rift in the Spanish monarchy
fields.trailText: Maria de las Mercedes de Borbon, who has died aged 90, was wife to a man who should have become king of Spain and mother to a son who, eventually, did. Her intervention, behind the scenes, prevented a lasting rift between Don Juan de Borbon, the rightful heir to the Spanish throne, and their son, Juan Carlos, chosen as successor by the victor in the 1936-39 civil war, General Franco.
fields.body:
Maria de las Mercedes de Borbon, who has died aged 90, was wife to a man who should have become king of Spain and mother to a son who, eventually, did. Her intervention, behind the scenes, prevented a lasting rift between Don Juan de Borbon, the rightful heir to the Spanish throne, and their son, Juan Carlos, chosen as successor by the victor in the 1936-39 civil war, General Franco.

She proved decisive in consolidating the monarchy, and Spanish democracy, after the dictator's death, by persuading her husband to renounce all claim to the throne. "Even though Juan never became King, and even though he was the rightful heir, to have our son become King meant continuity, which is the essential ingredient in a monarchy," Doña Mercedes told a biographer.

Her lack of pomp, and love of bullfighting and football, made her a popular figure in later years. She was born in Madrid, the daughter of Don Carlos de Borbon and his second wife, Luisa of France. She became a particular favourite of her father's cousin, King Alfonso XIII, who nicknamed her "La Brava" (Feisty) and gave her the title of Infanta, putting her on a par with his own children.

When she was eight, the family moved to Seville and she developed a great love of Andalucia, becoming a keen horsewoman. But when Spain became a republic, in 1931, she was forced to go into exile, with the rest of the royal family.

At a dance in Rome, she and her second cousin, Juan, who had become heir to the Spanish throne and was serving with the British Royal Navy, met again. He was taken with the tall, blonde, handsome woman he remembered as a child, and they married in 1935. After the second world war, they settled in Estoril, on the Portuguese coast near Lisbon, but temporary exile turned into decades of lonely isolation as Franco, who claimed he would restore the monarchy, played a nasty game of cat and mouse. The royal family were often short of money and relied on monarchist sympathisers for support.

Doña Mercedes comforted her husband and brought up four children, two boys and two girls, in a modest villa. Her strength of will ensured her daughter, Margarita, born blind, led as normal a life as possible. She later said one of the happiest days in her life was when Margarita married. The saddest was when her younger son died, accidentally, while playing with a shotgun with his brother.

Don Juan's offer to fight with the nationalist side during the civil war had been rebuffed. So, too, was his intention, declared in 1945, to become "King of all Spaniards" and heal the rifts of war. Instead, Franco offered to take the couple's elder son, Juan Carlos, and educate him in Spain. Doña Mercedes said she missed him so much that talking on the telephone became unbearable and they decided to write instead.

In summer 1969, Juan Carlos telephoned his father to say Franco had appointed him future king. Don Juan considered that, in accepting without consultation, his son had betrayed him. Doña Mercedes felt Franco had left her son no option and struggled to reunite the family.

She and her husband watched Juan Carlos confirmed as king, by the Spanish parliament in 1975, on television in Paris, while they ate lunch. "It was very moving," she said. Her discreet diplomacy continued and, in 1977, at a low-key ceremony in the King's private residence, Don Juan renounced all claim to the throne, bowing to his son and saying: "For Spain, always for Spain, everything for Spain. Long live Spain. Long live the King." As always, Doña Mercedes was at his side.

In 1983, the couple returned to live in Madrid. Two falls in later years confined Doña Mercedes to a wheelchair, but she remained a regular in the royal box at the bullring and an ardent supporter of Seville's Betis football club. She took a keen interest in her grandchildren. Presenting Crown Prince Felipe with a shotgun, despite his mother's opposition, she said: "The family has always shot".

She died, unexpectedly, after celebrating the new year with her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and thousands filed past her coffin as it lay in state. Her son accorded her a full state funeral and burial at the Escorial Monastry, built by Philip II, and theoretically reserved for reigning monarchs.

fields.headline: Victor Serebriakoff
fields.standfirst: Ex-manual worker who rose to the top in Mensa
fields.trailText: In 1949 Victor Serebriakoff, who has died aged 87, was shown an advertisement by his wife Mary for Mensa, the society supposedly for people of high intellegence. Thus did Serebriakoff undertake a Mensa test, enter the organisation and eventually take it over.
fields.body:
In 1949 Victor Serebriakoff, who has died aged 87, was shown an advertisement by his wife Mary for Mensa, the society supposedly for people of high intellegence. Thus did Serebriakoff undertake a Mensa test, enter the organisation and eventually take it over.

An eccentric Australian, Roland Berrill, a non-practising barrister, instigated Mensa in 1946. He envisaged it as a panel of the intellectually gifted to be consulted by governments and others. But Berrill's oddities began to annoy Mensa members, and he resigned. He was replaced by Serebriakoff, who decided that Mensa should be uncommitted and impartial, with no corporate views, and that nothing said by any member should be considered anything other than that individual's personal view.

Serebriakoff inherited an organisation with a membership which had shrunk to a handful. But he advertised, publicised, and the numbers started to grow again, with Mensa becoming mainly a social body. Serebriakoff's posts included international general secretary, international chairman and editor of the British Mensa magazine, finally becoming the third honorary international president.

The son of a Russian father and a Cockney mother, Serebriakoff was a manual worker until an army test revealed his intelligence. He became manager of a sawmill and, as Victor Serry, wrote books with such exciting titles as Metrication In The British Timber Industry and British Sawmilling Practice.

Mensa grew to more than 100,000 members in more than 20 countries, with hundreds of local and special groups and countless publications. The 1996 50th birthday celebrations in Manchester, London and Oxford (Mensa's birthplace) attracted about 1,500.

I read Victor's book IQ: A Mensa Analysis And History (1965) long before I met him. He also wrote Mensa: The Society For The Highly Intelligent (1985). His other books covered intelligence and the brain, the education of intelligent children - a particular concern - and mental testing.

I joined Mensa in 1973, and became familiar with his short, bearded, energetic figure, and attended his "think-ins", where a member or non-member would introduce a topic (he gave me a copy of IQ inscribed "To a very regular thinker"). I also went to Mensa At Cambridge, which he started in 1980, held at a college to explore a theme with distinguished speakers, and occasionally to his black-tie dinners, where, as always when he presided, he insisted that everyone who wished to speak should do so.

While not denying being elitist or rightwing he was always tolerant of other views. When Mensa suffered dissension and he was criticised, sometimes offensively, he remained calm and courteous.

One early Mensa member whom Serebriakoff met (and, he said, didn't particularly like) was Winifred Ida Rouse. When Mary died of cancer in 1952, he was referred to a hospital almoner - it was the same Win Rouse. With his wife dead only a few hours he asked her out, something he later said even he found hard to understand. They married and she accompanied him to Mensa events and made, he said, a wonderful mother to his children. She became the British director of International Social Service and died in 1995. He is survived by his son and daughter.

 Victor Serebriakoff, Mensa administrator, born October 17, 1912; died January 1 2000

webTitle: Israelis press for curbs on law of return

fields.headline: Israelis press for curbs on law of return
fields.standfirst: The tide of non-Jewish immigrants is alarming politicians
fields.trailText: A powerful political consensus is building in Israel to change one of its emotive founding principles - that it be a haven for anyone of Jewish descent who wants to live there.
fields.body:
A powerful political consensus is building in Israel to change one of its emotive founding principles - that it be a haven for anyone of Jewish descent who wants to live there.

A coalition of disgruntled taxpayers, Orthodox Jewish movements and first-wave Soviet immigrants is growing so alarmed by the number of non-Jewish immigrants that revision, or even abolition, of the "law of return" looks likely.

In a startling sign of how far Israel has travelled since its creation in 1948, the change could mean that people judged Jewish enough by the Nazis to be sent to the gas chambers would no longer automatically be eligible for citizenship.

Under Nazi Germany's Nuremberg laws, people with one or two Jewish grandparents were persecuted, and in occupied countries like Poland ended up in the gas chambers. Israel's law of return, passed in 1950, decreed that anyone with even one Jewish grandparent had an automatic right to Israeli citizenship, even if they were not religious Jews.

With the opening of the former Soviet Union's borders, however, and the growing economic gulf between impoverished Russia or Ukraine and prosperous Israel, many Israelis believe that nominal Jews and bogus Jews are abusing the law - enjoying generous resettlement packages and welfare benefits and diluting the Jewish nature of the state.

The drive to change the law of return has created strange bedfellows in Israel's parliament, none stranger than the ultra-Orthodox Shas party and the ex-Soviet immigrants' party of Nathan Sharansky.

Shas has tabled an amendment to the law to limit automatic citizenship rights only to those who are "halachic Jews" (Jewish under religious law, which recognises only descent through the mother) - barring entry to immigrants claiming Jewish descent through the male line.

Rabbi Nissim Ze'ev, Shas's founder, claimed that many new immigrants had paid for arranged marriages and had no commitment to Israel.

"They come as couples, then after they get citizenship they split up," he said. "In the US you have to wait maybe seven years to get a green card. But people come here, say: 'I'm a Jew' and get a pension."

Yuli Edelstein, the deputy speaker of the Knesset and head of Mr Sharansky's Yisrael B'aliya faction in the legislature, said he never thought he would find himself supporting a change to the law of return.

Born in Ukraine and educated in Moscow, he was one of the 1970s Soviet refuseniks jailed for his support for Jewish emigration from the USSR. He emigrated to Israel in 1987 and in a previous government headed a department responsible for assimilating immigrants into Israeli society.

"When people used to say there were a lot of non-Jews among the newcomers, I got very angry," he said. "Now, we're talking more and more about people who, to put it plainly, have no business here.

"These are not people who are suffering from anti-semitism or who have any connection to the Jewish people. We're talking about people who discover, or falsely discover, some Jewish relatives and try to use that to enhance their economic situation."

Mr Edelstein opposed the Shas amendment, which he said had little chance of success. But he said there were a range of other proposals, such as not giving grandchildren automatic citizenship unless their Jewish grandparent could immigrate with them.

"If there was any proof that, say, the grandchildren of Jews were suffering from anti-semitism in Vinnitsa or Volgograd, no one - not even the ultra-Orthodox - would turn them away," he said. "It's not that Israel is losing its serious attitude to what happened [in the Holocaust]: it's more of a problem of the gap between the third world and the industrialised countries."

Last year 53% of new immigrants were non-Jews. "Any person who's somehow got a distant relationship to the Jewish people can bring five, 10, 15 - I think the record was 77 - members of their family who don't claim they have any Jewish traces," he said.

In Jerusalem's Klin Grocers, a chill cabinet is heaped with a rich display of pork products - sausage, pork fat, ham - for the city's thousands of non-Jewish immigrants, like Nina Prezument, an ethnic Russian from Uzbekistan.

She believes that even the present law of return is too restrictive. She was granted citizenship by virtue of her marriage to a Russian Jew, but her son by her first marriage is purely Russian, so cannot join her and is stuck in Tashkent.

"The Moroccans and the Ethiopians come here and it's one Jew and 13 people. And I can't bring one healthy, hard-working young son," she said. "Is that fair?"

webTitle: Controllers of crash trains 'had lost phone numbers'

fields.headline: Controllers of crash trains 'had lost phone numbers'
fields.standfirst: Police say Norwegian death toll may be smaller than predicted
fields.trailText: Rail managers tried to avert the head-on train crash in central Norway in which 20 people are feared to have died, but were unable to contact the drivers because their mobile telephone numbers had been lost, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Rail managers tried to avert the head-on train crash in central Norway in which 20 people are feared to have died, but were unable to contact the drivers because their mobile telephone numbers had been lost, it was claimed yesterday.

The state railway network confirmed that it was investigating reports that duty managers had been unable to warn the trains that they were speeding towards each other on the same track.

"Whether there was a lack of clarity about [mobile phone] usage, and whether this had any significance for the accident is among the issues that will be investigated," it said.

The TV2 television station said controllers in the town of Hamar had realised the trains were on a collision course and tried to call the drivers. But, quoting anonymous sources, it said the list of mobile phone numbers was wrong.

The section of track north of the capital Oslo where the accident occurred did not have a system that would automatically stop trains running into danger, but was due to be upgraded next year.

Rescue workers yesterday found nine more bodies in the charred remains of the passenger trains but were unable to remove four of them as darkness slowed their efforts. Seven bodies were recovered on Tuesday, and police said four people were still missing - a total of 20 possible deaths. Twelve of the 30 injured remained in hospital, one in intensive care. Most of the rest were treated for broken bones.

Flags flew at half mast at railway stations throughout the country yesterday.

But Vidar Pedersen, the head of police operations on the scene, said the death toll looked like being much lower than the 35 estimated earlier. The police were working all-out to find the correct number of people on board the trains.

"We've said all along that the numbers were very uncertain," he said. One problem was that one train was a local shuttle, without a passenger list or count. Another problem was that some people with tickets for the other train had turned out not to have been on board.

The two diesel trains crashed head-on on Tuesday near Rena, 110 miles north of Oslo. Each train was travelling at up to 55mph around a curve when they collided.

Rescue workers said it could take days to recover all the bodies, many of which were badly burned. "We are prying loose bodies. It is very hard work because they are so stuck in the wreckage," said Trond Simarud. "We have to work millimetre by millimetre."

After the accident fire engulfed both trains, burning for almost six hours and blocking rescue efforts. "The worst thing to experience is to stand there and watch people burn _ going through that train and seeing people who were conscious who we couldn't help," said Ola Sunderaal, who was one of the first there.

Military tents were set up at the site for search crews yesterday and the smell of smoke lingered in the crisp air.

Three busloads of friends and relatives of the dead and missing arrived to place flowers and seek solace. Others gathered in nearby churches.

Eight Britons and a Dutch couple were on board the train but all survived without serious injuries, a police spokesman, Per Ravnkleven, said.

Britt Haugen Toth, of the Hedmark central hospital, said one British couple had been treated and released. AP

Britt Haugen Toth, of the Hedmark central hospital, said one British couple had been treated and released. AP

fields.headline: Bob Hill
fields.standfirst: Crusader for cleaner energy, solar power and third world students
fields.trailText: Professor Bob Hill, who has died aged 65, promoted clean energy, not just in Britain and Europe but across the globe. The ideal advocate of change - tackling the technology issue as well as the economic, environmental and social costs of different energy systems - Bob was a leading figure in alternative energy. He chaired the British Photovoltaics Association in 1994-95 and during the millennium year.
fields.body:
Professor Bob Hill, who has died aged 65, promoted clean energy, not just in Britain and Europe but across the globe. The ideal advocate of change - tackling the technology issue as well as the economic, environmental and social costs of different energy systems - Bob was a leading figure in alternative energy. He chaired the British Photovoltaics Association in 1994-95 and during the millennium year.

He was also a member of the solar energy advisory committee and the technology foresight energy committee, which advise the British government. In 1994 he led the 12th European Photovoltaic Conference and was involved in subsequent conferences, including preparation for next year in Glasgow.

Bob was born and brought up outside Leeds, and after graduating in physics from Imperial College took a doctorate there in solid state physics. In the mid-60s, he joined the research staff at Windscale (now Sellafield), focusing on nuclear safety before moving briefly to Newcastle university. He joined Newcastle polytechnic, now the University of Northumbria at Newcastle (UNN), in 1971. From there, he ran the Newcastle Photovoltaics Applications Centre. He wrote and edited 12 books, seven conference proceedings, 200 papers in refereed journals and major conferences and more than 100 confidential commercial reports.

His early work at UNN focused on thin film solar cells for terrestrial use exploring high efficiency coatings. By 1978, Bob was working on satellite solar panels. Knowing that it was difficult to generate money in new universities for fundamental research, he concentrated on developing hardware for testing solar cells.

He was a friendly scholar insisting on tolerance, even of views that questioned his own scientific rationalism. He had a waspish sense of humour, accompanied by laughter emanating from somewhere between the end of his beard and the beginning of his chest.

Northumbria's solar-clad building stands as a monument to Bob, but his finest memorial is his work in creating opportunities for third world graduate students to study applied physics. He leaves a daughter and son, Ben and Rebecca, and a wife, Anna.

 Robert (Bob) Hill, physicist, born June 24 1937; died November 26 1999

webTitle: Farmers delighted as town strikes culinary blow for France

fields.headline: Farmers delighted as town strikes culinary blow for France
fields.trailText: Worried that its children are picking up distressingly un-French habits in an era of Ronald McDonald and frozen pizzas, the small town of Pamiers this week became the first in the country to ban all but fresh local produce from its school canteen.
fields.body:
Worried that its children are picking up distressingly un-French habits in an era of Ronald McDonald and frozen pizzas, the small town of Pamiers this week became the first in the country to ban all but fresh local produce from its school canteen.

"We're striking a triple blow for rural French values," said the mayor, André Trigano. "This will ensure our kids stay healthy, teach them the taste of proper French food, and help keep our small farmers in business. It's also, um, not bad news electorally speaking."

The town council of Pamiers, in the mountainous far south near the Spanish border, voted last month to stop using ready-made, mass-produced meals in the community's sole school canteen, where 300 pupils eat each day. A week-long trial before Christmas proved a resounding success.

The ban followed a wave of popular French protests this summer led by the Roquefort cheese-maker José Bové, who declared war on McDonald's as an agent of US culinary imperialism, on industrialised agriculture and on poor quality food, and vowed to defend the interests of traditional French food producers.

"The results of our trial were completely unambiguous," said Mr Trigano. "With school dinners bought in bulk from outside, we had a rejection rate of up to 60%. With good local food from our own farmers, organic if possible, virtually nothing gets thrown away."

On yesterday's menu were egg mimosa and roast chicken from a local free-range poultry farmer, potatoes from a field three miles outside town, a salad free of fertiliser from a farm in nearby Foix, cheese from cows grazing at the bottom of the hill, and a pastry made that morning from locally-produced flour and butter.

Local farmers expressed their delight at the decision. "Finally, we have a mayor who's standing up for us," said Jacques Lavessières from the nearby village of La Bardaille. "And it's an investment for the future. By teaching the kids what French quality means, we'll wean them off McDonald's and all that other stuff."

The children were not too sure what organic meant, but said that they liked the food. "Organic is what mum makes at home when there are no burgers," hazarded Camille, aged 10. "But it tastes OK. I finished it, anyway."

webTitle: Italian town brings pet owners to heel

fields.headline: Italian town brings pet owners to heel
fields.standfirst: Recanati website
fields.trailText: Animal lovers have transformed a corner or Italy into a pet paradise which enshrines in law the right to walkies, friends and sex.
fields.body:
Animal lovers have transformed a corner or Italy into a pet paradise which enshrines in law the right to walkies, friends and sex.

Draughty kennels, chains and cramped conditions are no longer tolerated in the town of Recanati. Owners must jump through hoops to avoid infringing their pets' entitlements after the mayor, Fabio Corvatta, this week introduced 16 regulations which come close to a social contract between humans and their pets.

In theory, the rules apply to all animals, but are in practice aimed at dogs and cats. They guarantee pets the right to satisfy their fundamental needs, which are defined to include social rapport with members of their own species and breed.

"Legitimate sexual needs" must be catered for, as must the consequences. Owners are responsible for the health and well-being of any offspring, and regular visits to the vet for check-ups and advice on diets are obligatory.

The law, which is the latest twist to Italy's love affair with animals, specifies that pets' living quarters must be at least eight square metres, well-lit, ventilated and at a comfortable temperature. Chaining a dog's collar is banned except when absolutely necessary.

Bans on dogs have been lifted from two of the town's best-known parks and smaller dogs have been given permission, when on a leash, to also enter other parks and gardens.

The law encourages denunciations to the authorities of anyone who trains dogs to fight, breeds them for sale to vivisection laboratories or gives them away as prizes.

Recanati is a hill town in the Marches region of northern Italy. It has 20,000 residents, of whom half are pet owners.

Mr Corvatta, a leftwing mayor and the owner of a former stray cat, introduced the law after consulting animal rights groups. He bristled when asked about the sexual rights entitlement.

"Why does everyone focus on this? This law is about striving for peaceful cohabitation. It is about protecting animals and trying to make sure they don't disturb humans."

Italy has some of the most animal-friendly legislation in the world. Venice was the first city to pass an animal rights act, in 1987, which guaranteed stray cats an area to roam, and a national act was passed in 1991, which has benefited Rome's numerous cat colonies.

Controversy flared this week when the World Wide Fund for Nature warned that restoration work at Rome's colosseum was threatening the falcons, crows and owls nesting in its crannies. Archaeologists courted public hatred by accusing the birds of damaging monuments and suggesting they should be relocated.

fields.headline: No: 1556 Lace
fields.body:
Appearance: Fancy, flimsy frippery beloved of the Breton tourist board, writers of erotic fiction and red-blooded men who like their ladies racy.

Less keen: The women who are supposed to wear it. Or at least, their partners who have traditionally bought it. Despite its image as the favoured gift of unimaginative (or too imaginative) husbands and partners, sales of lacy underwear plummeted over the festive season.

The bottom falling out of the market, is it? Cheeky. But yes - there were considerably fewer suspenders in stockings this Christmas. The Sherwood Group, one of the country's leading lingerie manufacturers and supplier to Next, Top Shop and Marks & Spencer, has reported disappointing sales in November and December. After a 14% slide in its share price, the company is predicting less than shapely stock-market figures this year.

Bad news for Marks & Sparks? Plus ça change... Alas, the jolly green high street giant seems to have judged this one particularly badly. After seeing a dip in its massive 43% share of the UK bra market, the company teamed up with saucy underwear supremos Agent Provocateur in October to put a bit of S&M into M&S. Now it seems that what shoppers wanted after all was a multipack of cotton knickers and some tummy-control briefs.

So why have women cast aside their saucy undies? Girl power, of course. "Buying lacy lingerie was always really about men giving a present to themselves," says a psychologist. "Perhaps now women are more liberated and want a present for themselves. They are saying, 'I don't want to be a present for you.'" And comfort, no doubt, plays a part. Women have always been less keen than their partners on wriggling into itsy-bitsy scratchy thong thingies or contorting their assets into gravity-defying confections of mesh and chicken wire.

Don't say: "Hello boys!"

Do say: "Sensible, comfy, kidney-warming gym knickers are for life, not just for Christmas."

fields.headline: Beginning of the end
fields.standfirst: Divorce lawyers are calling it 'matrimonial millennial madness' - a rush to start the new century alone. The latest squabbling celebrities are Ted Turner and Jane Fonda, who want to 'take some personal time for ourselves'. But, asks  Joan Smith, can a marriage ever survive a trial separation?
fields.trailText: Divorce lawyers are calling it 'matrimonial millennial madness' - a rush to start the new century alone. The latest squabbling celebrities are Ted Turner and Jane Fonda, who want to 'take some personal time for ourselves'. But, asks  Joan Smith, can a marriage ever survive a trial separation?
fields.body:
Jane Fonda and Ted Turner have just announced one. Spice Girl Mel G and her husband Jimmy Gulzar tried one before confirming earlier this week that their marriage is over. Trial separations are the route more and more celebrities are taking when their marriages hit a rough patch - and the trend seems to have caught on with the rest of us as well, according to marriage counsellors. But are they genuine attempts to save relationships or just a kinder way of saying goodbye?

Turner, media mogul and billionaire, used the website of CNN, his cable news channel, to announce on Tuesday that he had separated from his Oscar-winning wife of eight years. He also insisted that the move was not a prelude to divorce, even though the marriage has been rumoured to be in trouble for some time. "While we continue to be committed to the long-term success of our marriage, we find ourselves at a juncture where we must each take some personal time for ourselves," he declared, sounding like a man with recent exposure to the language of therapy. (In 1998, he surprised an audience of 300 wealthy Californians by revealing that he had just come from a marriage counselling session in Santa Monica.)

Scary Spice and her husband spent some time apart last year, moving into separate wings of their Buckinghamshire mansion. The singer even went as far as consulting lawyers about custody of their daughter, Phoenix Chi, who is less than a year old. She got back together with Gulzar after counselling, but the marriage appears to have collapsed after a row on New Year's Day. The couple "have arrived at this decision after considerable discussion and attempts to make the relationship work", said Mel G's publicist. They have emphasised that they intend to remain good friends.

In Britain, 41% of marriages end in divorce. So do many relationships in which couples live together without ever making it official. With so many break-ups, and few rules to follow about what to do when a relationship ends, it could be that announcing a trial separation is part of a new etiquette - a way of softening the blow for couples who do not want to hurt each other any further. Equally, it might offer angry and distressed spouses time to calm down and realise what they value about the relationship.

Of course it is possible that, after a period of calm reflection, Fonda and Turner will achieve what the Gulzars have not. But marriage guidance counsellors, divorce lawyers and the few statistics which exist about trial separations agree that the odds are against it. The evidence is that, whatever couples say at the time, a trial separation is the beginning of the end - sometimes for the best of motives, such as wanting to avoid pain, and sometimes not. Relate, the counselling organisation for couples in trouble, carried out a study with the University of Newcastle some years ago which appears to bear this out: only a quarter of the couples in the study who came for help after embarking on a trial separation were still together six months after the counselling ended.

So the omens are not good for a Fonda-Turner reconciliation. Vanessa Lloyd Platt, one of London's best-known divorce lawyers, would go even further. "It's the American way of saying goodbye," she declares, shrieking with laughter. "When celebrities say they're having a trial separation, they mean that lawyers are already on to it."

According to Lloyd Platt, who deals with separating and divorcing couples every day of her working life, there is a crude gender divide here. "When a woman says she needs a trial separation, she usually means a trial separation," she says. "When a man says it, he usually means goodbye." It may be, though, that both partners really do mean the same thing, and what they are expressing is a reluctance to make the final break. Although no statistics are available on how many couples take this route as an eventual way out of a marriage or relationship that is not working, organisations such as Relate encounter it pretty frequently.

"I think that lots of people do opt for what they describe as separations," says Julia Cole, a Relate-trained couple counsellor and psychosexual therapist. "Very often it's linked to a feeling that somehow they can't make the final decision to say the marriage is over. It's a bridging exercise to making the final emotional leap into divorce proceedings." Judy Cunnington, director of London Marriage Guidance, offers a slightly different perspective. "As a rule of thumb," she says, "once you've separated, it makes it more difficult to come back together."

Separation, even if it is supposedly temporary, makes all the problems in the relationship public, she points out. "Friends and relatives tend to take sides. Everybody gets very shaken up by it." If one partner spends the trial separation talking about what is wrong with the marriage, friends are likely to react with astonishment - "What are you doing?" - if the couple eventually decide to get back together. But she agrees with Cole that the most likely outcome is a permanent split: "For probably the majority of people, it's a way to begin to make the separation."

The experts' opinions are worth bearing in mind this month, because it is the time of year when thousands of people think seriously of bailing out of long-term relationships. "This is our busiest time of year," says the irrepressible Lloyd Platt. "We're competing with the first day of the Harrods sale." Cole says that Relate, too, always get an increase in the number of couples approaching them at the beginning of January. This year, because of the new millennium, they are anticipating more than ever.

This means it is no accident that celebrities such as Turner and Fonda or the Gulzars have made their announcements this week. Lloyd Platt calls it "matrimonial millennial madness - people seem to be desperate to make a new start, get rid of the old relationship and start again". Depressingly, she blames the upsurge on the inability of men to handle women's success at work. The Turner-Fonda separation, she says, is a classic example of the problem: "She's a political activist. He wanted a little wife at home. It doesn't work."

The method they have chosen to try and resolve their difficulties may be fashionable, but the experts remain sceptical. "There's a role for saying we need to cool down," says Cole, "but there are ways of doing it which don't involve moving out, such as spending more time apart." She also urges couples who have children to exercise caution. "All children hope, when their parents divorce, that they will get back together," she points out. A trial separation can be confusing and distressing if a parent does not return home after all.

The motive for choosing a trial separation is no longer to do with the stigma of divorce but "something much deeper", believes Cunnington. It is about a sense of failure, of not wanting to admit that the relationship is completely finished. Yet she also points out that, for some couples, living separately actually helps the relationship work - and even allows them to be better parents. "It's not always a bad thing," she says. While this is almost certainly true for a minority of couples, the majority view of trial separations is sobering. You may think you're being mature and sensible, but what you are really doing is embarking on the long goodbye.

fields.headline: Snowed under
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Northumberland

As a new year dawned, a milestone one, we took our dogs and our sticks to walk in the Cheviots. Reaching the car park at Ingram we were into snow and, thankfully abandoning our vehicle, set off up the hills. All-terrain bikes had blazed a trail, because shepherds here do their rounds on wheels now rather than legs. Times have changed: two feet are no longer enough with one man having to look after three hirsels; these are hills hosting 500 sheep. Almost all lambing is done in hemmels and when the lambs are a few days old, provided they are fit, families are turned out.

The greatest drawback to the motorised accomplice is that it prevents the shepherd hearing his sheep, so they still use collies. webTitle: Handbuilt by Ducati, sold within hours

fields.headline: Handbuilt by Ducati, sold within hours
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Italian motorcycle maker Ducati has sold out the first year's production of its new handbuilt limited edition MH900e model within hours of offering on the internet.
fields.body:
Italian motorcycle maker Ducati has sold out the first year's production of its new handbuilt limited edition MH900e model within hours of offering on the internet.

Enthusiasts from Japan, the US, Australia and Europe clicked onto the group's website to snap up the 500 bikes, according to Ducati. Though the strongest demand came from Japan a company spokesman said about 51 orders came from British enthusiasts.

A prototype of the bike, which is meant to recall the days of racing legend Mike Hailwood was first unveiled in Germany in September, though the first production models are not expected to reach the showrooms until the summer.

As well as selling the equivalent of all this year's production, Ducati said that it had also taken order for hundreds more bikes. "We always thought that the internet would be the best way to take the excitement of the MH900e directly to our enthusiasts," said Ducati's chairman and chief executive Federico Minoli. "But even I have to admit the response of our 'ducatisti' has beaten my expectations."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Robinson leads energy council
fields.body:
Robinson leads energy council

Ann Robinson, director general of the British Retail Consortium until last month, will head the new Energy Consumers Council being set up under the government's utilities bill - due to be published in the next few days.

Mrs Robinson will immediately become chairman of the Gas Consumers Council, replacing Jenny Kirkpatrick, and of the Electricity Consumers Committee, replacing Rodney Brooke.

She has set herself three goals in the liberalised, competitive energy market: supporting the development of confident and knowledgeable customers, influencing companies' practices to benefit consumers and helping them get satisfactory redress when things go wrong.

HSBC lifts US presence

HSBC boosted its presence in the United States yesterday by announcing that it has formed a relationship with the investment banking partnership Brown Brothers Harriman.

The relationship involves HSBC using the research by Brown Brothers Harriman's equity analysts in the US and allows Brown Brothers, one of the last partnerships on Wall Street, to retain its independence. HSBC closed its own research operation in the US last year.

New car prices fall by 1.9%

New car prices fell 1.9% in November, compared with the same month in 1998 according to new figures.

Alliance & Leicester's monthly car price index, calculated in conjunction with What Car?, showed a 13.5% drop for one-year-old cars and a decline of 9.3% for cars more than three years old.

Trevor Hilliard, managing director of retail financial services at A&L, said: "It would seem that manufacturers are now responding to mounting pressure from consumers, who, dissatisfied that prices are not falling fast enough, are holding back from making a car purchase."

The pressure on retailers is expected to increase later this month when the competition commission publishes its report into industry pricing practices.

Esat urges rejection of bid

Esat, the Irish telecommunications group, yesterday urged shareholders to reject a $1.9bn (£1.16bn) from Norway's Telenor.

The Norwegian group, which had bid $1.6bn initially, raised its offer last week, but yesterday Esat said the new bid did not reflect Esat's true value.

The Irish group said talks with other possible suitors were continuing though it declined to say how many companies it was talking to.

Telenor first launched the Esat bid in conjunction with Sweden's Telia but was forced to go it alone when the planned merger between the two Nordic groups collapsed at the end of last year.

Hyder accepts £70m hit

Hyder, the debt-ridden Welsh utility, yesterday bowed to pressure from shareholders and accepted tough price controls from water and electricity regulators that will knock £70m off profits this year.

The group, which last month cut its dividend by 60%, had been seen as one of the most likely to appeal against the 10% cut in water bills ordered by Ofwat chief, Ian Byatt.

Hyder has to fund a £1.3bn investment programme when its debts are £1.7bn.

The Hyder board was worried that it could face an even stiffer investment demand from the new Welsh assembly and environment agency.

It is already shedding 1,000 jobs, nearly a fifth of its workforce.

webTitle: Next leads in Christmas sales stakes

fields.headline: Next leads in Christmas sales stakes
fields.trailText: Fashion chain Next has set a scorching pace for rival retailers with a set of Christmas trading figures that other store groups are likely to find very hard to match.
fields.body:
Fashion chain Next has set a scorching pace for rival retailers with a set of Christmas trading figures that other store groups are likely to find very hard to match.

The group, which has consistently outperformed in the high street fashion business and reaped substantial benefits from the decline of Marks & Spencer, said its store sales between August and Christ mas were 18% ahead of 1998 levels. Like-for-like sales - which exclude the contribution made by newly opened shops - were ahead 8%.

Sales made via the Next Directory mail order operation were up 5% and overall Next brand sales were up 15%. The group said it had gone into the new year with the same amount of stock as last year and that its January sale had been successful.

Next is the first big retailer to report its Christmas performance and yesterday analysts were impressed. It is one of only a handful of companies in the troubled retail sector that is still gaining ground. Among the others are Dixons, JB Sports and jeweller Signet, which will unveil its own Christmas figures today.

Next's chief executive David Jones said that in the month leading up to Christmas like-for-like sales were up 10%.

The company's figures con trast sharply with the most recent information from Marks & Spencer. There were widespread leaks from the beleaguered store at the end of last year that its Christmas sales were about 15% down on the previous year.

Yesterday Mr Jones said customers' attitudes had changed over the past couple of years, but that stores that stocked the right goods at the right prices could still do well.

"Shoppers of today only buy what they really want, whereas a few years ago they used to spend money simply because they liked spending money, " he said. "We have good quality merchandise at good prices and people trust us. For instance, we still don't discount goods in the middle of a season."

Mr Jones said he was pleased with mail order sales through the Next Directory, which have increased customer numbers by 2%.

webTitle: Railtrack plea over train delay penalties

fields.headline: Railtrack plea over train delay penalties
fields.trailText: Railtrack last night launched an unprecedented appeal in the high court against the threat of multi-million pound fines for failing to cut delays to trains. The company said it had applied for a judicial review of an enforcement order issued last month by Tom Winsor, the rail regulator.
fields.body:
Railtrack last night launched an unprecedented appeal in the high court against the threat of multi-million pound fines for failing to cut delays to trains. The company said it had applied for a judicial review of an enforcement order issued last month by Tom Winsor, the rail regulator.

This sets Railtrack the target of reducing delays to passenger trains by 12.7% in the year to March 31 and a fine of £4m for every percentage point by which it fails to reach that target.

The group said it wanted to establish whether the proposed size of the fine is proportionate "in relation to precedent". It added: "Whilst targets can play a role in im proving train punctuality they must be achievable and their penalties reasonable."

Company sources said Railtrack, unlike any other company, including train operators, faced penalties even if it improved performance. "If we cut delays by 8.5% we could still be fined £18m and that's disproportionate," they said.

They said that Great Western Trains had been fined just £1.5m for its part in the Southall disaster while construction firm Balfour Beattie had been forced to pay £1.2m after a tunnel for the Heathrow Express service collapsed.

Industry sources said it could take months or even years for the case to be heard, leaving a sword of Damocles hanging over Railtrack.

The group, responsible for stations, track and signalling, achieved just a 2.3% improvement in punctuality in 1998-99 when it was due to hit 7.5%. Mr Winsor said it must make up the shortfall and a further 7.5% in the current year.

webTitle: US firm puts Channel 5 stake on sale

fields.headline: US firm puts Channel 5 stake on sale
fields.standfirst: United and CLT-Ufa seek to expand their interests
fields.trailText: Two leading shareholders in Britain's Channel 5 said yesterday that they would seek to buy parts of an 18% stake in the television channel offered by US venture capital group Warburg Pincus.
fields.body:
Two leading shareholders in Britain's Channel 5 said yesterday that they would seek to buy parts of an 18% stake in the television channel offered by US venture capital group Warburg Pincus.

Britain's United News & Media and European broadcaster CLT-Ufa - both 29% stakeholders in the two-year-old station - said they would apply to buy part of the stake, reported to be worth £171m.

A spokesman for British media group Pearson, which owns a 24% stake in the channel, declined to comment.

Channel 5 had asked for the groups to submit intentions by the end of business yesterday, and said that it would make a further announcement in a few days.

United said it would apply to buy the stake despite concerns about breaching a cap on audience share if its planned £7.8bn merger with Carlton Communications goes ahead.

The combined United-Carlton group, according to recent figures, would have just below the 15% audience share allowed by British law.

Channel 5's 5% viewing share would push the group over the limit, however a spokesman for United said it would leave that decision to a later date.

"We have to exercise our right today. We'll have the discussion with the regulator about whether we can continue to hold [the additional stake]," the spokesman said. "We think Channel 5 is a good thing and a good investment and we want to continue to hold that."

The spokesman said that United would apply to buy just over a third of the Warburg stake, worth around £170m and valuing Channel 5 at £950m.

CLT-Ufa, owned by Luxembourg-based holding company Audiofina and Germany's Bertelsmann , said that it had put in a bid to raise its stake in Channel 5.

CLT-Ufa's interest in the British media market is well-known. The chairman of Audiofina said in December that CLT-Ufa still had to develop its British business and did not rule out further moves here.

Last night the company put out a statement confirming that it had bid £170m for the full 18% holding.

"The final stake CLT-Ufa obtains ... depends on the extent to which other shareholders exercise their pre-emption rights," Audiofina said, adding that the move confirmed its intended strategy to become a "major player" in the British television market.

Reports suggested the purchases would likely leave CLT-Ufa and United with 35% stakes, and Pearson with the remaining 30% if it bought the rest of the stake.

The Warburg Pincus stake in Channel 5 had also attracted some other suitors.

British pay-television company Flextech is said to have made an offer and pay-TV company BSkyB is also said to have looked at the stake but declined to make an offer.

Pearson has appointed David Wan, previously chief executive at Penguin, as the new president of the publishing group. He replaces Michael Lynton who leaves later this month to join America Online as president of its international operations.

Before joining Penguin last year, Mr Wan was president of Simon & Schuster's US school publishing business.

- Reuters

webTitle: Dublin joins the Börse  Pan-European  exchange

fields.headline: Dublin joins the Börse  Pan-European  exchange
fields.trailText: The Dublin and Frankfurt stock exchanges are linking up in a move which should pave the way for the Irish to join the planned eight-strong pan-European alliance, writes Mark Milner .
fields.body:
The Dublin and Frankfurt stock exchanges are linking up in a move which should pave the way for the Irish to join the planned eight-strong pan-European alliance, writes Mark Milner .

The deal could also re-open the debate about whether the pan-European stock exchange alliance should be based on a single trading platform - the electronic system through which share deals are carried out - or by linking the exchanges' existing trading structures.

Under the terms of the deal, the Irish Stock Exchange will run its market on a special section of the Frankfurt-based Deutsche Börse's Xetra trading platform, allowing Dublin-based traders to plug into local access points rather than having their own telephone lines into the German exchange.

According to Tom Healy, the chief executive of the Irish Stock Exchange, the deal has a double benefit for his exchange.

"It will give us a high level of visibility internationally - and that is important as a small market within the euro-zone.

"Secondly, as the German system is a core part of the pan-European alliance, we will automatically have an alliance-compliant system."

Initially the eight exchanges involved in the planned pan-European alliance - Frankfurt, London, Paris, Milan, Madrid, Brussels, Amsterdam and Zurich - had intended to use a single trading platform, but have now opted instead to link their existing platforms.

Although Frankfurt's Xetra system will not replace an existing electronic platform when it is introduced some time before the end of the first half of the year in Dublin - the majority of trading is at present carried out using screens and telephones - it could lead to pressure for further systems consolidation throughout Europe.

"Right now, we have eight exchanges operating individual platforms. This shows there is an alternative," said a spokesman for the Frankfurt exchange.

The old trading floor of the Dublin stock exchange, pictured, is still used occasionally, although almost all the business is now executed by telephone and screen.

fields.headline: Coke seeks a better image
fields.standfirst: Black executive persuaded to stay on
fields.trailText: Coca-Cola has persuaded its most senior black executive to stay with the beleaguered drinks company and help improve its battered public image after a series of public relations disasters.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola has persuaded its most senior black executive to stay with the beleaguered drinks company and help improve its battered public image after a series of public relations disasters.

In his first significant move since being appointed as chief executive of the multinational company last month, Douglas Daft has appointed Carl Ware to head a new global public affairs and administration department.

Mr Ware, the only non-white senior executive at the Atlanta-based group, announced his retirement two months ago after being passed over during a round of promotions. The move pointed to a reportedly strained relationship with the former chairman and chief executive, Douglas Ivester. Mr Ware's decision to return came as eight former and current employees launched a race discrimination lawsuit against the company.

It also followed a series of public relations crises which included tussles with European regulators and the mishandling of a contamination scare on the continent.

The crises prompted last month's departure of Mr Ivester, whose handling of the various issues had been judged to have appeared arrogant and out of touch.

Mr Ware said yesterday that he was keen to focus on building better government relations, particularly in Europe where Coke has come under scrutiny over its competitive as well as social behaviour. The 26-year company veteran said he wanted to bring a "fresh approach" to all the areas he is now responsible for.

The move by Coca-Cola was welcomed by the powerful African-American political lobby in Atlanta.

Mr Daft said: "Carl's principal role is to ensure that the Coca-Cola company continues to be welcome around the world, and that we apply 'community' and 'neighbour' equally to those who live next door or on the next continent."

Mr Daft is also expected to make other organisational and management changes in an effort to turn around the ailing company.

webTitle: PWC sent into Versailles to protect banks' £65m

fields.headline: PWC sent into Versailles to protect banks' £65m
fields.trailText: The big banks behind troubled trading financier Versailles, have hired new investigating accountants in an attempt to safeguard loans believed to total £65m, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The big banks behind troubled trading financier Versailles, have hired new investigating accountants in an attempt to safeguard loans believed to total £65m, it emerged yesterday.

PriceWaterhouseCoopers has been appointed to look at the company's books by the three lead banks - National Westminster, Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays.

KPMG stopped working for the banks just before Christmas but continued working for Versailles with accountants Baker Tilly. A terse statement from KPMG yesterday disclosed that Versailles "terminated" that arrangement on Tuesday. The crisis was triggered on December 8 by the disclosure of accounting irregularities uncovered by the department of trade and industry. webTitle: Rothschild beefs up New York operation

fields.headline: Rothschild beefs up New York operation
fields.trailText: Rothschild, the blue-blooded investment banking group, plans to bolster its US banking operation by appointing a high-profile chief executive with a remit to double its staff numbers in New York.
fields.body:
Rothschild, the blue-blooded investment banking group, plans to bolster its US banking operation by appointing a high-profile chief executive with a remit to double its staff numbers in New York.

The family-controlled and notoriously secretive bank, which helped Britain boost its coffers during its fight against Napoleon, said it hoped that Gerald Rosenfeld, yesterday named as chief executive of its North American operation, would help to attract new recruits in the US.

Mr Rosenfeld, 53, is a former head of investment banking at Lazard, Rothschild's close competitor.

Recently working at his own Wall Street firm, Mr Rosenfeld will become a partner of Rothschild's French operation and a director of its London arm, a move which is intended to allow the fractious bank to take a firmer rein of its US operation.

Philip Swatman, head of investment banking at NM Rothschild Corporate Finance in London, said the bank needed a bigger presence in America, where it employs 35 advisers on mergers and acquisitions, because of the demands of its clients which are predominantly European and include companies such as British Telecom.

The bank also has long-standing relationships with many European governments which has allowed it be involved in privatising compa nies previously owned by the state.

"A lot of our clients are interested in doing deals in the US [but] because our operation is low profile they tend to turn to US banks. That then leaves us fighting a rearguard action for the rest of our days," said Mr Swatman.

So-called US "bulge-bracket" investment banks, such as Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Merrill Lynch, have been increasing their presence in Europe and last year they beat their Euro pean rivals in advising companies on mergers and acquisitions in their own markets. In contrast, European firms have found it very difficult to crack the US investment banking market.

In addition to advising big firms on merger and acquisition opportunities, Rothschild plans to raise money to make investments in private equity deals in the US.

The current head of Rothschild's US operation, Hank Tuten, is expected to remain in New York.

webTitle: Time for a full-blown DTI inquiry

fields.headline: Time for a full-blown DTI inquiry
fields.standfirst: The £640m question
fields.trailText: A month after the suspension of its shares pending investigation into possible breaches of accounting rules it is still not business as usual at mysterious trade finance house Versailles. In fact, the story simply becomes more and more intriguing.
fields.body:
A month after the suspension of its shares pending investigation into possible breaches of accounting rules it is still not business as usual at mysterious trade finance house Versailles. In fact, the story simply becomes more and more intriguing.

One chapter began in the autumn of 1998, when an anonymous caller began contacting newspaper offices making various allegations about the Versailles' founder, chairman and chief executive, Carl Cushnie, and the way the business was run. This newspaper, and presumably others, quietly looked into the allegations but made little headway.

Versailles had always maintained the lowest of City profiles. Nobody seemed to know the company or understand its business, and there was always the suspicion that given Mr Cushnie's colour - black - and his paper wealth - £345m, pre-suspension - the anonymous caller might be motivated by something other than whistleblowing.

Another chapter opened last spring, when a department of trade and industry inspector - poking around an odd Liechtenstein foundation with business links to Versailles - started to ask questions over accounting practices. Another six months elapsed before the matter became public, by which time Mr Cushnie had turned £29m of his Versailles paper into old-fashioned readies.

Now the whole affair can be explained away as a piece of accounting academia - we're talking serious FRS5s here - and a melodramatic reaction by the authorities. Mr Cushnie can claim, as he has, that he sold stock on the assumption the DTI had finished its inquiries.

A pretence can be made that when investigating accountants Baker Tilley finish their report at the end of this month and everything is shown to be just fine, the company can resume its meteoric rise on the stock market; and nothing that has emerged over recent weeks has given any substance to the anonymous allegations first made 15 months ago.

But with the company's financial adviser and stockbroker both now gone and KPMG - the other accountancy firm charged with sorting out the mess - shown the door this week, it is now clear that Versailles no longer has a fu ture as a London-listed company in its present form. Against the 250p suspension price, it is doubtful that if the shares were relisted this morning they would trade much above the 1995 flotation price of 8p.

Whoever is to blame, a full £640m of stock market value has been destroyed here. Shareholders ranging from pension funds to holders of Peps, have lost real money. It is time now for a full-blown DTI inquiry, externally appointed inspectors and all.

Bank bugging

Fresh from his part-time job stamping on non-existent bugs, Don Cruickshank will now be able to give his full attention to the high street banks - some of whom still fear he might be trying to stamp them out, too.

This regulator earned a reputation for terrifying telephone companies when running Oftel, and he can now start going through the masses of data squeezed out of the banking industry so slowly and painfully last year.

First, though, it seems that Mr Cruickshank will kick off with a series of senior-level meetings with the big high street players - perhaps in an attempt to show a conciliatory face.

However, the industry should remember that this is a man determined to make his mark, and with the apparent backing of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to boot. The millennium bug turned out to be little more than a minor, albeit expensive, irritation, and it is best to assume that Mr Cruickshank will want to make sure he does not become associated with non-events.

He has already irritated the banks by buzzing around them and, despite their protests about a fiercely competitive marketplace swamped by new internet entrants, made them fear the worse.

Those with most to lose, of course, seem to be the traditional clearing banks, whose customers have in the past shown themselves more likely to divorce than shift their current accounts to an alternative bank, however shoddily they have been treated.

It is too early to guess at what detailed recommendations are likely to be forthcoming, but making it quicker and easier for both corporate and retail customers to move their custom is a dead cert. He could also hit the sector's leaders hard by meddling in the back office, giving his views on how money moves around the system and how it might be improved. Inevitably, changing the process will involve sharing the profits more widely. If he does, we can expect this species to bite back.

webTitle: She taught the world to love the synth. She brought us one weird instrument after another. Yet all she ever wanted was to play Bach

fields.headline: She taught the world to love the synth. She brought us one weird instrument after another. Yet all she ever wanted was to play Bach
fields.standfirst: Rosalyn Tureck talks to  Rob Cowan
fields.trailText: It is now almost 70 years since a gifted youngster from Chicago had a mysterious revelation about how to perform the music of Johann Sebastian Bach. A week before her 17th birthday she lost consciousness while sitting at the piano preparing to learn a new Bach prelude and fugue. When she came to, her approach to the composer's music had changed utterly... Rosalyn Tureck talks to Rob Cowan
fields.body:
It is now almost 70 years since a gifted youngster from Chicago had a mysterious revelation about how to perform the music of Johann Sebastian Bach. A week before her 17th birthday she lost consciousness while sitting at the piano preparing to learn a new Bach prelude and fugue. When she came to, her approach to the composer's music had changed utterly.

That teenager is now 85 years old and busies herself playing, teaching, writing and running a Bach Research Foundation from her Oxford home. Although long celebrated as one of the most notable Bach interpreters of her generation, Rosalyn Tureck does not consider herself a performer. "That was never my goal," she says. "I don't go out on stage to earn an ovation. My aim has always been to capture an inner world." She ponders momentarily. "I can remember thinking along those lines even as an 11-year-old, contemplating a special world where others might join me. When I succeed, the audience knows immediately. I have walked off the stage at the Royal Festival Hall drunk with communication. In a sense, I haven't been 'playing' at all."

Tureck has always taken an unconventional approach to music. At the age of 10 she was taken backstage at a concert by Lev Terman, the electronic-instrument inventor. She studied with him, and at 17 she made her Carnegie Hall debut playing his Theremin, the instrument that later gave the Beach Boys' Good Vibrations its eerie wailing sound. But during her teens she also flexed her muscles as a pianist, grappling with Brahms's massive Second Piano Concerto and experimenting with playing two Chopin studies simultaneously, one with each hand.

Tureck's repertoire subsequently expanded to incorporate Albéniz, Debussy and Stravinsky, but Bach would soon conquer all. Yet she was not alone in championing him. In 1955 Columbia/CBS (now Sony) launched a blockbuster - its now historic recording of Bach's Goldberg Variations by the Canadian-born pianist Glenn Gould. Suddenly, Tureck had a major rival. And if you hear the two pianists side by side (Gould recorded the Goldbergs twice, Tureck at least four times), you recognise certain similarities. "He did notice some things that I did," Tureck concedes, "but he had no idea of my reasons for doing them."

As for the differences, she cites Gould's well-known penchant for detached notes, those crisp, clipped gestures that help make his playing so distinctive. Tureck would tell you that each Bach composition demands its own roster of colours and nuances, that detached notes should be subtly varied - which was definitely not Gould's style.

Tureck continued to experiment with electronic instruments. She collaborated with Robert Moog, who gave her one of the eponymous synthesisers he first marketed in 1964. She in turn lectured on it at her New York Bach Institute, performing the same Bach sinfonia on, successively, a harpsichord, a clavichord, a piano and the Moog. On other occasions, she worked with Walter (later Wendy) Carlos, whose synthesiser recordings of Bach wowed an impressionable public back in the 70s and 80s. "I knew him when he was 'him'," she says, guardedly. "He was very ingenious, and very clever. It was an effective approach but it led nowhere. And it was so very complicated." Tureck the purist approaches electronic instruments as instruments, not as consoles for gimmicks or tricks.

Her current reputation rests on her achievements as a pianist. In the 40s her New York all-Bach piano recitals ranked as major musical events, and her audiences included composers such as Aaron Copland, David Diamond (who wrote music for her) and Leonard Bernstein.

Then there was the series of recitals she gave at the California Institute of Technology, where she met numerous distinguished scientists. "We had a marvellous time together," she recalls proudly. "They adopted me, allowed me along to private evenings where I heard some quite wonderful discussions. We talked about ideas. For me, it was like oxygen." A little later, this musical-scientific alliance extended to New York. When playing a recital in town, she would follow her performances with a night of heady discussion. But why this fascination? "I am not interested in aping the scientists in any way," she insists. "It's just that I have found a profound link between the two ways of thinking, in the way structures are created and evolved."

These ideas, and many more like them, lie at the crux of her teaching. But she has no illusions about the difficulties involved in launching a career today. Was it different in the past? She throws her head back and laughs. "My dear, I know that people say that - but it's not true. When I was young, there were one or two major competitions. Now there are dozens, as well as record contracts, managerial contracts, cash prizes - even free pianos! There's no comparison. But there's something pernicious, and that's this preoccupation with image - issues like 'How do I look on the platform?', 'What gimmicks can I think of?' "

Technique is another stumbling block, she says. "Most people view technique as an ability to play lots of consecutive notes very fast. Of course, that's important, but when you speak of genuine technique, that's just the beginning. Technique for me is more to do with how many degrees of dynamics you can produce, how many varieties of touch."

These subtle priorities are very much in evidence on the 1952-3 New York recording of Bach's Well-Tempered Clavier that Deutsche Grammophon reissues next week, a set that Bach aficionados and record anoraks have been chasing for years. No one is more surprised about it than Tureck herself. "I had just returned from the United States when the phone rang," she says. "It was someone from Deutsche Grammophon. 'We're putting out your Well-Tempered Clavier on CD,' he said. I asked him which one (the BBC owns a second recording) and he told me that it was the 50s version. I was almost in shock. Those LPs were available in America for almost 25 years without a break. I'm always being asked for them."

Tureck was very happy with the recording sessions, but then she nearly always is. On one occasion, the spell of performance was broken when the producer blurted out, "Miss Tureck, please stop breathing!" She had been aiming at the ultimate in delicate texture, "and I was getting it. What they were hearing was just my normal, quiet breathing!" As ever, her experience of Bach generated an almost mystical intensity. "I sit there, and the only thought that is in my mind is: let the music play you."

Although Tureck does not adhere to any religious dogma, she feels a profound spirituality in Bach's music. "When he wrote his music 'to the greater glory of God', he meant it," she says. "And when he wrote his sacred music, he meant all of it. Even as I tell you this, I experience a sort of chill, because it was so profound. You see, I live in a world of spirituality. That's my real life - that inner, infinite world inside of us. For me, it is the fountain of everything."

 Rosalyn Tureck's 1952-3 recording of Bach's The Well-Tempered Clavier is rereleased by Deutsche Grammophon on Monday.

fields.headline: Heightened sexuality
fields.standfirst: Derek Malcolm picks his 100 greatest movies. This week, number 50: Alfred Hitchcock's Vertigo
fields.trailText: Derek Malcolm picks his 100 greatest movies. This week, number 50: Alfred Hitchcock's Vertigo
fields.body:
It doesn't seem so very long ago that Alfred Hitchcock was considered not much more than a superior craftsman specialising in slightly glib movies the public liked. A superior craftsman, perhaps, but scarcely a real artist.

Now, of course, we see things very differently. Hitch is dubbed a master and a round dozen of his films are regarded as classics. One of them, made in the late 50s, is Vertigo, the strangest, most perverse movie he ever created. It was never really popular except with the critics. But for once one can confidently say they were right.

The story has James Stewart as Scotty, a private eye cursed with a pathological fear of heights since being held responsible for the fatal fall of a fellow officer in the days when he was in the police. Hired to protect a threatened woman (Kim Novak), his "weakness", as the coroner puts it, stops him saving her from a suicidal leap. We know he was also in love with her.

When he comes out of the institution in which he is undergoing treatment, he meets another woman who reminds him of his dead love (actually it is the same one, since her death was fabricated as cover for a murder). Obsessively he tries to make the woman resemble her previous incarnation. "Couldn't you like me, just me, the way I am?" she says after an uncomfortable shopping expedition.

What he wants seems to be what Hitch himself always wanted - a blonde ice goddess. And the film seems to fit perfectly into its director's own view of sexuality, which seldom reaches beyond an unrequited obsession that virtually deranges those in thrall to it. But the film isn't just about that. Scotty and his woman are caught up in more than their slightly lunatic affair. The plot twists and turns around the original murder with almost Gothic abandon until its famous, and superbly shot and edited, climax in the belltower.

You could call Rear Window, Vertigo and Psycho an unequalled trilogy about voyeurism or, if you want to be more orthodox, a set of films forcing ordinary audiences to admit their unordinary fears. Hitchcock's great films, as the critic David Thomson says, are only partly his. They also belong to the minds of those who interpret them.

A superior craftsman, perhaps, but scarcely a real artist. Now, of course, we see things very differently. Hitch is dubbed a master and a round dozen of his films are regarded as classics. One of them, made in the late 50s, is Vertigo, the strangest, most perverse movie he ever created. It was never really popular except with the critics. But for once one can confidently say they were right. The story has James Stewart as Scotty, a private eye cursed with a pathological fear of heights since being held responsible for the fatal fall of a fellow officer in the days when he was in the police. Hired to protect a threatened woman (Kim Novak), his "weakness", as the coroner puts it, stops him saving her from a suicidal leap. We know he was also in love with her. When he comes out of the institution in which he is undergoing treatment, he meets another woman who reminds him of his dead love (actually it is the same one, since her death was fabricated as cover for a murder). fields.headline: Song and dance
fields.standfirst: When it comes to musicals, the Bridewell theatre can teach the West End a thing or two. By  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: When it comes to musicals, the Bridewell theatre can teach the West End a thing or two. By Lyn Gardner
fields.body:
Peter Brook once famously described the theatre as an empty space, filled only when an actor steps onstage. He was wrong. Like the audience, every theatre space brings with it its own baggage and own history. Some even bring a little magic with them.

The old furniture depository in Islington that is now the Almeida is a brilliantly sympathetic space in which it is hard to do wrong. Another more recent addition is the Bridewell, the theatre founded in 1993 by Carol Metcalfe in what was once a swimming pool. Some say that every ley line in London converges on the site near Ludgate Circus where the St Bride's Insti tute was founded during the 19th century to bring educational opportunities to the workers of Fleet Street and the City. During the summer there was swimming, and in the winter months the pool was boarded over and used for concerts and plays and lectures.

By the time Carol Metcalfe stumbled across the building in the early 90s, on the lookout for a space she could use for a one-off production by her new theatre company, the building had fallen into disrepair.

But Metcalfe looked beyond the cobwebs, the floods and the infestation of rats and saw the building's potential as a theatre. Even more amazingly, she persuaded the board of the St Bride's Institute, who had drawn up plans to turn the place into a conference centre, that art should come before commerce.

But then Metcalfe comes from persuasive stock. During the Depression of the 30s her father, an unemployed Clydeside ship-builder, walked down the labour exchange queue one day and persuaded his former colleagues that they should put on plays. The Labour Exchange Players became a local legend, famed for its amazingly sophisticated scenery constructed by men who brought all the skill to creating stage illusions that they had once devoted to building ships.

Despite his delight in the theatre, Metcalfe's dad didn't want his daughter acting or involved in drama professionally, firmly putting down "his big Presbyterian foot" when the matter was raised. So Carol got married, moved to London and spent 20 years as a housewife, during which time she was involved with a local amateur dramatics group, the Questors.

So, astonishingly, when she founded the Bridewell, Metcalfe had had no professional training or experience. But she did have a vision. In a few brief years and with the help of associate director, Clive Paget, a friend from her Questors days, Metcalfe turned the Bridewell into a musical theatre venue that has no peer.

It is at the Bridewell that you can find rare Sondheim such as Saturday Night, the unperformed musical dating from the mid-50s that Metcalfe persuaded the composer and lyricist to let her premiere, as well as forgotten Broadway musicals such as Cy Coleman's On the Twentieth Century.

But Metcalfe also has her eye on the future. Recent successes at the venue include Michael Nyman's chamber opera The Man Who Mistook His Wife For a Hat, Stephen Clark's and Andrew Peggie's plague musical Eyam, and the British premiere of Adam Guettel's truly original Floyd Collins, the story of a Kentucky farmer who became a news sensation in the 20s when he became trapped underground. You can bet that where the Bridewell dares, the West End may eventually find the nerve to follow.

Believing that in order to create a future for the modern musical you have to learn from the successes and flops of the past, this week Metcalfe comes up with yet another first, the British premiere of Lerner and Lane's 60s oddball Broadway musical about reincarnation, psychoanalysis and time travel, On a Clear Day You Can See Forever. Most people know it only from the film adaptation that starred Barbra Streisand.

Almost seven years on and having made her mark, Metcalfe can shrug off the lack of professional experience: "For a long time I tried to keep it quiet because people can be snooty." And she points out that her years of amateur work gave her a thorough grounding in musical theatre. "It is the amateurs who are keeping the old musicals alive."

But it is to the future that Metcalfe is looking. "What I'm looking for in a musical is the idea that the only reason for having the music is that it bares the bits that the words can't bare. The best musicals are about the soul."

Now, just as hopeful playwrights send their scripts to the Royal Court, it is to the Bridewell that those hoping to break into the musical theatre send their tapes.

"There is talent out there. The problem is how to nurture it. These people need access - the chance to learn from seeing their work staged. I think the West End has been slow to recognise this, so we do our best. The vision is clear; it's the realities that are cloudy."
