fields.headline: Eva Neurath
fields.standfirst: After fleeing the Nazis she co-founded a leading British publishing house and produced books which reflected her passion for high culture
fields.trailText: In August 1998, at her 90th birthday, celebrated in her large house in Highgate - a string trio played as her many friends ate at flower-centred tables - Eva Neurath ended her brief thank you to everyone by raising her arms wide and almost singing out, "I love life".
fields.body:
In August 1998, at her 90th birthday, celebrated in her large house in Highgate - a string trio played as her many friends ate at flower-centred tables - Eva Neurath ended her brief thank you to everyone by raising her arms wide and almost singing out, "I love life".

Indeed she did. And the elegant joy with which she lived her life came to her so naturally - in the delight she took in the highest forms of culture, especially music, in her house in Italy surrounded even in the hottest summer by its cool green lawn, in her always beautifully styled appearance, but above all in producing at Thames and Hudson books that attested to her great respect for high culture - one might have imagined nothing had happened to her to cause anything but total delight in the world.

In fact, Eva, who has died aged 91, survived world horrors. She spoke about these horrors both with gravity and - not a contradiction - almost a lightness of tone, sometimes with a delicate snort of laughter. She would never, she said, have become what she became if it hadn't been for that chap in Germany, meaning Hitler. For it was because of the Nazis that she, her second husband Wilhelm Feuchtwang and their baby son Stephan left Berlin, where she was born and brought up, to come to England.

Feuchtwang had in fact been arrested as a Jew by the Gestapo, but because he was Austrian and Hitler had not yet taken over Austria, he, technically a foreigner, was released; but he and his family left the day of the Anschluss, and later he learned that some hours later the Gestapo had come again to arrest him.

In London, Eva and her son Stephan lived in dim rooms, and she worked as a domestic; her husband was interned as an enemy alien on the Isle of Man at the outbreak of war. In the camp he became friendly with a German Jewish inmate, Walter Neurath, who had been living in England for some time. Working for the book "packager" Adprint, Neurath had been responsible for a series, Britain In Pictures, which was seen as proof of his loyalty to Britain, and he was released. He was asked by Feuchtwang, who remained interned, to help his wife and son, and Walter Neurath not only found Eva a job at Adprint, but started, in 1949, the publishing house Thames and Hudson with her. They married, and on the death of Walter Neurath in 1967 Eva became chairman, a term she insisted on using for herself.

She was the first exponent of the "integrated spread" - the integration of text and illustrations. Her great expertise was in quality colour reproduction of works of art. She would often go far out of her way to oversee the printing of a book expressly to adjust the colour of the reproductions. One of the last great efforts she made was, over three sleepless nights, to approve every sheet of the catalogue of the 1985 Francis Bacon Tate Gallery retrospective.

Often interrupting her talk with a nasal "Hum?" which, it seemed, was a way of making sure one was keeping up with her, Eva was vivid in recounting stories from her life. If one were having a meal with her in her home, her stories could include her asking one to go to the wine cellar for another bottle of wine which might for a moment be seen not as a sudden request but yet another turn in the story. When the story all came together, it was very impressive, not only for Eva's constant, finely controlling awareness of all the elements that would, finally, make a whole, rich narrative, but for the evocative details: from her childhood in Berlin, the detail of being accidentally stuck in the eye with the nib of a pen, the detail of listening to her older sister play the piano in another room, the detail of her mother coming into her room to say goodnight before going off for the evening.

And if Eva was, by nature, open with one, she expected one to be open with her. She might ask someone she had just met about his relationship with a lover, and, on seeing the expression of amazement, reassure the person "I don't mean your sexual relationship. I mean your night-time relationship." This might cause more amazement unless one knew that Eva was very attracted to Jungian analysis and notions.

Having left school aged 14, identifying with the Jewish students who were being expelled, Eva was largely an autodidact. In her home, among her beautiful Biedermeier furniture, one would almost always find her reading a book by, say, Heine, in German of course. And when interviewing a prospective editor for a position at Thames and Hudson, she might talk with him, not about publishing, but the late quartets of Beethoven.

She was an intelligent woman with a strong will, a will backed by equally strong loyalty. She did not indulge sentimentality, but her loyalty found expression in passionate enthusiasm and great affection. One might be standing before her, talking about an opera performance one had been to with her, when, suddenly, she would, with a quick, elegant movement of her wrist, grasp one's chin and, smiling, kiss one on the lips.

On her death bed, she said, "I know that I'm dying, but my mind won't let me." She was still living in the present and still fighting for life.

Her son Stephan Feuchtwang is an eminent anthropologist of China at London university. Thomas Neurath, the son of Walter Neurath from his previous marriage is Thames and Hudson's managing director, and Connie Kaine, Walter Neurath's daughter, is director of design in the publishing house. Eva Neurath has left five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.

 Eva Neurath, publisher, born August 22 1908; died December 21 1999

webTitle: Boy to return to father in Cuba

fields.headline: Boy to return to father in Cuba
fields.standfirst:
Exiles lose bid to keep six-year-old in Florida

More about the Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: Cuban exiles threatened yesterday to launch a civil disobedience campaign after US immigration officials ruled that the six-year-old boy caught in a tug-of-war between the anti-Castro community in Florida and the Caribbean island should go back home.
fields.body:
Cuban exiles threatened yesterday to launch a civil disobedience campaign after US immigration officials ruled that the six-year-old boy caught in a tug-of-war between the anti-Castro community in Florida and the Caribbean island should go back home.

Elian Gonzalez's family have been demanding his return to Cuba since November when fishermen picked him up clinging to an inner tube off Florida. His mother and stepfather were among 10 people who died when a boat full of refugees capsized.

The ruling requires that he be back with his father in Cuba within nine days but Elian's relatives in Miami were going to court to seek an emergency hearing to oppose the Immigration and Naturalisation Service's order.

"This decision has been based on the facts and the law," said the INS commissioner, Doris Meissner. "This little boy, who has been through so much, belongs with his father.

"Mr Gonzalez has had a close and continuous relationship with his son. The father made it clear that he wants the boy returned as soon as possible and the INS believes that the father is expressing his true wishes."

Elian has been adopted by Miami's anti-Castro Cubans as the embodiment of the plight of those who are prepared to risk their lives to flee communist rule.

Since being taken on the 90-mile crossing to Florida on November 25, he has been used as a symbol for the redemptive powers of American values, receiving politicians and a puppy, visiting the Disneyworld and Universal theme parks, having his first day at school and posing for photographs with the stars and stripes.

The struggle over the little boy's future came just as hostilities between the US and Cuba seemed to be easing, with gestures such as reciprocal visits by baseball teams, the start last month of regular though restricted flights from New York to Havana, and the fact that more Americans are finding their way to the island.

But the White House tried to cool the exiles' ferver, with President Clinton saying the child's interests had to take precedence. Yesterday's ruling, where family law seems to have taken precedence over political interests, should also help repair the damage. There was delight among ordinary people after a cautious official announcement on state TV.

Elian's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, says that his former wife did not have permission to remove his son from Cuba, where there have been regular anti-US demonstrations over the affair. The US Council of Churches and the Catholic Church in Cuba both back Mr Gonzalez, who had shared custody.

But relatives in Miami, who were granted temporary custody when Elian arrived in the US, still insist he should stay. "They're inviting a social explosion here if he's returned without having his day in court," said Jose Basulto of Brothers to the Rescue, a Miami organisation opposed to Fidel Castro's government.

Community leaders are calling for acts of resistance, such as forming a human chain around the house where Elian is staying, or bringing traffic to a halt, if he is moved.

Ramon Saul Sanchez, leader of another exile group, the Democracy Movement, also urged lorry drivers, motorcycle groups and others to protest. "We call on all affiliated truckers and independents to prepare to demand peacefully but with determination that our rights as an oppressed people be respected."

"He's going to have a future and a career here, all the things he'd never have over there [Cuba]," said his second cousin, Marisleysis Gonzalez who, with his great-uncle, has looked after Elian.

fields.headline: Tim Burton - part two
fields.standfirst: Burton's mentors and working relationships | The look and feel of Sleepy Hollow | The financiers
fields.trailText: Part two of the Tim Burton interview at BFI Southbank
fields.body:
MK: There's a very strong Germanic influence in your films - the folklore, Expressionism. Sleepy Hollow is written by an American but it has a Germanic feel.

TB: People did say that like any true American he did rip it off some other country. It was possibly a German folklore which

MK: So it isn't an American folk story?

TB: Well, it is but we started early in America ripping off other people.

MK: Do you dream like a German expressionist director?

TB: I don't really dream, I space out during the day - that's one of my problems wonder off when someone's talking to me. I can't remember any dreams in my life. There's so much strange in real life that it often seems like a dream.

MK: There's a strong theme of mentors in your work, for example Vincent Price. What is it about those actors which gives you such inspiration?

TB: It's people who you've seen that have given you a lot. In some ways I felt they helped me psychologically because you see these people up on the screen going through torment and being on the outside and somehow you relate to them and it helps you get through life. It's a real honour and pleasure to then meet these people. I've found that the people who play villains are the nicest people in the world and people who play heroes are jerks. It's like people who play villains work out all their problems on screen and then they're just really wonderful people. I think Michael Gough thought I was always laughing at him because of the costume but I was just looking at him thinking, "He was in Horrors of the Black Museum and Konga - these are my favourite films!" It just makes me really happy.

MK: The thing you said you liked most about Ed Wood was that he was enthusiastic about everything. I'm probably going to paraphrase you but you said that "The lovely thing about Ed Wood movies was he didn't let bad acting, bad sets or even bad takes get in the way of telling the story". Do you think the enthusiasm he and you have is rare in Hollywood directors?

TB: I would think it was common because with all the stuff you go through that's the only bit of positive energy you can get. If someone had said you going to do a movie where people are dressed like George Washington with all these wigs, [I'd never have believed it], but you see all these great people dressed in these weird costumes and you can't help but get a weird energy from that.

MK: How does your relationship with Danny Elfman [composer] work? Do you go and sing the thing to him?

TB: I don't sing to anybody. We've gone through it all together. The first movie he scored was the first movie I did and he adds another character to it, he helps to set the tone.

MK: Sleepy Hollow has a very particular look, it's somewhere between black and white and colour. What have you and the cinematographer [Emmanuel Lubezki] done to get that semi-sepia bleached look?

TB: He's a Mexican we had the luxury of using Mexican horror wrestling films as our inspiration. In fact we often thought we were making a Mexican wrestling movie - the most expensive Mexican wrestling movie ever! We did a lot of testing before we shot to get the right feeling and tone so we tested colours and fabrics and make-up a lot.

MK: But what is that colour, because it's not Hammer colour, it's something else.

TB: We did a slight bleaching process to the film which is being done a lot now but we tried to find the right tone of it and then it was just down to the fabrics and the tone and the lighting schemes and the compositions. We didn't really know what we were getting until we did enough tests and thought "Let's go for this zone right here" but each day it would change, anyway.

MK: Do the financiers always understand what you're doing and take it on the assumption that because it's you it's going to be good?

TB: It helps being 10,000 miles away! And I don't answer my phone too often so that also helps. But they were really supportive on this. There were times that I go through when it's not always that way, but all the way up through the rating they were right there and I appreciated that because they could have easily have said, "Cut this, do that, put a head on the headless horseman all the time, take out all the head shots" - which was the only way we could have gotten a lesser rating.

fields.headline: Man Utd 1 - 1 Necaxa
fields.trailText: Man Utd: Bosnich, G Neville, Irwin, Silvestre, Stam, Butt, Keane, Beckham, Giggs, Cole, Yorke. Subs: Rachubka, Van Der Gouw, Higginbottom, Sheringham, P Neville, Cruyff, Greening, Wilson, Solskjaer, Wallwork, Berg, Fortune.
fields.body:
Man Utd: Bosnich, G Neville, Irwin, Silvestre, Stam, Butt, Keane, Beckham, Giggs, Cole, Yorke. Subs: Rachubka, Van Der Gouw, Higginbottom, Sheringham, P Neville, Cruyff, Greening, Wilson, Solskjaer, Wallwork, Berg, Fortune.

Necaxa: Pineda, Cabrera, Almaguer, Aguinaga, Perez, Delgado, Lopez, Vigna, Milian, Montecinos, Higareda. Subs: Alvarez, Guadarrama, Ambriz, Scotti, Acosta, Terres, Ochoa, Velazquez, Becerril, Hernandez, Oliva, Vazquez.

Referee: Horacio Marcelo Elizondo (Argentina)

1 So here we go, here we go. United kick off in what, if reports are to be believed, should be a speedy game designed by Necaxa to drown United in a puddle of their own sweat. The fixture does not seem to have roused the interest of the locals and the cavernous Maracana looks deserted with only 8000 spectators prepared to sit around in 30°C heat. United knock it around at the back before finally crossing the half-way line. Dwight Yorke has an early pop to test Hugo Pineda in the Necaxa goal.
3 Salavador Cabrera starts a move which ends in a free-kick for Necaxa from the corner of the penalty area. A scramble and a goal-kick result.
5 Everyone looking sluggish and unwilling to run too fast. United are having the best of the early possession, helped largely by Necaxa giving the ball away with impunity.
8 Jose Milian runs onto a long ball on the edge of the United area but Jaap Stam musters well. Cristian Montecinos (chief bad-hair culprit in the Necaxa team with jagged vein stamped on his blonde crop) follows up with a shot from the clearance but skies it. Necaxa finding their feet and making inroads into the United area.
10 United wake up as Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane exchange passes on the edge of the Necaxa area. Giggs has a shot but puts it wide.
11 United win a free-kick 30 yards out, David Beckham takes and plays it short to Giggs who is tackled masterfully by Alex Aguinaga. Necaxa attempt a break that comes to nothing.
15 Goal: Man Utd 0 - 1 Necaxa A Stam error allows Alex Aguinaga a run on goal that results in a free-kick square-on, 20 yards out. United's wall shuffle back and forth, Montecinos steps up and fires the ball clean over the wall. Mark Bosnich nowhere.
16 Booking: Keane for dissent. He plays with his minimalist hair and tries to shrug it off. United looking rattled.
20 United trying to build from the back, but Necaxa succeed in getting the ball forward again and an error by Gary Neville almost allows the slash-headed Montecinos in on goal.
22 Denis Irwin plays in Giggs on the left of the Necaxa area; he wins a corner but Necaxa 'keeper Pineda gathers with ease.
23 Beckham passes to Cole in the penalty area, who plays the ball back to Dwight Yorke. Yorke is relieved of possession before he has a chance to bring the ball down and shoot.
26 United beginning to step up the pace, but cannot find any rhythm and appear to be struggling for control on the lush Maracana pitch
28 Gary Neville goes down injured and for a moment it looks as if he is going to be dragged off on the dreaded Fifa trolley.
29 United trying to get behind the Necaxa defence but get caught offside.
32 Booking: Augustin Delgado for a blatant dive. Bosnich came out to meet him and Delgado pretty much flew over him without a hint of a nick.
36 Necaxa win a corner. Played in high and headed clear by Stam; Milian retrieves and rifles in a shot that Stam clears once again.
38 Montecinos races away down the right, plays in Luis Perez. Beckham charges back up the pitch to make a crunching tackle at the expense of a corner. Cleared by Neville, allowing United to attempt a break. Yorke passes to Keane, who finds Cole on the left. Back in to Nicky Butt who then finds Beckham but United fail to capitalise on the space and lose possession.
43 Red card and it's Beckham, who else, for serious foul play. Charges in on Milian with a high tackle near the nethers. Big scuffle and Beckham is pushed clear, but the referee bides his time and then drops the bombshell.
44 Booking: Giggs for taking his protests over the sending-off too far.
45 Some scrappy play and then half-time. Beckham will miss Saturday's Vasco da Gama match for reacting to previous provocation from Milian and could also be suspended for United's third game against South Melbourne. United look to be missing Paul Scholes, with Keane and Butt unable or unwilling to make those vital runs from midfield.

46 Second half. Necaxa make an early assault on the United goal. Delgado goes down, no foul, but a corner eventually results. Gathered by Bosnich.
48 Necaxa again - Aguinaga on the right plays the ball across field to Delgado who fluffs his chance when he should have played in Montecinos.
50 Aguinaga the source of many of Necaxa's moves as the Mexicans continue to push up.
51 Mickael Silvestre plays in Cole down the left of the Necaxa area; Cole turns his man and plays back to Giggs who, leaning back, fires over.
52 United getting their act together as Yorke releases Neville down the right of the Necaxa area, but his cross is wasteful. Beckham, meanwhile, is ushered away from the United bench.
56 Montecinos, in possession 25 yards out, fires in a vicious shot but Bosnich makes a flying save
57 Penalty to Necaxa: Silvestre is dispossessed on the right by Montecinos who races into the area; Silvestre gets back to make a challenge as Montecinos faffs around, and is harshly adjudged to have pulled down the Mexican. Penalty. Aguinaga takes it tentatively and Bosnich makes the save. A breathing space for United that may spur them on to an unlikely equaliser.
60 Thousands of spectators now piling in to the Maracana to catch the Vasco da Gama v South Melbourne game that follows this match. United seem to be drawing strength from the now vibrant atmosphere.
64 Sending-off! Alex Ferguson is told to leave the bench and must watch the game from the top of stairs. Beckham is now allowed to sit on the grass.
66 Yorke plays Giggs into the area, but Giggs can't reach the ball. He doesn't give up and forces a corner, but it is wasted.
68 Another corner for United as Alex Ferguson's men begin to make up ground - Giggs takes but it is cleared easily.
70 Keane leads repeated charges into the Necaxa area. United's captain runs 70-80 yards to pick up the ball on the edge of the area, continues through the defence and makes a fine shot that is saved. Probably United's best chance. To their credit, they are not giving up.
72 Keane continuing to push forward as United find more space in which to work.
73 Substitutions Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, Phillip Neville, Teddy Sheringham on for Butt, Cole and Irwin.
77 Booking Sheringham for a sharp tackle. Substitution: Vazquez on for Montecinos.
78 Sheringham squanders a chance in the Necaxa area from a cross by Solskjaer, when he is forced to shoot from a bad angle.
79 Penalty to United: Handball . Yorke takes but it is saved by Pineda.
80 Substitution: Ambriz on for Vigna.
83 Goal: Man Utd 1 - 1 Necaxa A looping long ball from midfield is headed on by Sheringham who finds Solskjaer on the right of the area. He tries a shot that turns into a cross for Yorke to fire home the equaliser. Substitution Acosta on for Higareda
85 United look to be coping with the conditions better than Necaxa at this stage in the game and continue to push for a winner. Memories of the Champions League final still fresh in the mind.
88 Vazquez dilly-dallies 30 yards out before passing to Perez on the right. United look exposed, but Stam makes a great tackle to save the day.
90 Three minutes of stoppage time as the frantic pace of the second half shows no sign of letting up. End-to-end stuff as Necaxa are twice caught offside (once falsely) and United continue to seek a winner. Full-time Manchester United 1 - 1 Necaxa.

fields.headline: Tim Burton - part three
fields.standfirst: 'Are all your films equal children?' | Working with particular actors, and how he directs | Films for, and featuring, children | Superman
fields.trailText: Part three of the Tim Burton interview at BFI Southbank
fields.body:
MK: Do you feel proud of your work as a whole? The film that never clicked for me was Batman because it doesn't feel as if it is specifically your film. On the other hand I love Mars Attacks. In Europe you can go "Ak, Ak" [Mars Attacks alien noise!] and everyone knows what it is, but in America that's not the case. Are your films all equal children?

TB: Yeah, they're all as you say, bodies. I feel close to all of them. It's hard to look at them for a while because you just experience how cold it was that day or how that horse wasn't there at that point. It takes a while to watch it and feel it more objectively.

MK: After Beetlejuice there was a huge outcry when you wanted to cast Michael Keaton for Batman, but you said you knew he could act the part. Do you think you have a particularly close affinity with your actors?

TB: I've liked everybody I've worked with because I'm not really very verbal and up until recently I just sat and didn't really speak much so when you see these great actors bringing things to life that's where I get a lot of positive energy and I've been very lucky to work with people that surprise you and when you deal with the technicalities of these films it's really the thing that keeps the sun shining. You do four takes and all of the people on Sleepy Hollow give it four different levels of things. I wish we could play all of the takes of some of these people because they are so interesting.

MK: What's going to happen to Conversations with Vincent - the documentary you shot with Vincent Price?

TB: I had trouble with the rights with some of the clips and it's been so long now that I want to revisit it and maybe think of it in another context. But it's some of the last footage of him so I would like to get it up sometime.

MK: Your films have such a specific style that I imagined that you would get up and say to an actor "I want this and I want that", but that's not what you do?

TB: I don't think so. I sort of leave my body so I don't know what I do exactly. When I'm talking to people I see them trying to follow something that I've tried to say and then they usually go [shrugs shoulders] and say "Yeah" [ in vague voice] and go off and do something great! I'm not quite sure what I do, I wave my arms around a lot but I'm not sure if any of it's meaningful in any way.

MK: We read all the time that a Tim Burton film is the world seen through a child's eyes, and in Sleepy Hollow you're not particularly reverential about children.

TB: That one scene in the film where the little one gets it (Laughter). We used to have endless conversations in our neighbourhood and in my school we wouldn't go and see movies with kids in them because we hated the way kids were portrayed - they were always given a break, they were always treated cuter. We always loved it when kids were treated like everybody else and so that's what we did here - he gets the same treatment as everyone else. People forget that kids are intelligent and they like to be treated with - well this [Sleepy Hollow] isn't necessarily intelligent - but not given the cutesy treatment.

MK: Do you think you putting on screen a genuine version of that child's eye view because another thing you said was that you hated being referred to as a child because it sounds like a retard.

TB: [Laughs]Yeah, it's kind of a dismissal but the thing about that time of life is that things are new and interesting and you're not aware of things on an intellectual level yet, you're reacting to things more emotionally which I think is an interesting thing. As you get older you go through experiences and it gets the same and usual, so it is nice to try to keep that sense of things where everything seems a little strange and weird and unusual from that time which it does.

TK: There is a quality of non-judgmentalism in your films which is child-like, you present something strange and people just accept it. You said once in the case of Ed Wood that your favourite scene was when he meets his wife and he says, "I'm a transvestite" and she says, "Okay".

TB: That's a really quiet moment, but it's one of my favourites. From very early on there was this constant desire for people to categorise people, and I always thought that was something of a dismissal, it doesn't allow people to be who they are and show different sides of their personality. So when people are open and not judgmental I just find that really beautiful and great and somewhat rare.

MK: There's also an element of wish-fulfilment in for example Edward Scissorhands where the jock gets it. It's like the outsider now watching those people now failing.

TB: YEAH! Well, you talk to a lot of film-makers and you realise that they're all the people who couldn't get dates in high school and there is a lot of pent-up "I knew those people would peak in high school". I just think it's part of the creative spirit.

MK: Has Superman fallen by the wayside? What happened?

TB: I worked on that for a year and I'm sure they'll do it at some point - once they get all their fast food things lined up. That's the problem with these things. In the first Batman you didn't hear the word 'franchise' and these movies are hard to make but they make it harder when they come at it the other way round. It was something that had never happened to me before. When you work hard on something and it doesn't happen it's hard to go back.

MK: Is Sleepy Hollow a reaction to your experiences on Superman?

TB: Yes, all those heads are studio executives [Laughter]. Well you know the poster: 'Heads will roll' that's our motto!

MK: What is your next project?

TB: I'm still on this really. You spend so much time on a film you want to take a deep breath and have a feeling inside that you can sustain for a couple of years.

MK: When you see the film now is it the film you wanted to make?

TB: I can't watch it right now. I'll watch it in three years and really enjoy it. But I feel really good about it, I enjoyed this, I enjoyed the people, it was the first time to specifically deal with this kind of imagery and it was a great team of artists and that always makes you remember why you love doing it.

MK: Your films have such a specific style that I imagined that you would get up and say to an actor "I want this and I want that", but that's not what you do? TB: I don't think so. I sort of leave my body so I don't know what I do exactly. When I'm talking to people I see them trying to follow something that I've tried to say and then they usually go [shrugs shoulders] and say "Yeah" [ in vague voice] and go off and do something great! I'm not quite sure what I do, I wave my arms around a lot but I'm not sure if any of it's meaningful in any way. MK: We read all the time that a Tim Burton film is the world seen through a child's eyes, and in Sleepy Hollow you're not particularly reverential about children. TB: That one scene in the film where the little one gets it (Laughter). We used to have endless conversations in our neighbourhood and in my school we wouldn't go and see movies with kids in them because we hated the way kids were portrayed - they were always given a break, they were always treated cuter. We always loved it when kids were treated like everybody else and so that's what we did here - he gets the same treatment as everyone else. People forget that kids are intelligent and they like to be treated with - well this [Sleepy Hollow] isn't necessarily intelligent - but not given the cutesy treatment. TB: [Laughs]Yeah, it's kind of a dismissal but the thing about that time of life is that things are new and interesting and you're not aware of things on an intellectual level yet, you're reacting to things more emotionally which I think is an interesting thing. You said once in the case of Ed Wood that your favourite scene was when he meets his wife and he says, "I'm a transvestite" and she says, "Okay". TB: That's a really quiet moment, but it's one of my favourites. From very early on there was this constant desire for people to categorise people, and I always thought that was something of a dismissal, it doesn't allow people to be who they are and show different sides of their personality. So when people are open and not judgmental I just find that really beautiful and great and somewhat rare. MK: There's also an element of wish-fulfilment in for example Edward Scissorhands where the jock gets it. It's like the outsider now watching those people now failing. TB: YEAH! Well, you talk to a lot of film-makers and you realise that they're all the people who couldn't get dates in high school and there is a lot of pent-up "I knew those people would peak in high school". I just think it's part of the creative spirit. MK: Has Superman fallen by the wayside? What happened? TB: I worked on that for a year and I'm sure they'll do it at some point - once they get all their fast food things lined up. That's the problem with these things. In the first Batman you didn't hear the word 'franchise' and these movies are hard to make but they make it harder when they come at it the other way round. It was something that had never happened to me before. When you work hard on something and it doesn't happen it's hard to go back. MK: Is Sleepy Hollow a reaction to your experiences on Superman? TB: Yes, all those heads are studio executives [Laughter]. Well you know the poster: 'Heads will roll' that's our motto! MK: What is your next project? TB: I'm still on this really. You spend so much time on a film you want to take a deep breath and have a feeling inside that you can sustain for a couple of years. MK: When you see the film now is it the film you wanted to make? TB: I can't watch it right now. I'll watch it in three years and really enjoy it. But I feel really good about it, I enjoyed this, I enjoyed the people, it was the first time to specifically deal with this kind of imagery and it was a great team of artists and that always makes you remember why you love doing it. fields.headline: So dream on, Mr Kennedy
fields.standfirst: Proportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: For historians of the future, it will be a nice teaser, and one can imagine the exam question: "At the end of the 20th century, was electoral reform a serious prospect in British politics?" Top marks will likely go to the essays saying "no". Since there is a limit to how far even Tony Blair can ignore or provoke his own party, he now has good reason to drop the hot potato of PR. What remains an interesting question is how far he ever believed in it in the first place.
fields.body:
For historians of the future, it will be a nice teaser, and one can imagine the exam question: "At the end of the 20th century, was electoral reform a serious prospect in British politics?" Top marks will likely go to the essays saying "no". Since there is a limit to how far even Tony Blair can ignore or provoke his own party, he now has good reason to drop the hot potato of PR. What remains an interesting question is how far he ever believed in it in the first place.

He certainly believes in the "Blair project". This is the grandiose name for a permanent realignment of politics, with a large centre-left grouping (more centre than left, one might say). And he has made teasing noises to the Liberal Democrats about a referendum on PR. That now seems very distant.

If Labour distaste for PR is right, it is right for the wrong reasons - often the case in politics. There have been quite enough experiments in various countries to see its various defects. In Germany, constituency members are topped up with party lists elected by PR. Party bosses - often themselves topped up financially from Helmut Kohl's secret slush fund, we now learn - control these lists. Names are moved up and down according to good conduct, thereby ensuring even more malleable and mediocre legislators than our own. This makes the choice of that system for the Scottish assembly all the sorrier.

In Italy and Ireland, PR is plainly responsible for political sclerosis, with almost interminable one-party rule by unbudgeable Democristiani or Fianna Fail. The Italians are so fed up with PR that they are getting rid of it.

Many Israelis would like to do so as well. In Tel Aviv a couple of years ago, I half-facetiously said to Shimon Peres: "You don't mean you'd like the shocking Westminster system?" and he answered, with vehemence, "Absolutely. Our electoral system is the worst thing to happen to us."

The former prime minister meant the way that a very pure system of PR ensures shifting coalitions. In a throughly perverse fashion, real power is thereby granted to small parties of religious reactionaries, one of which has just yet again dictated terms to the government.

None of these far-flung examples weighs as heavily with Labour as what Bagehot called the brute force of a parliamentary majority. There was never (our exam candidate may well suppose) much chance of reform after the morning of May 2 1997.

Plenty of Labour politicians, like John Prescott, already hated PR. How mixed Blair's feelings were we may never know. But we do know that his plans were unsettled by the size of his landslide. Before the election, the l-word was forbidden at Millbank. This was partly simple superstition, but it was partly because a landslide did not suit the Blair project. Blair wanted to open his big tent to the Lib Dems, and would have offered Paddy Ashdown a cabinet seat if his majority had been 40 or less.

As it was, the new premier's face grew longer and longer, according to those who were with him, as the night wore on and his majority grew bigger. He is now obliged to change the subject for the indefinite future.

The conundrum is anything but new. We very nearly did get electoral reform 80 years ago (more marks to examinees who remembered that), as part of the 1918 representation of the people act which gave us almost-full democracy, with the vote for men over 21 and women over 30. What scuppered reform then was a dispute over the method. The Lords wanted proportional representation in the strict sense, which means multi-member constituencies, as in Ireland. But the Commons were wedded to single- member constituencies, and proposed the alternative vote. In the end, neither was passed, though AV was used for electing university members until they were done away with by the Attlee government.

There is a cheap and cheerful Labour jibe at Charles Kennedy: if Liberals are so keen on PR, why didn't they introduce it in 1906, when they had just won their own 130-seat landslide? Another exam-paper saw says that: "Free Trade is the policy of the strong." Electoral reform is the policy of the weak.

When proposals for electoral reform came in 1918, the war had unsettled politics, no party had an absolute majority, and there was a coalition government. The best fresh chance for PR would be if Labour failed to win a clear majority at the next election. At present, that looks as much in Charles Kennedy's dreams as William Hague's.

fields.headline: Tim Burton - part four
fields.standfirst: The windmill scene in Sleepy Hollow | The internet | Humour in grotesque films | Modern movies | Working with Johnny Depp | Pumpkin heads | Life outside movies | Working partnerships | Re-viewing his movies | The 'mindless blockbuster' | Publishing his artwork | Filmic inspirations | Alternative realities | Violence | Burton's early career
fields.trailText: Part four of the Tim Burton interview at BFI Southbank
fields.body:
Question 1: Was the windmill scene in Sleepy Hollow a homage to Brides of Frankenstein?

TB: Yes, and to Frankenstein. The great thing about those visual horror films is there's real potential for strong, beautiful imagery. It's the one genre that really lends itself to creating strong images. And I've always loved that idea of windmills - your mind aimlessly spinning. I don't know what the symbolism of it is but it's beautiful.

Question 2: Do you feel that the extensive coverage that Sleepy Hollow has received on the internet is be a good thing?

TB: All technology can be used for good and evil and I think it's got its positives and its negatives. I always long for the days when I used to go and see films and you didn't know anything about them. There is something amazing and beautiful to experience something without knowing the budget and everything about it. People are interested so you have to go along with it, but I do miss that seeing something and being surprised and not knowing anything about it.

MK: Is it intrusive?

TB: It's strange because I've read on the internet all these projects I'm meant to be doing I'm supposed to be doing. I feel like I have a psychotic or evil twin doing things on my behalf and I don't know about it.

MK: Yes you're meant to be doing The Naked Civil Servant.

TB: Yeah, I read that and it's like "Jesus, What the Urghh! What's going on?". And there's something about the printed word, whether it's gossip or not somehow it has a reality to it which sometimes a little bit frightening.

Question 3: How important is humour in grotesque films?

TB: Humour was important to us and it's a difficult balance because when you're trying to make something funny and it's also grotesque and you're also trying to keep a dramatic thrust and it's also slightly heightened you're never sure what you're getting. That's why I never like to say whether something is a drama or a comedy - just to keep yourself covered just in case it's not funny you can always say it was a drama. But when you see these great people dressed this way there's a certain absurdity. I just thought it would come across as so ludicrous if [Sleepy Hollow] tried to be completely, completely serious but they all found the right balance and the right tone of it and it's always interesting to mix those things together.

Question 4: What modern Hollywood films do you enjoy?

TB: When you're working on a film it's hard to go and see films. You don't get out of an 18 hour day and go: "I wanna go and see a movie!". But it does seem like it's a good time, it seems like a positive time, there's low-budget films and there's more of a wealth of different types of things that are happening so I haven't much lately. I hope to go out now and catch up on things.

Question 5: How did you first get to work with Johnny Depp, and what's he like to work with?

TB: First of all there was Edward Scissorhands, and he's got these eyes which a silent actor would have and it's nice to work with people who can convey things that way and that character [Edward Scissorhands] really needed that. Johnny was doing this TV show where he's perceived as this teenage heartthrob and he's not that type of a person, so he really understood the dynamics of the character. He didn't speak in that, and in Ed Wood he wouldn't shut up! And he doesn't care how he looks and there's a freedom to that. I remember in Ed Wood his inspiration was Ronald Reagan and I was thinking of a ventriloquist's dummy! And you put those together and he's really good about picking up on that stuff. In [Sleepy Hollow] we were quite excited about the first male action adventure hero as portrayed by a 13-year-old girl, so he gets all those of weird elements in there together and it's quite fun to watch from film to film.

MK: Didn't Scott Rudin [producer] say that in every film Johnny Depp is in with you that he is you?

TB: I don't think that, because I like to see these characters for who they are and I think I would get uncomfortable if I ever felt that way I would turn in another direction. I like to relate to the characters and feel them to a degree.

MK: In the press notes to Sleepy Hollow it says, "in the mould of Martin Scorsese and Robert De Niro" so that's the thing you're in now.

TB: All I know is that I love working with him and he's great, and each time it gets better because you see something new and that's what I love about film.

Question 6: What's with the pumpkin heads in all your movies?

TB: Well, you know when you come from Southern California you try to create what you don't have and we didn't have weather, we didn't have texture, it was always sunny - no seasons. I think it is desire to create the things that are missing in your life.

MK: The pumpkin thing is an American thing rather than an European thing isn't it?

TB: It's a symbol of the Fall which is one of my favourite times of year. It's the shortest time but it's also somehow magical and exciting.

Question 7: What else do you enjoy in life apart from movies?

TB: I like drawing, I like to travel. I find there's just not enough time to space out and I think that's where you end up doing your best work when you're not having to think about something and you're able sit back and look at things because things move so fast it seems now that the time of doing that and thinking and looking at things in a strange way is quite helpful and enjoyable.

MK: Haven't you just written a book?

TB: A year ago I did a mental patient poetry book.

Question 8: You said that making a movie is the most out of control things you can do. Apart from the actors is there anyone else you particularly like working with?

TB: The problem with film is you never know when you're going to be able to make a film so you can't have people waiting around for you. Sometimes it's fun to work with the same people and work with new people and mix it up, and I really enjoyed this [Sleepy Hollow] because it really was an international cast and crew and you really feel close to the people you're working with and it's great to mix it up now and then and sometimes you have to. Working with the same people is fun because you get to see them try different things as well and that be as exciting as working with somebody new who is surprising you for the first time.

MK: And you've developed relationships with people you worked with at Disney, these relationships go back 20 years.

TB: Yes, and it's really nice to work with people who understand and really love the artistry of building sets, it's great.

Question 9: How long is it before you view films back, and are they what you imagined before?

TB: Three years, and the further away they get the more I like them. I don't know exactly what that dynamic is but it ends up coming full circle to how I felt about it at the beginning. But working on a film you just see so much of it all of the time and it becomes like Chinese water torture you feel this drip on your forehead endlessly and it takes a while to get over that.

MK: And how much of what we see on the screen is that vision in your head?

TB: It is out of control and I think the best thing you can do is hope for is something closely in the zone of it but that's what I love about the B films, it's great when you see the inconsistencies because it somehow makes it more human in a way. I find those films very appealing, they feel much more human to me.

Question 10: Do you think there will be an end to the mindless blockbuster?

TB: This one feeds into that a little bit but somehow it feels like an interesting time. I think there will always be those types of films, but I think there might be more different types of films to go along with it so there is more of a choice. You can maybe just avoid those ones and go and see some of the others which I think there'll be more of.

MK: How out of step are you with mainstream Hollywood?

TB: You have meetings with executives and they all talk about blockbusters, but the absurd thing is that if anyone knew exactly what that was they'd all be like that. They pretend they know what they're talking about but the thing is to be passionate about it and try and do something that you want to do but that's always a problem, that weird pretending and thinking, like Ichabod pretending you know what you're talking about when you don't.

Question 11: Are you going to publish any more of your artwork or photography?

TB: Yeah, it's great doing it and not be chained to an animation table and have the opportunity to do it when I can and I do love it. It's a sort of therapy, helping me to think and I hope I'll always do it. If it's not too bad I guess some of it will get published. Right now I just use it as a great form of thinking and enjoyment, and as long as I don't have to draw those foxes I'm fine!

Question 12: Who are the people who inspire you now?

TB: I always consider my prime film-going experience early on because I think those are the times when things remain with you for your whole life. People from the monster movies and people with whom you can identify when you see their film that they're able to have a feeling that's theirs and anyone who can get that across in film. Luckily there's too many to mention.

MK: Is there anyone you particularly admire that you've never had the chance to work with or meet?

TB: Meeting the people is sometimes scary because you don't know what it's going to be like sometimes it's best just to have that memory and the feeling of the work that they done.

MK: Had you met Christopher Lee before Sleepy Hollow?

TB: No, that was amazing because two hours went by and I realised I had been hypnotised by Dracula (Laughter)

Question 13: If you weren't a film-maker what would you be doing?

TB: Be in jail probably! I don't know, I'd probably still have my restaurant job.

MK: Were you any good at school?

TB: I was part of a weird group of kids who got our energy from trying to get through school without doing anything. That's what directing is like in a way, this kind of hovering about! We tried to fake the report I did okay but it was kind of sociopathic. I was lucky the last year of school I broke my right hand and I didn't have to do anything, it was amazing, I thought, "I should have broken my hand earlier - starting in first grade maybe".

Question 14: What about violence in the world around you - how do you go about addressing those issues?

TB: I was never scared by monster movies, more by real life. Coming from LA I prefer anywhere else in the world because there there was a dynamic of people acting a certain way but not really being that way. The mythology of people friendly and smiling, masking something else which always me feel uneasy and disturbed.

Question 15: What were you doing at 23?

TB: I was chained to my animation desk, sleeping half of the day. I learned to sleep with my pencil in my hand sitting up at my desk so when the bosses came in I'd just boink [blinks awake and sits upright]. Those were the years of catching up on sleep.

MK: Gags aside, it must have been a good grounding?

TB: Actually it was more interesting at CalArts. Disney was tougher, but I worked with great people like a great animator called Glenn Keen who's still there who took me under his wing and I learned how to deal with a big organisation.

MK: How did it feel working with Vincent Price as the father figure in Edward Scissorhands?

TB: He was great, and when I met him - after I'd sent him Vincent that short story - he was very open and positive, and it was the first experience I'd had like that where somebody who you admired was also a great person. He did so much, he had an amazing art collection which he gave to a poor East LA college. You see people who get jaded, and to see someone who goes through such a career and is a wonderful person it keeps you going throughout your life, and as with Sleepy Hollow you meet these people all the time and it just helps you when you go through that other stuff with the corporations. It's a real shining light.

But working on a film you just see so much of it all of the time and it becomes like Chinese water torture you feel this drip on your forehead endlessly and it takes a while to get over that. MK: And how much of what we see on the screen is that vision in your head? TB: It is out of control and I think the best thing you can do is hope for is something closely in the zone of it but that's what I love about the B films, it's great when you see the inconsistencies because it somehow makes it more human in a way. I find those films very appealing, they feel much more human to me. Question 10: Do you think there will be an end to the mindless blockbuster? TB: This one feeds into that a little bit but somehow it feels like an interesting time. I think there will always be those types of films, but I think there might be more different types of films to go along with it so there is more of a choice. You can maybe just avoid those ones and go and see some of the others which I think there'll be more of. MK: How out of step are you with mainstream Hollywood? TB: You have meetings with executives and they all talk about blockbusters, but the absurd thing is that if anyone knew exactly what that was they'd all be like that. They pretend they know what they're talking about but the thing is to be passionate about it and try and do something that you want to do but that's always a problem, that weird pretending and thinking, like Ichabod pretending you know what you're talking about when you don't. Question 11: Are you going to publish any more of your artwork or photography? TB: Yeah, it's great doing it and not be chained to an animation table and have the opportunity to do it when I can and I do love it. It's a sort of therapy, helping me to think and I hope I'll always do it. If it's not too bad I guess some of it will get published. Right now I just use it as a great form of thinking and enjoyment, and as long as I don't have to draw those foxes I'm fine! Question 12: Who are the people who inspire you now? TB: I always consider my prime film-going experience early on because I think those are the times when things remain with you for your whole life. People from the monster movies and people with whom you can identify when you see their film that they're able to have a feeling that's theirs and anyone who can get that across in film. Luckily there's too many to mention. MK: Is there anyone you particularly admire that you've never had the chance to work with or meet? TB: Meeting the people is sometimes scary because you don't know what it's going to be like sometimes it's best just to have that memory and the feeling of the work that they done. MK: Had you met Christopher Lee before Sleepy Hollow? TB: No, that was amazing because two hours went by and I realised I had been hypnotised by Dracula (Laughter) Question 13: If you weren't a film-maker what would you be doing? TB: Be in jail probably! I don't know, I'd probably still have my restaurant job. MK: Were you any good at school? TB: I was part of a weird group of kids who got our energy from trying to get through school without doing anything. That's what directing is like in a way, this kind of hovering about! We tried to fake the report I did okay but it was kind of sociopathic. I was lucky the last year of school I broke my right hand and I didn't have to do anything, it was amazing, I thought, "I should have broken my hand earlier - starting in first grade maybe". Question 14: What about violence in the world around you - how do you go about addressing those issues? TB: I was never scared by monster movies, more by real life. Coming from LA I prefer anywhere else in the world because there there was a dynamic of people acting a certain way but not really being that way. The mythology of people friendly and smiling, masking something else which always me feel uneasy and disturbed. Question 15: What were you doing at 23? TB: I was chained to my animation desk, sleeping half of the day. I learned to sleep with my pencil in my hand sitting up at my desk so when the bosses came in I'd just boink [blinks awake and sits upright]. Those were the years of catching up on sleep. MK: Gags aside, it must have been a good grounding? TB: Actually it was more interesting at CalArts. Disney was tougher, but I worked with great people like a great animator called Glenn Keen who's still there who took me under his wing and I learned how to deal with a big organisation. MK: How did it feel working with Vincent Price as the father figure in Edward Scissorhands? TB: He was great, and when I met him - after I'd sent him Vincent that short story - he was very open and positive, and it was the first experience I'd had like that where somebody who you admired was also a great person. He did so much, he had an amazing art collection which he gave to a poor East LA college. You see people who get jaded, and to see someone who goes through such a career and is a wonderful person it keeps you going throughout your life, and as with Sleepy Hollow you meet these people all the time and it just helps you when you go through that other stuff with the corporations. It's a real shining light. fields.headline: House prices up 30%, says Halifax
fields.trailText: House prices leapt again in December, surprising economists who had expected a levelling off in the market and tightening pressure on the Bank of England to raise base rates next week.
fields.body:
House prices leapt again in December, surprising economists who had expected a levelling off in the market and tightening pressure on the Bank of England to raise base rates next week.

Average house prices rose 2.6% in December alone, or an annualised rate of more than 30%, according to the Halifax price index published today. December's rise was the second biggest recorded during last year and the fifth highest ever, with all the other big monthly increases taking place during 1988 at the peak of the housing boom.

The increase takes the annual rate of house price inflation to 13.6% from 10.7% in November and pushes the average house price to £83,108, compared with £73,071 one year ago. Halifax economist Martin Ellis said: "The market is obviously very strong and is rising at its fastest rate for 10 years."

Steep price rises are beginning to take first-time buyers to affordability limits not seen since the late 1980s. The Halifax figures show that the average mortgage advance for first-time buyers is up almost 30% since January last year, rising from £47,839 to £62,136. The size of new mortgages in relation to income is also increasing rapidly. At the beginning of last year first-time buyers were paying a multiple of 3.3 times income to finance a home but it has reached 3.8 times income.

However, Halifax believes that the housing market is not out of control. The quarterly rise for October-December was 3.4%, a lower rate than the 4.4% increase between the second and third quarters of last year, largely because the index fell 0.4% in November.

The leap in the annual rate was also exaggerated by the temporary weakness in the housing market last November and December as consumer confidence was undermined by the Asian financial crisis and fears of an impending recession.

Halifax is sticking to its forecast of 8% average price increases this year and expects a 0.5% rise in the bank rate. Nationwide is predicting average house price increases of 11%.

fields.headline: Mutuals wrongfoot carpetbaggers
fields.trailText: Chelsea and Skipton building societies have sidestepped the threat of demutualisation by claiming that carpetbaggers' resolutions do not push for conversion. The move has left members uncertain as to whether they will receive windfall payments.
fields.body:
Chelsea and Skipton building societies have sidestepped the threat of demutualisation by claiming that carpetbaggers' resolutions do not push for conversion. The move has left members uncertain as to whether they will receive windfall payments.

After two months of legal talks the societies announced yesterday that they would allow two resolutions, submitted by Richard Yendall, the coordinator of Carpetbagger.com's demutualisation campaign, to be aired at their annual meetings, and urged members to vote in favour.

The announcement came as a surprise after Portman building society rejected identical Carpetbagger.com resolutions on December 30 and said it would expel Mr Yendall because of his involvement. But Chelsea and Skipton reasoned that the wording of the main resolution - "This meeting invites the board of directors to consider taking steps to change the independent mutual status of the society" - does not constitute a move to force conversion.

Instead both argue that the resolutions are "reasonable" since they ask the boards only to "consider taking steps", which John Goodfellow and Michael Bage, the chief executives of Skipton and Chelsea, said their boards do every year and will welcome support from their members for continuing to do so.

"The board's support for these resolutions is not support for conversion," said a statement from Chelsea, a sentiment which was mirrored by a Skipton press release.

Neither would acknowledge that their strategy ignored the obvious intent of the resolutions. Mr Goodfellow denied the carpetbaggers had made such intent clear, despite a statement published when the resolutions were submitted which read: "The resolutions have been designed to achieve the joint aims of conversion and a charity donation."

Loan league

Mutuals consistently beat banks on low-cost loans over periods of one and four years, a Research Department study shows. It placed building societies in the top eight of 25 mortgage lenders for the cheapest interest-only loans over one year; in the four years to 1999 mutuals filled the top 10 places

Top billing over a year went to Nationwide: a customer with a £50,000 loan would pay annual interest of £3,286.64; second to fifth were Yorkshire, Bradford & Bingley, the next conversion candidate, Derbyshire and Portman.

Worst was Northern Rock, demutualised in 1997; annual interest for a mortgage borrower was calculated at £3,551.51, or £264.87 more than Nationwide

Yorkshire topped the four-year chart with a £1,023.67 lead over Alliance & Leicester, another former mutual placed 25th

fields.headline: Sugared dumb fairy
fields.standfirst: Nutcracker, Coliseum, London **
fields.trailText: English National Ballet has been advertising treats from its cast list all through its London run of Nutcrackers, including guest star Mihn Pham from Toulouse. For this we should be grateful. Paris may be only a train ride away, but its ballet company hasn't performed here in 15 years, and any glimpse of its renowned stable of dancers is always worthwhile.
fields.body:
English National Ballet has been advertising treats from its cast list all through its London run of Nutcrackers, including guest star Mihn Pham from Toulouse and Agnès Letestu and Jose Martinez from Paris Opera. For this we should be grateful. Paris may be only a train ride away, but its ballet company hasn't performed here in 15 years, and any glimpse of its renowned stable of dancers is always worthwhile.

Letestu (dancing the Sugar Plum Fairy on Tuesday night) is certainly a showcase for Parisian training. She shapes her phrases with pretty elegance and the delicacy of her legs and feet belie their confident strength. But on this brief appearance she seems a disappointingly calculating artist, taking few risks and fewer apparent pleasures in her own dancing. The qualities of her style look superficial and fussy rather than evidence of personality or interpretation. Her partner, Jose Martinez, is likewise tall and finely made, with the peculiarly refined precision that is prized in French men. Yet he seems curiously young and underpowered, as if his talents are waiting to be realised.

It is unfair, however, to make more than provisional judgment, for the shock of returning to Derek Deane's Nutcracker is the reminder of how sidelined its "star" performers are.

This production is dominated by a slick, exhibitionist Drosselmeyer (Deane's own role) whose fancy tricks and creepily manipulative influence on Clara leave no room for the benevolence of the Sugar Plum Fairy. When Clara is whisked away to the Kingdom of Sweets, the Fairy is not permitted to greet her or listen to her story. All she gets to do is perform the grand pas de deux with her Prince, that dance becoming one among many impersonal numbers.

The erosion of the Fairy's role is symptomatic of Deane's heartless treatment of the whole plot. The Nutcracker's story may be trivial, but its roots lie deep in fairy tale morality. When the story is effectively abandoned and the ballet reduced to tricks and divertissements, it leaves not only little for audiences to respond to, but little for dancers to make sense of.

Until Saturday. Box office: 0171-632 8300

fields.headline: History in the making
fields.standfirst: Tavener's Fall and Resurrection, St Paul's Cathedral, Radio 3 **
fields.trailText: John Tavener's music never truly belonged to the 20th century, so it seems rather appropriate that the first major work of the new century in London should be his Fall and Resurrection. It was completed in 1997 and dedicated to the Prince of Wales, who was in the audience for Tuesday night's exemplary premiere.
fields.body:
John Tavener's music never truly belonged to the 20th century, so it seems rather appropriate that the first major work of the new century in London should be his Fall and Resurrection. It was completed in 1997 and dedicated to the Prince of Wales, who was in the audience for Tuesday night's exemplary premiere by the City of London Sinfonia conducted by Richard Hickox, with the BBC Singers, St Paul's Cathedral Choir and soloists Patricia Rozario, Michael Chance, Martyn Hill and Stephen Richardson. The event will be broadcast on BBC2 on Saturday.

With a text assembled by his regular collaborator Mother Thekla, the 65-minute score deals with Tavener's familiar themes - the creation of the world through God's love, man's fall from grace and the loss of Paradise, the incarnation of the Word, and finally the possibility of redemption for mankind through the resurrection. It uses his familiar musical vocabulary too, based in this case on a Byzantine chant.

In one sense nothing happens in Fall and Resurrection - the music presents the text, relying heavily on repetition, and strenuously avoids anything that could be construed as development or counterpoint, both products of the humanist tradition in western music that Tavener has so frequently attacked. The music depicts rather than explores; each section of the score is carefully labelled, so that its meaning is unambiguous. It is written for believers, for those who share its theology.

For the rest of us, some of the ideas are certainly striking on first hearing. It is a work written for a large space and the aural perspectives that a building like St Paul's Cathedral can provide, so that the fanfares triggered by a ram's horn sounding from the gallery, the sinuous melodies of the kaval (a kind of Middle Eastern flute) underpinning the first utterances of Adam and Eve, the whirling chorus whose words dissolve into texture (far more chromatic than much of Tavener's music), and the flurry of guitar from which the counter-tenor's psalms emerge are all clothed in a numinous halo. But by the third or fourth repetition the ideas lose their forcep; one aches for fresh ideas, for the text to be illuminated in specific rather than generalised ways. The lack of movement becomes stultifying; however quickly the surface detail is moving, the basic pulse always seems the same contemplative slowness. Tavener's motivation, combined with his rejection of almost all of the conventional apparatus of musical expression remain seriously problematic.

webTitle: Men find stressed wives hard work

fields.headline: Men find stressed wives hard work
fields.standfirst: The British Psychological Society website
fields.trailText: Men with wives or girlfriends in high-flying careers are more than twice as likely as their partners to become depressed after listening to the rigours of their working day, according to psychological research.
fields.body:
Men with wives or girlfriends in high-flying careers are more than twice as likely as their partners to become depressed after listening to the rigours of their working day, according to psychological research.

Men whose partners complain most frequently about work suffered higher levels of depression than those whose wives or girlfriends offloaded their work anxieties elsewhere.

But women, while some times becoming anxious about their partners work stresses, were far more successful in avoiding being depressed by it, the research, conducted by psychologists at the University of Hertfordshire, showed.

The study, unveiled yesterday at the British Psychological Association conference in Brighton, overturns previous research which suggested women typically became anxious and depressed by the strain of their partners' jobs.

But the previous studies have not always included women who worked and have focused on male dominated fields such as police officers, military personnel and air traffic controllers. In this study, all 40 couples were in full time professional or managerial jobs, with a similar salary.

Commenting on why the women in the study dealt so much better with their partners' work strains, the report's co-author, Sophie Crossfield, said: "It could be argued that women in managerial posi tions in IT and finance have to be that much tougher to succeed in those fields, and so don't take on the spouse's emotional burden.

"Research also suggests women have wider social support networks than men whereas men rely solely on their partners for support, so if the women have busy careers they may not be able to offer this."

She added: "If you go home and offload on your partner, it will have an effect on them."

fields.headline: Hi-tech stocks take a bruising
fields.standfirst:
Switchback ride as investors scramble to unload positions

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Investors scrambled to unload hi-tech shares yesterday as worries about rising global interest rates continued to unnerve the markets.
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny, Mark Milner, Jill Treanor and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
Investors scrambled to unload hi-tech shares yesterday as worries about rising global interest rates continued to unnerve the markets.

After Tuesday's record fall, the FTSE 100 dropped a further 130 points yesterday to finish at 6535.9, its lowest close since November 23. The London market has shed 5.7% over the last two days.

The European Central Bank's decision to leave interest rates on hold failed to comfort continental exchanges, which suffered heavy losses.

In France, the CAC-40 index finished down 192 points - or 3.4% - while in Germany, the DAX closed down 85 points at 6502.07, or 1.29%.

Technology and telecoms stocks were hardest hit in Europe. The FTSE's two high-tech newcomers, ARM and CMG holdings - both stars of the year-end rally - ended the day as the session's worst performers. CMG was down 471 at £38.50 while ARM Holdings was off 340, at £36.69.

Techmark, the London index for technology stocks, suffered as the sector fell from grace, finishing the day down 173 points at 3503 - a 4.72% fall.

Its French counterpart, the Nouveau Marché, fell 8.3% its sharpest ever one-day fall, while the German Neuer Markt fell 6.35%.

Even private investors - who have been the backbone of the dot.com bandwagon - appeared to have had second thoughts about the giddy heights relatively unknown companies had reached.

Justin Urquhart-Stewart of Barclays Stockbrokers, which had several hundred customers trying to deal on Christmas day, said the small investors who had fuelled the end of year rally in hi-tech stocks were taking profits.

"People have been suffering from internet vertigo. They are taking some quite healthy profits instead of getting burnt," he said.

Many analysts see this week's falls in share prices as simply blowing the froth off an overheated market, but the danger of a full-scale rout is not discounted.

"Everybody is trying to whistle in the dark and pretend it is just a healthy correction," said Joe Hall, head of European equity marketing at Deutsche Bank. "The risk is that we see another sharp fall in the tech stocks, and that may start to unleash a bit of panic among private investors."

In the US big stocks staged a rally after Tuesday's collapse, with the Dow Jones bouncing back by 164 points an hour before the close. The tech-heavy Nasdaq continued to dive during the day and was down 91.00 at 3810.69 as London closed, after falling more than 4% at its weakest point. It rallied in later trading

"The market went up so fast and so far that it had to correct itself a little bit," said Jean-Paul Pierret, director of strategy at Natexis Capital. "We had to have a pretext - and higher interest rates was it."

Brokers expect US markets to remain volatile until next week after Friday's publication of the latest payroll figures - the next indicator of inflationary pressures which could influence whether US rates rise.

The ECB indicated that its rates decision had not been influenced by falling shares. "At this stage the situation was not affected with any state of fear. An orderly correcting move is not a problem," said Matti Vanhala, governor of the Bank of Finland and a member of the ECB's rate-setting council.

Brokers expect US markets to remain volatile until next week after Friday's publication of the latest payroll figures - the next indicator of inflationary pressures which could influence whether US rates rise. The ECB indicated that its rates decision had not been influenced by falling shares. "At this stage the situation was not affected with any state of fear. An orderly correcting move is not a problem," said Matti Vanhala, governor of the Bank of Finland and a member of the ECB's rate-setting council.

fields.headline: Funk in the foreground
fields.standfirst: Tony Remy Quartet, Ronnie Scott's, London ***
fields.trailText: Unlike many of the bop-based jazz guitarists who preceded him, Tony Remy, a lean, relaxed black Briton of the Courtney Pine generation, hasn't made his phrasing mimic the ducking and diving intricacies of a sax.
fields.body:
Unlike many of the bop-based jazz guitarists who preceded him, Tony Remy, a lean, relaxed black Briton of the Courtney Pine generation, hasn't made his phrasing mimic the ducking and diving intricacies of a sax. More often than not he has resembled a Philly session player, infectiously chopping chords save for the odd brief foray into single-line solos infused with soul and blues, and tied inexorably to the groove. Early in his career, Remy proved he could do this as well as anybody in the business.

Remy is at Ronnie Scott's in London this week. The upsides of his show are his own succinctly fluid playing, some inventive variations on the George Benson unison singing-and-soloing technique with the help of a voice- bending synth, and a sharp band. The downsides in a jazz context are that the preponderance of funky mid-tempo dance shuffles in this sit-down venue tends to make them blur together, and the tight rhythmic prescriptions of funk make it hard to force the fingers away from hot-licks playing to a phrasing of unexpected turns.

The vibraharpist Roger Beaujolais is one of the primary colours of this ensemble, and at times his ringing sound, harmonic subtlety and elegant phrasing against Remy's spare chordal hipness gave the group its jazziest aspect, recalling the early Gary Burton jazz-funk bands of the 70s. Their partnership was at its most sympathetic on a version of Goodbye Pork Pie Hat that began as a slow groover and cranked up into a churning and soulful funk exercise, with extra impetus coming from Joe Bashorun's inventive keyboard support. The smooth Stevie Wonderish vocals that followed were elegantly unremarkable, but Remy's blend of Phil Upchurch's hungry drive and Wes Montgomery's quiet caress were compelling qualities of the subsquent instrumental. So was the excellent Frank Tontoh's drumming, a mix of crackling boldness and secure backbeat-playing that is typical of him.

Until Saturday. Box office: 0171-439 0747
